abstract: Baptism of Children by A bert Pike
snippet: Baptism of Children by A bert Pike
lead_paragraph: Last evening, one of the most interesting, and, at the same time, novel ceremonies, connected with Free Masonry, was performed in Masonic Hall, Thirteenth-street, near Fourth-avenue, by the Thrice Potent Grand Master of the Scottish rite, ALBERT PIKE, late General in the rebel army, the Senior Warden being Gen. J.H. HOBART WARD, late of the union army. It consisted of the baptism of six children, ranging from six months to eight years of age, according to the Masonic ritual. This being the first time this ceremony was performed at the North a large number of Masons, with their wives, daughters, sons, &c., were present, so that the lodge-room was crowded. The ceremony took place in a Lodge of Perfection which was opened publicly. In the east on a platform were placed a font filled with oil, a vessel of consecrated oil, and a plate of salt. All being ready two lines were formed consisting of a guard with drawn swords facing inwards and the officers and members of the Grand Lodge of Perfection entered in procession to the music of a grand march by the organ. After several alarms the parents and children entered with the godfather and godmothers, the latter dressed in white; the children who were unable to walk were carried on a cushion covered with blue silk, by the master of ceremonies; after him came a brother carrying the lighted candles, black, white and rose color in the form of a triangle, while the choir sang the chant "Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings, Thou hast perfected praise." Then came the other children, two by two, then the fathers and mothers. The procession went three times round the lodge-room, the organ playing, and the chant still proceeding, while the Master and Wardens repeated certain sentences, the mystic sentence commencing "Suffer little children to come unto me," &c. After questions asked of the fathers and answered by them, the children were brought to the front and an impressive prayer offered up by Bro. WILSON SMALL, as Grand Chaplain. This was followed by a hymn, and the Master informed the godfathers and godmothers of their duty, while the Orator in the North, the Senior and Junior Wardens, admonished them and their parents to be true to themselves, to others, to their country and to God. Another prayer was then offered, and the children were brought to the altar. Their names were:

abstract: The body of a man, apparently about fifty years of age, gray hair and slight frame, was found in Gowanus Bay on Friday. The clothes of deceased consisted of a black sack coat, bound, single breasted and lined with black alpacca, ribbed cassimere vest, edge bound, blue cloth pantaloons, gaiters, white socks and drawers, white shirt and black necktie. On the left forefinger was a fancy ring, and in the vest pocket a pair of spectacles and case were found. Deceased had been in the water about eight days. Coroner BARRETT took charge of the remains.

abstract: On Friday night, ROBERT PARKER, of No. 50 Third-street, entered Mr. WILLIAM BRAAS' grocery, at No. 139 Stanton-street, and, having made a trifling purchase, took occasion to rob Mr. BRAAS' money-drawer while his back was turned, Policeman FISHER arrested PARRER and found $27 in his possession, and Justice MANSFIELD committed him in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: JOHN DELANEY, JOHN VERNON, and JOHN SHERRY, of No. 62 Mulberry-street, having been out drinking together nearly all day yesterday, reached home inebriated last evening, and repairing to the rear yard at about 7 o'clock, they fought, and DELANEY was shockingly beaten, and stabbed in the forehead. During the fight, WILLIAM PICKET, a youth of 13 years, interfered to separate the combatants, and received a deep and fearful stab in the back, just under the left shoulder. Officer HYDE, of the Sixth Ward, took him to the New-York Hospital, and he was attended by Dr. HOPPIN. Roundsman MCDONALD and Patrolman KABENY arrested both SHERRY and VERNON, and they were incarcerated in the Franklin-street Police-station. It is believed that the boy's wound must prove mortal.

abstract: Trial of Murphy
snippet: Trial of Murphy
lead_paragraph: The testimony before the Millitary Commission at St. Louis on Monday, in the case of William Murphy, charged with burning boats on Western rivers, and destroying other government property, was highly interesting. Francis Frazier, of St. Louis, who testified in the conspiracy trial at Washington, gave evidence against Murphy and the officers of the late rebel government Mr. Frazier is by trade an engineer on the Mississippi river, and was formerly in the rebel service, but was pardoned by the President. abstract: The ex-rebel Senator H.S. FOOTE, said in a speech at a meeting held in Nashville, on Saturday, Sept. 2 : "I am satisfied that President JOHNSON's attitude before the country, as it has been clearly and authentically made known to us of late, is such as to entitle him to the confidence and support of his fellow-citizens throughout the republic, which confidence and support, from all indications now presented to us, I feel confident he will receive. I earnestly beseech the Almighty that he will sustain our Chief Magistrate in the efforts he is making to restore his countrymen everywhere to all the precious rights which they once exercised, and to all the happiness they once enjoyed, President JOHNSON and outers of his noble official predecessors, formerly stood on the middle ground, between secession on the one side, and consolidation on the other, and is making fearless battle against factionists, wherever situated, for the great principles of constitutional liberty, handed to us by our revered fathers, and which we most anxiously desire to transmit to our own latest prosperity. I believe him to be possessed of all the high qualities necessary to the successful performance of the arduous task in which he is engaged. He has long public experience; much and varied ability; a discerning intellect; profound knowledge of men and parties; and a persevering and indomitable energy, which has never been surpassed. If he succeeds in what he has undertaken, he will earn a nation's gratitude, and the lasting admiration of mankind in all future ages. I am happy to see that good and enlightened men in the North, in the South, in the East and in the West, are coming zealously to his support, without regard to sectional prejudice, to former party obligations, or to the insiduous misteachings of political managers. I am prepared to go as far as he who goes farthest in giving what aid I can to President JOHNSON in the exertions he is making to compose the country, to restore the ancient constitutional land-marks, and to revive those feelings of cordial good will and amity which existed among our countrymen everywhere before the breaking out of that most unnatural and deplorable war which has just terminated.

abstract: Soldier's Home; Col. Collyer's Report
snippet: Soldier's Home; Col. Collyer's Report
lead_paragraph: The report of Col. VINCENT COLYER, to his Excellency Gov. FENTON, giving a digest of his interesting labors, while Superintendent of the Howard-street Soldiers' Depot, in the reception and care of soldiers returning from the war, has been received. The report covers fifty-six large pages, and gives a succinct and graphic account of the work which Col. COLYER carried to so successful an end. The greater part of the details are given in the original reports of the daily press, as evidences of the truth of his statements.

abstract: Herald, N. Y. Patronage Withdrawn from by Managers
snippet: Herald, N. Y. Patronage Withdrawn from by Managers
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, the managers of the leading theatres in this city held a meeting, at which it was resolved to withdraw their advertising patronage from the New-York Herald. The motive for this action is said to have been a refusal of the proprietor of the Herald to insert an advertisement of Mr. P.T. BARNUM's without assigning any reason therefor. Before the meeting had decided the question under discussion, Mr. STUART, of the "Winter Garden," offered an amendment to the effect that a committee be appointed to wait on Mr. BENNETT, and inquire why the Museum advertisement was refused. This amendment was carried by a majority of one, and Mr. WALLACK, Mr. LINGARD and Mr. STUART were appointed as such committee.

abstract: The new school-house, which has lately been erected in Twenty-third-street, between Second and Third avenues, was formally opened yesterday by the trustees of the school. In building the school, great care has been taken to afford the pupils and teachers all necessary comfort and accommodation. There are five entrances to the school, four of which are fireproof, especially designed for the egress of the scholars in case of fire. This calamity, however, can scarcely occur, as hot air or stoves are not used in the building, the required caloric being supplied by Messrs. TUOMEY & ELDE's steam beating apparatus.
lead_paragraph: The new school-house, which has lately been erected in Twenty-third-street, between Second and Third avenues, was formally opened yesterday by the trustees of the school. abstract: TIMES and Tribune's Pressmen, at Hoboken; Active vs. Gotham at Hoboken
snippet: TIMES and Tribune's Pressmen, at Hoboken; Active vs. Gotham at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: The first game of a home and home match between these crack New-York clubs was played Friday afternoon at Hoboken, and resulted in a signal victory for the Actives. Both clubs were short of their regular nines -- the Actives being minus the services of "Redman" and HATFIELD, while the Gothams were short of VAN COTT, FARRELL and G. WRIGHT. Good substitutes, however, took the places of the absent players, which placed the two nines on an equal footing. The game opened favorably for the Gothams by a score of 2 to 0, which the Actives overcame in the next innings, and from that point they took the lead and held it -- the game ending in seven innings by a score of 23 to 9.

abstract: Modern Reformer and His Antics
snippet: Modern Reformer and His Antics
lead_paragraph: The occupation of a Doctor of Medicine is not a life which is generally desired. Submit the question of the choice of a profession to a class in our public schools, and you would certainly find in it more aspirants for the bar than for the surgery, and possibly more for the pulpit than the bar. The reason for this is obvious. It is a sad thing to behold human suffering, and sadder when, in order to relieve it, the impassive operator is compelled to add to its poignancy before he can apply those remedies which will give ease to the patient. It is the same with the moral as with the physical reformer. To guage misery and plumb the depths of crime is not a pleasant, but a very necessary duty. It is far from agreeable to be compelled to stun the ears of the gay and busy throng with long lists of human wretchedness, and their natural concomitants, startling records of human guilt. Doubtless there are many who deprecate the policy of publishing such statistics, and some who consider the press itself as an aider and abettor of the very evils it searches out and exposes; while not a few tender-hearted people shudder at their recital, like wounded men shrinking from the requisite but sharp brobing of the skillful surgeon.
headline: {'main': 'The Modern Reformer and His Duties.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Modern Reformer and His Duties.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At a certain cross-roads in the State of Alabama, stood a small grocery or "whisky shop," previous to the rebellion, where "bust-head" and "chain lightning" were dealt out to the unwashed at the small sum of five cents a drink, or twenty cents a quart. The presiding genius of this delectable institution was one BILL SYKES, who among various other pets had a domestic crow, black as the ace of spades. This crow had learned, among other things, to repeat quite distinctly the words "damn you," which he, of course, heard frequently used in the grocery. During the prevalence of a knock down and drag out fight one day, however, the crow was frightened from his house and flew off into the woods never to return.

abstract: Inventions and Inventors, the Fate of
snippet: Inventions and Inventors, the Fate of
lead_paragraph: Seated in a comfortable car, which is whirled along at the rate of forty miles an hour; surrounded by pleasant associates, who enjoy with yourself every vista opened to view, whether mountain, forest, river, or cultivated plain, you feel the currents of life and happiness flow with freshening strength and celerity; you acknowledge, with no empty formalism, your obligations to the men who invented the means of adding so many enjoyments to us mortals in this stage of existence.

abstract: A singular case of suicide occurred at Pierpont, St. Lawrence county, N.Y., last week. Miss IRISH, residing with her parents a short distance above the village of Ellsworth, was engaged to be married. The appointed day arrived, the expectant bridegroom, was in waiting, the minister was approaching, and everytninh was in readiness, when file ceremonies were delayed by the mysterious disappearance of the young lady. Her sister stated that a short time before the marriage was to take place she came to her, somewhat agitated, kissed her, bade her good-by, and left the house. Thinking the agitation was but natural under the circumstances, no immediate alarm was felt, but as the time arrived and she did not return, search was made. The fears aroused by finding her hat on the river bank, were fully realized by the discovery next day of her body in the river. After leaving her sister, she must have proceeded immediately to the river.
lead_paragraph: A singular case of suicide occurred at Pierpont, St. Lawrence county, N.Y., last week. abstract: The Owyhee Silver Mines of
snippet: The Owyhee Silver Mines of
lead_paragraph: In the southwestern portion of Idaho Territory, some twenty miles from the right bank of Snake River, in the depressions and along the ridges of the Owyhee Mountains, are located the richest and most valuable silver mines yet known to the world. It is but recently, to speak comparatively, that these discoveries have been made, and already the primitive wilderness is changed to the abode of civilization and the theatre of that active life pertaining to the business of mining. Already three growing towns -- Booneville, Ruby City and Silver City -- are the flourishing points of profitable traffic. Some half dozen quartz mills are crushing the ore and sending forward their silver bricks to swell the aggregate of the wonderful and manifold productions of our common country. It is necessary that the great centres of commerce and capital on the Atlantic side of the continent should be better informed in reference to a section of country of so much consequence as the Owyhee mines. The productions of a country constitute the chief source of its wealth and prosperity. In the United States, more than any other country, and now more than at any other time, it is essential to encourage all industrial pursuits, and none more so than those which are promoted by the means of intelligent labor -- to develop every resource, that the revenues of the government may be drawn from every available quarter, so that our system of taxation may not be felt to be burdensome and oppressive. Mining is now among the most important interests of our country, and it will not be very long before our mineral products will. equal in value those obtained from agriculture. The Owyhee country is a vast treasury, which only requires the judicious investment of a small amount of capital, in addition to what is there already, to establish the magnitude of its richness and make it available to the world. Unlike ail other mining countries the valleys of the Ouohhee are exceedingly fertile and productive; even the summits of the mountains are covered with nutritious grasses. Groves of excellent timber, fir and pine chiefly, well adapted to the wants of the population, abound throughout that region. The water courses are abundant and constantly supplied by innumerable overflowing springs, which form the sources of the Owyhee River. The quartz mines are principally within an area of six miles long and four miles wide. The lodes have a common direction, tending North and South, and crop out boldly on the surface, so that in some instances they have been traced for a great distance. The vein matter varies from two to ton feet in width. The surface rock contains pay ore, some of which it is not uncommon to find yielding forty dollars to the ton. Free gold, in considerable quantities, is contained in the ore of a great many of the lodes, although disappearing at certain depths in the shafts, when the lode presents a body of distinct silver ore -- generally in the form of chlorides. Very often large doposits of polybasite -- which is as pure silver ore as can be obtained, being from seventy to eighty per cent. silver -- are struck in the shafts and drifts, even at no greater depth than sixty feet. Among the choice lodes may be named the "War Eagle," "Silver Legion," "Florida," "Morning Star," "Potosi," and "Oro Fino." The one reduced at the mills has yielded results varying from two hundred and fifty to five hundred dollars per ton, and the average value of ore thus reduced has been upwards of one hundred and fifty dollars to the ton. The country is rapidly filling up with an active, industrious and enterprising population, giving substantial evidence of its worth in the gradually augmenting treasure which each steamer semi-monthly brings to impart additional consequence to every department of our trade.

abstract: At the last meeting of the Board of Managers of this society, numerous letters applying for aid were read by the Secretary. One came from Canton, China, asking the board for $3,000 to purchase the late Dr. GODDARD's version of Chinese testaments, and employing colporteurs in circulating them among the vast hordes of Chinese. Another, from Rev. Dr. CROSS, of Toungpoo, India, for $1,000 to circulate Scriptures in his field of labor, now occupied by 50,000 people. Another from Rev. Dr. KINCAID, of Prome, the capital of the Burman Empire, giving interesting statements of labor in that country, and asking for further funds to aid him in circulating Scriptures in his field.

abstract: The Wirz trial was continued yesterday. Among the witnesses who have been recently summoned for the defence are Robt. E. Lee, Joseph Johnston, Howell Cobb and Robert Ould, late rebel Generals, and Joseph Brown, late rebel Governor of Georgia. Other prominent leaders of the rebellion will also be summoned before the close of the trial. Several days will probably elapse before these parties are examined. The trial is expected to continue several weeks longer. The examination of witnesses for the defence proceeds slowly, the counsel taking care to sift their testimony very carefully, for the purpose of making out that the evidence offered for the government will not justify a conviction.

abstract: from whom a thief had stolen $26,600, appeared by counsel CLARENCE A. SEWARD, Esq. against one CHAUNCEY JOHNSON otherwise Charles Jones, whom Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Police Precinct, had taken into custody on suspicion.
lead_paragraph: from whom a thief had stolen $26,600, appeared by counsel -- CLARENCE A. SEWARD, Esq. -- against one CHAUNCEY JOHNSON otherwise Charles Jones, whom Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Police Precinct, had taken into custody on suspicion. It appears that on the 26th ult., JOHNSON was seen lounging in the Adams Express Company's office, walking from desk to desk as though on important business, and shortly after he had gone from the money-delivery clerk's desk, a package containing $1,600 was missed. Mr. WM. MCGILL, the company's clerk, promptly laid the facts before Capt. JOURDAN, and that officer, knowing JOHNSON as a person who had served in State Prison for a like offence, went in search, but did not find him until Friday afternoon. JOHNSON, meantime, is alleged to have been in Messrs. AUGUST BELMONT & CO.'s banking-office, on Thursday afternoon, and to have stolen from their counter a package containing fourteen $1,000 and twenty-two $500 five-twenty bonds. The prisoner was taken to court on Friday afternoon, and Mr. WILLIAM F. HOWE, his counsel, claimed his release, saying that not only was there no evidence against him, but that no person had seen the money and bonds stolen by anybody. Mr. SEWARD pressed the charge, claiming that the magistrate should hold the accused for examination; and he was so held. He was examined on the charge of stealing $25,000 from Messrs. BELMONT & CO. yesterday morning, and the examination on the charge which is preferred by the Express Company is to be brought up again on Monday morning. The stolen thousand-dollar bonds are numbered as follows:

abstract: Atalanta vs. Atlantic, Brooklyn; on Hudson River
snippet: Atalanta vs. Atlantic, Brooklyn; on Hudson River
lead_paragraph: The amateur six-oared boat-race between the Atlantic Club of New-York, and the Atlantic Club of Hoboken took place yesterday on the Hudson River, opposite the Elysian fields. It was on a three-mile course, one and a half miles and repeat. The race was rowed by amateurs, and was simply for the honor of the thing, no money whatever pending on the result., though it is true several bets were made, but with the understanding the money should be spent in social enjoyment. In striking contrast to the race at Sing Sing last Monday, a large number of ladies were present, who seemed to enjoy themselves wonderfully, and added greatly to the delights of the race. Nothing was done or said that could offend the most fastidious taste, showing most conclusively that rowing as a pastime and recreation need not be surrounded by rampant rowdyism.

abstract: Yesterday morning the body of an unknown boy, of about 16 years of age, was found drowned off East Tenth-street. Policeman VAN TASSELL took it to the Union Market Police-station. The corpse was clad in grey pantaloons, linen coat and gaiter shoes. The youth's hair was jet black.

abstract: New-Haven Railroad; Collision in Depot; Lady's Leg Broken
snippet: New-Haven Railroad; Collision in Depot; Lady's Leg Broken
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning an incoming passenger car ran upon a car which was nearly or quite motionless, and every person in the moving car was knocked down. Many of the passengers received severe bruises, and a lady who stood on the platform sustained a compound fracture of a limb. The collision is attributed to the brakemen's inattention to their duties.

abstract: After continual backing and filling since the 30th of May last, the Kavanagh party have finally secured all their primary points, and yesterday afternoon it was mutually agreed that the first game should be played as above stated. This game is 250 points up, the three-ball French carom game, on a second-sized standard American carom table, with 25-16 inch balls.
lead_paragraph: After continual backing and filling since the 30th of May last, the Kavanagh party have finally secured all their primary points, and yesterday afternoon it was mutually agreed that the first game should be played as above stated. This game is 250 points up, the three-ball French carom game, on a second-sized standard American carom table, with 25-16 inch balls. Notwithstanding the arbitration the arbitrators gave no decision as to the height of the table, which was the only poinreferred to them. However, Mr. PHELAN, who acted for Mr. CARME, determined to waive this point, and as no further excuses could be brought forward, the hall was engaged and the preliminary arrangements concluded.

abstract: WILLIAM LARD, an Englishman, while painting a house in Spring-street, near Mulberry, feel from the scaffold, and was seriously injured. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital....GEORGE STEINER, of No. 54 Park-street, a Frenchman, went to the roof of his abode, on Friday night, while intoxicated, and fell thence to the sidewalk. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, and it was ascertained that he had sustained serious internal injuries.

abstract: A singular charge of grand larceny was on Friday brought before Judge WALTER. PETER WILLS, JOHN BENDENOUGH, CHAS. HUBER, and three others, were arrested on complaint of ERNST SCHMIDT, of High Ground Park, who alleges that the defendants, during Wednesday and Thursday last, went to his park and tore down a frame house belonging to him, which they carted away, the boards being worth $800. The counsel for the defendants stated that he advised the proceeding, as men built the house and never received any pay from the complainant Before any argument was proceeded with, the complainant withdrew his charge.

abstract: GEORGE and JOHNSON STANLY, aged 9 and 13 years respectively, were taken into custody by Policeman ROSENWALD, on Friday night, for stealing a horse and wagon from Mr. R.A. KLAWS, of Ninth-avenue and Fifty-third-street. Mr. KLAWS left his horse at the intersection of Fourth-avenue and Forty-second-street, while he went momentarily to the Harlem Railroad depot, and the young scapegraces leaped into the wagon and drove off. The prisoners were committed for examination.

abstract: The Aeronautic Amphitheatre at Central Park, yesterday afternoon, was crowded to its full capacity by interested spectators. The attraction was the proposed aerial-gymnastic performances of HARRY LESLIE, the Niagara rope-walker, and also a detached ascension of Prof. LOWE's war balloon. Owing to the high wind, it was impossible for Mr. LESLIE to make a "cable" ascension, and the two grand attractions were combined. About 6 o'clock the balloon was cut adrift, and as she shot up into the open space the daring gymnast coolly performed several perilous manoeuvres, continuing to dance upon his single string until lost to sight.

abstract: At about 3 o'clock yesterday morning Mr. MOSES ELSTIEN's apartments on the second floor of the tenement-house in the rear of No. 77 Elizabeth-street, was damaged slightly by fire of incendiary origin. Mr. ELSTIEN has $1,000 insurance in the Stuyvesant office. The building, which is owned by Mr. WM. WOODCOCK, may be repaired for $100, and is insured in the Citizen's office. Fire-Marshal BAKER will institute an investigation.

abstract: A fortnight ago Capt. CHARLES N. BRACKETT, of the City Hall Police, notified the keepers of emigrant boarding-houses that they must comply with the requirements of the law and post conspicuously in their houses their schedules of charges, printed in five spoken languages. He gave them one week to prepare their cards, and yesterday his officers having been sent on a tour of inspection, found in every emigrant boarding-house a large placard with board rates printed thereon in English, French, German, Dutch and Welch; so that now, if an emigrant pays from $3 to $5 a day fur board at any house, he may know whether that is the established rate of the house. There can be no more frauds under that head.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Commissioners of the Fire Insurance Companies held yesterday, to consider the propriety of changing the premium on cotton insurance, the board decided, by a two-thirds vote, to make the rate on cotton, and on other goods in stores where cotton is stored, one dollar and thirty-five cents on each hundred dollars, with privilege to the keepers or owners of the stores to pick cotton on the premises. Where a stipulation is made that there shall be no cotton picking, the rate will be one per cent.

abstract: London Daily News, on Child Murder in England; London Letter, Sept. 16
snippet: London Daily News, on Child Murder in England; London Letter, Sept. 16
lead_paragraph: Our English files teem with leaders and letters on the subject of the best method to be followed for the purpose of checking the crime of infanticide in that country. The difficulty appears to be that Mr. Bull cannot yet strike out a plan by which he can at once neglect the children and diminish the crime. As to fullfil both these requirements is a manifest impossibility, the meeting held in London on Monday, Sept. 4, came to no conclusion on the subject. Dr. CLARKE, the orator of the same, after stating that he had received above a thousand letters, some of which contained valuable suggestions, contented himself with negativing the proposition for establishing foundling hospitals with revolving baskets, "because they tended to increase immorality." He forgot that the lack of them operated to increase murder. But the true reason, it is surmised, was not that they would tend to increase immorality, but that they would eventually tend to increase the poor rates, which is a crime even worse than murder in that pauper-ridden country. The bewilderment, meantime, of poor Mr. Bull, continues to increase in a manner which, if it wore not horrible, would be ridiculous. He appears to be as lost in regard to what should be done in the crisis, as Mr. Toot was when the question was put to him, "Sir, in the case of a war with Russia, what are you to do with your raw materials?" It is almost a pity Mr. Bull is not a cannibal Mr. Toot's answer follows so readily, "Cook em, Sir, cook em." It will be remembered that Dean SWIFT solved a difficulty in the case of Irish babies in a similar manner. But we respectfully inform Mr. Bull we do not indorse such suggestions, for there is a diabolical doubt, that in his present state of excitement, he might be induced by us to carry out so very practical a solution of his present dilemma.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon Mr. R. PHRANER, in presence of Commissioner BERGEN, Capt. LEICH, Sergeants BEASLEY, CARPENTER, BUNCE and HALL, and many distinguished civilians, laid the corner-stone for a new Police-station, in Gates-avenue, near Marcy. The Forty-ninth Precinct, which is one of the largest in Brooklyn, embracing several public parks, has long needed suitable station-house accommodations. There are to be two buildings, the main edifice, and a smaller one in the rear, in which are to be the cells and lodgers' apartments. The dimensions of the main building are: 32x56 feet, and three stories high. The stories of the front building are as follows: First story, 12 feet; second, 11 feet; third, 10 feet 6 inches. The rear: First story, 10 feet 6 inches; second, 10 feet. On the first floor of the front building there are to be a muster room, Captain's private office, Captain's sleeping room, two rooms for the sergeants, a sitting room for the men, and a bathroom. The stories above are to be devoted for sleeping rooms. The main building is of brick, with brownstone trimmings, and a cupola is to surmount the whole. The house is to have all modern improvements. There are to be ten rooms on the first floor of the rear building, and on the first floor of the second, the lodgers' apartments. When completed the whole will cost $18,367. Mr. HILL, is the architect, Mr. HANNIGAN, a veteran in his trade, is the mason, and Mr. ALLEN, well known in the construction of the station houses, is the carpenter. The corner-stone contained a copy of the Scriptures, the Brooklyn City Charter for 1864, Brooklyn laws and ordinances for 1865, a copy of the general and special laws relating to the city of Brooklyn, a manual of the Metropolitan Police, a copy of of the amendment act passed 1864, a list of members of the Forty-ninth Precinct, a copy of the New-York TIMES, other daily newspapers and several other articles. Capt. LEICH will probably occupy the house on the 1st of January next.

abstract: Between 12 and 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, a party of Yorkville boys, who had been drinking and playing cards in MICHAEL MORAND's liquor-store, in Fourth-avenue, near Ninetieth-street, disputed over their game, and at length fought with knives and pistols, and DANIEL DANAHEA, one of their number, was stabbed in the right temple. The blade of the dirk with which he was stabbed passing through the skull and penetrating the brain. He lived an hour and a half. While the fight was at its height the Twenty-third Precinct Police were summoned, and Officers O'DONNELL, BUCKLEY, NOLAN, and FOY, responded and took the entire party to the Yorkville Police-station, where they rendered their names as Daniel Wall, Jeremiah O'Keefe, James Wall, Matthew Garretty, John Duffy, John Wolff, Morris Sheehan, Prtrick McNamara, Robert Porter, Thomas Matthews, and Michael Morand. Coroner COLLIN impanneled a jury yesterday afternoon, and after carefully examining the witnesses, the jury found a verdict under which the Coroner held DANIEL WALL as principal, JEREMIAH O'KEEFE as accessory, and the following named as witnesses: JAMES WALL, MATTHEW GARRETTY, JOHN DUFFY, JOHN WOLFF, MORRIS SHEEHAN, and PATRICK MCNAMARA. The principal and accessory were committed to the Tombs, and the witnesses were sent to the House of Detention. It appearing that ROBERT PORTER, THOMAS MATTHEWS, and MICHAEL MORAND were not engaged in the fight, they were released from restraint. DANAHEA was a native of Ireland, 35 years of age, and dwelt in Ninetieth street, between Fourth and Fifth avenues.

abstract: Magazines for October
snippet: Magazines for October
lead_paragraph: -- Harpers' New Monthly Magazine (New-York, HABPER & BROTHER) comes before us this month, with the same general style and contents, or intellectual physiognomy, as it may be called, rendered familiar by the experience of many previous appearances; adventure, fiction and recent history, are all well represented in its pages -- the first by an interesting article, "Down in the Cinnabar Mines," descriptive of the mineral and metallic workers of New Almaden, the great mercury yielding district of California. It is well illustrated, and the writer is extremely well "posted up," as the visit it records was made during the present year. The paper most important in its relation to late events and the truth of future history, is undoubtedly "Jefferson Davis," a searching examination of that gentleman's claim to ability and statesmanship, by Gen. JORDAN, late Chief of Staff to Gen. BEAUREGARD, in the Confederate service. Some of the facts it relates are, as might be expected, new to us in this part of the country; the general argument is well sustained, and the conclusions pressed home -- showing with a force that is difficult to resist how much the arch rebel has been overrated in every point of view, and how easily at a distance, the acrid and petty obstinacy of a narrow mind is mistaken for heroic firmness of will and stability of purpose. "Sherman's Great March" is an abstract of Major NICHOL's book, with characteristic embellishments. WILKIE COLLINS continues what a critic will call his "Chinese puzzle." Armadale," shifting the puppets into new perplexities without eliciting one spark of human feeling. "Our Mutual Friend" contains a fanciful murder scene. DICKENS has evidently made a special study of the physiology of homicide, and is at home in delineating the youth and development of the fatal purpose while it lurks scarcely recognised in the criminal's breast "Visit to the Isle of Puritans" is a satirical attempt to bring into startling contrast the habits and modes of thinking of the early colonial kings with our modern ways of life; the attempt is better than the execution. The other miscellaneous matter of the magazine is readable and amusing.

abstract: On Friday afternoon Policemen KING and HAYDEN, of the Thirty-second Precinct, found the body of a soldier in the woods near old Fort George, at One Hundred and Ninety-ninth-street.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon Policemen KING and HAYDEN, of the Thirty-second Precinct, found the body of a soldier in the woods near old Fort George, at One Hundred and Ninety-ninth-street. In the pockets they found a discharge paper, dated "Delancey House, D.C., July 28, 1865," and indicating that the bearer had been a corporal in Capt. VICTOR PRAXMARER's Company, of the Forth-sixth New-York Veteran Volunteers, and that he was a native of Amsterdam, Hol[???] HENRY VAN NIEROP by name, 44 years of age, [???]persmith. Finding the throat apparently cut, and a razor in the deceased's pockets, the officers argued that he had cut his throat and deliberately put his razor away while his life's blood was ebbing; but Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, Jr., who made a postmortem examination on Saturday, found that the soldier's throat had not been cut, and could not find conclusive evidence of suicide. The corpse was so much decomposed that it was impossible to determine whether there had been any internal wounds, and the gash which the officers had mistaken for a cutting of the throat was a jagged wound extending from the mouth to the ear. Two pools of blood were visible within twenty feet of the spot where the body was found, and in the soldier's pockets was an empty bottle; and from these facts it may be inferred that while inebriated the soldier may have attempted suicide and perished from hemorrhage.

abstract: Marsh Lanes and Chills and Fever
snippet: Marsh Lanes and Chills and Fever
lead_paragraph: It has been a subject of very general complaint this season, with those who have lived in the suburbs, that chills and fevet have prevailed to an unusual extent. The moisture of the early part of the year, and the intense heat of the Fall -- the former in overflowing the marsh lands and the latter in tempting to late out-door enjoyment -- explain this aggravating visitation. Long Island and Staten Island have, of course, been the principal theatres of its ravages, but the west bank of the Hudson and both sides of the Sound have not by any means been spared. Wherever indeed there was marsh land in the neighborhood, there the residents were surely set on the chatter and the burn.

abstract: GRAND DEMONSTRATION AT ELIZABETH SPEECHES BY GEN. HITE AND OTHERS. A very large and enthusiustic meeting was held on Saturday evening, at Library Hall, Elizabeth. The hall was densely packed...
lead_paragraph: GRAND DEMONSTRATION AT ELIZABETH -- SPEECHES BY GEN. HITE AND OTHERS. -- A very large and enthusiustic meeting was held on Saturday evening, at Library Hall, Elizabeth. The hall was densely packed with a very respectable and appreciative audience, a great many ladies being present. The national colors were tastefully suspended from the sides of the building, and several banners bearing curious devices, such as, "WIRZ is no 'Fellow-citizen' of Ours," were on and around the platform. A fine brass band was in attendance, and discoursed some very excellent music. The meeting was called to order by A.J. CRANE, Esq., at 8 o'clock, and Hon. JOHN DAVIDSON was the first speaker who was introduced. He spoke in a very numerous and interesting manner for about one hour, holding the audience at one time in a rapture of thought, and at other times bursting out in raptures of applause. The constitutional amendment he advocated in very strong terms, and exposed the fallacy of the platform of the Democratic party, who he denounced as traitors in the strongest terms. The "stone of the corner" as he termed New Jersey, which was rejected, is, on the 1st of November, to be made the "chief stone of the corner." He described in flowery terms the valor and patriotism of the New-Jersey troops who fought in the late war, many of whom were present and appreciated all he said. His speech throughout was one of those spirit-stirring and eloquent appeals which never fail to produce a lasting conviction. At the conclusion of his remarks the band struck up a national air. Gen. HITE was then presented to the audience, whom he kept in a continual roar of laughter by the recitation of his comic anecdotes. The Copperheads he denounced as the worst enemies of the Union, for to save him he did not know where to place them, whether as rebels or as Union men; they were like the nigger on the fence -- one time for the Union, and at another time for the rebels. He spoke at length of the character and services of Gen. ROSSEAU, whom he hoped the audience would have the pleasure of listening to before this campaign was over. Ask this man, said he, what he would do with these men who remained up North, grumbling, afraid to go and fight -- talking of the constitutional measures and other matters, instead of fighting to save their country, and he would say to you, I would send them among their fellow-citizens down South. In referring to the sympathy which the Democrats professed to the soldiers, he said, soldiers, How many times were you allowed to vote while in camp? Ah! not at all. No; but you were denounced as Lincoln hirelings and had no right to vote. These Democrats say they are not in favor of negro suffrage, but are in favor of all other kinds of suffrage. Well, we are not. How would you like rebel suffrage? [Sensation.] Now this is the only State which has not accepted the constitutional amendment, and so long as the people of this State reject progression, so long will they lag in the progress of science, art and manufacture. For God when he made this nation, made it to work; and he made this government to carry out the principles of virtue and morality. The government tried to put down a rebellion, and still were willing to continue the accursed institution of slavery; and no victory was ever gained worth mentioning until the proclamation of emancipation came. But after that it was victory and success every step of the way. [Applause.]

abstract: The great Fair of the American Institute has now been open to the public for three weeks. In common with the opera and the theatres and all places of public resort, it has been overflowed night after night, and as the latter days of its existence draw near the attendance becomes greater.
lead_paragraph: The great Fair of the American Institute has now been open to the public for three weeks. In common with the opera and the theatres and all places of public resort, it has been overflowed night after night, and as the latter days of its existence draw near the attendance becomes greater. The exhibition of to-day differs greatly from that of a fortnight since. Then, to a certain extent, confusion reigned supreme -- no one could tell where the head or tail was, the machinery was not all in place, and what was ready was not in motion. Now the busy hum of the wheels in heard from eight o'clock in the morning until ten at night; all day long the immense "Waterfall" dashes its volumes of deep blue liquid from its capacious mew; the brick machine slides out and chops off its little bricks by the hundred; the horse-shoe miracle bends the bar into desired shape, and with a single click stamps the work as perfect; the planing machines, the thundering crushers, the swiftly turning lathes, the pondrous printing presses, the wierd-looking knitting apparatus, the nimble-working sewers -- all are as busily engaged, without cessation, as if the life of a nation depended on their action. In the morning the majority of the visitors are men interested in machinery or gardening; in the afternoon ladies and children predominate; at night when the splendid brass band lends its additional inspiration, the rooms are crowded with all sorts and conditions of men from town and country. A more brilliantly beautiful scene it would be difficult to find, and, as the catalogue as given in the TIMES, ranges through every realm of art and science, and neglects in no way the products, pure and simple, of nature's self, it would be strange indeed if we could not all and somewhat of interest, amusement and instruction.

abstract: Tacony Gun oat; Officers of
snippet: Tacony Gun oat; Officers of
lead_paragraph: The gunboat Tacony, 12 guns, and one of the Atlantic squadron, having been thoroughly overhauled, has sailed from Boston for her station at Charleston. The following is a list of her officers: Commander, W.G. TEMPLE; Lieut.-Commander, H.M. Blue; Lieutenant, C.D. Jones; Passed-Assistant Surgeon, G.D. Slocum; Acting Assistant Paymaster, A.D. Bache; Acting Master, C. Wappenhaus; Acting Ensigns, W. McLeod, H. Jones; Mates, B.H. Hertman, W.H. Howland, W.H. Lecinet, F.C. Bailey; First Assistant Engineer, in charge, N.B. Clark; Second, G.E. Tower, H.C. Blye; Acting Third, W.E. Holland, M.H. Perry; Surgeon's Steward, Edward F. Dow.

abstract: BRYANT STRATTON  Co.'s BUSINESS COLLEGE. The regular evening sessions of Messrs, BRYANT, STRATTON  Co.'s business and commercial college will commence this evening.
lead_paragraph: BRYANT STRATTON & CO.'s BUSINESS COLLEGE. -- The regular evening sessions of Messrs, BRYANT, STRATTON & CO.'s business and commercial college will commence this evening. It is the design of the principals to render this feature of the institution at once attractive and efficient. The college is now located in the Mortimer Building, corner of Twenty-second-street and Fifth-avenue, where five large apartments are devoted to the instruction of some five hundred pupils. At a comparatively trifling expense, the youth who intends to devote himself to a business career, may here obtain a thorough practical knowledge of book-keeping, commercial law, business correspondence, &c., taking part in actual transactions until he becomes thoroughly familiarized therewith. A system of bank and joint stock accounts is also taught, together with the art of telegraphing. Messrs. BRYANT & STRATTON have now thirty-three branch colleges in operation, extending from this city to distant Missouri and Minnesota.

abstract: Wayland, Dr. Francis
snippet: Wayland, Dr. Francis
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. FRANCIS WAYLAND, who was more than 28 years President of Brown University, was prostrated by a paralytic stroke on Tuesday last, and died on Saturday afternoon, at 5 1/2 o'clock, aged 69 years. The funeral will take place on Wednesday, morning at 11 o'clock, at the First Presbyterian meeting-house, in Providence.

abstract: -The Sentinel, published at Jacksonville, Oregon, of the 12th ultimo, says: "Several of our citizens returned last week from a visit to the Great Sunken Lake, situated in Cascade Mountains, about 75 miles northeast from Jacksonville. This lake rivals the famous valley of Sinbad the Sailor. It is thought to average 2,000 feet down to the water all round. The walls are almost perpendicular, running down into the water, and leaving no beach. The depth of the water is unknown, and its surface is smooth and unruffled, as it lies so far below the surface of the mountain that the air currents do not affect it. Its length is estimated at twelve miles, and its breadth at ten. There is an island in its centre having trees upon it. No living man ever has, and probably never will, be able to reach the water's edge. It lies silent, still and mysterious in the bosom of the 'everlasting hills,' like a huge well, scooped out by the hands of the giant genii of the mountains, in the unknown ages gone by, and around it the primeval forests watch and ward are keeping. The visiting party fired a rifle several times into the water, at an angle of forty-five degrees, and were able to note several seconds of time from the report of the gun until the ball struck the water. Such seems incredible, but is vouched for by some of our most reliable citizens. The lake is certainly a most remarkable curiosity."

abstract: Cheshire Case, the, and Judge Lotts' Decision
snippet: Cheshire Case, the, and Judge Lotts' Decision
lead_paragraph: If there were any expectations that the habeas corpus proceedings in the case of CHARLES CHESHIRE before the Supreme Court in Kings County, would result in a conflict of authority between the courts of the State and the Government of the United States, those expectations were brought to nothing by the decision of the case by Judge LOTT on Saturday last. The position of the matter was this: CHESHIRE, who was one of the Supervisors of Kings County and a member of the Enrolling Board, was tried before a court-martial and convicted of receiving money improperly in connection with his position, and was sentenced to be fined and imprisoned.

abstract: Go to their work prepared for "business." On Saturday evening, Mr. JAMES T. WALKER, of the Broadway Hotel, observed that two youngsters who were riding on the front platform of a Broadway Railroad car were crowding everybody on the platform, and when, presently, one of them rudely jostled him and leaped from the vehicle, Mr. WALKER understood the movement and gave chase, his watch having been stolen. The flight and pursuit were spirited until one of the thieves turned upon and knocked down, with a loaded cane, Mr. JOHN MOONEY, of No. 87 West Twenty-seventh-street, a gentleman who had joined in the chase, and Mr. WALKER, despairing of capturing the fugitives, drew his revolver and threatened to shoot them if they would not quietly surrender, and then the older thief -- JOHN BROWN by name -- give himself up and was turned over to Policeman LINDEN, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct. The other fellow kept on, and, turning a corner, was soon out of sight. Subsequently, at Jefferson Market Police Court, Mr. WALKER recognized BROWN's confederate sitting among the spectators, anxiously watching the course of proceedings, and he also was arrested. He rendered the name of THOMAS BELL. The prisoners, in default of $2,000 bail each, were committed for trial.

abstract: COUNTERFEIT UNITED STATES CURRENCY. Constable STILLWAGEN, of Queens County, yesterday arrested two men named PATRICK GUVEN and THOMAS McGLINN, charged with passing counterfeit United States currency of the denomination of fifty cents.
lead_paragraph: COUNTERFEIT UNITED STATES CURRENCY. -- Constable STILLWAGEN, of Queens County, yesterday arrested two men named PATRICK GUVEN and THOMAS MCGLINN, charged with passing counterfeit United States currency of the denomination of fifty cents. The prisoners were taken to the Forty-seventh Precinct Station-house and searched, when $54 of the bogus currency was found upon the person of GUVEN. The prisoners were locked up.

abstract: The steamers City of Boston and Erin, which sailed from this port on Saturday are said to have taken out $1,000,000 in bonds for the use of the embryotic Irish Republic. It is currently reported that as soon...
lead_paragraph: The steamers City of Boston and Erin, which sailed from this port on Saturday are said to have taken out $1,000,000 in bonds for the use of the embryotic Irish Republic. It is currently reported that as soon as these bonds reach Ireland matters will assume a more definite form, and a proclamation also printed here will be spread broadcast throughout the land, and so well guarded is every avenue that there is no possibility of the British Government obtaining the documents or of interfering with the plan of distribution. It is claimed that the bonds have nearly all been subscribed for, and many of them by people whom the Government least suspect.

abstract: The steamship Allemania, from Southampton, Sept. 20, arrived at this port last evening. She brings three days' later intelligence. The Fenian agitation in Ireland continues to absorb public attention. A large number of arrests have been made by the Irish Government, and it was supposed that others would follow. The authorities are taking every precaution to prevent the movement from attaining formidable proportions. As a general thing the English papers treat the whole matter with ridicule. Most of the Paris journals take the same view of it. At the same time it is considered politic to take a firm stand, and show the Fenian leaders that the government is ready and able to put them down with unsparing severity. Accounts from France represents the crops as in a very favorable condition. The official Gazette of Vienna contradicts the rumor that the government intends to establish in the German Provinces of Austria a system of provincial self-government. Herr VON BISMARCK has been elevated to the rank of Count. The Spanish Minister to Italy has been officially received by VICTOR EMANUEL.

abstract: A telegram from the Hague of Sept. 18, says: "The Dutch Chambers were opened to-day. The following are the most important points mentioned in the speech from the throne: The relations with foreign Powers are stated to be friendly, and the conditions of the colonial possessions favorable. The finances are prosperous, and the redemption of the public debt will be continued. The harvest is better than was expected. Measures have been taken to arrest the progress of the dangerous epidemic prevailing among cattle, and if necessary the attention of the Chambers will be again directed to the subject."

abstract: Nationalities of United States Naval Officers
snippet: Nationalities of United States Naval Officers
lead_paragraph: It has been stated by many vain-glorious and bigoted foreigners that the personnel of our navy was in the majority composed of foreigners, and we have been at some pains to place before our readers the following statement of facts, gleaned from the best known authority, and thus to give credit to those to whom it is due. Of the total number of officers in the naval service at the close of the war, 5,956 were born in the United States, 748 were foreigners, and 889 did not furnish the place of their birth.

abstract: The great romances, and the great matters of fact are all marvellously alike in quality, and in the most poetic deed there is the keenest sense of use. In other times, when the...
lead_paragraph: The great romances, and the great matters of fact are all marvellously alike in quality, and in the most poetic deed there is the keenest sense of use. In other times, when the world was in its youth, it did epic things consciously, and valued them for their poetry; now that it is grown old and full of wiseacres, its romance, like that of a middle-aged man, is unconscious, and hidden and forgotten in an obvious utility. But there never was anything so epic sung in the old times as an event of our own, which till now has been set to no higher music than the strains of the local reporters; to which Jenkins, not Homer is poet.

abstract: MY DEAR SIR: The inclosed may interest and be deemed worthy of preservation. So many personal friends having heard of, became curious of seeing and perusing Mr. LINCOLN's letter, that it was in danger of mutilation, and I caused it to be "printed for private distribution." Among them, certain conductors of  the press politically antagonistic obtaining a sight of that letter, copied and animadverted thereupon.

abstract: The matinee on Saturday brought the first week of Mr. MARETZEK's season to a brilliant close. The opera was "Faust," concerning the evening performance of which we have already spoken. There is nothing to be added now except that Mr. CARL BERGMANN conducted for the first time this season, and with all his accustomed point and intelligence. The attendance was brilliant, and fully up to the standard of former years. No form of entertainment has been accepted more cheerfully than this. Indeed it has often occurred to us that Mr. MARETZEK might occasionally change the order of performances with advantage to himself. The heart of Flora Fitz-Flimsey would throb with delight were she told that there would be three matinees and only two soirees in the week. Imagine the consternation which that fair creature's amazing bonnets would produce by the repeated shocks of three diurnal appearances at the Academy of Music!

abstract: Occurred between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, in AMELIA SCHUTGEN's dance-house, in the lower part of Cherry-street, and FRANCIS LAMARR, of the steamer Isla de Cuba, was stabbed in one hand and arm and in the back, the latter wound penetrating his liver. MICHAEL GRIFFITH was also stabbed, and several others are supposed to have been severely wounded by the pistols, poniards, bludgeons, decanters, and glasses that were used. Information having been given the police, Officers DORSEY and FITZGERALD went to the den and apprehended LAMARR, GRIFFITH and JOHN NICHOLAS, and took them to the Oak-street Police-station, where Dr. HUDSON, of No. 1 Madison-street, attended them. LAMARR, who does not appear to have participated in the fight, was taken aboard the Isla de Cuba, flying in the East River, and GRIFFITH and NICHOLS, having been held until morning in the station-house, were taken to the Tombs and committed for examination. The fight is said to have been commenced by a gang of Italians.
lead_paragraph: Occurred between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, in AMELIA SCHUTGEN's dance-house, in the lower part of Cherry-street, and FRANCIS LAMARR, of the steamer Isla de Cuba, was stabbed in one hand and arm and in the back, the latter wound penetrating his liver. MICHAEL GRIFFITH was also stabbed, and several others are supposed to have been severely wounded by the pistols, poniards, bludgeons, decanters, and glasses that were used. Information having been given the police, Officers DORSEY and FITZGERALD went to the den and apprehended LAMARR, GRIFFITH and JOHN NICHOLAS, and took them to the Oak-street Police-station, where Dr. HUDSON, of No. 1 Madison-street, attended them. LAMARR, who does not appear to have participated in the fight, was taken aboard the Isla de Cuba, flying in the East River, and GRIFFITH and NICHOLS, having been held until morning in the station-house, were taken to the Tombs and committed for examination. The fight is said to have been commenced by a gang of Italians.

abstract: -We are informed that of the bells of Charleston which were brought to this place, but three remain now on the spot where they have been so long exposed to the weather, and that all of these three are broken. One of them is the bell of St. Paul's Church; the other two remaining are those of St. Michael. These bells were originally eight in number. They were examined soon after the raid of SHERMAN, and four of them, all of St. Michael's, were sound and perfectly uninjured. All these have disappeared, but in what direction, how, why, and by whose hands, is utterly unknown. They are supposed to have been stolen, though as only the sound bells have been taken away the hope is entertained that these were saved and stored carefully by Major NIERNSEE. That gentleman is now absent from the city, and we must wait his return before we learn whether they are safe or not. If stolen, they could only have been stolen with the view to sell as old metal; and why, if such were the object, the sound bells should have been taken and the broken left, it is difficult to conceive. We are requested to correct the statement made in a Charleston paper, that when these bells were brought to Columbia, they were left exposed on the platform at the railroad depot. On the contrary, they were promptly housed, in a building on the Capitol grounds, which was fired and destroyed by SHERMAN's troops, at the time of the general conflagration of the city. The site where the bells still lie is that of the building which covered them. -- Columbia Phoenix.

abstract: HIGHWAY ROBBERY. On Saturday evening last, a lad named ANTHONY HANEY, aged fourteen years, was attacked and robbed in Hudson-avenue. HANEY is employed as a clerk in a tinware store in Myrtle-avenue, near Carll-street. He was on his way...
lead_paragraph: HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- On Saturday evening last, a lad named ANTHONY HANEY, aged fourteen years, was attacked and robbed in Hudson-avenue. HANEY is employed as a clerk in a tinware store in Myrtle-avenue, near Carll-street. He was on his way to his home, No. 71 Hudson-avenue. All the money he had with him, consisting of $9 50, was taken. A youth named ED. CLARK, aged fifteen years, was arrested and identified as one of the assailants. He was held for a hearing.

abstract: -Without at all committing the TIMES to an indorsement of the statement that "all the crowned heads of Europe are in grief at the prolonged absence of Mr. HERRMANN," we can safely state that very many thousands of American-born men, women and children are very greatly delighted at his presence here. They will have an opportunity of looking at and being mystified by him to-night, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. His wonderful broken English and excessively entertaining programme will be varied from those of last week at the same place. We understand that the Mayor of the city and everybody else willing to pay for a ticket are invited to attend.

abstract: -Plymouth Church has on old and ricketty organ, upon which for many years Mr. JOHN ZUNDEL played with wonderful success. He left some time since, and his vacant bench was temporarily supplied by Mr. WHITNEY, a young and very clever artist. Mr. MULLER, formerly of Albany and latterly of this city, has been permanently engaged by Mr. HUTCHINSON, the new chef, and yesterday the congregation were astonished at beholding some four and twenty new faces in the seats where for several years, say twenty, others had been familiar.

abstract: The trial terms of the civil courts on law will commence to-day. During the Summer vacation business of a litigated character has accumulated rapidly, and the month of October begins with unusually heavy calendars. There will be this month no less...
lead_paragraph: The trial terms of the civil courts on law will commence to-day. During the Summer vacation business of a litigated character has accumulated rapidly, and the month of October begins with unusually heavy calendars. There will be this month no less than nine civil courts of record, whose jurors will be required in session, and this without including the Marine Court. They are as follows: The Supreme Court, Oyer and Terminer. Circuit, Part I., will be held by Justice LEONARD; Part II., by Justice BARNARD, in the General Term room, and Part III. by Justice SUTHERLAND, at No. 73 Duane-street. The General Term of this court adjourned over on Friday last. During the two weeks that it has been in session, a large number of important cases have been argued, and many of them disposed of. Mr. Justice CLERKE will hold the Special Term, and Mr. Justice INGRAHAM will preside at the Chambers of this court during the month.

abstract: DONATIONS FOR THE SOLDIER'S WIDOW. The Superintendent of the Working Women's Protective Union, No. 80 White-street, desires to acknowledge the following donations in behalf of Mrs. ROGER's, the widow of the soldier who died at No. 182 Avenue A, on Saturday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: DONATIONS FOR THE SOLDIER'S WIDOW. -- The Superintendent of the Working Women's Protective Union, No. 80 White-street, desires to acknowledge the following donations in behalf of Mrs. ROGER's, the widow of the soldier who died at No. 182 Avenue A, on Saturday afternoon. It will be a source of gratification to the donors to know that the money raised through this and other sources has relieved Mrs. ROGER's necessities, for which she feels deeply grateful, and desires to return her sincere thanks. Mr. John Wilson, $10; From Walter, $1; A Lady, $1; Sympathy, $2; M.B., $2; From a Friend to Union Soldiers, $2; Charity, $1; left at Sun Office, W.P.W., $1 50; M.J.R., $2; J.B., $1; From a friend $2; A Lady, $1; J.R., $1 50; From Friends, $6. Total, $34 50.

abstract: The deaths in New-York during the past week were 422 104 men, 74 women, 113 boys and 113 girls a decrease of 85 from the mortality of the previous week, and of 45 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased, 223 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows:
lead_paragraph: The deaths in New-York during the past week were 422 -- 104 men, 74 women, 113 boys and 113 girls -- a decrease of 85 from the mortality of the previous week, and of 45 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased, 223 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption 58, infantile marasmuss 54, cholera infantum 32, dysentary 20, inflammation of the lungs 19, ship fever 16, dropsy in the head 10, typhoid fever 6, deaths from external causes 40 -- among which are reported 6 premature births, 8 deaths from old age, 11 drowned, and 6 killed by accidents.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest. Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -Those of the Southern States which have thus far taken satisfactory action in their Reconstruction Conventions, are the very States which, before the war, occupied the most extreme ground regarding slavery and "Southern rights." Mississippi, Alabama and South Carolina were at once the most pronounced and the most unanimous in their disunion sentiments; they were the States in which the Democratic party had the most widespread and permanent power. Other of the States in which conventions have yet to be held -- such as Georgia and North Carolina -- were always more temperate, more conservate, and had a much greater leaven of Whiggery and Unionism. We shall therefore look for action from these States at least equally satisfactory and creditable as that of those States which have already held their conventions.
lead_paragraph: -Those of the Southern States which have thus far taken satisfactory action in their Reconstruction Conventions, are the very States which, before the war, occupied the most extreme ground regarding slavery and "Southern rights." abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. A house of magnificent proportions, and full of what the Irish call the "quality" more so than on any other evening since the season began assembled here last evening. The occasion was the revival of a favorite opera, and the return to the operatic stage of one of the best tenors we have ever had on it.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A house of magnificent proportions, and full of what the Irish call the "quality" -- more so than on any other evening since the season began -- assembled here last evening. The occasion was the revival of a favorite opera, and the return to the operatic stage of one of the best tenors we have ever had on it. The first was PETRELLA's "Ione;" the second Signor MAZZOLENI. Let us at once record the genuine favor with which the gentleman was received. His appearance was the occasion for a burst of applause, so hearty and kindly in its nature that it was apparent it came from those who remembered his previous triumphs, and were glad to see him back to win others. The reception, if it may be dignified by the name, was quite flattering, and somewhat unusual. New-York as a rule is decidedly ungrateful to to its favorites. It is glad, on any pretext, to get rid of them. When they return it is equally glad to make fun of them. Remember how this precious community used that unfortunate BRIGNOLI, the man who is declared at this moment to be not only the successor to but the equal of MARIO. No; as a rule we save our applause for new comers, and are fractious and unfair when called upon to confirm our early preferences.

abstract: John Walker et al. vs. The Mayor of the City of New-York, &c. -- The amount claimed in this action is small -- only $200 -- but the principle involved is highly important to the taxpayers of the city. The plaintiffs, in their complaint, allege that on the 14th day of July, 1863, several rioters entered the premises known as No. 64 Greenwich-street, and then and there wantonly destroyed a piano, the property of the plaintiffs. They claim the article was so badly damaged that it was rendered entirely worthless?, and that before the damage it was worth $200. These facts seem to have been sufficiently proved. On the part of the defendants, it was claimed that there wan in the case no sufficient evidence that the persons who committed the damage, if any, belonged to the rioters; for aught that appeared, the piano question might have been injured by any person who, out of spite or revenge, went in and committed the trespass, or it might have been done from a spirit of mere wantonness, or by thieves for the purpose of plunder. During the few days of the riotous proceedings in July, 1863, all New-York people knew such conduct was common. This offence is alleged to have been committed in the lower part of Greenwich-street, and it is a notorious fact that the real rioters did not congregate there. Defendants' counsel said that this was only one of a class of cases whose name is legion. Some of them have been tried, and in nearly every instance the plaintiff has succeeded. He insisted that there was no merit in this case, and that there must be a stop put to this system of swindling the tax-payers of the city.
lead_paragraph: John Walker et al. vs. The Mayor of the City of New-York, &c. -- The amount claimed in this action is small -- only $200 -- but the principle involved is highly important to the taxpayers of the city. The plaintiffs, in their complaint, allege that on the 14th day of July, 1863, several rioters entered the premises known as No. 64 Greenwich-street, and then and there wantonly destroyed a piano, the property of the plaintiffs. They claim the article was so badly damaged that it was rendered entirely worthless?, and that before the damage it was worth $200. These facts seem to have been sufficiently proved. On the part of the defendants, it was claimed that there wan in the case no sufficient evidence that the persons who committed the damage, if any, belonged to the rioters; for aught that appeared, the piano question might have been injured by any person who, out of spite or revenge, went in and committed the trespass, or it might have been done from a spirit of mere wantonness, or by thieves for the purpose of plunder. During the few days of the riotous proceedings in July, 1863, all New-York people knew such conduct was common. This offence is alleged to have been committed in the lower part of Greenwich-street, and it is a notorious fact that the real rioters did not congregate there. Defendants' counsel said that this was only one of a class of cases whose name is legion. Some of them have been tried, and in nearly every instance the plaintiff has succeeded. He insisted that there was no merit in this case, and that there must be a stop put to this system of swindling the tax-payers of the city.

abstract: The recent detached ascension of the great war balloon "United States," on Saturday last, was one of peculiar interest. As was stated in Sunday's TIMES, the ascension took place at 6 o'clock P.M., from the balloon inclosure, in Sixth-avenue, near the Central Park.
lead_paragraph: The recent detached ascension of the great war balloon "United States," on Saturday last, was one of peculiar interest. As was stated in Sunday's TIMES, the ascension took place at 6 o'clock P.M., from the balloon inclosure, in Sixth-avenue, near the Central Park. The high wind which prevailed all day having subsided sufficiently to admit of a voyage being taken to the skies, preparations were soon made to that end. Prof. LOWE, the experienced aeronaut, entered the car, followed by Mr. FLEURY, a passenger, and by HARRY LESLIE, who is so well-known as the "the hero of Niagara." The appearance of this renowned gymnast created great excitement, and he surprised every one present by his slight physique, not appearing at all like what fancy had painted him. His dress was one of those handsome gymnastic costumes, so much worn by grotesques in the French cirque, and was elaborately embroidered.

abstract: Returns from the election yesterday in Connecticut indicate the decisive defeat of the proposition to amend the Constitution so as to allow negroes to vote. It is assumed that the majority against the proposition will be nearly five thousand. Intrinsically, the election is of little consequence, since there are but few colored men in the State; but just at this juncture, when the same question is paramount in the Southern States, this verdict is pregnant with importance.

abstract: Account of his Violent Death
snippet: Account of his Violent Death
lead_paragraph: WM. L. YANCEY came to his end by violence. It was toward the close of the second session of the first Confederate Congress that he broke from the counsels and influence of Mr. DAVIS, and became, with Mr. HENRY S. FOOTE, a leader of the opposition. Mr. BEN. HILL, a Senator from Georgia, had likewise changed his front, and was remarkable for the earnestness, personal interest and persistency with which he sustained the measures of an administration to which his allegiance had been given but late in the day. Mr. YANCEY, it will be remembered, had returned from an unsuccessful mission to Europe, and was representing Alabama in the Confederate Senate. The question of a navy was under discussion in secret session. The debate ranged beyond the parliamentary limits, and Messrs. YANCEY and HILL became animated over the abstract doctrines of State rights and the divinity of slavery. High words passed, and finally the lie was given by Mr. HILL. Mr. YANCEY leaned forward, and as he aimed a blow at his adversary, was caught in the arms of the latter, and thrown violently back over a desk. Mr. HILL is a man of wonderful muscular development. Mr. YANCEY was never very heavy, though lithe and active. In the fall, his spine was seriously injured, and when the bystanders rushed upon the two and drugged the one from the other, the great fire-eater lay unconcious upon the floor, with a little trickle of blood oozing from his lips. He was carried to his hotel a vote of secrecy was passed, and the encounter hushed up. No one in Richmond except that body of men knew of the circumstance for six months after. Meanwhile the victim did not recover. He drooped from day to day. He became listless, hopeless and vacant. He was transferred to his own home, where his convulsions ceased a few weeks before his death, which was tranquil and calm. -- Nashville Banner.

abstract: It seems that the Gastein Convention by which Prussia and Austria have disposed of the fortunes of the Duchies is regarded by the Western European Powers -- especially England -- as a defiance of the treaties of 1815 and 1852. Lord RUSSELL has, therefore, taken once more to lecturing the German Powers for their disregard of the public opinion of Europe and the legitimate claims of the Duchies to be heard, before their destiny is finally sealed by the decree of their conquerors. The lecture, from all accounts, is exceedingly severe, and it will probably produce as much practical result as the British Secretary's efforts to prevent the dismemberment of Denmark two years ago.

abstract: The London Times in putting forth the preposterous statement that it was upon information furnished by Secretary SEWARD, concerning Fenian plans and plots, that the seizure at the Irish People office was made, is but carrying out a line of policy it adopted at the first actual appearance of Fenianism in Ireland a month or two ago. That policy was to undermine the confidence of the Fenians, or rather of the Irish people in each other, in their leaders, and in all whom they had come to look upon as friends, aiders or abettors. When the Fenian drilling first began and the fact of an organized movement had become manifest, the Times told the Irish that the British Government had its agents in every one of their companies, its spies in every one of their circles, its informers at every one of their meetings, no matter how private or where held. It told them that some of their drill-masters were in Her Majesty's pay, and some of their head officers were British hirelings and traitors to their cause. All this, was, of course, greatly exaggerated; but it would assuredly destroy the confidence of many. The Times now continues this same policy by informing these poor people, many of whom eagerly believed they had a friend in Mr. SEWARD, that the American Secretary of State is using all his power to destroy them, and has really acted as an informer to the British Government.

abstract: The government intends to dispose, at public auction, of the timber, lumber and abattis in the dismantled forts around Washington. The following are the names of the forts which have been dismantled thus far:
lead_paragraph: The government intends to dispose, at public auction, of the timber, lumber and abattis in the dismantled forts around Washington. The following are the names of the forts which have been dismantled thus far: Forts Marcy, Bennet, Haggerty, Woodbury, Cass, Allbany, Scott, Jackson, Runyon, Berry, Barnard, Reynolds, Garesche, Williams and Willard, all of which are on the south side of the Potomac. Those dismantled on the north side are Forts Jamison, Thayer, Morris. Saratoga, Bunker Hill, Slemmer, De Russey, Smcalle, Kearney, Russell, Graines, Bayard, Simmons and Mansfield. Forts Snyder, Ricketts, Wagner, Davis, Meigs and Chapin, across the Eastern Branch, have also been dismantled. A large number of batteries, block-houses, stockades, &c., composing the defences of Washington, have also been removed.
