abstract: Sale vs. Sun Insurance Co. Marine Insurance
snippet: Sale vs. Sun Insurance Co. Marine Insurance
lead_paragraph: William A. Sale and others vs. the Sun Mutual Insurance Company. -- The trial of this action was commenced yesterday in the Superior Court, before Justice BARBOUR. The amount of money involved is not very large, being between three and four thousand dollars, but there are some principles of law in the case which if they are not, ought to be settled as between marine insurers and the insured. The facts are briefly as follows: In the Summer of 1863, the plaintiffs effected an open policy of insurance on goods to be shipped from the port of Matamoras to the port of New-York, by a vessel known as the brig Trade Wind. There were some other marine insurance companies that took risks on the same vessel and cargo, but their names do not appear, and for a proper adjudication of the questions involved, it is not material that they should. The defendants are charged with having insured one-third of the cargo, and about this there is no dispute. About the 6th of August, 1863, the Trade Wind was loaded with cotton and sailed soon after from the port of Matamoras for the port of New-York. The plaintiffs had upon her one hundred and sixty-six bales. When the brig arrived off Cape Lookout, she was overtaken by a storm, and during the stress of weather a portion of the cargo was wholly lost. The plaintiffs lost eleven bales. The remainder of their one hundred and sixty bales, was at length brought on to New-York, and sold at public auction on the 9th and 17th days of October of the same year. On the 9th of October, sound cotton was selling in New-York at 92 cents per pound, and on the 17th at 90 cents. The price at which it was valued at Matamoras, where it was shipped about three months before, was 65 cents per pound. A large portion of the plaintiff's cotton, which was brought on to New-York, could not be identified with certainty, for the reason that, owing to the water getting into the vessel and among the bales, the bags or sacks that held the cotton burst, and much of it had to be overhauled and resacked, or else brought on here in a loose state. There appears to be no dispute about the bales which could be identified after their arrival here; but the plaintiffs claim they are entitled to $8,351 37 from the defendants, on the general average. The defendants, on the other hand, insist that they are only liable for $5,225 07, as their proportion, and this amount they are willing to pay, with interest since the liability accrued. The questions in the case are considered important, as regards the value of insured goods at the place of shipment and at the port of destination, and also in respect of the fall or advance in the price of merchandise sold at public auction under the circumstances this cotton was at the time. The trial will be continued to-day, when the facts will be more fully developed, and the law governing such cases more fully stated by the court.

abstract: The steamship Arago and Fulton, which enjoyed before the war a high reputation for comfort and good management as passenger vessels, are announced as nearly ready to resume their trips on the New-York and Havre line, touching at Southampton. We have often heretofore referred to the mortifying fact that the Atlantic steamship traffic was monopolized by foreigners, who, as the natural result of having matters all their own way, were able to drive a highly lucrative trade without being over-careful of the convenience and economy of their patrons. Therefore we hail this promise of competition with satisfaction, and trust the enterprise will meet the success it merits.

abstract: CHILD MURDER.-- The body of a newly-born male infant was found floating in the river, foot of North Ninth-street, E.D., yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: CHILD MURDER. -- The body of a newly-born male infant was found floating in the river, foot of North Ninth-street, E.D., yesterday morning. It had been in the water several days, and was somewhat decomposed. There was not a particle of clothing upon it. The child had evidently been murdered, as the front part of its head was mashed to a jelly, which could not have occurred accidentally. The physical proportions of the infant were admirable at birth. Coroner BARRETT took charge of the remains, and will institute a searching inquiry, with the view of bringing the murderer to Justice.

abstract: Conventions; Suggestions to on Duty to Freedmen
snippet: Conventions; Suggestions to on Duty to Freedmen
lead_paragraph: The Southern conventions, if they would secure an early representation of their States in Congress, should take care to leave as little ground as possible for the opponents of that admission to stand upon. No solid ground is now left save what relates to the freedmen. The renewed loyal spirit of the Southern people has so distinctly manifested itself through these conventions and other public channels, that the North can no longer doubt it, and none of our representatives in Congress will seriously impugn it. The question that will be made is not whether the late rebels have sincerely returned to their allegiance to the government, but whether they mean to do justice to that race whom circumstances have made the wards of the government. If it can be shown that no such justice is done or intended, the restoration of the Southern States to their full civil capacity will be contested strenuously, and, in all likelihood, effectually. The rehabilitation of the Status involves a remission to them of all their old municipal power over all within their limits, white and black; and the government must find some kind of security in advance, express or implied, that this power will not be abused to the harm of the freedmen.

abstract: Reorganization of
snippet: Reorganization of
lead_paragraph: Austria has a curious and difficult task before her. She is to restore self-government to Hungary, and yet retain the supremacy of Austria. Her favorite policy, by which for so many years she has retained these various races and hostile provinces under her rule -- that of playing off one race or interest against another -- is still pursued. Magyars may be kept down by putting Slavonians up, and Hungary may be prevented from being a unit by giving a separate, political life to her provinces.

abstract: This is the day on which Gov. FENTON, as Chief-Magistrate of the Empire State, will hold high court at the City Hall, for the investigation of charges preferred by certain parties against His Honor the Mayor, C. GODFREY GUNTHER; the Recorder, JOHN T. HOFFMAN; the City Inspector, F.I.A. BOOLE, and the Comptroller, MATTHEW T. BRENNAN. The Mayor, it is reported, has so effectually cleared his skirts, that the Governor declines to proceed further in his case. The Recorder, standing upon his dignity and his rights, declines to obey officially the summons of the Governor. The City Inspector professes his eagerness to appear, that he may exhibit a clean record, and slay with wrath his malignant foes.

abstract: Iroquois; Ports Visited by and Officers of
snippet: Iroquois; Ports Visited by and Officers of
lead_paragraph: The steam screw sloop Iroquois, 9 guns, Commander C.R.P. RODGERS, arrived at the Navy-yard on Sunday evening from an extended cruise in the Atlantic Ocean and the East Indies, from whence she came in ninety-four days, including seven days spent in port. The Iroquois wan put in commission at Baltimore on the 31st of March, 1864, and after serving some months on our coast she was ordered to cruise in the English Channel. She sailed from New-York on the 10th of July, 1864. Her stay in those water extended over a period of two months, when she was dispatched to the East Indies via the coast of Brazil. During the time she has been on foreign service she has traversed the distance of 44,100 statute miles, of which 14[???] miles have been under sail alone.

abstract: The steamship Belgian, from Liverpool Sept. 21, via Londonderry Sept. 22, passed Father Point yesterday afternoon en route to Quebec. There were no new developments in the Fenian movement. JAMES MURPHY, one of the men arrested at Dublin, who described himself as a citizen of Boston, and protested against his arrest, had been set at liberty, after an interview between the American Consul and the authorities. The American officer arrested at Queenstown, on the arrival of the City of Limerick, turns out to be a Federal Captain named MCAFFERTY. A number of Fenian documents were found in his possession, with evidence that he is connected with the movement. The arms of Brig,-Gen. GLEASON, of the United. States Army, who was also a passenger on the City of Limerick, were taken from him. An important meeting of American bondholders was held in Frankfort recently, to listen to an address on American financial and commercial prospects. There were rumors of ministerial changes in France, and also of government reforms, including more liberty to the press.

abstract: On the night of the 18th ultimo. Messrs. JOHN LOTTY & CO.'s warehouse, in Eighth-street, near Chestnut, Philadelphia, was entered by burglars, who chisled through a brick wall from an adjoining building, and stole silks and other dry-goods of the value of $15,000, with which they escaped. Chief Detective FRANKLIN telegraphed to the police of the seaboard cities, offering a suitable reward and minutely describing the persons whom he suspected, and with this description Detective Officers ELDER and MCCORD began work here; unsuccessful, however, until Wednesday evening last, when they saw their man in Broadway. Taking him into custody, and searching his two trunks, at his hotel, Officers MCCORD and ELDER found fifty pieces of silk and a diagram, from which they inferred that the residue of the goods might be found in a tomb in the Monument Cemetery, and on going to Philadelphia and making the facts known to Chief FRANKLIN, our officers were sent, with Philadelphia Detectives TAGGERT and SMITH, to the tomb of Mrs. ISAIAH GABEL, where they found a hundred pieces of silk, which were identified by Messrs. LOTTY & CO. The prisoner, whose name is FRANK PEACOCK, otherwise Wagner, otherwise Stevens, is held at Police Headquarters, awaiting the arrival of a requisition from Gov. CURTIN. The fellow is well known by the police of Baltimore and Philadelphia.

abstract: It is barely possiblethat this trial will load to more important developments than have hitherto been suspected. The apparent impossibility of controverting the powerful array of facts adduced by the prosecution, seems to have compelled the defence to abandon their naturally direct course, and, while impliedly confessing judgment, undertake to show that Capt. WIRZ was not the responsible party. It is stated that this line of defence takes the extremely remote stand-point that the real responsibility for the maltreatment of our men at Andersonville, rests upon our own government, or at least upon the officers in charge of the exchange of prisoners, because of the suspension of exchanges during 1863-64. Should this style of defence be admitted, we may as well begin the trial anew, and commence the list of witnesses on one side with ANDREW JOHNSON and Secretary STANTON, and on the other with JEFFERSON DAVIS and Secretary SEDDON, and so go through the entire history of the exchange business. But we hardly think this course will be pursued; it would prove a two-edged sword, and smite backwards more effectively than forwards. The prosecution are not unwilling to admit reliable testimony of DAVIS' knowledge and participation in this fearful business, but we do not believe that the defenders of WIRZ are in any hurry to furnish it. It is too late for their client to turn State's evidence; his case is apparently hopeless; all the evidence on his side, thus far, is negative and worthless -- the witnesses "did not see" and "did not hear." Such testimony might be taken by the ream; but of what value can it be? -- proving a negative does not go far to disprove an affirmative. If the defence are permitted to open the question of exchanges, we hope it will be thoroughly ventilated. There is a great deal of mistiness in the public mind about the matter, and it must sooner or later be cleared up.

But we hardly think this course will be pursued; it would prove a two-edged sword, and smite backwards more effectively than forwards. The prosecution are not unwilling to admit reliable testimony of DAVIS' knowledge and participation in this fearful business, but we do not believe that the defenders of WIRZ are in any hurry to furnish it. It is too late for their client to turn State's evidence; his case is apparently hopeless; all the evidence on his side, thus far, is negative and worthless -- the witnesses "did not see" and "did not hear." Such testimony might be taken by the ream; but of what value can it be? -- proving a negative does not go far to disprove an affirmative. If the defence are permitted to open the question of exchanges, we hope it will be thoroughly ventilated. There is a great deal of mistiness in the public mind about the matter, and it must sooner or later be cleared up.

abstract: The, Mr. Seward and the London Times; and Muskets labeled U. S.
snippet: The, Mr. Seward and the London Times; and Muskets labeled U. S.
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the English journals are making quite an outcry because on one musket taken, in the hands of a captured Fenian, were found the letters "U.S." Now, we propose that every musket or other gun which may be captured during this Anti-Fenian war, and found to be thus marked, be forthwith returned to the United States, the captors receiving in exchange therefor a similar gun, marked with the British mark, captured from the late Confederates. We can continue that exchange indefinitely, and have a good many thousand British muskets on hand after all.

abstract: SATTERTHWAITE'S Circular, dated on the evening of the 20th, says: "The market for American Securities has been very active, and up to the 19th with steadily advancing rates.
lead_paragraph: SATTERTHWAITE's Circular, dated on the evening of the 20th, says: "The market for American Securities has been very active, and up to the 19th with steadily advancing rates. 5-20s were at one time done as high as 68 1/4, but gave way, and closed heavy at 68@68 1/4. Eries had been largely bought up to 58 1/2, when they reacted to 57, but on renewed buying have again improved to 57 1/2@57 1/4. Illinois in demand at an improvement on the week of about three-quarters of a dollars. Atlantic and Great Western bonds in demand, and few to be sold, even at an advance of two to three dollars.

abstract: Certificates of Indebtedness--Proposals for Funding
snippet: Certificates of Indebtedness--Proposals for Funding
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Treasury publishes in our advertising columns this morning an important announcement of "Proposals for funding Certificates of Indebtedness, Compound Interest Notes and Treasury Notes," to the extent of fifty millions of dollars. The action is taken in virtue of the authority contained in the act of March 3d last, to provide ways and means, and which provides, among other things, that any Treasury Notes, or other obligations bearing interest issued under any act of Congress, may, at the discretion of the Secretary of the Treasury, and with the consent of the holder, be converted into any description of bonds authorized by said act. The Secretary, therefore, (to use the language of the official notification,) gives notice to the holders of "Certificates of indebtedness which mature before the 1st day of January next, of compound interest notes, and of one and two year Treasury Notes, of the readiness of this Department to give in exchange for them, to the extent of fifty millions of dollars, six per cent. Five-Twenty Year Bonds at three per cent. premium; that is to say, one hundred dollars of bonds for each one hundred and three dollars in certificates and notes; provided the conversion is made prior to the 1st day of November next. The bonds issued in exchange for such certificates and notes will bear an interest of six per cent. per annum, payable semi-annually in coin, upon the 1st days of May and November, and will be redeemable at the pleasure of the government after five years, and payable in twenty years from the 1st day of November, 1865." Other details of the scheme are fully and clearly set forth by the Secretary.

abstract: a Reform Needed
snippet: a Reform Needed
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the cool breezes of Autumn, we still are compelled to inhale the putrid smell so sickening and stiflings, which still pervades the lower portion of the city and along the river edges. The evening airs waft these fumes into the very heart of the city, and noiselessly prey upon us and undermine our health. To the stagnating water around the docks we charge this almost intolerable nuisance. The combined filth of miles of sewers, the excrescences of hundreds of slaughter-houses and manufactories are brought down and deposited between the piers, and from this feculent pile rise up the deathly vapors which pervade our nightly inhalations.
headline: {'main': 'Our Dock System A Reform Needed.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Dock System A Reform Needed.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning, the large five-story building on the northwest corner of Oliver and South streets, which was occupied by Mr, JACOB LAMBERT as a liquor-store, and by sixteen families as a dwelling, was destroyed by fire, of probably, incendiary origin.
lead_paragraph: Between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning, the large five-story building on the northwest corner of Oliver and South streets, which was occupied by Mr, JACOB LAMBERT as a liquor-store, and by sixteen families as a dwelling, was destroyed by fire, of probably, incendiary origin. The flames were first discovered in the rear of Mr. LAMBERT's liquor-store, between 11 and 32 o'clock, and before the bells struck they had enveloped the stair-case leading to the upper stories, and thus cut off the tenants' means of egress. Happily, however, the occupants of the building preserved their presence of mind, and without attempting to save any of their effects, all fled to the roof, and thence escaped on the roofs of adjoining buildings.

abstract: The new steamer Henry Chauncy, Capt. GRAY, arrived at her dock yesterday morning at 1 o'clock, having been out on a trial trip along the Eastern Coast as far as Portsmouth, N.H. She left here on last Thursday afternoon, and carried out only a few of the directors of the company. The trip was pleasant in every respect, and the vessel proved herself all that might be expected of her. She will be put on the line between this port and Aspinwall. She is one of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company's new fleet.

abstract: Now that the absolute folly of attempting to rent a domicile is conceded on all hands, the question arises whether the shortest and easiest method of successful house-hunting is not by house-haunting. In other words, whether to get possession of your "neighbor's house," the which you are forbidden to "covet," you may not most readily accomplish your object by letting loose a troop of ghosts in its more remote apartments. To do this, requires no such ingenious devices as the Davenports got up for the amusement and enlightenment of their audiences. A much more simple apparatus will suffice, as witness the effect lately produced in Jersey City. You may begin by securing two members of the well-known Grimalkin family, attaching their posterior extremities to each other by a bit of hempen twine, obtained any day at your grocer's. Deposit them carefully in the cellar or basement of the desired (not "coveted") premises, and a very good ghostly demonstration will be made in the course of less than a minute. Or, second, you may attach to the corresponding extremity of "Fido" two or three tin kettles and pans, placing him and his new-found ornaments in the same humble apartments. Thereby will hang a tail immediately. Or, third, you may hoist a ladder against an outside wall, raise a garret window, introduce several armfuls of brush, tin-pans, old pots, brick-bats, pokers, &c., &c.., the aforesaid heap to be as duly mingled and tossed about as doctor's medicine before gulping. The last experiment ought to be tried in a dark night, and as there is to be an eclipse this evening, it strikes us that a very edifying visit might be made in this manner from a-loft, while the moon is experiencing a sort of nightmare. But in any case make sure that in the locality reside a goodly sprinkling of spiritualists or Irish laborers; otherwise your costly preparations and elaborate execution may turn out to no purpose, excepting a collection of black and blue marks on your own cuticle.
lead_paragraph: Now that the absolute folly of attempting to rent a domicile is conceded on all hands, the question arises whether the shortest and easiest method of successful house-hunting is not by house-haunting. You may begin by securing two members of the well-known Grimalkin family, attaching their posterior extremities to each other by a bit of hempen twine, obtained any day at your grocer's. Or, second, you may attach to the corresponding extremity of "Fido" two or three tin kettles and pans, placing him and his new-found ornaments in the same humble apartments. Thereby will hang a tail immediately. Or, third, you may hoist a ladder against an outside wall, raise a garret window, introduce several armfuls of brush, tin-pans, old pots, brick-bats, pokers, &c., &c.., the aforesaid heap to be as duly mingled and tossed about as doctor's medicine before gulping. The last experiment ought to be tried in a dark night, and as there is to be an eclipse this evening, it strikes us that a very edifying visit might be made in this manner from a-loft, while the moon is experiencing a sort of nightmare. abstract: Constitutional Amendment Should be Ratified by South
snippet: Constitutional Amendment Should be Ratified by South
lead_paragraph: We have taken occasion more than once to express our admiration of the manly and courageous manner in which the people of the South accept the results of the recent war. We doubt if any parallel for it can be found in history. They have been terribly scourged and beaten in a war they themselves commenced. They have lost property, population, pride, hope -- everything that great communities hold dear -- but they have not lost their manliness, their practical wisdom nor their fortitude under calamity. They do not moan for pity like defeated Hungarians, nor conspire like conquered Frenchmen, not swear like the beaten Irish, They accept their fate with self-reliant resignation and at once proceed, with firmness and sagacity, to make the best of their new condition. The war has taught them wisdom and they are not above profiting by its lessons.

abstract: -- We learn from a party  who has been interested in the projected scheme of emigration from the Southern States to Brazil that the whole project has been given up. After the close of the war, when the Southern people expected to be treated with great severity by the government, and when there was no prospect for their section but the prospect of ruin, the Brazilian movement was received with favor, and many planters expressed their purpose of seeking homes in South America. But the magnanimity of the government, and the brightening prospects of the South, have materially affected their views about emigration, and the fact that Brazil itself is engaged in a great war has changed their ideas of that country as a peaceful home. Of the few Southerners who may leave their native land in permanence, the majority will settle in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: -- We learn from a party who has been interested in the projected scheme of emigration from the Southern States to Brazil that the whole project has been given up. abstract: Free Press in the South
snippet: Free Press in the South
lead_paragraph: A fact which ought to make us the more patient with the political and social evils left by slavery, is the absolute freedom of the press to discuss every public concern. Such a freedom exists, and is practically exercised, in every Southern State. It is not military authority that secures it, but public opinion. Nobody calls it in question. The assimilation to the North in this respect is universally recognized to be one of the natural and necessary results of the war. This in itself is of more real consequence than anything which has been done, or left undone, by the conventions.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of "Ione" last evening was, in all respects, an improvement on the first if that can be said of singers who really distinguished themselves on Monday evening. The orchestra under Mr. MARETZEK'S able direction not only seized all the delicate and ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "Ione" last evening was, in all respects, an improvement on the first -- if that can be said of singers who really distinguished themselves on Monday evening. The orchestra under Mr. MARETZEK's able direction not only seized all the delicate and all the striking ideas of the score, but went affectionately and encouragingly with the singers, helping them through in a way that MARETZEK can alone effect. The chorus, too, was in excellent trim. It would be difficult, indeed, to hear a better performance of PETRELLA's popular work.

abstract: to the South, Plans for
snippet: to the South, Plans for
lead_paragraph: -- It was always the policy of the fire-eating party in the South to repress immigration to the Southern States from free countries. They feared the effect of this population upon their tenure of power, and upon their sacred institution. Now, each State seems more anxious than the other to secure free immigration. They appreciate its effect upon the young States of the West, and comprehend that it is the source of greatness and wealth. Virginia and North Carolina have both taken action in the matter, and now the Governor of South Carolina has projected measures for the benefit of that State. It is proposed to appoint a State Commissioner, with power to ascertain and advertise all lands for sale, to open information offices, to distribute broadcast descriptive pamphlets, and to station emigration agents in the chief ports of Europe. The plan is an excellent one, and will in time prove effective. Many of the Western States have agents in Europe, who keep the people informed as to the advantages of the States they represent, and thus turn tons of thousands of excellent settlers to those States.

abstract: Connecticut Election, the
snippet: Connecticut Election, the
lead_paragraph: The people of Connecticut have decided by about 5,000 majority, that they will not permit negroes to vote. They are to be excluded from suffrage, not because they lack intelli gence or capacity, but solely and simply because they are black. That there is any reason for so broad and hostile a discrimination, scarcely any one pretends. Experience has proved that on the whole the negro, under the same circumstances, falls not at all below the white in thrift, in reliability, and in whatever makes a good and trustworthy citizen. Nor could the people of Connecticut have apprehended any danger of any kind from admitting this new class of voters to the polls; for the negro voters in that State could scarcely have exceeded 2,000 or 2,500.

abstract: The operations of the Internal Revenue Bureau are being gradually extended over the States of the South. Those who think that only extremely small revenue returns will be received from that section of country, owing ...
lead_paragraph: The operations of the Internal Revenue Bureau are being gradually extended over the States of the South. Those who think that only extremely small revenue returns will be received from that section of country, owing to the universal destitution of the people, may have their opinions modified by two considerations -- firstly, the large sums of money and of cotton that have been coming from the South during the last three months to pay for the enormous quantities of goods that have been furnished from the North, and chiefly from this city. Secondly, the vast accumulation in Washington of petitions for pardon from twenty-thousand dollar men.

abstract: On Monday evening Mr. and Mrs. THEODORE TILTON celebrated, at their residence in Brooklyn, their Tin Wedding, the tenth anniversary of their marriage. Nearly four hundred guests were present, among whom were Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Rev. Drs. Storrs, Cuyler, Leavitt, Irinee, Putnam, and ...
lead_paragraph: On Monday evening Mr. and Mrs. THEODORE TILTON celebrated, at their residence in Brooklyn, their Tin Wedding, the tenth anniversary of their marriage. Nearly four hundred guests were present, among whom were Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Rev. Drs. Storrs, Cuyler, Leavitt, Irinee, Putnam, and Farley, Miss Phebe Cary, Hon. Moses F. Odell, Robt. Dale Owen, Ex-Mayor Hall, A.J. Spooner, Henry C. Bowen, and a fair representation of the editorial fraternity. The parlors were lavishly supplied with bouquets and baskets of choice flowers, presented by Messrs. CHITTENDEN, of Brooklyn, and HASKELL, of Llewellyn Park, N.J. The guests, as in duty bound, individually brought an offering of tin-ware, which, in the aggregate, seemed sufficient, when set out on the tables, to supply the wants of the happy couple in that peculiar line for life, and their children and grandchildren after them. Some of the gifts were quite elegant and beautiful, and there was such a variety of them that it almost appeared that the guests had consulted together to determine that no article should be duplicated. The evening was passed in a delightful manner, many happy hits being made by humorous persons in the company. An effusion by Miss PHEBE CARY was read by OLIVER JOHNSON, in which a witty play upon the word "tin" was introduced in easy verse, making much amusement. Letters were received from Dr. CHEEVER, Rev. SAMUEL J. MAY, EDNA DEAN PROCTOR, P.T. BARNUM, and others, regretting their inability to participate in the festivities, and expressive of an infinity of good wishes for the recipients.

abstract: First Message to General Assembly
snippet: First Message to General Assembly
lead_paragraph: Gov. BROWNLOW, of Tennessee, sent his first Message to the General Assembly yesterday. He recommends amendments and additions to the franchise law, but says: "I am by no means an advocate of its repeal, nor do the loyal people of the State wish any sweeping change." The restoration of civil law has worked well, and prosperity is promised in every section. Guilty rebels should be treated with severity, in proportion to their offences; the mass of them with not less than ten years' disfranchisement, and the leaders with neither mercy nor forbearance. He says: "I am convinced that the white and colored people cannot live together, politically or socially, as equals." He advocates the setting apart of some portion of the national territory, best adapted for the purpose, for a nation of freedmen. The testimony of negroes is recommended to be taken in the courts on the same basis as that of white persons.

abstract: When the publication of THE NATION was commenced, there was naturally a good deal of doubt felt and expressed in many quarters as to the existence of any demand on the part of the public for such a paper as THE NATION aimed to be. We are glad to say that the experience of the last three months has satisfied us that this doubt was not well founded. We believe we are justified in asserting that no such reception has ever in this country been accorded to any weekly paper, not pictorial, as this journal has received. We find, both in the number of our subscribers and the expressions of opinion which reach us from all parts of the country, abundant proof that such a paper as we seek to supply is sure both of wide circulation and hearty appreciation. The most sanguine anticipations we ventured to form on this point have been realized. In other words -- and we trust we say this without being held guilty of undue self-laudation -- the American public has shown that its literary taste is higher than it has been commonly assumed to be.

abstract: Speech at Syracuse
snippet: Speech at Syracuse
lead_paragraph: The Democratic candidate for Secretary of State has made a Speech at Syracuse, which we transfer to our columns that our readers may see for themselves what reasons he offers for allowing himself, a Republican and a soldier of the Union, to be used to draw votes to the Democrats and men opposed to the war. A painful interest attaches to this deflection, not to say defection, of one who has in the past made for himself so honorable a record. This speech will do nothing to abate it.

lead_paragraph: -- HUNTINGTON's picture of "The Republican Court," now on exhibition at the Art Gallery, No 625 Broadway, is one of the few objects of interest that are entirely American. It is a profitable study to look over the sixty faces there represented and trace out their destiny. The last of all, GEORGE WASHINGTON PARKE CURTIS, who appears in the picture as handsome boy of fifteen, died only eight years ago. Among the more eminent persons represented we notice Washington, Adams, Hamilton, Louis Phillippe Fisher Ames, Jefferson, John Jay, the two Trumbulls Gilbert Stuart, John Hancock, Dr. Rush, Baron Steuben, Gen. Lincoln, Gen. Knox, Francis Hopkinson, Gen. Green, three Morrises, (Lewis, Robert and Gouverneur,) Henry Laurens, Oliver Wolcot, Oliver Ellsworth; and of the gentler sex, Mrs. Washington (Martha Dundridge,) Mrs. John Adams, Mrs. Hamilton, Mrs. Rufus King, Nelly Curtis, Mrs. Robert Morris, Dolly Paine, Harriet Chew, Anne Willing, Abigail Adams, Pamela Dwight, Sarah Van Brugh Livingston, Sophia Chew, Lady Duer, Sally Foster, (Mrs. Harrison Gray Otis,) Mrs. Ralph Izard, Mrs. Gorge Clinton, Polly Carroll, Mary Ann Wolcott, and Martha Jefferson. Not alone is this fine picture worthy of attention, but there is also an excellent collection of paintings, mainly by German artists, that will add materially to the enjoyment and instruction of the visitor.

abstract: Last evening, Mr. JOHN DECKER, Ex-Chief Engineer of the New-York Fire Department, was the recipient of a very handsome testimonial from the members of Broderick Engine No. 1, of San Francisco, Cal. The presentation took place at the Metropolitan Hotel. Mr. C.K. GARRISON, Ex-Mayor of San Francisco, presided, and Mr. JAMES B. MACMAHON, Ex.-Clerk of the Supreme Court of the State, acted as Secretary. Mayor GUNTHER was invited to occupy a seat on the right hand of the President.

abstract: A large number of people were present last evening in the grounds of Otto Cottage, Hoboken, in order to ratify the nomination of MARCUS S. WARD, for Governor of New-Jersey. Dr. CHARLES WEHLE was president of the meeting, and introduced Brig.-Gen. LITTLEFIELD, now in command of a District in North Carolina, the Hon. ALBERT DAVISON, and Gen. SWIFT, of Louisiana, all of whom addressed the audience, which was of the most enthusiastic description. The Union Glee Club also enlivened the meeting by several patriotic and national songs. Gen. KILPATRICK, who was the orator of the evening, said, that a little over four years ago ROBERT TOOMBS had boasted he would call the roll of slaves on Bunker Hill. At tha time he (the General) was in New-York and heard the song, "The Sword of Bunker Hill," sung by about 400 ladies with so much vim and vigor that he was convinced there was stuff enough in the people of the North to prevent any such roll being called. Copperheads had said he was afraid to visit Hoboken and address the meeting; he was going to speak at Newark on Saturday next, and invited all present to be there to see if he were absent or not.

abstract: Commissioner NEWTON has issued his report for the month just closed. It relates chiefly to farm stock. In the summary he states that the average amounts consumed in great Britain and Ireland is about 56,000,000 of bushels more than produced. The deficit of this year will then make it about one-third greater, or 72,600,000 bushels. It may, however, be much greater. The immense corn crop of this country, now safely grown, will enable us to ship largely of wheat to foreign countries, although the wheatcrop has been injured fully as much as reported in the last monthly, and the quality of the new crop is not good in many States. The amount of old wheat will not be as great as anticipated. The buckwheat and potato crops may be very large, but the danger of the rot is too imminent to base any calculations upon the latter crop.

abstract: Alarming Increase of Price
snippet: Alarming Increase of Price
lead_paragraph: -- At an auction of coal yesterday, by wholesale, the prices realized, convey an alarming intimation to the multitude of poor consumers, of the Winter prospect before them. The lowest rates at the sale were a fraction under $11 a ton. While a large quantity of stove coal went off at $12. The average increase since the middle of July is about $4 50 a ton. The purchasers yesterday seemed to thing themselves fortunate in making the bargain they did. It will not be much consolation for those who are still without their Winter supply, to learn that the subscribers to some of the mutual companies organized for the protection of consumers, can, to-day, lay in a full stock for the season at about $6 a ton. Such is the actual fact. And it is clear that the public have not been fully aroused to the necessity of meeting trade combinations by counter combinations. This coal question brings the matter of cooperation into strong relief.

abstract: Commissioners ACTON, BERGEN and MCMURRAY, at Police Trials, yesterday, listened to eighty-eight complaints against officers of the Metropolitan Police force. Only one was for a capital offence, namely, drunkenness. A charge against Capt. CHARLES ULMAN, alleging that he and Sergt. AHEARN had conspired to rob an inebriated soldier, and a charge alleging that Capt. NATHANIEL R. MILLS had kicked a person whom he had ordered to go on, were overthrown by testimony. Mr. HAWKS, landlord of the St. Nicholas Hotel, was a witness in the case.
lead_paragraph: Commissioners ACTON, BERGEN and MCMURRAY, at Police Trials, yesterday, listened to eighty-eight complaints against officers of the Metropolitan Police force. abstract: We yesterday briefly alluded to a difference between the manager of the Fair and one of the exhibitors. Since, that time some new developments have been made. About 6 o'clock Tuesday evening the signs of Mr. HELMBOLD, the party in question, were forcibly taken down, and the printing of the paper called the Fairest of the Fair was stopped. We understand that this action on the part of the manager, for it seems that it was not the official action of the board as a body, was promptly resented by Mr. HELMBOLD, who commenced a civil action yesterday morning against the offending member, Mr. R.B. DAWSON, before Judge SMITH, at the Jefferson Market Court, laying his damages in the sum of $250. The case is set down for the 13th inst. Meantime, we are advised that the managers themselves are not agreed upon the propriety of the proceedings in the case, and still further trouble is not improbable.

abstract: ACADEMY OF Music.--There are rare occasions when the entire musical forces of the Academy seem to move of themselves, by an impulse alike irresistable and charming. This was certainly the case last evening when "Ernani"--fullest blooded of all VERDI'S operas--was played for the first time this season. We cannot remember to have heard the work better performed. The ensembles were admirable, and the singers without exception were in their best voice. Mlle. ZUCCHI, ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There are rare occasions when the entire musical forces of the Academy seem to move of themselves, by an impulse alike irresistable and charming. This was certainly the case last evening when "Ernani" -- fullest blooded of all VERDI'S operas -- was played for the first time this season. We cannot remember to have heard the work better performed. The ensembles were admirable, and the singers without exception were in their best voice. Mlle. ZUCCHI, who so far has been under the weather, shone forth last evening in pristine splendor. Her voice was grand and profuse, and her acting perfectly fine. The new tenor Signor IRFRE appeared to great advantage in the title-role. He has a voice and style which improve rapidly on acquaintance, but we cannot help suggesting that if the gentleman would drag the time less frequently, it would not detract from the meritorious vigor and earnestness of his singing. Signor ANTONUCCI, as Silva, revealed the quality and capacity of his voice finely in the Infelice, which has not been sung so well since the best days of MARINI. The part of Don Carlos was sustained on the occasion by Signor MARRA, who made his first appearance, and achieved a marked and merited success. He has a fine baritone, full and sympathetic in quality, and of ample power even for the discouraging dimensions of the Academy -- which, by the way, he did not seem to estimate accurately, and in consequence slightly over-exerted himself to his own prejudice. Signor MARRA's style is large and dramatic, and his ease on the stage and in the delivery of his voice indicate that he has had abundant experience. The debut was a complete success -- perhaps the most prompt and unequivocal of the season.

abstract: Morris Ketchum et. al. vs. E.B. Ketchum; Wm.B. Isham and Samuel M. Gallop vs. E.B. Ketchum et. al. and C.R. Isham et. al. vs. E.B. Ketchum et. al. -- These three actions were all commenced by attachments on the 15th day of August last, a day or two subsequent to the discovery of young Ketchum's defalcations. The one first above entitled was commenced earlier on the day named than were the other two. Yesterday a motion was made to set aside the attachments in the second and third suits, in order that execution might proceed against the property of E.B. Ketchum, and in favor of his former partners".

abstract: The splendid exhibit of the condition of our national finances which has just been given, has been made possible, we should not fail to remember, by the prompt and energetic action of the War and Navy Departments, in reducing the size of our public establishments, and curtailing expenses in every possible manner. Officers of all grades have been dismissed as rapidly as their services could be dispensed with; regiments have been disbanded as quickly as the orders could be made out; vessels have been put out of commission and sold as fast as the necessary labor could be accomplished; provost-marshals and courts have been abolished as speedily as affairs would allow; and all the vast machinery of war has been done away with, even before the people have fairly realized that the war itself is over. In all this, we have heard no accusations of favoritism to parties or individuals; and it seems almost incredible that throughout, there should have been developed such an extremely small amount of cheating, swindling or peculation.
lead_paragraph: The splendid exhibit of the condition of our national finances which has just been given, has been made possible, we should not fail to remember, by the prompt and energetic action of the War and Navy Departments, in reducing the size of our public establishments, and curtailing expenses in every possible manner. abstract: At a meeting of the board, last evening, President JAMES M. McLEAN in the chair, after routine business, a report was presented by the committee that had been instructed to institute inquiry concerning the attendance of non-resident children at our schools, and a resolution was offered closing the schools against the children of non-residents. Messrs.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the board, last evening, President JAMES M. MCLEAN in the chair, after routine business, a report was presented by the committee that had been instructed to institute inquiry concerning the attendance of non-resident children at our schools, and a resolution was offered closing the schools against the children of non-residents. Messrs. Neilson, Roosevelt, Hastie, Dupiguac, Farr, Miller, Vance and Hayes discussed the resolution at length, and informed the board that not only do the ferry-boats take hundreds of children across the rivers immediately after school hours, but the Harlem Railroad runs a train which is known as the school train. Mr. ROOSEVELT hoped that the board would not summarily expel those non-resident female pupils who are completing their course in the schools. Mr. MILLER thought that the board's action should be sweeping, inasmuch as these pupils, having graduated at the Grammar Schools, may claim admission to the Free Academy. The resolution was finally adopted by nineteen yeas, and no nays. The question of in the first and second grades of the Grammar Schools came up, and Mr. MILLER thought that the Eleventh and Thirteenth Wards were entitled to the additional teachers that would be required to teach these languages, the population of those wards being mainly of German descent. Messrs. HASTIE, NEILSON, ROOSEVELT and VANCE also advocated the resolution authorizing the teaching of French and German in the first and second grades in the Grammar Schools, and the resolution was adopted.

abstract: -- We do not hear anything now-a-days of any of the stupendous schemes that were in vogue a few months ago, for paying off, at one stroke, the national debt. But we hear of something much more promising. Without any of these schemes, the great work has been begun, as appears from the just-published Treasury statement, by reducing the debt twelve and three quarter millions within a month. If, says a Philadelphia paper, we can do as well in every month as in September, we shall reduce our debt one hundred and fifty millions a year, at which rate we could entirely rid ourselves of the national burden within a score of years. The regular revenues are rising in amount, and must continue to do so from causes now in active operation; and thus the surplus applicable to the extinguishment of the debt is augmenting and will augment.

abstract: Doubtless one of the principal causes of the prominence given to the Fenian movement in the British press is the dearth of political or party excitement in other quarters. The reaction from the brief turmoil of the general election was peculiarly visible in the flatness of the English journals for several weeks before the Fenians came to the rescue. The British press had usually a hard struggle with dullness during what the Saturday Review calls "the silly season" -- when Parliament is not in session, and when the most sensational features of the day's news are a four-column literary review in the Times, or an agricultural speech by a rural M.P. The election this year reduced the term of general stagnation by several weeks. But the conflict was so decisive in its results that it left nothing to speculate upon as to the future of the rival parties. Continental politics, moreover, are dull beyond all precedent. In the Summer of 1864, the Danish invasion furnished fresh matter of tragic interest every day for months. And overshadowing every other cotemporary event, there were the daily bulletins of the struggle in this country, sufficient alone, if intelligently discussed by the British and European press, to feed the utmost craving of the public appetite for news. All these extraneous sources of supply have now been drained out. The Gastein Convention, with its coolly barbarous disposition of the Principalities, does not supply the place in public interest of the butcheries at Duppel. And the progress of reconstruction in this country does not compensate for the loss of the war news budget sent hence by each Atlantic steamer. There is absolute dearth in every civilized quarter of the world where gleanings of news were formerly available for the British journalist. The Fenians, at such a juncture, have proved a god-send. Narrowly looked into, their movements and the movements against them present as much of broad farce as of genuine sensation. But no generous looker-on will begrudge the British newsman the privilege of making the most of his subject, now that it has so luckily turned up.

abstract: Queens County, N. Y., Agricultural Fair
snippet: Queens County, N. Y., Agricultural Fair
lead_paragraph: The twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society opened yesterday morning at the Fashion Course, Flushing, about one-fourth of a mile north of the West Flushing depot. Notwithstanding the threatening weather of the morning the number of articles and animals on exhibition was quite fair. All lack in numbers, however, was more than compensated for by the quality of those present, many of which were confessed superior to those of any previous exhibition of the kind ever held in this famous county. The Fashion grounds occupy sixty-three acres, are inclosed by a brick wall ten feet high and contain a commodious building of 600 feet in length, for show stands, restaraunts, &c. There is probably no show ground in the State superior to this. Mr. JOHN C. JACKSON, President, and Mr. JOHN HAROLD, Secretary, succeeded admirably in making the arrangements agreeable to both spectators and exhibitors. Nothing, so far as diligence on the part of the managers and enthusiasm of the citizens of the county and adjacent section is concerned, is wanting, and to-day, the weather being favorable, the exhibition will doubtless prove one of the best of the kind ever witnessed on the island.

abstract: THE FEAST OF TABERNACLES. -- The Jewish "Feast of Tabernacles" commenced at sunset last evening, and will continue for seven days. It is an occasion of great joy. Boughs are suspended in the synagogues and private houses, to signify that the children of Israel are dwellng in booths. The observance commenced on the return of the Jews from the Babylonish captivity; and the book of Nehemiah expressly declares that "since the days of Joshua, the son of Nun, had not the children of Israel done so." The first and eighth day being the Sabbath, on the occasion of a "solemn assembly," the residue of the time is devoted to mirth and hilarity.

abstract: Among the passengers by the steamship Persia, which arrived on Tuesday night, were Mr. PERRY, our Consul to Tunis, and an embassy from the Bey of Tunis, MOHAMMED SADYK, who are sent here for the purpose of condoling with our government on the death of Mr. LINCOLN, and felicitating it on the return of peace. The members of the embassy are Gen. OTMAN HASHEM, Special Envoy from the Bey of Tunis; Col. RAMIRO GAITA, his Aid-de-Camp; the Chevalier ANTOINE CONTI. Secretary and Interpreter.
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers by the steamship Persia, which arrived on Tuesday night, were Mr. PERRY, our Consul to Tunis, and an embassy from the Bey of Tunis, MOHAMMED SADYK, who are sent here for the purpose of condoling with our government on the death of Mr. LINCOLN, and felicitating it on the return of peace. abstract: David Tilton vs. James Murphy and Hugh Smith. -- The defendants, on the 3d day of January, 1863, were the owners of a certain line of stages, well known as the Wall-street Line. Early in the evening of that day, Mr. David Tilton was driving up Wall-street in his wagon, and, as the testimony showed, he was on the right hand side of the street, when, just as he crossed Broad-street, he was met by one of the defendants' stages, on the same side and going at a rapid rate. When the vehicles were quite near each other, the driver of the stage suddenly undertook to cross over, and, in doing so, the stage swung around, struck the plaintiff's wagon, upset it and throw plaintiff out. The result was that his shoulder was dislocated, and, as he claims, he was otherwise seriously injured in such a manner as to incapacitate him from attending to his usual avocations for a long time after. He now comes into court and claims damages against Messrs. Murphy & Smith for $5,000 for injuries he received in consequence of the gross and wanton recklessness of their driver. The facts as above stated, appeared from the testimony of the plaintiff and his witnesses. Plaintiff's counsel insisted that inasmuch as plaintiff was all the time on the right hand side of the street, it was clear that the accident occurred through no fault of his. The defendants' stage was on the wrong side, and when the driver saw that he was in danger of coming in collision, he undertook to get out of the plaintiff's way, in doing so he struck the wagon, and hence the damage to his client was caused. It was all the fault of the defendant's driver, he contended, and the plaintiff had come into court with clean hands. The driver was on the side of the street where by the laws of the State of New-York he had no business. It was every driver's duty to keep on the right hand side of the street or road.
lead_paragraph: David Tilton vs. James Murphy and Hugh Smith. -- The defendants, on the 3d day of January, 1863, were the owners of a certain line of stages, well known as the Wall-street Line. Early in the evening of that day, Mr. David Tilton was driving up Wall-street in his wagon, and, as the testimony showed, he was on the right hand side of the street, when, just as he crossed Broad-street, he was met by one of the defendants' stages, on the same side and going at a rapid rate. When the vehicles were quite near each other, the driver of the stage suddenly undertook to cross over, and, in doing so, the stage swung around, struck the plaintiff's wagon, upset it and throw plaintiff out. The result was that his shoulder was dislocated, and, as he claims, he was otherwise seriously injured in such a manner as to incapacitate him from attending to his usual avocations for a long time after. He now comes into court and claims damages against Messrs. Murphy & Smith for $5,000 for injuries he received in consequence of the gross and wanton recklessness of their driver. The facts as above stated, appeared from the testimony of the plaintiff and his witnesses. Plaintiff's counsel insisted that inasmuch as plaintiff was all the time on the right hand side of the street, it was clear that the accident occurred through no fault of his. The defendants' stage was on the wrong side, and when the driver saw that he was in danger of coming in collision, he undertook to get out of the plaintiff's way, in doing so he struck the wagon, and hence the damage to his client was caused. It was all the fault of the defendant's driver, he contended, and the plaintiff had come into court with clean hands. The driver was on the side of the street where by the laws of the State of New-York he had no business. It was every driver's duty to keep on the right hand side of the street or road.

abstract: Poor Whites, Education for; Education Needed for Poor Whites of the South
snippet: Poor Whites, Education for; Education Needed for Poor Whites of the South
lead_paragraph: There is no subject more worthy of the attention of the people of the North and of the South at the present time than a consideration of the best means for instructing and elevating the poor whites of the Southern States. In view of the changed condition which the freedmen hold to their late masters, it is a subject which will receive more attention from the educated classes of the South than it ever has heretofore. From all the statistics gathered previous to the rebellion, and during its existence, it is evident that there has never been, in any other portion of the country, a class of people more utterly destitute of all the means for obtaining a knowledge of the most simple and common rudiments of education.

abstract: Nom'd Dem. Gov. of La.; Investigation by Gov. Fenton, second day
snippet: Nom'd Dem. Gov. of La.; Investigation by Gov. Fenton, second day
lead_paragraph: The second session of the Gubernatorial Convention was held yesterday, at 10:30 o'clock A.M. Gov. FENTON was accompanied by Gen. HARVEY and Gen. SWAIN, of his staff, while the several counsel, including H.H. ANDERSON, Esq., who is associated with Judge ALLEN for Mr. DEVELIN, sat as before at the Aldermanic desks. The audience, which was very large, was in a happy mood; the defendants were radiant and their counsel jolly, while candor compels the record that the counsel of Messrs. KINGSLEY, MCCAFFERTY & CO. were solemn as the tomb and glum as misers.

abstract: -- The future happiness of the Southern negroes depends so largely upon their being able to maintain amicable and profitable relations with those who formerly stood in the relationship of masters to them, and who yet are, and for a long time will remain, the principal holders of real estate and owners of capital, that we have frequently taken occasion to deprecate every scheme which had a tendency to stir up animosities of race or collisions of interest. The Southern whites will inevitably control the labor and the fortunes of the blacks for many years to come, and in all the daily affairs of life, will exercise an immediate and controlling power. The blacks will constitute a great population of subordinate laborers, making continual advances in well-being and intelligence, or else will retrogade into a condition worse in many respects than the bondage from which they have been emancipated. Which of these fortunes is in store for the Southern negro, depends more upon the whites of the South than upon anything that can be said or done in the North.

abstract: Hughes's Atmospheric or Lightning Ore Stamp
snippet: Hughes's Atmospheric or Lightning Ore Stamp
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, a party of gentlemen interested in mining operations and the reduction of ores, assembled at CONDICT & CO.'s foundry, in Jersey City, to witness the operation of HUGHES' atmospheric or lightning ore stamp. The machine exhibited was of full working size, with two stamps of about twenty-five pounds weight each, attached to a piston moved up by a double cam, forcing them and the piston at the upper end into an atmospheric or air cylinder, the ascent of which produces a vacuum underneath the piston-head, which forces the stamp down with great velocity and power. By this means, 500 blows of 4,000 pounds each per minute are given, and with a steady and uniform motion, without the aid of a balance-wheel. The mortar is inclosed and detached from the main running gear, the stamps moving up and down in it through a groove. It is claimed that by the application of the atmospheric principle, a stamp of twenty-five pounds weight will give a more effective blow (by the velocity gained) than can be given by the ordinary stamp of six hundred pounds weight. The total weight of the Hughes stamp machine is but about 1,000 pounds, which is less than any other machine known; at the same time it does the work of an ordinary fine stamp mill with less than half the ordinary expenditure of power. A quantity of gold quartz was placed in the machine, and in a very short time it was turned out as an almost impalpable powder. It is claimed by the inventors that any known ore, including the stubborn ones of Colorado, can be reduced in the same manner. By the use of a fan blower, a current of air carries the particles as soon as reduced to a powder into a room or box, where they settle and are taken out without a particle of waste.

abstract: Special Officer ROGERS, of the St. Nicholas Hotel, arrested JOHN DUNN, a youngster of polished address, who was detected, late on Wednesday night, attempting to enter Mr. JOHN J. FRENCH's room, (No. 280,) with nippers and false keys. At the suggestion of District-Attorney HALL, who was in court yesterday morning. Justice DODGE committed the prisoner, under the 18th section of Chapter 508, Laws of 1860, as follows: "If any person shall be found by night in any dwelling-house or other building whatsoever, with intent to commit any larceny or felony therein, under such circumstances as shall not amount to an attempt to commit felony, every such offender shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor."

abstract: Hackmen at Depots and Piers; Justice Barnard's Opinion Sustaining
snippet: Hackmen at Depots and Piers; Justice Barnard's Opinion Sustaining
lead_paragraph: On the 26th and 27th of September, ult., Capt. Petty of the Fifth Precinct Police, and men under him arrested quite a number of hackmen, for alleged violation of the law. Soon after the arrests were made, a writ of habeas corpus was applied for and granted by Justice BARNARD, of the Supreme Court. When the writ was made returnable, Capt. Petty appeared in court and stated that the hackmen who had been arrested had violated the law, and that the proprietors of the Albany boats and others had applied to him to have the hackdrivers arrested if they persisted in leaving their coaches, crowding the piers and going on board of boats just arrived, for the purpose of soliciting patronage. Capt. Petty at the same time stated that these men had been repeatedly warned of the consequences of a violation of the law, and that their rights and liabilities had been especially impressed upon them. David Hogan and two other coachmen, applied, through Mr. Richard Beamish, their counsel, for a discharge on the ground that they had been guilty of a violation of no State law, and of no ordinance of the city. The matter was fully argued by counsel and the court took time to consider.
headline: {'main': 'An Important Opinion The Hackdrivers Arrested by the Police, Discharged by the Supreme Court.; SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS OCT. 5. abstract: This organization (German) made their tenth annual excursion yesterday, and Conrad's Elm Park was chosen for their pleasure-ground. The line of procession was taken up at 9 o'clock A.M., from the Mercer House, and after a march through the principal thoroughfares the "Guard" arrived at the Park about 1 o'clock. Immediately afterward the shooting for prizes commenced, and this occupied about three hours. At the conclusion of the shooting a dinner was served up by Mr. CONRAD, Jr., in his best style. The "Guard" numbered just eighty men, under command of Capt. BROD, but with the ladies and gentlemen guests the company fell little short of three hundred. Thirty-two prizes were awarded, Mr. HILBRAND receiving the first. After the distribution of the awards the large hall of the hotel was cleared, and the light-hearted company prepared for dancing, which was kept up to a late hour, when the party adjourned, well satisfied with the day's enjoyment.

abstract: Detective-Officer PHILIP FARLEY and Officers ANDERSON and BEDELL, of the Thirteenth Ward, arrested WILLIAM H. BLAKE and ISAAC BERNSTEIN, of No. 247 Eighth-avenue, and they were committed to answer a charge of receiving three cases, containing 150 pieces of muslin, of the value of $2,000, the property of Messrs. CHARLES H. WELLING & CO., of No. 35 Murray-street. On the 12th ult., OSCAR B. CORNWELL, one of Messrs. WELLING & CO.'s cartmen, took the muslins on his cart, and started for the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company's pier, at Battery-place; but, before he had reached his destination, WILLIAM H. BLAKE, it is alleged, leaped upon the cart, and proposed that the cartmen should steal the goods, and he would dispose of them and divide the proceeds. CORNWELL consented, and, on reaching Pier No. 1, BLAKE took Messrs. WELLING & CO.'s receipt-book into the freight-office, and there forged the signature of the receiving-clerk. The two then drove to No. 247 Eighth-avenue, and there delivered the muslins to BERNSTEIN; and CORNWELL, returning to Messrs. WELLING & CO.'s, left the receipt-book on the shipping-clerk's desk. On the 17th the firm to whom the goods had been consigned telegraphed, inquiring why their purchase had not been forwarded, and then the robbery was disclosed. CORNWELL, who confessed, was committed to the House of Detention as a witness, and BLAKE and BERNSTEIN were sent to the Tombs.

abstract: -- By reference to the list which we publish elsewhere, it will be seen that the Singer Sewing-Machines (both family and manufacturing) carry off the first premiums from the State Fair, which closes to-day. It is worthy of remark that these machines are rarely seen at fairs, and the Singer Company have not entered into the general scramble for premiums which has characterized the past few years. The agent in this city saw fit, however, to come out on this occasion in force; and, notwithstanding the competition was sharp -- the Wheeler & Wilson, Grover & Baker, &c., &c., joining in the contest -- it was plain to be seen, when the practical tests were applied, that the "plumes" must be handed over to the Singer machines. -- Ulica Daily Observer, Sept. 15.

abstract: The United States vs. Antonio Rasa, Daniel Rasa and Calegici Prejcia, alias Frank White. -- These men who were charged with counterfeiting money in large quantities, had on Monday last their final examination. The case was given to the jury about 8 o'clock in the evening of Monday, and after a short absence they returned with a verdict of guilty against white and the elder Rasa, but acquitted the younger one.

abstract: -- The Chamber of Commerce yesterday passed resolutions declaring the expediency of having a new post-office erected in New-York. No doubt what these resolutions affirm respecting the inadequacy of the present building to meet the business requirements of the city is correct, but we doubt whether the site -- which the chamber in their resolutions so greatly extol -- is much more accommodating than the building now in use. The approaches to a post-office -- erected, no matter after what design or at what cost on the present site -- must always be inconvenient and not unfrequently hazardous, from the narrowness and overcrowded condition of the contiguous streets. The location may be good enough for the accommodation of a large business class. But for the general public more open and accessible ground is needed.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest, financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages deaths of the week.

abstract: Tilton vs. Murphy and Smith. Stage Collision
snippet: Tilton vs. Murphy and Smith. Stage Collision
lead_paragraph: David Tilton vs. James Murphy and Hugh Smith. -- Mr. David Tilton, while riding in his wagon on Wall-street, was run into by one of the defendants' stages and upset. By the accident he had his shoulder dislocated, and claimed $5,000 damages. It was shown that the driver was not on the right side of the street, and the jury, after a short deliberation, rendered a verdict for the plaintiff of $250.

abstract: SEWELL WORTLEY, of Lynchburgh, Superintendent of the Quartermaster's office, under Capt. ALBERGER, and JOHN ODELL, one of BAKER'S detectives, severally testified as to their looking down through a hole on the movements of Gen. BRISCOE in the room below, where the money was deposited. The latter subsequently searched Gen. BRISCOE, and found the missing treasure in his private office. The money and bullion, and the money bags and packages, were identified by this witness.
lead_paragraph: SEWELL WORTLEY, of Lynchburgh, Superintendent of the Quartermaster's office, under Capt. ALBERGER, and JOHN ODELL, one of BAKER'S detectives, severally testified as to their looking down through a hole on the movements of Gen. BRISCOE in the room below, where the money was deposited. The latter subsequently searched Gen. BRISCOE, and found the missing treasure in his private office. The money and bullion, and the money bags and packages, were identified by this witness. ODELL, during his cross-examination, said that at his second interview with Capt. ALBERGER, at Gordonsville, he said Gen. BRISCOE had spoken to him on the matter, and proposed to get him out of the difficulty by throwing suspicion on a former rebel officer who was the owner of the safes. In conversation Capt. ALBERGER said they appeared to be down on him. After Gen. BRISCOE's arrest he said to the witness: "I thought I was a better detective than you. I wanted to get the principal." The witness replied: "I don't see how you can catch the principal after having committed the burglary yourself."

abstract: Public Schools, Overcrowd ng by Non-Residents
snippet: Public Schools, Overcrowd ng by Non-Residents
lead_paragraph: -- TheBoard of Education have felt themselves justified in taking action against the crowding of the city public schools by the children of non-residents. It seems that pupils are sent to these schools from all the outlying suburban districts -- including Jersey City, Hoboken, Brooklyn, Williamsburgh, Morrisania and elsewhere -- and that in some cases special trains are run for their convenience. A vote of exclusion has been unanimously passed by the board; and we dare say their action may have been well considered, although it is altogether anomalous that a condition of things should exist requiring the public schools to be shut in the faces of any decently behaved children -- no matter where they come from. It is a question, moreover, whether a city tradesmandoing all his business within the city limits, paying his full share of the local taxes, and doing his entire duty generally as a citizen, can equitably be denied the right of sending his child to one of the city schools, merely because the overcrowding of houses on the island has driven him for the time into a suburban residence. We say there is a question of equity involved in this matter, which we trust the exigencies of their position have not compelled the board to overlook. It ought certainly to be regarded as a tribute to the excellence of our city schools that they are sought after by non-residents. And we doubt if the action of the board will not be keenly criticized by those immediately interested.

abstract: The members of the Tunissian embassy left the Astor House yesterday afternoon for a drive through the Central Park. Athough the atmosphere was rather cool they appeared to enjoy the ride through the park and the principal thoroughfares of the city. They were taken to the chief points of interest in the park, with the beauty of which they were evidently fully impressed. On their return they visited a photographic establishment in Broadway, and reached their quarters at the Astor House at quite a late hour. They will leave for Washington to-day or to-morrow.

abstract: Queens County Agricultural Fair; Flushing, L. I.
snippet: Queens County Agricultural Fair; Flushing, L. I.
lead_paragraph: The twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society, which opened Wednesday morning, at the Fashion Course, Flushing, and continued yesterday, has proved quite a success. The unpropitious state of the weather undoubtedly kept many from attending, and detracted somewhat from the general interest of the occasion. Yet the attendance on Wednesday was not less than 8,000 people, and Thursday 12,000 probably visited the fair grounds.

abstract: N. Y.; Mrs. Virtue by Hack driver in Central Park
snippet: N. Y.; Mrs. Virtue by Hack driver in Central Park
lead_paragraph: JOHN FOLEY, a hackman, was arraigned before Justice KELLY, at the Fourth District Police Court, on Wednesday, on a charge of assaulting and robbing Mrs. CAROLINE VIRTU in Central Park, on Tuesday evening. The complainant, who resides at the corner of Clove and Atlantic avenues, Brooklyn, alleges that herself and a lady acquaintance employed FOLEY to drive them through Central Park. She also states that FOLEY gave her some drugged liquor, and that while partially insensible he attempted an indignity. Mrs. VIRTU screamed for help, and a Parkman arrested the accused. The complainant and accused were taken to the Nineteenth Precinct Station-house. Mrs. VIRTU was still suffering from the effects of the liquor she had drunk. On becoming composed, she informed Capt. HARTT that she had been robbed of two diamond rings and a gold watch and chain, valued in all at $575. None of the property was found on the prisoner. Mrs. VIRTU declined to make a charged against FOLEY. He was accordingly discharged, and then persistently demanded that he should be paid for driving the ladies through the park. In this, however, he was unsuccessful, and finally drove off. Although he had no proof against the hackman, Capt. HARTT believed he had stolen the property. He accordingly directed Officer VAN ARSDALE to follow him. The latter did so, and as FOLEY entered his stable at the corner of Fortieth-street and Second-avenue, he was arrested. The officer demanded the restoration of the property stolen from Mrs. VIRTU. FOLEY was startled at the demand, and immediately produced the watch, chain, and rings, which were identified by the owner. Justice KELLY committed the accused for trial without bail.
headline: {'main': 'Yorkville Before Justice Kelly.; OUTRAGEOUS ROBBERY IN THE CENTRAL PARK.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Yorkville Before Justice Kelly.; OUTRAGEOUS ROBBERY IN THE CENTRAL PARK.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Jeremiah J. Hamilton vs. Wentworth S. Butler. -- This action has been up in the Superior Court of this city several times before, and has twice been fully reported in the NEW-YORK TIMES. On the 17th of May last, in the same court where it now is, it was abandoned, after being partially tried, for the reason that one of the jurors on duty had been heard to say that he knew one of the parties to the suit, and he would not believe that party under any circumstances, or words to that effect. The Judge then sitting sent the cause over to this term, with a severe reprimand to the juror.

abstract: The Congressional Oath in; Mr. A. H. H. Stuart; and the Congressional Oath
snippet: The Congressional Oath in; Mr. A. H. H. Stuart; and the Congressional Oath
lead_paragraph: We are glad to note that in the Congressional canvass of Virginia there is a general disposition to leave the field exclusively to candidates who can take the stringent Congressional oath that they have never participated in the rebellion. Out of the eight Congressional districts, five have candidates running who can all meet the Congressional requirement. But in the Accomac district, the Lynchburgh district, and the Charlotteville district, there are candidates who avow that they will not and cannot take the oath, and yet claim that if elected, Congress cannot and will not refuse to admit them. In this last district, A.H.H. STUART, Secretary of Interior under Mr. FILLMORE, being a candidate, declares his inability to take the oath, yet defies Congress to keep him out, if elected. He asserts that the oath is unconstitutional, and that the Republican party will never dare to make practical applition of it.
headline: {'main': 'The Congressional Oath in Virginia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Congressional Oath in Virginia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Value and Economy of the
snippet: Value and Economy of the
lead_paragraph: -- It is gratifying to have a contradiction of the late telegraphic statement that the "Veteran Reserve Corps" was being mustered out of service. The men in this corps are such as have been partially disabled in service, but who still retain sufficient health and limbs to perform garrison duty and numerous other military labors which will yet for a long time be needed. We have seen one superb regiment of this body in which the Colonel had lost his left arm, the Lieutenant-Colonel a leg, in which six of the Captains commanding companies had lost each his right arm, and every other officer of the regiment was disabled for life. All of these men had been in active business and excellent position before the war, and all felt the small pensions to which they are entitled after they leave the army as inadequate to their support. All of them made admirable officers of the corps, equally capable for all their duties with men physically complete, as was evidenced by the condition and capacity of their regiment.

abstract: In the Supreme Court, yesterday, an important opinion was delivered by Justice BARNARD, in the case of the New-York hackmen who were arrested about ten days ago for an alleged violation of the corporation ordinances, in leaving their coaches, crowding on the piers and boats, and forcing themselves into railroad cars just arrived, for the purpose of importuning passengers.
lead_paragraph: In the Supreme Court, yesterday, an important opinion was delivered by Justice BARNARD, in the case of the New-York hackmen who were arrested about ten days ago for an alleged violation of the corporation ordinances, in leaving their coaches, crowding on the piers and boats, and forcing themselves into railroad cars just arrived, for the purpose of importuning passengers. The Court held, among other things, "that there is no law or authority to arrest any one for peaceably soliciting the patronage of a traveler, and that any citizen, duly licensed, has a right to go with his carriage to a depot or steamboat landing, and quietly ask a passenger standing on the dock if he wishes a carriage. The police had no right to arrest the petitioners, nor have they a right to arrest others for doing the same thing, unless they are disorderly."
