abstract: Carme vs. Kavanagh; First of Three Games
snippet: Carme vs. Kavanagh; First of Three Games
lead_paragraph: Over twelve hundred persons assembled at GALLAHER's room, in Twenty-fourth-street, last evening, to witness the first match, of a series of three, between Messrs. PIERRE CARME and the heretofore invincible DUDLEY KAVANAGH. It will be remembered that soon after his arrival in this city, M. CARME gave exhibitions at the Cooper Institute, and on his first appearance he challenged any player in America to play him one match each, in the French carom game -- the four-ball American game -- pushed barred -- and the full American game, as played for the championship. These challenges, with some modifications, were accepted by KAVANAGH, and since they were definitely determined on have created a great excitement in billiard circles throughout the United States. Indeed, among the spectators last evening were many prominent billiard men from all sections of the country, including John Deery, champion of America; Melvin Foster and Michael Geery, of Washington; R.T. Ryall, James Palmer and Chris. Bird, of Philadelphia; Wm. Goldthwait, of New-Hampshire; John McDevitt, of Illinois; and all the prominent players of this city.

abstract: At the New-York Hospital, yesterday, Coroner WILDEY took the ante-mortem deposition of WILLIAM PIGOT, Jr., of No. 62 Mulberry-street, a youth of 11 years, who was mortally stabbed on Saturday evening last, while interfering in a fight between his father and one JOHN SHERRY, one of Mr. PIGOT's neighbors. According to the testimony, SHERRY, who had been drinking all day, entered Mr. PIGOT'S apartments and attacked him without provocation, and Mr. PIGOT's boy, stepping between SHERRY and his father, received a mortal stab in the back. SHERBY was arrested at the time and committed to the Tombs.

abstract: Lazarus Murder, Sentence of Clark and Macdonald, Accessories
snippet: Lazarus Murder, Sentence of Clark and Macdonald, Accessories
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday Judge RUSSELL sentenced James C. Clark and James Macdonald who were implicated in the Lazarus murder. His Honor said that the testimony introduced on the trial of Clark showed clearly that the prisoner voluntarily assisted the murderer Friary in an attempt to escape. He said the characters of both these men were bad. Macdonald was a notorious rowdy, and a charge of highway robbery was pending over Clark. Under these circumstances they might deem the sentence of the court a light one. Macdonald was then sent to the State Prison for two years and Clark for two years and three months.

abstract: Blondins at Albany
snippet: Blondins at Albany
lead_paragraph: So far as we can learn, the trick of the political prestidigitators at Albany is not likely to be crowned with very brilliant success. At first, to be sure, it excited astonishment and elicited applause; but even these are rapidly subsiding. It is always amusing to see a dozen chickens taken out of an empty hat, or ten kinds of wine poured from a single bottle; but prudent people don't readily rely on such hats and bottles for their daily supplies. That sort of thing is all very well in its way, but it don't "wash." Tricksters and clowns may be very clever and very amusing, but they are not the kind of material out of which statesmen are made and on which we rely for the conduct of public affairs.

abstract: Ketchum M. vs. E. B. Ketchum; to set aside attachment
snippet: Ketchum M. vs. E. B. Ketchum; to set aside attachment
lead_paragraph: Morris Ketchum et al. vs. E.B. Ketchum, Wm. B. Isham and Samuel M. Gallop vs. E.B. Ketchum et al., and C.R. Isham et al. vs. C.B. Ketchum et al. -- A motion was made to set aside the attachments in the second and third suits, in order that execution might proceed against the property of C.B. Ketchum in favor of his former partners. The motion was opposed by Mr. Francis N. Bangs, who urged that a partner or partners could not attach the property of an absconding copartner on an unliquidated account, and it was shown that at the time the attachment was granted the remaining partners were ignorant of the amount abstracted by Edward B. Ketchum, and the attachment could not be for an indefinite and unsettled account. The court reserved its decision.

abstract: Le ter to Eighteenth Ward Union Ratification Meeting
snippet: Le ter to Eighteenth Ward Union Ratification Meeting
lead_paragraph: The large hall of the Domilt Dispensary was filled, last evening, by an intelligent audience of Union men and women from the Fourteenth Assembly District, who had gathered to ratify the Union State ticket. Col. H. BEENY called the meeting to order, and Mr. ORLANDO L. STEWART was made Chairman. The Ex-Assistant District-Attorney said, [???], that, as it is important at this time that loyal men should have control of the Government of New-York, this meeting had been called as the initial of a series of ward meetings of citizens who desire that only loyal men should be chosen to office. Mr. JOSEPH B. VAERNUM, the first speaker, called the attention of the audience to the phenomenon of all the newspapers and politicians who were traitors during the war being the foremost supporters of the ticket which is called Democratic. Hon. FREDERICK A. CONKLING indorsed President JOHNSON's policy, but demanded that every black man who had fought in the Union army should be permitted to vote. Rev. WILLIAM H. BOOLE read the published appeal of the Mozart Democracy -- the men, he said, who during the war received the gold which was the price of the country's blood. That document cried "Peace, peace," but there is no peace. The conflict for human freedom is not ended -- it is merely transferred from the field to the forum. The nomination, by the Syracuse Convention of Gen. SLOCUM, reminded him of the church which sought to hide its sins by employing a very good minister.

abstract: Ryers vs. Rangen. Slander
snippet: Ryers vs. Rangen. Slander
lead_paragraph: Lewis R. Ryers vs. Wm. B. Ranken. -- The plaintiff in this case, an Alderman, claims $5,000 to $7,000 damages for certain slanderous words used by the defendant, such as "he is a dirty little thief;" 'he is a robber;" "he is a thief, and I can prove it." The defendant pleaded justification. A motion was made to strike out all that portion of the answer which relates to justification, on the ground that by the well-settled law of this State relating to actions for slander, the defendant cannot put in a general denial, and justify in the same pleading.

abstract: and Philadelphia Canards on Mexico
snippet: and Philadelphia Canards on Mexico
lead_paragraph: --For several weeks we have enjoyed the most delightful freedom from canards. The canardist of the Rio Grande has been silent; the canardist of Cairo dumb; the canardist of Philadelphia has been in a state of coma; the canardist of Newbern has been slaughtered. The news of the day, though not very exciting, has always been reliable, and we have been relieved from the duty of contradicting on one morning what had been printed the morning before. Only the good men of Wall-street have been able now and then to startle each other by some financial item of vast importance and perfect baselessness; but, as these items have seldom got into more than one of the papers, they did not perturb the sweet serenity of the general public in contemplating the question of Reconstruction.

abstract: GRAND RATIFICATION MEETING AT BERGEN -- ADDRESSES BY GEN. SWIFT, A.W. TENNY, ESQ., AND OTHERS. -- A large and enthusiastic meeting was held, on Thursday evening, in the New Wigwam, in Palisade-avenue. The meeting was called to order by the President, who made a few pertinent remarks as to the opening of the new hall, &c., after which the Union Glee Club, of New-York, entertained the audience with one of their much-admired songs, "Poor Old Jeff." Gen. SWIFT was the first speaker introduced to the audience. He advocated in strong terms the constitutional amendment, and earnestly advised the masses to vote the Union ticket, which was in his opinion the only successful and true one. He was followed by DE WITT C. MORRIS, Major PANGBORN and Hon. MATHEW ARMSTRONG, of Jersey City, and A.W. TENNY, Esq., of New-York. Mr. TENNY was the last speaker, but his address was the most interesting, forcible and entertaining of all that were delivered, and it was well worthy of being heard by a large audience and in a more suitable place, for the building in which he spoke is not yet half completed, and the disadvantages of a speaker are very many.

abstract: A great mass meeting of negroes and freedmen was held at Edgefield, Tenn., on the 5th, six thousand persons being present. An address was made by Brig.-Gen. FISK. He rejoiced that the negroes of Tennessee were free as God intended them to be. He told them that they must prove themselves entitled to freedom by industry, sobriety and integrity. His duty was to see that they discharge their duties.
lead_paragraph: A great mass meeting of negroes and freedmen was held at Edgefield, Tenn., on the 5th, six thousand persons being present. An address was made by Brig.-Gen. FISK. He rejoiced that the negroes of Tennessee were free as God intended them to be. He told them that they must prove themselves entitled to freedom by industry, sobriety and integrity. His duty was to see that they discharge their duties. He would put the black man in the jury-box and on the witness-stand. His remarks were received with great enthusiasm. He was followed by several other speakers, after which the meeting adjourned. Gen. FISK states that during the past week 600 or 700 negroes have been sent to their former homes in different parts of the State, and have contracted with their former owners to work for wages. Within a month there will be a general clearing out of negroes here, arrangements having been effected to procure them labor in different parts of the South.

abstract: ARREST OF CONFIDENCE OPERATOR. -- A fancy dressed individual, giving the name of WM. EDSALL, arrested by Officer HARNEY, was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday, on suspicion of having stolen a valuable single harness, which he had in a black traveling bag. On Wednesday, EDSALL went to a livery stable in New-York, and after telling some huge stories, employed a hack at $1 50 an hour, and after running up a bill of $15, gave the driver the slip, but was traced to the Jersey City d[???]p[???], where he was apparently waiting for the departure the Philadelphia train. The officer, being [???] of the fellow's operations, and suspecting [???] to  be a rogue, took him into custody. Yesterday EDSALL was identified as the man who attempted to pass a forged check of $120, drawn on the Sixth National Bank of New-York, at the Commercial Saloon, corner of Greene Montgomery streets. The accused was held for examination.

abstract: Fever Nests in--East Sevente nth-street Case
snippet: Fever Nests in--East Sevente nth-street Case
lead_paragraph: We chronicled, a few days since, in our city column, an interesting experiment in a sanitary way, by our police, which shows what can be done even under the law which we have, and what remains to be done. A very efficient officer of the "Sanitary Squad." Capt. LORD, had his attention called to a tenement-house in East Seventeenth-street, which was in a shocking sanitary condition. Filth and dirt prevailed here; the wretched tenants were crammed and crowded into the small rooms; heaps of garbage festered about the building; the halls were dirty and unwhite-washed, and the house, like hundreds of others, became a den of nastiness. Soon among its occupants typhoid took perennial possession, and the building became what is so expressively known as a "fever-nest." Here pestilence was sheltered and carefully nurtured until, well-fledged and strong, it should be able to take to itself wings and fly to hundreds of fresh quarters far away.

abstract: Cur Tunisian friends are having a good time, and if their bump of humor is at all conspicuously developed they are likewise having a jolly time. In addition to the thousand and one courtesies extended them by our merchants and others, they yesterday received and accepted an invitation to visit the American Institute Fair in Fourteenth-street. The managers of the Institute, with a reckless disregard of fact and a somewhat daring attempt at romance, announced, by means of sundry placards, that the Boy of Tunis and his suite would be at the Fair in the evening, and, having prepared the brass band, started a committee, consisting of Gen. HALL and Mr. THOMAS MCELPATH, to escort the gentlemen and their friend, Mr. Consul PERRY, to the exhibition.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's "Ballo" attracted the usual overflowing audience last evening, but failed to draw the general amount of applause. The latter circumstance is explained by the fact that nearly all the male singers were more or less under the weather. Signor MAZZOLENI had to thread his way gingerly in the upper regions, and in the barcarolle, strange to say, did not obtain the encore to which he has been so long accustomed. He was discreet enough, however, to save a galop for the end, and so came out bravely. Signor BELLINI was so unwell that it was with difficulty he commenced the evening. Rather, however, than have a change in the bill, be persevered, and considering the very apparent bronchial difficulty under which he was laboring, did extremely well.

abstract: N. Y.,wines
snippet: N. Y.,wines
lead_paragraph: About twenty miles up the Hudson, a region opens out which has long been a favorite of the lovers of the picturesque and the beautiful. On the west bank the somewhat stern line of the Palisades breaks abruptly off, and a lovely valley leads away to the hills on the Hackensack. On the cast, a series of wooded ridges with deep ravines and streams flowing between, rolls on toward the Sound. To the north, the stately river spreads out into the broad, peaceful Tappan Sea, with a bold, dark bluff, "Point No-point," projecting into it, and a softly-fading purple perspective stretching away to the hills of the Highlands.

abstract: Negro Suffrage, and its Admission as a State
snippet: Negro Suffrage, and its Admission as a State
lead_paragraph: Colorado, as well as Connecticut, has just given its decision against negro suffrage. This circumstance has led a cotemporary, possessed of very extreme views on the question of negro voting, to take ground against the admission of Colorado into the Union, for which application will be made at the forthcoming session of Congress. "The admission of Colorado," we are told, "now becomes analagous to that of any of the rebel States; and, however desirable it may be for her prosperity, or for the balance of loyal power in the United States Senate, that she should be received into the Union, it is of infinitely greater consequence for the nation to determine its political creed and rule of action." "The issue has been made; we hope it will not be dodged by Congress, and that the Territory will remain as it is (a Territory) until it is ready to execute justice among all its citizens."

abstract: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning, JOHN H. EDDINGTON, Jr., Elizabeth-street, who had been abroad with his wife and her sister, and was on his way home, was assaulted by one JOHN KELLY and stabbed in the side, back, and shoulder. Hearing the women's shricks, Patrolmen MULLALLY, of the Fourteenth Precinct, and BIRMINGHAM, of the Tenth, hastened to the spot and arrested KELLY. Mr. EDDINGTON was taken to the New-York Hospital, but as the wounds appeared to be slight, he was permitted to depart yesterday forenoon. KELLY was sent to the Tombs and held until afternoon, when, there being no complainant against him, he was released from restraint.
lead_paragraph: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning, JOHN H. EDDINGTON, Jr., Elizabeth-street, who had been abroad with his wife and her sister, and was on his way home, was assaulted by one JOHN KELLY and stabbed in the side, back, and shoulder. Hearing the women's shricks, Patrolmen MULLALLY, of the Fourteenth Precinct, and BIRMINGHAM, of the Tenth, hastened to the spot and arrested KELLY. Mr. EDDINGTON was taken to the New-York Hospital, but as the wounds appeared to be slight, he was permitted to depart yesterday forenoon. KELLY was sent to the Tombs and held until afternoon, when, there being no complainant against him, he was released from restraint.

abstract: Yesterday morning the Envoy of the Boy of Tunis, Gen. OTMAN HASHMEM, attended by Col. RAMIRO GAITA, his Aide-de-Camp, and Chevalier ANTOINE CONTI, the Secretary and Interpreter of the embassy together with Mr. AMOS PERRY, the United States Consul at Tunis, and accompanied by Mrs. and Miss PERRY, visited BRADY'S photographic gallery in Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning the Envoy of the Boy of Tunis, Gen. OTMAN HASHMEM, attended by Col. RAMIRO GAITA, his Aide-de-Camp, and Chevalier ANTOINE CONTI, the Secretary and Interpreter of the embassy together with Mr. AMOS PERRY, the United States Consul at Tunis, and accompanied by Mrs. and Miss PERRY, visited BRADY'S photographic gallery in Broadway. The distinguished visitors expressed themselves much pleased with their visit, and displayed their acquaintance with our late unfortunate struggle by asking for the portraits of many of the more important characters concerned in it. They were especially impressed with the portrait of our late President, Mr. LINCOLN, to whose widow they bear a letter of condolence. Previously to leaving, Mr. BRADY took portraits of the Envoy and his attendants in various styles. The autographs which enrich Mr. BRADY's book, are unique in their character.

abstract: In the Superior Court, yesterday, before Justice McCUNN, Mr. S.L. NEWBURY, sought to recover the sum of $1,788.31 against the city for damages sustained to his property by the rioters, on the 14th of July, 1863. Plaintiff was a jeweler, doing business at No. 250 Tenth-avenue. He was also an enrolling officer under Capt. MANNEIRRE, and for this reason he was obnoxious to many of the rioters.
lead_paragraph: In the Superior Court, yesterday, before Justice MCCUNN, Mr. S.L. NEWBURY, sought to recover the sum of $1,788.31 against the city for damages sustained to his property by the rioters, on the 14th of July, 1863. Plaintiff was a jeweler, doing business at No. 250 Tenth-avenue. He was also an enrolling officer under Capt. MANNEIRRE, and for this reason he was obnoxious to many of the rioters. The plaintiff was notified by a friend a few hours before the attack was made, that the mob had decided to sack his premises. He accordingly double-barred his doors and windows, took his wife and child and left. These facts were undisputed, but the Corporation Counsel obtained a dismissal of the complaint on the ground that the plaintiff, when his friend informed him of the intended attack, did not forthwith call on the Mayor and the Sheriff of New-York for assistance, as is provided by the statute of 1865. An appeal will be immediately taken by the plaintiff to the General Term.

abstract: Trial, and Newspaper Writers as Witnesses
snippet: Trial, and Newspaper Writers as Witnesses
lead_paragraph: The Judge-Advocate in the WIRZ trial seems to have cast grave reflections on the credibility of a witness, during the proceedings yesterday, on the ground that the witness in question was a correspondent of two New-York journals. There is no doubt that correspondents are sometimes liable to the suspicion of manufacturing reports which have no foundation. The "reliable gentleman," for instance, who turns up every other night at Philadelphia or Cairo, after a confidential chat with Gen. GRANT, is one of those correspondents that we think Col. CHIPMAN would have good reason to impeach on the witness-stand or anywhere else. And the same, even in a greater degree, is true of the worthy who does the principal part of the fighting on the Rio Grande for the press of New-Orleans. But the bare fact of a witness having been known as a correspondent of a public journal ought not of itself, we should think, to invalidate his testimony, even in a military court. Perhaps Col. CHIPMAN has an experience different from journalists; but if the press were to apply his rule to the vast multitude who address themselves to it every day, the literal conclusion that "all men are liars" would be inevitable. In this matter, moreover, of the testimony for the defence of WIRZ, we think Col. CHIPMAN would best consult the public interests by giving the fullest scope to those who have anything to say in mitigation of the unparalleled crimes laid at the prisoner's door. The evidence is not laid before an ignorant or prejudiced jury, but before a court perfectly competent to weigh every separate item of testimony with judicial calmness and impartiality. Straining points to impeach the evidence of the defence is therefore unbecoming, to say the least.

abstract: Yesterday morning, Patrolman O'NEIL, of the Twentieth Precinct, arrested PATRICK RYAN, a brakeman employed on the Hudson River Railroad, and the prisoner was committed to answer the complaint of CHARLES BAUER, a German emigrant, alleging that the accused had attempted to steal the contents of his traveling bag. Mr. BAUER, who had come to this city to take passage for California, stepped from a car at the Hudson River Railroad Depot, and left his luggage behind Presently returning, he saw RYAN cutting open his carpet-bag; but on the approach of BAUER RYAN fled, and was pursued into the street, where he was taken into custody.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, Patrolman O'NEIL, of the Twentieth Precinct, arrested PATRICK RYAN, a brakeman employed on the Hudson River Railroad, and the prisoner was committed to answer the complaint of CHARLES BAUER, a German emigrant, alleging that the accused had attempted to steal the contents of his traveling bag. abstract: The Tunisean Embassador and suite, accompanied by Mr. PERRY, the American Consul at Tunis, visited BRADY'S Photographic Gallery and sat for their portraits. In appearance they are very much like ordinary individuals dressed in broadcloth, the only characteristic feature about them being the red fez, which is one of the principal manufactures of their country,...
lead_paragraph: The Tunisean Embassador and suite, accompanied by Mr. PERRY, the American Consul at Tunis, visited BRADY'S Photographic Gallery and sat for their portraits. In appearance they are very much like ordinary individuals dressed in broadcloth, the only characteristic feature about them being the red fez, which is one of the principal manufactures of their country, and so common along the shores of the Mediterranean. After leaving BRADY's, the party went to the Historical Society's building, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, where they spent nearly an hour examining relics of the revolution and other curiosities. They appeared to be pleased with their visit, chatting gaily in French the while.

abstract: and the Democratic Combination Circus; Election, Democratic Circus, a Grand, Suggested
snippet: and the Democratic Combination Circus; Election, Democratic Circus, a Grand, Suggested
lead_paragraph: The Democrats are trying very hard to get their traveling circus into active operation. They started at Syracuse last week -- under the immediate management of Brig.-Gen. JOHN A. GREEN, -- with some rather striking performances from the two well-known political gymnasts, Maj.-Gen. SLOCUM and GOV. SEYMOUR. They threw some splendid summersets, -- doubled themselves up, opened and shut like jack-knifes with the greatest ease and rapidity, turned their backs upon themselves and each other so quickly that it was impossible to say which was which, or when either of them was himself or anybody else in particular, and satisfied the spectators perfectly that neither of them had a bone in his body. They did some fine riding in the ring -- though in the two-horse performance they were a good deal jostled and bewildered by the superior speed and mettle of the Republican nag. They did their best, by whip and spur, to keep the Democratic cob alongside -- but "blood will tell" -- and Republican, true to his descent and fired by the practice of the last four years, shot ahead of his untrained competitor whenever he liked, and gave both the riders one or two ugly falls. Manager GREEN lost his temper repeatedly, and with a good deal of difficulty dodged the horses, who came very near running over him; Democrat kicked at him viciously once or twice, but he plied the whip with vigor and tolerable effect.
headline: {'main': 'The Election--The Grand Democratic Combination Circus.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Election--The Grand Democratic Combination Circus.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Friday night THOMAS S. WELLING, a seaman, having become inebriated, assaulted several persons on Pier No. 40, East River. Patrolman NELLIS, of the Seventh Ward, undertook to arrest him, and seizing a belaying pin, he struck the officer on the bead, prostrating him to the sidewalk. An alarm rap brought assistance, and WELLING was taken to the Madison-street Police-station. He was committed for trial.

abstract: Post-office, The Movement for a New
snippet: Post-office, The Movement for a New
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that the Chamber of Commerce has taken up the subject of a City Post-office. Its call upon the Postmaster-General and upon Congress, to provide a decent building for this branch of the public service, will meet with an emphatic response. The one now used is a disgrace to the city and a scandal to the government. There is not a fire-engine company, nor a police justice in this city that is not infinitely better accommodated, in the transaction of its business, than the Post-office Department of the General Government. A rickety old church, with cracked walls and decayed timbers, patched up in every quarter, with bare or fallen ceilings, cramped, crooked and dilapidated in every respect, is all that the National Government can afford for the transaction of the business that comes closest home to the people in the metropolis of the continent. The merchants have a granite palace which cost two millions for the payment of their custom duties, -- and the Sub-Treasurer has a marble building of equal splendor for their custody. But the mass of the people who go for their letters must hang around a tumble-down old church, which scarcely affords shelter from the rain to the crowd of clerks who are required to transact its business. How these clerks save themselves from the rats that infest the old concern, is a standing mystery.
headline: {'main': 'The New-York Post-Office.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New-York Post-Office.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Nearly all Eastern goods are still advancing. Large transactions are taking place, partly on speculation, in Eastern whisky, candles, mackerel, soap, etc., at higher prices. Coal oil sells at $1.70 per gallon, mackerel at $3 a kit and $11 a half barrel. Whisky is $1.75@$1.80 a gallon. The market is entirely bare of Eastern products in first hands. Wheat has advanced to two cents a pound. Flour sells at $6.25 per barrel.

abstract: Recently Messrs. BARTHOLIC & ISAACSON, of No. 60 Nassau-street, merchants, were arrested on accusation of receiving goods that are alleged to have been stolen by one of the late clerks of Mr. FREDERICK BOOSS, of No. 44 Maiden-lane. Mr. BOOSS testified, yesterday, that while JAMES WRIGHT was in his employ he frequently missed goods from his store, and that between October, 1864, and April, 1865, more than $10,000 worth of furs and silks were stolen therefrom; that some of these goods were found at the dwelling of BARTHOLIC, at No. 46 Henry-street, and others at No. 60 Nassau-street, that BARTHOLIC admitted that he had purchased $4,000 worth of these goods from WRIGHT, and paid only $1,500 therefor, and ISAACSON likewise admitted that the goods had been stolen, and that himself and BARTHOLIC had ripped the lining from many of the furs and shipped them to Saugerties and thence back to New-York, and sold them to various merchants. These confessions, the witness said, were made at the Seventeenth Precinct Police station and counsel assert that they were extorted after three days' confinement in a solitary cell. Other witnesses were examined, and the hearing was adjourned.

abstract: A WOMAN CHARGED WITH KILLING HER HUSBAND CORONER'S INVESTIGATION. An inquest was held in Jersey City last evening, by Coroner HANLEY, on the body of THOMAS BELIFIELD, residing at No. 223 South Sixth-street, under circumstances that led to the belief that his death was caused at the hands of his wife.
lead_paragraph: A WOMAN CHARGED WITH KILLING HER HUSBAND -- CORONER's INVESTIGATION. -- An inquest was held in Jersey City last evening, by Coroner HANLEY, on the body of THOMAS BELIFIELD, residing at No. 223 South Sixth-street, under circumstances that led to the belief that his death was caused at the hands of his wife. From the testimony of the daughter, EMMA, 14 years of age, it appears that her mother is of dissipated habits, and was intoxicated on Friday. On the evening of Friday BELIFIELD came home, and finding his wife lying upon the bed, ordered her to get up; but refusing he pulled her off the bed on the floor; some difficulty occurred when the witness beard a heavy fail, and running into the room, saw her father lying [???] on the floor, and her mother exclaimed, "I have [???]or will put you where you will never hurt me again." Witness supposed at the time that her mother had killed her father, and told the people so that came in. A physician was immediately sent for, but when he arrived her father was dead. Dr. JAMES CRAIG testified that he made a post-mortem examination and found both lungs diseased, and the brain congested, with extravasation of blood through it. The immediate cause of death was congestion of the brain. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above facts. Mrs. BELIFIELD, who had been arrested and committed to the City Prison, was set at liberty.

abstract: Cossham, Handel, M. P., Lecture Before Union League Club; Lecture Before Union League Club
snippet: Cossham, Handel, M. P., Lecture Before Union League Club; Lecture Before Union League Club
lead_paragraph: Last evening Mr. HANDEL COSSMAN, one of the English capitalists who have recently made a tour through the Western States, addressed an audience at Cooper Institute, by invitation of Union League Club. It would seem proper, and quite the correct thing, for gentlemen, after inviting a person of Mr. COSSHAM's distinction to express his views before them, to attend his lecture, but we failed to notice a baker's dozen of the Leaguers in the select audience of fifty who listened to the eloquent and interesting address of our English visitor.

abstract: The Binghampton (N.Y.) Republican relates the singular case of SEYMOUR BUTTS, of Windsor, Broome County, who has been deranged on the subject of snakes. He imagined himself to be in great  danger from them, and was seized with the idea that if he are food the snakes would cause his death.
lead_paragraph: The Binghampton (N.Y.) Republican relates the singular case of SEYMOUR BUTTS, of Windsor, Broome County, who has been deranged on the subject of snakes. He imagined himself to be in great danger from them, and was seized with the idea that if he ate food the snakes would cause his death. He abstained from food for four weeks, subsisting on water alone, which he would only take from a bottle, filled under the surface. After this he had camphor mixed with the water, and on this continued to live until fifty-one days had elapsed, during which time he had taken no other nutriment.

abstract: Expression of National Character in Crime
snippet: Expression of National Character in Crime
lead_paragraph: At a moment when crime seems epidemic throughout the world, when the European journals of every language vie with our own newspapers in contributing to the cotemporary history of violence, the observer of the dark side of human nature thus presented cannot fail to note the apparent assimilation of all nations in the methods and character of crime. Formerly it happened that the different peoples, living much in ignorance of each other, and made remote by the difficulties of travel, produced each a type of wickedness, which was Italian, or Spanish, or French, or English. But now poison is more resorted to in England than in Italy, and murder is done with Italian cunning and reticence; while in France crime is attended by many circumstances of sullen ferocity, which were once thought to characterize it chiefly in England. Has advancing civilization indeed created, with a community of blessings and comforts, a hideous community of crime, also, in which the old national characteristics are disappearing? Or are these characteristics merely repressed by the conventionalism which is varnishing the surface of human nature to one effect everywhere, and are they still to be developed by inquiry?
headline: {'main': 'Expression of National Character in Crime.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Expression of National Character in Crime.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This court, more than any other in the country, indicates the increase or decrease of offences of a  minor character. In the course of the year there are from five to six thousand offenders arranged to plead for assault and battery, larceny, and other misdemeanors.
lead_paragraph: This court, more than any other in the country, indicates the increase or decrease of offences of a minor character. In the course of the year there are from five to six thousand offenders arranged to plead for assault and battery, larceny, and other misdemeanors. A great many cases are disposed of by a plea of guilty, many are withdrawn upon paying costs, while not a few -- several hundred, if not a thousand -- are discharged, the complainants declining to prosecute. We have, therefore, kept a record of those that have pleaded not guilty, together with the result. The following are the statistics of this year's trials up to the present time:

abstract: London Quarterly Review on American Affairs
snippet: London Quarterly Review on American Affairs
lead_paragraph: CECIL thinks it more improving to listen to the exaggerated criticisms of an enemy than the flatteries of a friend. The one will be sure to show us our weak points though with distortion and malignity, while the other may fail to see or to expose them. On this principle it may be well to listen to the after-war thoughts of the London Quarterly, in the able critique on American affairs which appeared in its July number. The article evinces knowledge of our history and politics, which it uses with a force that will no doubt produce conviction with those who are not in a condition to expose its distortion of facts, its preversions of history, and its special pleading throughout to make fit appear that all right, all valor and all claim to success in the war was on the side of the South, and all lawlessness, violence and brute force on the side of the North.

abstract: The second meeting of the Polytechnic Club for this season took place on Thursday evening, and was very largely attended. Among those present were many scientific gentlemen well known in this country. The Chairman, Prof. TILLMAN, opened the meeting by reading from a prospectus just received...
lead_paragraph: The second meeting of the Polytechnic Club for this season took place on Thursday evening, and was very largely attended. Among those present were many scientific gentlemen well known in this country. The Chairman, Prof. TILLMAN, opened the meeting by reading from a prospectus just received the plan of the French Industrial Exhibition to be held in 1867. By the order of the managers, all applications for space from foreign nations must be applied for before the 1st of November, 1865. This being so close at hand, American exhibitors would not have a fair opportunity to make their requisitions for space in which to place their articles. To remedy this, the American Institute will make immediate application for 400 square feet, and exhibitors will apply to the Secretary for such room as they may need.

abstract: Our American Cousin, History of the Play
snippet: Our American Cousin, History of the Play
lead_paragraph: The placards and cards which have appeared recently signed LAURA KEENE and JOHN LUTZ, though of a character which we feel sure the lady at least will, upon reflection, regret, will at least have one effect, of which Mr. STUART cannot complain, that of calling fresh attention to a play which enjoyed on its first presentation here more popularity, and was witnessed by greater numbers, than any new piece ever presented on the New-York stage, and which rivals, if it does not exceed, the celebrated run of "Hamlet" by EDWIN BOOTH at the Winter Garden. It may not be uninteresting, then, at this moment, to give a brief sketch of the origin and career of this far-famed "American Cousin."
headline: {'main': 'THEATRICAL.; The American Cousin.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THEATRICAL.; The American Cousin.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: lished in the Boston Daily Advertiser a very able expose of the present condition and prospects of the Hoosac Tunnel. He thoroughly examines the questionable enterprise, describes its gross mismanagement with a masterly hand, and as the result of his investigations, reaches the following conclusions: "What is to be done? To-day we can get out by pocketing a loss say of $1,800,000. Every day's work only increases the sum, which will be a total loss in the end. One of two things the State will do; either abandon the enterprise, sell off and close up a bad job, or else find some responsible parties who will agree to take the whole thing off her hands and complete it. If it cannot be got rid of on better terms, a gift of a million or two of money with it to any parties that will relieve the State of the disreputable business, would be better than for the State to continue the work. Cost what it may to get out, the old Bay State ought not to be engaged in railroad building. This wretched sectional interest has dominated State conventions and State politics too long, and demoralized our aspirants for office too sadly, to be allowed any longer to disturb our political Israel.

abstract: Recreations and Amusements for the Public
snippet: Recreations and Amusements for the Public
lead_paragraph: In the list of items which are appointed to fill up the sum of human life, the wise man does not forget to inform us that there is a time to dance, and also that there is a time to play. Without wishing to intrude upon the peculiar province of our clerical brethren, it is submitted that we may infer from these texts that it is not fitting that man should devote his entire existence, or indeed the major part of it. to either mental or physical toil, and also that there are periods of relaxation required, which, it may be added, are just as necessary to moral, as rest is to physical health. This statement maybe, and no doubt is, opposed to the materialism of the age, which very often estimates the value of productions at a higher figure than it places upon the welfare of the producers themselves.

abstract: PICKPOCKETS IN THE BROADWAY STAGES. Yesterday forenoon, Mrs. GRAHAM, of Eighteenth-street descending from a twenty-third-street stage in Broadway near Fourth-street hailed Roundsman EDWARD R. DE LAMATER, of the Broadway police, and informed him that she had lost her wallet in that omnibus...
lead_paragraph: PICKPOCKETS IN THE BROADWAY STAGES. -- Yesterday forenoon, Mrs. GRAHAM, of Eighteenth-street, descending from a twenty-third-street stage in Broadway near Fourth-street hailed Roundsman EDWARD R. DE LAMATER, of the Broadway police, and informed him that she had lost her wallet in that omnibus, Officer DE LAMATER bade her tarry near the corner while he overhauled the vehicle; he had, however, a spirited race with the stage, but captured it near Bleecker-street. Entering, he required whether any person had found a wallet. Nobody had. "Then" said he, "permit me to search this vehicle;" and the passengers having risen, he found a wallet under the feet of a gaudily-attired female. He returned to Mrs. GRAHAM and to his amazement learned that the wallet which he had recovered was not her property, and contained $20 more than hers, she having had only $30. A gas-bill in the wallet disclosed the owner's name, and he notified the lady yesterday afternoon; but under the Metropolitan Police rule the owner cannot get her property until it passes through the hands of the Police Property Clerk. That gentleman will restore it to her to-morrow morning. Officer DE LAMATER thinks that the female at whose feet he found the wallet had stolen two port-monnaies, and, on seeing him, dropped the one that he recovered, as a ruse to throw him of scent.

abstract: The boys of the Grand-street Grammar School No. 8, accompanied by their teacher, Mr. G.B. HENDRICKSON, went on an excursion on Friday last, to Sing Sing, to visit the prison, taking the staunch little steamer Norwalk. They had a delightful sail on the Hudson, discussing all the principal places of literary and historical interest which they passed.
lead_paragraph: The boys of the Grand-street Grammar School No. 8, accompanied by their teacher, Mr. G.B. HENDRICKSON, went on an excursion on Friday last, to Sing Sing, to visit the prison, taking the staunch little steamer Norwalk. They had a delightful sail on the Hudson, discussing all the principal places of literary and historical interest which they passed. The noble palisades, rearing their tall columnar forms like huge ramparts for miles along its western shore, furnished a peculiarly interesting topic for scientific instruction. These rocks, at all times picturesque and beautiful, are at this season of the year especially so; the mass of shrubbery which, in Summer, fringes many of them to their very crests with living green, is now fast assuming the gorgeous garniture of Autumn. Having been previously provided with a pass through the kindness of Judge JOHNSON, the courteous Superintendent of the prison, they experienced no delay in passing the guards. They were in time to see the convicts, over 800 in number, march in to dinner, some wearing the ball and chain, some the iron crown, and all in prison garb. They marched in regular order, their feet keeping time with a heavy tread, apparently as doleful as the hearts that beat above them. After dinner they visited the various workshops, and were greatly interested in several machines, one of which manufactures its own pegs, make its own holes and "pegs a shoe in the twinkling of an eye." They also visited the chapel, hospital and library, where they were introduced to Rev. Mr. LUCKEY, the venerable and distinguished chaplain of the prison, who addressed some pertinent remarks to the boys. In the female prison they were shown the nursery, where were several bright and handsome infants born since the incarceration of their mothers.

abstract: The national income from internal revenue, through the past week, reached $11,499,009, thus averaging the handsome sum of $1,916,501 a day. From the beginning of the current fiscal, year, July 1, to the close of the past week, the receipts of the government from this source amounted to $100,935, 322, making an average income, for eighty-three business days, of $1,206,084 a day, equal to a yearly aggregate of $376,298,208. A government in the enjoyment of an income like this is not likely to be sorely pressed for money. As the officers employed in the collection of this enormous revenue are adding by experience to their knowledge of the bearings of the law on the taxable interests of the country, the administration of this vitally important branch of the public service gains in efficiency and economy, yielding more and more satisfactory resuits to the National Treasury.

abstract: The Truth on his Remark to Gov. Fletcher on a White Government
snippet: The Truth on his Remark to Gov. Fletcher on a White Government
lead_paragraph: -- We Wish that those gentlemen who take the trouble to give to the public the private remarks or opinions of distinguished public men, would be particularly careful to propagate accurate versions of such remarks or opinions. Incorrect reports not only injure the distinguished men who are their victims, but they mislead the community, and frequently give wrong directions to public sentiment. A prominent Eastern Abolitionist lately declared in a public speech that President JOHNSON, in a private conversation with the Governor of Missouri, made the remark: "This is a white man's country, and while I am President it shall be a white man's government." There is nothing particularly criminal about the remark in itself; but then it was not made by President JOHNSON to Gov. FLETCHER; and we are pleased that Gov. FLETCHER has taken the pains to set the matter right. He has authorized the statement that the President did not make the observation attributed to him, but as far as the Governor remembers, President JOHNSON used about the following words: "I am in favor of the white man," or, "I belong to the white man's party." Those who think that the Governor has peformed an unimportant labor in rectifying this matter, or who think that the corrected version amounts to the same thing as the other, have paid little attention to politics, opinions, logic or language.

abstract: Vivisection of Canard about Mexico
snippet: Vivisection of Canard about Mexico
lead_paragraph: --The demolition of the villainous fiction attributing to Lieut.-Gen. GRANT the utterance of sundry wicked and foolish remarks concerning our Mexican relations, has been complete. We exposed its falsity from internal evidence as soon as it had got into print; but as the dispatch opened by announcing that its statements were "established beyond a doubt," the other proofs of its truthlessness become of interest, now that these proofs, may be considered as having reached a satisfactory conclusion. The original telegram was at once minute and indefinite. It gave for authority a "distinguished Illinoisan" who had been in conversation with GRANT, and who repeated to a third party the remarks of GRANT. When the names of the unnamed individuals were demanded, we were furnished with those of Judge CATON, of Illinois, and Mr. SMITH, editor of the Chicago Tribune. No sooner had this been done, however, than Judge CATON, who happened to be in this city, published a card over his own signature, denying that GRANT had ever, in his presence, made the remarks attributed to him, and denying that he (CATON) had ever quoted such remarks in the presence of SMITH as coming from GRANT. In addition to this, the Chicago Tribune declares that the "SMITH referred to in the alleged conversation with Judge CATON is not the editor of that paper."
headline: {'main': 'VIVISECTION OF A CANARD.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'VIVISECTION OF A CANARD.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- A correspondent of the Evening Post questions whether Mr. SEWARD properly couples, in his dispatches, "the United States" with a plural verb. The Post gives no definite reply, but seems inclined to think that Mr. SEWARD mistakes. It is enough to say that the Secretary of State, in entering State papers, ought not to violate the phraseology of the constitution. In the constitution, the name "United States" is used uniformly in the plural; as in the clause "Treason against the United States shall consist only in levying war against them, or in adhering to their enemies."

abstract: Internal Revenue, First Fiscal Quarter of Peace
snippet: Internal Revenue, First Fiscal Quarter of Peace
lead_paragraph: The Import trade of the United States for the first quarter of the current fiscal year -- the first year of peace since 1860-61 -- has yielded to the Treasury the unprecedented sum in Gold of FIFTY MILLIONS OF DOLLARS; that is, if we esti mate for the outports the same relative percentage of Customs to the port of New-York as last year, to wit, twenty-eight per cent. of the whole, while New-York receives seventy-two per cent. of the whole. The original or gold value of the foreign goods actually marketed, or upon which these fifty millions of Customs revenue were paid in, is not far from one hundred millions, the average rate of duties being within a very small fraction of fifty per cent.

abstract: The Fung Shuey, Capt. GOUGH, from New-Orleans Sept. 30, via Southwest Pass Oct. 1, 1865, with merchandise and passengers to H.B. CROMWELL & Co., arrived last night. Oct. 1, at 7 A.M., 12 miles off Southwest Pass, passed steamship Geo. Cromwell, bound in. Oct. 2, at 3 P.M., 33 hours from the bar, E.S. ANDERSON, cabin passenger, died of consumption and was buried at sea. Oct. 7, at 1 P.M., long. 75 lat. 36 11, passed steamship Vicksburgh, having broken her machinery and going under high pressure, steering north. Oct. 8, at 7 A.M., passed steamship Chase, steering south.

abstract: -- Saturday forenoon, Mrs. GRAHAM, of Eighteenth-street, descending from a Twenty-third-street stage in Broadway near Fourth-street, hailed Roundsman EDWARD R. DE LAMATER, of the Broadway police, and informed him that she had lost her wallet in that omnibus. Officer DE LAMATER bade her tarry near the corner while he overhauled the vehicle; he had, however, a spirited race with the stage, but captured it near Bleecker-street. Entering, he inquired whether any person had found a wallet. Nobody had. "Then," said he, "permit, me to search this vehicle;" and the passengers having risen, he found a wallet under the feet of a gaudily-attired female. He returned to Mrs. GRAHAM and to his amazement learned that the wallet which he had recovered was not her property, and contained $20 more than hers, she having had only $30. A gas-bill in the wallet disclosed the owner's name, and he notified the lady yesterday afternoon; but under the Metropolitan Police rule the owner cannot get her property until it passes through the hands of the Police Property Clerk. That gentleman will restore it to her this morning. Officer DE LAMATER thinks that the female at whose feet he found the wallet had stolen two port-monnaies, and, on seeing him, dropped the one that he recovered, as a ruse to throw him of scent.

abstract: On Saturday very little testimony was taken before the Wirz Military Commission. Most of the session was occupied by Judge-Advocate CHIPMAN with an argument against the admission of the testimony of Gens. Lee and Johnston, Howell Cobb, Mallory, Moore, Commissioner Ould and others, for the defence, on the ground that they were conspirators with WIRZ. Dr. JOSEPH JONES, of the Georgia Medical College, was then placed on the stand, and produced a report which he made, under permission of the rebel authorities, concerning the diseases, &c., at Andersonville. It appears that his object was to illustrate facts relative to gangrene, malarial fevers, and camp and other diseases. The report shows the frightful mortality -- the number of deaths, daring one period, being as large in the stockade as in the hospital. He describes, the men as miserable, hopeless, and abject in the extreme. Very many of them were mere skeletons, incrusted with dirt and covered with vermin. Some of them cursed their own government for refusing to an exchange of prisoners. It was, he said, impossible to depict the scene. Capt. GILMORE, on duty at Norfolk, testified as to the seizure of watches, silver spoons, forks, watch-chains, lockets, photographs, &c., taken from a man named GARRISON on the eastern shore of Virginia, who claimed to be counsel for R.B. WINDER. The court adjourned until next Thursday morning.

abstract: Three persons who were held on the charge of burglary, attempted to escape from the prison van, going from the Fourth District Court to the jail on Saturday last. They managed to force the back of the wagon out by means of a hammer. One of them, named JAS. ROBERTSON, got off. The others were detained by Officer O.H. SMITH, of the Forty-fourth Precinct Police, and taken to jail, where they are safely lodged.

abstract: At a meeting of gentlemen called to devise some measures for rescuing the multitude of fallen women to be found in our metropolis, and for preventing others from falling who are exposed to temptation, it was resolved that there is an urgent call for the establishment of a House of Reception in the midst of the city, is which those who desire to reform may find a temporary refuge, and in which the virtuous may seek protection in their exposure. The undersigned were appointed a committee to raise the funds for such an institution, and were authorized to place it under the entire control of the lady managers of the Magdalen Female Benevolent Society. These ladies have consented to take the charge of such a house, in addition to the home already established and filled to its utmost capacity. An appeal is now made to all who are interested in the moral character of our city, and in the temporal and eternal welfare of their fellow-men, to contribute liberally to the establishment of such an institution. It in not deemed necessary to set forth the enormity of the evil which so loudly calls for vigorous efforts at removal. It stares us in the face on every corner and in every street. It is one of the most melancholy features of this social evil, and at the same time a source of encouragement to labor for their reformation, that so many of the victims of this vice are young girls. It is confidently believed that under the wise management of the ladies who are to have it in charge, this House of Reception will be instrumental in accomplishing great good, and that, through the many avenues of influence which it will open, it will inaugurate a new era in efforts to rescue the fallen and deliver the tempted. An agent will be duly authorized to collect funds for this object, and, in the meantime, contributions may be sent to either of the undersigned. Donations will be acknowledged every month. A.R. Wetmore, No. 81 Vesey-street; David Hoadley, No. 88 Wall-street; Z.S. Ely, No. 101 Front-street; Stephen Cutter, No. 128 East Twelfth-street; R.N. Havens, No. 15 Nassau-street; E.D.G. Prime, No. 37 Park-row.

abstract: Fashion Course. Ella Sherwood and Shark
snippet: Fashion Course. Ella Sherwood and Shark
lead_paragraph: The match for $2,000 at two-mile heats, between Ella Sherwood and Shark came off on Saturday, and resulted, as will be seen, in the victory of the former in two straight heats. The time made was much better than could have been expected with a heavy track, and a strong breeze flowing. The attendance was not large, Saturday being a bad day to attract a crowd.

abstract: There will be six performances of opera, here and in Brooklyn, during the present week, by which it will be rightly inferred that Mr. MARETZEK is in good working order. The Brooklyn night is Thursday, ("Poliuto,") the rest of the week we have to ourselves, beginning this evening with "Il Truvatore," and ending on Saturday with "Ione" as a matinee. In the cast of VERDI's work we and the name of a new contralto, Mlle. B. DE ROSSI, who is the Asucena. ZUCCHI, MAZZOLENI and BELLINI sustain the other principal parts, and the orchestra will be under the direction of Mr. CARL BERGMANN. We are glad to notice by the announcements for the week that "Ernani" is to be repeated on Wednesday evening. The work made a decided hit on the occasion of its revival last Wednesday, and its repetition has been very generally demanded. We see also that FRICCI's comic opera (with which the Paris season opens) of "Crispino e la Comare" is in active preparation, and will be speedily produced. The music is singularly light, piquante and graceful.

abstract: Mr. J. abstract: The Republicans of Brooklyn have placed the name of SAMUEL BOOTH at the head of their city ticket. This is in accordance with a suggestion made in the TIMES a few weeks since -- a suggestion which was then regarded as absurd and prejudiced by many of the good people of our sister city. Mr. BOOTH, if elected, will make an excellent Mayor. Long familiarity with the routine of office, hard work in the field of civic duty, years of experience in the management of finance, combine to make him as good an officer as the city can produce. His integrity is unquestioned, his life unblemished, his reputation unsullied. Although less known to the general public than the present able incumbent, and although of not so much mental calibre as Hon. Mr. STRANAHAN, whose name was mentioned in this connection, Mr. BOOTH has very many friends among a class of men who always vote, and vote for the right ticket, so that while the Democracy defiantly proclaim their ability to carry the State by a large majority, it is believed by those competent to judge that Mr. BOOTH will make a good fight, and cause them a great deal of trouble to prove their assertion.

abstract: A young artist named BARTLETT, but a few months since a simple marble-cutter, has produced a choice head and bust, which he calls the Yankee Girl, and which is causing quite a sensation in artistic circles. As a work pure and simple it is in some respects deficient, but as the first work of an uneducated hand, it is miraculous. BARTLETT'S studio is the Mason  Hamlin Building, next to the Metropolitian Hotel.

abstract: Discussion with Gen. Kilpatrick at Newark
snippet: Discussion with Gen. Kilpatrick at Newark
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening the much-talked of -- at least in New-Jersey -- discussion between Maj.-Gen. KILPATRICK and Hon. A.J. ROGERS, came off in front of the Court-house, Newark, N.J. The challenge for the discussion emanated from Mr. ROGERS, who offered to meet Gen. KILPATRICK three times a week until election, to discuss the issue of the present campaign in New-Jersey. It was promptly accepted, and the meeting on Saturday evening was the first of the series.

abstract: The Fall meeting of the Passaic County Agricultural Association will commence to-morrow at Paterson, N.J. The programme issued by the Association is of the most varied description, as will be seen by reference to the advertisement, there being no less than four heavy stakes down for decision on each of the three days to which the meeting extends. On tomorrow, the opening day, the first race will be "The St. Leger Stake," of $1,000, for three-year olds, two and a quarter miles, p.p., which has no less than forty entries, with every prospect of a large field coming to the scratch, and a most exciting contest. There are also, on the same day, a purse of $200, mile heats; one of $500, two-mile heats; and a selling-stake, one mile and a quarter.

lead_paragraph: The proprietors of the Fifth-avenue Hotel, sent to court a young man of about 30 years, whose fine address won the Judge and all the spectators. The prisoner, whose actual name is D. STELLIFER MOULTON, rejoices in the pseudonym of "STELLIFER, the King, Reigning Prince of the House of David, and Guardian of American Desity." He bears an autograph letter from Messrs. WORTHINGTON, FLANDERS & CO., of the Boston Traveler, indorsing him as their regular New-York correspondent, and among his papers are copies of correspondence between himself and many gentlemen of eminence in social, financial and political circles. The most interesting of these is a paper which Mr. MOULTON received from Messrs. abstract: Recently Messrs. BARTHOLIC & ISAACSON, of No. 60 Nassau-street, merchants, were arrested on accusation of receiving goods that are alleged to have been stolen by one of the late clerks of Mr. FREDERICK BOOKS, of No. 44 Maiden-lane. Mr. BOOHS testified, on Saturday, that while JAMES WRIGHT was in his employ be frequently missed goods from his store, and that between October, 1864, and April, 1865, more than $10,000 worth of furs and silks were stolen therefrom; that some of these goods were found at the dwelling of BARTHOLIC, at No. 46 Henry-street, and others at No. 60 Nassau-street; that BARTHOLIC admitted that he had purchased $4,000 worth of these goods from WRIGHT, and paid only $1,500 therefor, and ISAACSON likewise admitted that the goods had been stolen, and that himself and BARTHOLIC bad ripped the lining from many of the furs and shipped them to Saugerties and thence back to New-York, and sold them to various merchants. These confessions, the witness said, were made at the Seventeenth Precinct Police-station, and counsel assert that they were extorted after three days' confinement in a solitary cell. Other witnesses were examined, and the hearing was adjourned.
lead_paragraph: Recently Messrs. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. In the person of Mlle. B. DE ROSSI, who appeared here last evening for the first time, Mr. MARETZEK has evidently made a valuable addition to his already powerful company.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- In the person of Mlle. B. DE ROSSI, who appeared here last evening for the first time, Mr. MARETZEK has evidently made a valuable addition to his already powerful company. The lady is an experienced contralto, whose voice, without any particular saliencies, is yet good, and completely at her command. She acts well, and knows the business of the stage thoroughly. Her interpretation of the role of Azucena was in every way satisfactory.

abstract: The effect  of the President's conciliatory policy abroad has a practical illustration in the news from Europe which we publish this morning.
lead_paragraph: -- The effect of the President's conciliatory policy abroad has a practical illustration in the news from Europe which we publish this morning. The President's speech to the Southern delegation is said to have inspired general confidence in the speedy and cordial reunion of the North and South. Along with this general statement comes the report that "the amount of business done in American securities has been of a magnitude unprecedented since the outbreak of the rebellion." Further, we are told, "Five-twenties have been largely taken at an advance of quite two per cent." The advance, however, does not extend alone to government bonds, but to other American securities as well. We refer, in another column, to various causes as leading to this result. But the great central fact with which the improvement in our credit is connected, we take to be the interpretation which is put, abroad, upon the Executive policy of reconstruction. The idea is, that a permanent military occupation of the late insurgent States means national bankruptcy; that reunion, on the President's simple method, signifies national strength, solvency and good faith with the public creditor. This foreign view of the case entirely coincides with liberal opinion here.

abstract: A dispatch from Brussels says: "The Nord publishes a telegram from Paris, which says: "The text of Earl RUSSELL'S circular upon the Gastein treaty, published by the Independence Belge, is an invention, the object of which was to create the belief that a good understanding existed between the English and French cabinets. The circular of M. DROUYN DE LHUYS is alone authentic."

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Three steamers arrived yesterday from Europe, the Bremen at this port, the North American at Father Point, and the China at Halifax. The news is up to the 1st inst., one week later than by the Persia. The Fenian agitation still continues to create excitement. Arrests are daily made, and the government shows a disposition to deal with great firmness with all the leaders in the movement. American Securities have been very active at advanced rates, the Five-Twenties reaching 70[???]. The news from the Continent is not especially important.

abstract: THE NEWARK ELECTION TO-DAY. -- The Newark municipal election will be held to-day, and it is important, in view of the active canvass now going on in New-Jersey for the State election, that the Union men of Newark should roll up a heavy majority for their candidates for city offices. The gentlemen who have been nominated for these municipal positions are individually worthy of the hearty support of their constituents, regardless of the beneficial effect which their election will have on the pending State canvass, and we trust that no Union man entitled to vote will neglect this opportunity of performing a piece of practical patriotism. Residents of Newark, doing business in this city, of whom there are large numbers, should especially see to it that the Union candidates are not defeated through their remissness, in refusing to set aside their ordinary business for a short time in order to spend an hour or two at the polls. Vote early, and the prospect of victory is excellent.

abstract: The return game between the Empire and Active Clubs was played at Hoboken on Saturday last, in the presence of quite a large crowd of spectators, quite a number of whom were ladies. The first game between these clubs, which took place early in the season, resulted in the success of the Empires by a
lead_paragraph: The return game between the Empire and Active Clubs was played at Hoboken on Saturday last, in the presence of quite a large crowd of spectators, quite a number of whom were ladies. The first game between these clubs, which took place early in the season, resulted in the success of the Empires by a score of nearly two one; but in this game the Actives turned the tables, beating the Empires 24 to 15 in a game of eight innings. KELLY, of the Actives, owing to a lame hand, played right field, and HATFIELD went behind, where he surpassed himself and astonished his friends by the manner in which he filled the position. WALKER was absent, and STOCKMAN pitched in the first part of the game, and EBBETTS in the latter part, and both did well. In fact, with all the changing about, the only weak positions in the nine were CRAWFORD at third and VANDERWERKEN at short. "Redman" was as usual, most effective at second, although ROONEY led the score, having four runs and one out, while "Redman" had four runs and two outs. The Empires were short two or three of their first nine -- MILLER being particularly missed at the first base, and KELLY at second. Considering the strength of their nine, they made a very creditable display. WILSON led the score, and WATERMAN was next. Mr. BURNS, of the Mutuals, filled the position of umpire in a creditable manner, rendering very prompt and satisfactory decisions. The following is the score.:

abstract: Humiliated by World's Patronage
snippet: Humiliated by World's Patronage
lead_paragraph: -- Our neighbor of the Tribune has incurred the patronizing applause of the World. His views on negro suffrage are commended as in harmony with the Republican creed, and he is promised the "lead of the party" if he will only stick to them and come out in open hostility to President JOHNSON. This must be a strong temptation to Mr. GREELEY, but we fear he don't quite see how the World can give title to the great things with which it tempts him. The Editor of that journal is not the first Copperhead who has taken people up into a high mountain for similar purposes.

abstract: Alabama Convention practically established Negro Testimony
snippet: Alabama Convention practically established Negro Testimony
lead_paragraph: -- Some of our neighborsindulged in a good deal of indignation against the South on the strength of a telegraphic dispatch announcing that the Alabama Convention had "practically abolished" the admission of negro testimony in courts of justice. The Tribune made it the occasion of a very long and very emphatic leading editorial. We ventured at the time to say that the word "abolished" was undoubtedly written "established," and so it proves. The convention passed a resolution admitting negro testimony until the adjournment of the next Legislature. That body will have the right to put this matter on a permanent footing, -- but meantime negroes are permitted to testify.

abstract: Election--Prospects of Canvass
snippet: Election--Prospects of Canvass
lead_paragraph: The Democratic organs profess to be very confident of success in the coming election. But their confidence is based wholly on presumed or predicted divisions in the ranks of the Administration Party. All their efforts in the canvass are to foment such divisions. Their orators and their presses teem with assertions that such divisions exist, and with appeals to personal jealousies, hatreds and distrusts, for the purpose of increasing them. The World and Argus are eloquent and pathetic in assuring the "radicals" that WEEI and Company controlled the Syracuse Convention; and they are equally eloquent and pathetic in assuring the "conservatives" that the radicals control the party. SUMNER, GREELEY WENDELL PHILLIPS, and other first-class bug bears, are paraded diligently for effect upon one class of Union men; while SEWARD, WEEI and President JOHNSON are held up for the terror of another. The matter of negro suffrage is the particular hobby upon which all these intrigues are made to hinge.

abstract: Gen. OTMAN HASHEM, the Tunisian Ambassador, and his suite, accompanied by Mr. AMOS PERRY, Mrs. PERRY, Miss PERRY and Gen. HALL, paid a visit, yesterday morning, to Mayor GUNTHER, at the City Hall. The Mayor welcomed Gen. HASHEM most cordially, and said he was sure he only echoed the sentiments of the citizens of New-York when he proffered the hospitalities of the city to the representatives of Tunis. The General, through Mr. PERRY, who acted as interpreter, made an appropriate reply.

abstract: A divorce suit of considerable interest came up yesterday, before Justice INGRAHAM, in the Supreme Court. In September, 1864, the plaintiff, GABRIELLA SELTZER, wife of ALEXANDER SELTZEE, obtained a decree of absolute divorce from her husband on the ground of adultery.
lead_paragraph: A divorce suit of considerable interest came up yesterday, before Justice INGRAHAM, in the Supreme Court. In September, 1864, the plaintiff, GABRIELLA SELTZER, wife of ALEXANDER SELTZEE, obtained a decree of absolute divorce from her husband on the ground of adultery. She now moves to have the same set aside, and the case sent to a referee, on the ground that the proceedings were commenced in sport and not for the purpose of securing a final separation; also, on the ground that the Supreme Court decree was obtained by collusion and fraud. About six months after the judgment of divorce the husband -- who was found guilty of adultery -- married another woman in the State of New-Jersey; and it is claimed that he is now in contempt and has no legal standing in court, having violated the laws of the State of New-York and the provisions of the decree, both of which forbid the offending persons under the circumstances marrying again during the lifetime of the other. The case was argued at much length, but no decision has yet been rendered.

abstract: NEW POLICE STATION IN THE FIRST WARD.  The police force of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, or western half of the First Ward, have surrendered the cramped and dingy old dwelling which they occupied so many years in Cedar-street, and moved into fine, roomy quarters which the city has provided at No. 99 Liberty-street.
lead_paragraph: NEW POLICE STATION IN THE FIRST WARD. -- The police force of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, or western half of the First Ward, have surrendered the cramped and dingy old dwelling which they occupied so many years in Cedar-street, and moved into fine, roomy quarters which the city has provided at No. 99 Liberty-street. This new police station, which is in many respects the finest in the city, is a Liberty-street; wholesaling warehouse refitted. It is 100 feet in depth by 30 in width, and five stories high, with cellar and sub-cellar under the whole. On the ground-floor are the business office, a spacious and lofty apartment of about 60 by 30 feet, and the patrolmen's sitting-room, in the rear, a room of about 30 by 40 feet. In the cellar -- a light and airy place, closely resembling a common English basement -- are two large rooms for lodgers, and in the rear ten well-ventilated cells. The sub-cellar, a damp and noisome dungeon, contains two cells that ought never to be used. The second floor of the edifice contains handsome rooms for the accommodation of Capt. JOHN C. HELME and Sergeants ELIPHALET N. PECK, WILLIAM MCCLEARY, JAMES ROCKWELL and JACOB SIEBERT; and on the third and fourth doors are roomy apartments for the fifty-three subordinate officers of the precinct. The building, as refitted, cost the city about $60,000.

abstract: ARREST OF ALLEGED COUNTERFEITERS. -- On Sunday night a young man named JAMES MOORE, who says he is employed by the Tenth-avenue Railroad Company of New-York, was arrested by Officer LANGAN, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, on a charge of passing counterfeit fractional United States postal currency. On being taken to the station-house, bogus 50 cent stamps representing $10 in value, and $40 in good money was found on his person. During the night, MOORE intimated that a man named CHARLES G. SANDS, of No. 101 Spring-street, New-York, manufactured the bogus money which he had. Officers LANGAN and HILAIRE GUISCHARD, acting upon this information, went to New-York in search of SANDS, and before daylight arrested him at his residence. The officers searched the house, but found neither counterfeit money nor implements for its manufacture. A man named THOMAS MOONEY, in SANDS' company, was also arrested. One of the prisoners made a vigorous effort to escape but did not succeed. The three prisoners will be examined by United States Commissioner NEWTON.

abstract: On Sunday morning last, while all the people were at church, California was terribly shaken by an earthquake. Two tremendous shocks were felt within the space of half a minute. The church-bells were rung by the agitation of the earth, walls were cracked, plastering knocked down, and some crockery smashed. One or two unfinished buildings in San Francisco were thrown down; but no lives were lost, and but few persons were injured, though everybody was terribly scared.

abstract: Speech at Yonkers, N. Y.
snippet: Speech at Yonkers, N. Y.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of Westchester County generally, and of Yonkers particularly, opened the Fall campaign last night with an enthusiasm rarely found outside of the rural districts. Although the meeting which was held on this occasion had the advantage only of some forty-eight hours' announcement, the good people thereabouts rallied in great numbers about the standard, on which is inscribed the name of Gen. BARLOW, and hailed with delight the near prospect of an address from that gallant soldier, backed as he was by Hon. Senator WILSON, of Massachusetts.

abstract: RESPONSIBLE. -- Gen. HITCHCOCK, one of the Union Commissioners for the exchange of prisoners of war, has published another letter in vindication of Secretary STANTON. The General denies, in the most positive terms, that the Secretary of War ever refused, as has been charged, to exchange man for man, officer for officer, according to grade. He asserts that no proposition to that effect was ever received from Judge OULD, or his superiors. The Confederates persistently refused to exchange colored soldiers on any account, and our government, as a matter of principle, could not disown its settled policy by consenting to any proposition of abandoning the colored troops to their fate. The colored troops captured by the Confederates numbered five thousand, and not a few hundred, as reported. It was only at the last stages of the rebellion that the Richmond leaders modified their views by consenting to exchange free colored men. The government would not and could not abandon the protection of the whole army employed in its defence.

abstract: LAUNCH OF A PILOT-BOAT. A pilot-boat bearing the name of A.T. STEWART, the drygoods millionaire, was successfully launched, yesterday afternoon, from the ship-yard of Mr. E.F. WILLIAMS, at Greenpoint, in presence of a large attendance of ladies and gentlemen.
lead_paragraph: LAUNCH OF A PILOT-BOAT. -- A pilot-boat bearing the name of A.T. STEWART, the drygoods millionaire, was successfully launched, yesterday afternoon, from the ship-yard of Mr. E.F. WILLIAMS, at Greenpoint, in presence of a large attendance of ladies and gentlemen. The Spanish steam frigate, Isla de Cuba, lying near by, was gaily dressed in bunting for the occasion, as was Mr. JESSURUN's yacht, the Galgo, of Curacoa, both of which presented a very beautiful appearance, and with the national ensign living from the various ship-yards and house tops in the vicinity, served much to enliven the scene. The ceremony of christening the vessel was performed by a very interesting young lady, Miss ELLEN M. CLARK, daughter of JONAH N. CLARK, Esq., who stood on the bow as the boat glided from the ways, and as her stern dipped in the water, broke a bottle of wine on the bowsprit, and in a loud and distinct voice proclaimed the name the vessel should in future be known by. This is the twelfth vessel of this class built by Mr. WILLIAMS in ten years; and she is said, by competent judges, to excel in beauty of model his previous efforts. The dimensions of the A.T. Stewart are -- length over all, 80 feet; length on deck, 76 feet; breadth of beam, 21 feet; depth of hold, 7 feet 10 inches, and will be about 100 tons carpenter's measurement. She was built to replace the George Steers, No. 6, which was lost on Barnegat shoals on the 12th of January last. She will be commanded by DANIEL CHAPMAN.

abstract: Etheridge M. Fish vs. Lorena Fish. -- Some months ago an action was commenced by the plaintiff, in which he sought a decree of divorce on the ground of the adultery of his wife. After going through the various forms required, the suit was, for some reason, abandoned when nearly completed, and soon after a new action was commenced by the plaintiff for the same alleged cause. The defendant's attorney now makes a motion to enjoin plaintiff from proceeding further in the second action until the costs of the former suit are paid. The court took the papers and reserved its decision. For the motion, Mr. Clinton; opposed, Mr. Emery.
