abstract: When, three years ago, the English cotton-growers began to fear a dearth in the future supplies of cotton, they organized the Manchester Cotton-growers' Association. It was a voluntary association, but raised large sums of money from its members and from manufacturers generally, and with this money it organized a vast system for the procurement of cotton from all the cotton-growing countries of the globe. It sent agents everywhere to stimulate the growth of the staple, and furnished machinery, assistance and sometimes capital and labor, to planters in India, Egypt, Turkey, China and other countries. It met with such remarkable success that last year the supply was nearly equal to the demand, though prices were high.

abstract: Heathen, the
snippet: Heathen, the
lead_paragraph: We notice that subscriptions are being taken up in Great Britain and Germany for the benefit of our Southern freedmen, and we understand that a large sum of money has been lately received in this country from these sources. It is to be used in supplying the wants of the destitute negroes, and in general educational and missionary work among them. The kindness of these foreign donors is certainly commendable, and their contributions prove that their interest in the negro is something more than fanciful.

abstract: Policy and the Opposition; Gov. Sharkey's Proclamation; Freedmen's Bureau, Gov. Sharkey and Gen. Slocum on; Proc. on Freedmen's Bureau
snippet: Policy and the Opposition; Gov. Sharkey's Proclamation; Freedmen's Bureau, Gov. Sharkey and Gen. Slocum on; Proc. on Freedmen's Bureau
lead_paragraph: A most virulent war has been opened in Mississippi against Judge SHARKEY, the Provisional Governor, for his issue of a proclamation Which may be found in another column. This proclamation announces an agreement with the Freedmen's Bureau to transfer to the civil authorities of the State the right to try all cases in which the rights of freedmen are involved, on condition that they be allowed the right to testify, and all the rights accorded to white men before the courts. The Governor declares that "the late constitutional amendment, which abolishes slavery, abolishes also all laws which constituted a part of the policy of the system of slavery, and in declaring that the negro shall be protected in his person and property, establishes principles which, of themselves, entitle the negro to sue and be sued, and as a necessary incident to such right, that he is made competent as a witness, according to the laws of evidence of this State." The newspaper organs of the party which has just come near electing an unpardoned rebel (Judge FISHER) Governor, in opposition to a strong Union candidate, are denouncing this action of the Provisional Governor with intensest bitterness. The Jackson Daily News, the leading Fisher champion, declares that "no public man in Mississippi can survive the storm of indignation which will pelt him into obscurity when he stands forth the avowed advocate of the equality of the negro before the judicial tribunals of the country." This language, doubtless, is overheated by party zeal, yet there can be no doubt that the President's policy, as understood and applied by the Provisional Governor, is to be embarrassed and opposed in every practical way by the party which has just shown such strength at the polls.
headline: {'main': "The President's Policy, and the Opposition.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Policy, and the Opposition.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. ADAM MAYER, of No. 458. Fifty-first-street, accidentally shot himself in the breast with a pistol, last evening, and was seriously wounded. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital....LUTHER CLARK, of No. 7 Hester-street, was severely wounded, yesterday afternoon, while riding on the front platform of Morrisania car No. 19, one of his feet having been caught in the bridge....JOHN BROWN, of No. 207 Spring-street, leaped from the front platform of a Harlem Railroad freight car, at the intersection of White and Centre streets, yesterday afternoon, and falling on the track, the wheels passed over him and mangled his right thigh. He was taken to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: the William Tell Case
snippet: the William Tell Case
lead_paragraph: On the night of the 19th of March last, the ship William Tell, under the command of Capt. WM.W. FRENCH, was within about twenty miles of Pernambuco. It was the mate's watch on deck. The Captain was sleeping in his cot in the cabin. The second mate was also asleep in his room, and the steward in the next room to him. About 9:30 o'clock the steward was awakened by groans from the second mate's room. Thinking the mate was dreaming, the steward knocked on the partition to awake him, but as the noise continued, he sprang up and found the second mate standing in his doorway bleeding and almost senseless from what proved to have been two severe cuts of an ax in the face. The steward at once ran for the Captain, and to his horror, found him dead in his cot, having been murdered also by blows of an ax. The steward rushed on deck and called the mate, who learning the state of things, armed himself and some others whom he could trust, and proceeded to put all those of the crew who were in the Captain's watch in irons.

abstract: On Pennsylvania Election
snippet: On Pennsylvania Election
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania and Ohio held their elections yesterday. In the former State the contest was quite tame, there being no prominent officer to be chosen, the highest being AuditorGeneral, who is at best a mere clerk. But few returns are in as we write, yet, such as they are, they seem to indicate the choice of Gen. HARTRANFT, the Union candidate, by a handsome majority over Col. DAVIS, his Democratic opponent. In Ohio there was a more spirited canvass, there being a Governor to choose. Although at this moment we have not a word in the way of returns, we are quite sure that the Republican candidates named below are elected by immense majorities:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. BELLINI'S opera of "I Puritani" was given here last evening to an unsually brilliant house, brilliant we mean for Tuesday, the least popular of the opera off nights. The distribution was excellent, and the performance in consequence was exceedingly well balanced and satisfactory. Miss KELLOGG'S Elvira is well known.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- BELLINI's opera of "I Puritani" was given here last evening to an unsually brilliant house, brilliant we mean for Tuesday, the least popular of the opera off nights. The distribution was excellent, and the performance in consequence was exceedingly well balanced and satisfactory. Miss KELLOGG'S Elvira is well known. The graceful music of the role suits her voice, and its occasional brilliancy is very acceptable when so delicately and musically rendered as it was last evening. Miss KELLOGG was in fine voice. Signor IRFRE improves rapidly on acquaintance. He is an admirable tenor, and a thoroughly good artist in every sense of the word. We have not for many years had a better Arturo. From the exquisite scena of the first act to the concluding duet of the last act he was earnest, impassioned and good. In the latter, indeed, he excelled himself, surprising every one with the power of his voice and the control which he exercises over it. The piece had to be repeated. Indeed, the encores of the evening were numerous enough, beginning with the polacca and ending as we have mentioned. Signor BELLINI and Signor ANTONUCCI were also in capital voice, and sang and acted with equal spirit. The liberty duet was given with great gusto. In all respects the performance was a good one, and will bear repetition.

abstract: Water Commissioners of Detroit vs. Burr. Breach of Contract
snippet: Water Commissioners of Detroit vs. Burr. Breach of Contract
lead_paragraph: The Board of Water Commissioners of Detroit vs. Henry A. Burr et al. -- The action is brought by plaintiffs to recover of defendants, as sureties, the sum of $50,000. In 1856, Messrs. Dickcrson & Sickles, who are the real parties defendant, entered into an agreement with the plaintiffs, who represented the Corporation of the City of Detroit, to construct engine-houses and furnish boilers for the water works of the city. The corporation had determined to have water introduced, and the planting allege that they took the necessary steps to carry out the plan, a part of which was that Messrs. Dickerson & Sickles should construct and furnish certain portions of the apparatus, &c. The defendant and others signed a bond whereby they became bound that the contracting mechanics should well and faithfully perform all they stipulated, on or before the 18th of July, 1857 -- in default thereof the obligors of the bond were in pay the sum of $59,000 to the City of Detroit. It is now claimed by the plaintiffs that Messrs. Dickerson & Sickles did not perform their agreement as to the construction, although the time for the completion thereof was frequently extended, and it is claimed that by reason of their non-fulfillment the city has suffered and been greatly damaged.

abstract: WM. HOGAN, aged 15, was charged with lifting two pieces of cassimere cloth from the door of the store of MORRIS MICHAEL, in Thirty-seventh-street. He was seen taking the goods, but he ran so fast that he could not be caught.
lead_paragraph: WM. HOGAN, aged 15, was charged with lifting two pieces of cassimere cloth from the door of the store of MORRIS MICHAEL, in Thirty-seventh-street. He was seen taking the goods, but he ran so fast that he could not be caught. Two weeks afterward he applied some stuff to a pane of glass, and shoved it in so noiselessly that nobody heard him. As soon as an opening had been made, and he thought no one was looking at him, he commenced to pull out a bale of cloth, but while doing so he was caught, and was yesterday sent to the House of Refuge. The officer who made the arrest said he had served eighteen months there already, and had managed to escape from that institution.

abstract: BERNARD STORPE, of No. 81 Butler-street, Brooklyn, recently a book-keeper for Messrs. CLINTON & HUGHES, of No. 56 Reade-street, dealers in enameled cloth, committed suicide by leaping from a ferryboat into the East River yesterday morning. About six months ago Mr. HUGHES, the partner who transacted the firm's business in-doors, was prostrated by typhoid fever, and the management of affairs fell upon STORPE. It is supposed that at this time the bookkeeper commenced a series of defalcations, and that at the time when Mr. HUGHES recovered and reappeared in the store, the amount of his peculations had reached about $3,000. He had not, however, covered his tracks well; for Mr. HUGHES detected several errors in his first glance at the books, and upon this discovery STORPE fled to Brooklyn. Mr. HUGHES, not desiring to prosecute his unfaithful clerk, but wishing rather to ascertain precisely how the firm's affairs stood, sent letters begging STORPE to return and rectify the books; but as he paid no attention to the summons, the firm were forced to appeal to the courts. They accordingly made affidavit before Justice LEDWITH, and yesterday morning Officer CHANDLER, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, went with a warrant to STORPE's abode and took him into custody. While evening to the city STORPE leaped from the ferry-boat into the East River, and two naval officers manning one of the ferry-boat's skiffs, attempted to rescue him, but unfortunately the boat was capsized and the three were immersed. The naval officers were saved, but STORPE was drowned. His body was recovered and taken to the Beekman-street Police Station, and there an inquest was held by Coroner WILDEY, STORPE was 65 was 55 years of age. What disposition he made of Messrs. HUGHES & CLINTON's money does not appear. He has left a widow and three helpless children in indigence.

abstract: -The Tribune persists in its efforts to magnify an ordinary and not unusual collision at a primary election into an affair of importance. The Union Primary, on the occasion referred to, was, with the exception of the dispute in the Eighteenth Ward, conducted with the most perfect good order, and were calm expressions of the sentiment of the Union party. They were, therefore, a suitable occasion for commendation. And yet, from the tone of the Tribune, its readers are left to infer that our party is demoralized, while, in fact, it was never better united or more harmonious.
lead_paragraph: -The Tribune persists in its efforts to magnify an ordinary and not unusual collision at a primary election into an affair of importance. abstract: Gen. Connor's War to the Knife against
snippet: Gen. Connor's War to the Knife against
lead_paragraph: Gen. CONNOR, the Indian fighter of the Rocky Mountains, has proclaimed war to the knife against all the red men of that section. We doubt very much whether the government will sustain him in any such policy. He has been fighting these people very hard and very steadily during the last four years; and the latest reports of his operations had statements that could hardly be explained in any other way than that he had been guilty of massacres. There is among the papers of last Congress a terrible document containing the details of the Indian massacre in Colorado, by Col. CHIVINGTON; and we fear the fact that CHIVINGTON has thus far been allowed to go unpunished, has led other officers operating against these Indians to act with a ferocity that is disgraceful in a Christian people. We have heard all that can be said against the Indians, and we understand perfectly the anxiety of Western settlers to have the entire race exterminated. But a great government cannot, with impunity, permit injustice, even to the most helpless of its people.

abstract: SAMUEL L. GOUVERNEUR died on Friday, Sept. 29, at his residence, Needwood, near Harper's Ferry, Mr.GOUVERNEUR was the son of NICHOLAS GOUVERNEUR, an old and respected resident of this city, and well known to many of our older citizens.
lead_paragraph: SAMUEL L. GOUVERNEUR died on Friday, Sept. 29, at his residence, Needwood, near Harper's Ferry, Mr.GOUVERNEUR was the son of NICHOLAS GOUVERNEUR, an old and respected resident of this city, and well known to many of our older citizens. Early in life, when a promising member of the bar, he married the daughter of President MONROE, and served as his private secretary during his two Presidential terms. He was subsequently appointed Postmaster of the City of New-York, and held that position under President JACKSON.

abstract: The gunboats Algonquin and Winooski are being put in order for the river race. The Algonquin has had 33 tubes put in her boilers, and it has been decided to remove every other float from the wheels of each vessel. They will be allowed to carry as much coal and pressure of steam as they choose to carry, and whichever boat makes the fastest time will be the winner. The boilers of the Algonquin have been subjected to a hydrostatic test, which resulted favorably.

abstract: AN OLD SCHOOL-HOUSE DESTROYED BY FIRE. -- Between 10 and 11 A.M. yesterday a fire broke out in the old Bushwick School-house, in Bushwick-avenue, near North Second-street, E.D., and the building was entirely destroyed, with its contents. The house has lately been used as a cigar factory and residence by Mr. ADOLPH PILLOW, who loses $500 on his stock and $450 in money. There was no person in the building at the time of the fire. There was an insurance of $600 in the Harmonia Company of New-York on the tobacco, but the building, which was owned by the city, was not insured.

abstract: The Democratic speechmakers and newspapers find it very hard work to conform to their Albany platform in what they say. They have to take back so many of their past statements, have to deny so much they had always asserted, have to change their former positions so completely, that they find it difficult to keep countenance before the people. And every now and then they get back into their old and natural attitudes, despite the necessity of their assuming sincerity in their conversion. We guess the American people see all this. We fancy they have both memory and foresight. And we think likely they will not -- at least not en masse -- become the victims of misplaced confidence.

abstract: Yesterday the distinguished visitors from Tunis, on invitation from the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections, paid a visit to Randall's and Blackwell's Islands. Mr. PERRY, his wife and daughter, Gen. HALL, and Commissioners BRENNAN and BOWEN, accompanied them.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the distinguished visitors from Tunis, on invitation from the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections, paid a visit to Randall's and Blackwell's Islands. Mr. PERRY, his wife and daughter, Gen. HALL, and Commissioners BRENNAN and BOWEN, accompanied them. On landing at Randall's Island, the children were found drawn up in line to welcome them, and went through with some military evolutions with so much precision and skill, that they elicited warm commendation from the visitors. At the conclusion, a youngster named HENRY HAINER stepped forward, and addressed the Ambassador as follows:

abstract: A case of considerable interest, involving the sum of over $50,000, was commenced yesterday in the Superior Court, Part First, before Justice MCCUNN and a jury. The parties to the suit are the Board of Water Commissioners of the City of Detroit, against HENRY A. BURR and others. The defendants are sued as sureties on a bond executed by them in behalf of Messrs. DICKINSON & SICKLES, contractors, who are the real parties defendant in interest. The gentlemen last named, in 1856, entered into a contract with the City of Detroit, to construct a number of pumps, engine-house and engines, to be used in supplying the City of Detroit with water. By the terms of the first agreement, Messrs. DICKINSON & SICKLES were to complete their work on or before the 18th of July, 1857, but the time was subsequently extended. The defendant, BURR and others, became sureties that the contracting parties would faithfully perform the stipulated work. They performed a portion of the work, and the City of Detroit, through their representatives, the plaintiffs, from time to time, advanced money on the contract, amounting in the aggregate, as they claim, to over $50,000. The defence insist that the work which was done was imperfect and did not at all answer the purpose. The trial, which has just commenced, will be continued to-day.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The repetition of "Ernani" attracted another fashionable house last evening. The cast was the same as yesterday week, but the singers were hardly in such fine voice. Signor MARRA indeed was in a deplorable plight, and could barely proceed after the second act. Fortunately Mme. ZUCCHI was all right, and Signor IRFRE warming to his work, speedily routed the trifling hoarseness which troubled him in the first act, and sang subsequently with capital spirit and effect Signor ANTONUCCI was admirable; and the orchestra and chorus were all that could be desired.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The repetition of "Ernani" attracted another fashionable house last evening. The cast was the same as yesterday week, but the singers were hardly in such fine voice. Signor MARRA indeed was in a deplorable plight, and could barely proceed after the second act. Fortunately Mme. ZUCCHI was all right, and Signor IRFRE warming to his work, speedily routed the trifling hoarseness which troubled him in the first act, and sang subsequently with capital spirit and effect Signor ANTONUCCI was admirable; and the orchestra and chorus were all that could be desired.

abstract: CORONERS' INQUESTS. -- Coroner BARRETT, last evening, held an inquest at No. 110 Ewen-street, E.D., on the body of a young married woman named WILHAUP, who died suddenly at 4 o'clock the same morning. The testimony showed that the woman died from suffocation, having suffered for some time with a wen in her throat. . . . The jury in the case of MICHAEL NICHOLS, who was killed at the embankment accident in Remsen-street, on Wednesday last, acquitted the parties having charge of the work of any carelessness, and rendered a verdict of accidental death.
lead_paragraph: CORONERS' INQUESTS. -- Coroner BARRETT, last evening, held an inquest at No. 110 Ewen-street, E.D., on the body of a young married woman named WILHAUP, who died suddenly at 4 o'clock the same morning. The testimony showed that the woman died from suffocation, having suffered for some time with a wen in her throat. . . . The jury in the case of MICHAEL NICHOLS, who was killed at the embankment accident in Remsen-street, on Wednesday last, acquitted the parties having charge of the work of any carelessness, and rendered a verdict of accidental death.

abstract: Bierstadt's Rocky Mountains, bought by James McHenry, England
snippet: Bierstadt's Rocky Mountains, bought by James McHenry, England
lead_paragraph: well-known picture of the "Rocky Mountains" has been purchased by JAS. MCHENRY, Esq., who will carry it with him to London early next month. Twenty-five thousand dollars was paid for the picture -- a liberal sum, to be sure, but the check for the amount was not reluctantly drawn, as Mr. MCHENRY is a connoisseur in pictures, and cheerfully pays generous prices for meritorious works of art The "Rocky Mountains" will be added to a collection which already comprises many notable pictures valued in the aggregate at $600,000.

abstract: The President's discourse before the regiment of negro troops who paid their respects to him on Sunday, is characterized at once by the plainest homeliness and by the deepest philosophy. Knowing the black race thoroughly, from life-long intercourse with them knowing their feelings and failings, their hopes and needs, their temptations and dangers, their capacities and characteristics he offered them such advice concerning their ...
lead_paragraph: The President's discourse before the regiment of negro troops who paid their respects to him on Sunday, is characterized at once by the plainest homeliness and by the deepest philosophy. Knowing the black race thoroughly, from life-long intercourse with them -- knowing their feelings and failings, their hopes and needs, their temptations and dangers, their capacities and characteristics -- he offered them such advice concerning their daily and ordinary conduct in the future, as cannot but prove of the highest benefit, should it be heeded by its recipients. He pertinently inculcated the practice of those old manly virtues which always have constituted, and always must constitute, the foundation of whatever is noble in individual or national life. Sobriety, honesty, purity, industry, patience, perseverance, forbearance, peacefulness, respect for the laws of the land and the moral code of society -- these are among the fundamental and everlasting elements of well-being, which cannot be ignored by the statesman, any more than by the moralist, and the importance of which the President urged urged upon his colored military audience in language of forcible simplicity.
headline: {'main': "The President's Last Speech.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Last Speech.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -On Tuesday the Board of Directors of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum met at Farnwood, when it was reported that at present there are in the asylum 219 males and 166 females, making an aggregate of 385 pupils. Mrs. STONER, the late matron, after having been connected with this institution for thirty-two years, has resigned, and the board manifested their respect for her long and faithful services by letter and resolutions. The committee of female visitors presented her with a handsome Bible. At present the institution in greatly crippled through want of means, and it would be well for our charitably-disposed citizens to bestir themselves in the matter. Sir MORTON PETO and his companions have been invited to visit the asylum, which they will do, it is understood, at the end of the present, month.
lead_paragraph: -On Tuesday the Board of Directors of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum met at Farnwood, when it was reported that at present there are in the asylum 219 males and 166 females, making an aggregate of 385 pupils. The committee of female visitors presented her with a handsome Bible. At present the institution in greatly crippled through want of means, and it would be well for our charitably-disposed citizens to bestir themselves in the matter. Sir MORTON PETO and his companions have been invited to visit the asylum, which they will do, it is understood, at the end of the present, month.

abstract: At police trials yesterday, Commissioners ACTON and BERGEN listened to ninety-three complaints. The most conspicuous on the calendar was that of Capt. JEDEDIAH W. HARTT, of the Ninteenth Ward, against Park-keeper JOHN BREENE, for improper conduct in arresting a gentleman and lady in Central Park, between 10 and 11 o'clock on the night of the 19th ultimo. Ordinary counsel might have bungled this trial; but Judge BEEBE, an Ex-Police Commissioner, having been retained by BREENE, managed it with consummate skill. During the trial of Officer JACOB FIERO, of the Twenty-second Ward, it was stated that Alderman MASTERSON's coachmen, at the southwestern gate of the Central Park, pay little heed to the laws, trusting to the Alderman's political influence to shield them. Other trials were mainly of routine character.

abstract: Some three or four hundred people assembled at the Fashion Race Course, L.I., yesterday, to witness the chariot race which had been advertised pretty extensively. The whole affair was simply a show, the managers of which thought that the novelty of the thing would serve to distract public interest from the Paterson races. The chariots, which were of the kind ordinarily used in circuses, were driven by eques triennes from the New-York Hippotheatron -- Miss VIRGINIA MASON and Senorita MARIE MARTINEZ by name. The animals used were of average speed, though the contest was the occasion of more ridicule than excitement. The best two heats in three was to win the race. Four heats were run, the first one being a tie; the second was won by Miss MASON's team -- 2:22; the third by MARTINEZ -- 2:26; and the last also by the Senorita -- 2:31. The winning team were chestnut-colored, and their driver was enthusiastically cheered at the conclusion of the race. There was no betting, and the entire affair was looked upon as considerable of a sell.

abstract: Paterson Fall Meeting--Second Day
snippet: Paterson Fall Meeting--Second Day
lead_paragraph: The second day of the Paterson Fall Meeting will be long remembered in racing annals as the most brilliant scene ever witnessed on this continent. Large as was the assemblage on the grand day of the Spring Meeting, larger still as was the culminating one of the meeting at Saratoga, both suffered a total eclipse yesterday at Paterson, where there was an attendance beyond all precedence. Old turfites refer with pride to the assemblages on Long Island, when Eclipse, Henry, Lady Suffolk, &c., were in their glory, and their contests drew spectators by thousands, and the old Union course echoed and reechoed with their shouts; but henceforth Paterson will stand alone in the quantity and marked superiority in quality of the visitors. So brilliant a coup d'oeil as that presented can better be imagined than described. The grand stand was crowded with elegantly-dressed ladies; the other capacious stands were wedged to repletion. The field was densely packed with equipages of the most recherche and the most nondescript character, and not a vacant spot could be found anywhere. Yet this dense mass of racing-loving humanity presented the most perfectly good-humored and orderly array. Not a single disorderly or improper character could be found within the precincts of the course, or for that matter outside of it -- the detectives took care of that -- oaths and objurgations were unheard, inebriety hid its head, and the strong body of police on duty were indulged with a complete sinecure. It is a great thing to possess a good character and a bright record. In these respects Paterson is patent in the public mind. Roughs and rowdies know full well that it is no place for them; hence they never attempt to put in an appearance there, having a potent fear of quick justice, and Jersey laws. The model management of the association shone resplendently on this occasion, and received its coveted reward in the unqualified approbation of all present. The arrangements of the Erie Railroad were of the most complete and satisfactory description. Determined to be up to the occasion for ten days past they have been collecting spare cars, and even sent as far as Cincinnati for additional ones. Some idea of the magnitude of the demand for transportation made on the company, may be gathered from the fact that one of the morning special trains had twenty-eight cars attached, another, twenty-six, and a third, twenty-two -- all three being so densely crowded that even standing room inside was unobtainable -- and the people clustered like bees on the platforms. Yet all were landed, and returned in safety, not the most trivial accident occurring. From early morning the Paterson plank-road was alive with vehicles, whose sinuous course could be traced by clouds of dust, as they swept past. As the curse was neared, the- crush and crowd were indescribable. The sleepy old Passaic awoke from its lethargy and put on an additional ripple, and the town of Paterson rubbed its eyes, and turned out its population en masse to witness the unwonted procession of New-York raiders. We append a summary of the day's racing:

abstract: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at the NewYork Hospital yesterday over the body of Dr. FRANK B. WILLIAMS, late assistant surgeon of the Fourth New-York Artillery Regiment, who died from the effects of a dose of morphine. It is said that deceased had recently drank to excess.
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest at the NewYork Hospital yesterday over the body of Dr. FRANK B. WILLIAMS, late assistant surgeon of the Fourth New-York Artillery Regiment, who died from the effects of a dose of morphine. It is said that deceased had recently drank to excess. On Tuesday evening he entered NAPOLEON DALTON's place, at No. 2 1/2 Barclay-street, and took a mixture which he said was medicine for heartburn. In a few moments he proposed to shake hands with DALTON, saying that it was the last time he should thus greet him (DALTON,) as he had taken about 50 grains of morphine, which he thought would kill him in half an hour. He was immediately taken to the New-York Hospital. Deceased was 38 years of age, and a native of Illinois.

abstract: Corner Stone Laid

lead_paragraph: At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon the locality of Fifth-avenue and Forty-fifth-street was visited by a large and respectable concourse, comprising the elite of the city, to witness the ceremonies incident to the laying of the corner-stone of the Church of the Divine Fraternity. The assemblage was quite an intellectual one, and the interest manifested in the proceedings fully attested the esteem and respect in which the pastor (Rev. Dr. E.H. CHAPIN) is held.

abstract: Fenian, Origin of the Name--Les Faineans--Do Nothings
snippet: Fenian, Origin of the Name--Les Faineans--Do Nothings
lead_paragraph: -A friend informs us that the various attempts to derive the term "Fenian" are so far failures, but that he has just hit it. He says that as all Irish revolutions have in some sort depended upon French help, and as the only actual benefit they ever got from that country was St. Patrick, they were determined this time to have the first installment in advance; and so, as they could find nothing else at hand, they seized upon the adjective Faineant, and transformed it into Les Faineans, literally the "Do-Nothings." If that is a correct statement, we half believe our friend is right, for they are thus far Do-Nothings indeed. The name is a good offset for Know-Nothings.

abstract: Will commence with a grand hurdle-race for $500, two miles, over eight flight of hurdles, all within the course, a fair view being obtainable at any point within the inclosure and on the stand. The second race is the Sequel Stakes for $300, for three-year olds, two miles, five entries. Third race, three-mile heats, for $700. Fourth race, purse $200, one and a quarter miles, with allowances for beaten horses, this will end the Fall Meeting, which has been, without exception, one of the most popular ever witnessed this side the Atlantic.

abstract: The English mind is supposed to move slowly but surely. If a long time is required for it to get to a point, it is supposed to remain a good while at the point. It adhered to the rebellion until after the last armed foe had expired, and only begins to believe in the Union alter a half year of peace has proved it to be firmly established. It believed in Confederate bonds after the Confederacy itself was tottering, and only acquires faith in the value of Federal securities when the necessity of faith has been superseded by sight. It appears that now English capitalists are beginning to be large purchasers of these securities, of which heretofore the Germans have been the chief European buyers. The likelihood is, that having begun this, they will carry it to a great extent and keep on it for a long while. The security is unsurpassed; and the profits accruing to European holders have been heavy enough to tempt English cupidity. The reports of our wealth, resources and prospects sent to England by the traveling capitalists who lately visited us, will be very stimulating; and the still better and surer reports of Secretary MCCULLOCH will strengthen the wavering. We are not anxious that the English should become holders of our national securities to a large extent; but we doubt if it can now be prevented even though these securities should rise 20 per cent. We understand that large orders were received here yesterday by the China, and the indications were of much larger calls in the immediate future.
lead_paragraph: The English mind is supposed to move slowly but surely. If a long time is required for it to get to a point, it is supposed to remain a good while at the point. It adhered to the rebellion until after the last armed foe had expired, and only begins to believe in the Union alter a half year of peace has proved it to be firmly established. It appears that now English capitalists are beginning to be large purchasers of these securities, of which heretofore the Germans have been the chief European buyers. The likelihood is, that having begun this, they will carry it to a great extent and keep on it for a long while. The security is unsurpassed; and the profits accruing to European holders have been heavy enough to tempt English cupidity. We are not anxious that the English should become holders of our national securities to a large extent; but we doubt if it can now be prevented even though these securities should rise 20 per cent. abstract: Augusta, Ga., Confederate Foundry, Incendiary; Dix, James A., Editor Boston Journal
snippet: Augusta, Ga., Confederate Foundry, Incendiary; Dix, James A., Editor Boston Journal
lead_paragraph: The Panama star says: "The unhappy wife of Gen. BARRI[???]S is now in Guatemala. She is one of the brightest ornaments in Central American society; a lady of the highest refinement, dignity and intelligence. The loss of a husband to whom she was so much attached, and by whom she remained so faithfully in his day of adversity, will be an irreparable affliction to her: but, with all her woman's modesty, she has a hero's courage, and we doubt not she will outlive her present grief, to see vengeance wreaked at some future day on the heads of those who have so deeply imbrued their hands in her husband's blood, and who now stand before the world a disgrace, to the whole Central American race, and a stain on the very name of humanity and civilization."
headline: {'main': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GENERAL NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Elections the, of Tuesday, Oct. 10
snippet: Elections the, of Tuesday, Oct. 10
lead_paragraph: The October elections in the great States of Pennsylvania and Ohio have been decided in favor of the Administration by the Republican party. Judging by present appearances, Iowa and Indiana, on the same day, took the same course. The States of the Centre and the States of the West utter their responses to Maine and Vermont, which pronounced their verdict last month. Neither in Ohio nor Pennsylvania, nor in the other States, has the campaign been of such warmth, or regarded of such importance, as to call forth the greatest energies of the parties, or the full vote of the people. Perhaps, the greatest efforts were made by the Democracy, because for the first time in years it now seemed that they might have a chance to win. Their platforms were less obnoxious, their candidates generally better than heretofore; the honor and fate of the country were not conceived by patriotic men to be at stake in the elections; and there were Symptoms of party disintegration and lassitude of political feeling, which, it was thought could not but inure to the benefit of the Democracy. They adopted all the expedients of party trickery to secure success. In one place they appealed to patriotism by nominating a soldier; in another they wrought upon prejudice by denouncing negro suffrage, and trying to fasten that measure upon their opponents; they attempted to take advantage of the great and unquestionable popularity of the Administration policy toward the South by claiming to be the most determined supporters of that policy, and they attempted to cajole the people into believing them the special adherents of President JOHNSON.
headline: {'main': "Tuesday's State Elections.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Tuesday's State Elections.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Thumb Screws and Dr. Mudd's Attempted Escape; Freedmen Suffrage and the Democratic Party
snippet: Thumb Screws and Dr. Mudd's Attempted Escape; Freedmen Suffrage and the Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: There never was a more complete failure than the attempt of the Chicago Platform party to make negro suffrage a party issue. When the question was first raised, they clutched at it as material that might be turned to splendid account in retrieving their desperate fortunes. It has turned to ashes in their grasp. To the Union party alone has the question been of any benefit. Its whole treatment has entitled that party more than ever to the respect and confidence of the country.

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA IN BROOKLYN.--"Poliuto" was given last night at Brooklyn Academy to a house which, although not as large as usual, was a great advance on the average attendance of last season. The honors of the evening were fairly divided between ZUCCHI, MASSIMILIANI and BELLINI.
lead_paragraph: ITALIAN OPERA IN BROOKLYN. -- "Poliuto" was given last night at Brooklyn Academy to a house which, although not as large as usual, was a great advance on the average attendance of last season. The honors of the evening were fairly divided between ZUCCHI, MASSIMILIANI and BELLINI. At the close of the first act, BELLINI, who, suffering somewhat from hoarseness, was otherwise superb in matter and manner, was enthusiastically called out, and after the second act, which closes with a magnificent quintette and chorus, the three principal artists were called and recalled before the curtain. Barely has an opera in its entirely passed with such absolute eclat; although by no means a favorite work with the patrons who reside in the City of Churches, "Poliuto" has by this night's production achieved an unprecedented success.

abstract: The Democratic nominations in Kings County and Brooklyn are identical with the suggestions made in the TIMES several weeks since, commencing with the name of MARTIN KALBFLEISCH for Mayor. In this county the Democracy have in former years been bit terly divided. The regulars and nationals and citizens and soreheads have fought each other with a zeal that in a better cause would have merited success.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic nominations in Kings County and Brooklyn are identical with the suggestions made in the TIMES several weeks since, commencing with the name of MARTIN KALBFLEISCH for Mayor. In this county the Democracy have in former years been bit terly divided. The regulars and nationals and citizens and soreheads have fought each other with a zeal that in a better cause would have merited success. Two years ago MARTIN KALBFLEISCH was Mayor of Brooklyn. The Democracy didn't fancy his way of doing things; he was of the one man party, and always wanted to be the one man himself. The consequence was that although the "old man," as his intimates call him, strained every nerve to secure the nomination, he was defeated by Mr. BENJ. PRINCE. Not content to abide by the dictate of his party convention, KALBELEISCH kicked the traces and ran an independent ticket. Col. WOOD was the Union nominee, and fairly swept all before him, so that on the day after election, Mr. KALBELEISCH was found in the pitiable plight of a Democrat who had violated Democratic usage, a candidate rejected by the people, and a politician outside the ring of the faithful.

abstract: It is a remarkable fact that the ordinary model lodging-houses for families in London are not materially in advance of our new tenementhouses in New-York. The English are by no moans so particular in the matter of ventilation as we are compelled to be by our climate, and their plans of building, though presenting...
lead_paragraph: It is a remarkable fact that the ordinary model lodging-houses for families in London are not materially in advance of our new tenement-houses in New-York. The English are by no moans so particular in the matter of ventilation as we are compelled to be by our climate, and their plans of building, though presenting immense advantages over the plans of the little two-story houses in which the laboring classes usually live in England, are not generally so complete as we might reasonably expect. The rooms are often low, ill-aired and by no means cheerful, but their great superiority is in the cleanliness with which they are kept, and the check which can be exercised in them on over-crowding or immoral and filthy habits.

abstract: Despite the depression in foreign exchanges, and the stringency in money, the market for government securities was quite strong and buoyant yesterday, especially for the gold-bearing bonds, which, under an active foreign demand, were on the advance. The Sixes of 1881 improved 1 to 1/2, and were in very light supply, as were also the first issue of Five-twenties, on which foreign orders mainly run. In the absence of an adequate supply of the earlier issue, the Five-twenties of 1864 were moderately purchased on foreign account, chiefly for the London market, at an avagrage of 2 per cent. under the current price of the bonds of 1862, to which those of 1864 are precisely similar, save that the latter have, absolutely two years longer to run before the redemption option of the government can take effect, a circumstance which home buyers for investment consider a decided advantage.

abstract: THE LATEST SIXTH-WARD HOMICIDE.--Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday over the body of WILLIAM PIGOTT, of No. 62 Maiberry-street, a youth of eleven years, who was mortally wounded while interfering in fight between JOHN SHERRY and JOHN DELANY. The testimony shows that, on the night of the 30th ultimo, JOHN DELANY, of No. 3 Franklin-street, called at No. 62 Mullberry-street to
lead_paragraph: THE LATEST SIXTH-WARD HOMICIDE. -- Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday over the body of WILLIAM PIGOTT, of No. 62 Mulberry-street, a youth of eleven years, who was mortally wounded while interfering in fight between JOHN SHERRY and JOHN DELANY. The testimony shows that, on the night of the 30th ultimo, JOHN DELANY, of No. 3 Franklin-street, called at No. 62 Mullberry-street to see SHEERY, and that at the moment of his entering the door an assault was made, and DELANY was knocked to the floor and jumped upon by SHERRY and one JOHN VERNON. DELANY escaped into PIGOTT'S room, and was pursued by SHERRY and VERSON, the latter having a knife in his hand. The fight was resumed here, and Mr. PIGOTT, lather of the deceased, was severely beaten, Mrs. PIGOTT was stabbed in the neck, DELANY received a severe cut on the head, and young PIGOTT was mortally wounded. The jury found that "WILLIAM PIGOTT came to his death by a stab wound with a knife, at the hands of JOHN Vinson," and further they hold JOHN SHERRY as an accomplice. VERNON is a native of Ireland, aged twenty-one years, and by trade a printer. SHERRY, also a native of Ireland, is thirty years of age, and a blacksmith. Both have been committed to the Tombs.

abstract: Party, Indelible Record of the Party, (Dem. Defeats)
snippet: Party, Indelible Record of the Party, (Dem. Defeats)
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the Democratic party have been counting largely, since the close of the war, upon a popular reaction in their favor. Their calculation has been that their old friendly relations to the South would specially commend them for the work of reconciliation which is now the order of the day; and also that the prevailing prejudice against the colored race could be turned, by a little management, to their great profit. They have expected much, too, from the lack of harmony in the Union party upon some of the questions pertaining to reconstruction. This disagreement, they were indeed, quite sure, would greatly distract and impair the working force of the party, even if it did not absolutely rupture and paralyze it. They professed, too, to bury forever all the issues of the war, and to adopt heartily the entire reconstruction policy of President JOHNSON. They undertook these Fall campaigns upon new ground entirely, and ground, too, so chosen as to give their opponents as little advantage of position as possible. They have plied every art, exhausted all strategy to gain success. The result is that they have been overwhelmed in every field. In September, they were routed worse than ever in Maine and Vermont, and in October they are again severely defeated in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana. All their high hopes have been dashed, and they will go into their November fights demoralized and despairing.
headline: {'main': 'The Late Democratic Defeats.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Late Democratic Defeats.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- The recent assessment of two per cent. on the salaries of the clerks in the Post-office is subject of bitter complaint. Several of the seven-hundred-dollar clerks allege that the deduction has left them without sufficient means to meet current expenses; and as the last money assessed at the Navy-yard is to be restored to the involuntary contributors, the Post-office clerks are anxiously looking for an order requiring the refunding of their money.

abstract: CAPTURE OF A RIVER THIEF. -- A man giving his name as AMOS NICHOLSON, was up before Judge DAILEY yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. It seems that early the previous night some citizens observed a boat with two men in it at the foot of Noble-street, Greenpoint, and they watched for a short time the action of the men, which soon became apparent. Thinking they were unobserved, the river thieves, as they proved to be, commenced to take on board their boat a large quantity of pig-iron. Citizen WILLIAMS interfered at this juncture and twice discharged his revolver at them. One of the thieves then jumped on shore and escaped. The other was captured and locked up during the night, and taken before Judge DAILEY as we have stated. His examination was postponed until today.

abstract: We print this morning an important order by the Lieutenant-General, which will very speedily muster out of service nearly all the volunteer army. He has assigned the artillery for the most part to the forts of the Northern States; the forts of the Southern seaboard, with two or three exceptions, are to be in charge of colored troops.
lead_paragraph: We print this morning an important order by the Lieutenant-General, which will very speedily muster out of service nearly all the volunteer army. He has assigned the artillery for the most part to the forts of the Northern States; the forts of the Southern seaboard, with two or three exceptions, are to be in charge of colored troops. All the volunteer cavalry east of the Mississippi goes out of service forthwith. Other reductions are in progress, and it will not be many weeks, if nothing goes awry, before we shall be reduced almost entirely down to the regular army.

abstract: Close of Labors of
snippet: Close of Labors of
lead_paragraph: The Woman's Central Association of Relief has closed its mission. Of the many benevolent organizations developed by the necessities of the war, this has been one eminently useful, invariably successful, always judicious and never selfish. It was begun in April, 1861, and in June of the same year it book voluntarily a position subordinate to the Sanitary Commission, devoting itself with fidelity and zeal to certain specialties. It proposed to open a central depot in the city of New-York, for the collection of hospital supplies; "such supplies to be delivered solely upon requesition upon the Sanitary Commission, or to agents authorized by it." The manner of obtaining these supplies was left to the association. This agreement, of mutual benefit, continued until the day of the association's dissolution, and was of great and patent service to the army and its friends at the North desirous of assisting its members. We find that the association has received and distributed, since May 1, 1864, the following enormous

abstract: Yesterday was indeed a gala occasion at the Fair of the American institute. Early in the morning, crowds, many hundreds, of people who had learned from the TIMES and other journals of the anticipated visit of the deaf and dumb children to the fair, thronged the building. We have never, save on one or two evenings, saw the large halls so densely packed as at this time.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was indeed a gala occasion at the Fair of the American institute. Early in the morning, crowds, many hundreds, of people who had learned from the TIMES and other journals of the anticipated visit of the deaf and dumb children to the fair, thronged the building. We have never, save on one or two evenings, saw the large halls so densely packed as at this time. Messrs. CARPENTER, CHAMBERS, TILLMAN, BRIDGMAN and other of the managers, radiant with the flush of success, and decorated gaily with the roseate cockade, had their hands full to keep the passages clear, while the good-looking M.P.'s, who were just as good-natured and complaisant as they were on the night of the opening, were more than busy in preserving order.

abstract: New-York Post-office vs. Brooklyn Post-office
snippet: New-York Post-office vs. Brooklyn Post-office
lead_paragraph: The return game between the employes of the New-York and Brooklyn Post-offices, which was played at Bedford, on the Capitoline grounds, Tuesday afternoon, resulted in favor of the Brooklyn Club, on a score of 29 to 25. But seven innings were played, on account of the darkness, game being called on the eight inning, after the New-Yorkers had made eight runs, with two hands lost. All the play of the Brooklyn nine exhibited considerable knowledge of the game, particularly WAGGONER at first and DUNN at second. The New-Yorkers all did well, with the exception of DUSENBURY and YEOMAN. Quite a number of the attaches of the two post-offices were present with their lady friends, and when the game became tedious, they improvised another ball ground and had a muffin match, while the ladies, not to be outdone by their "mail" friends, had a quiet game of "croquet" all to themselves, which they seemed to enjoy hugely.

abstract: The new order for military reduction just issued by the Lieut-General, is of a sweeping character, and quite justifies the opinions of those who had thought that GRANT's designs for a permanent army were of the most moderate character. Two lines sweep out of the service all volunteer cavalry east of the Mississippi River. A short sentence provides for the garrisoning by colored troops of all sea-coast forts south of Fortress Monroe, with two exceptions, and orders the mustering out of all other colored troops as fast as they can be dispensed with. Other sections of the General Order make provision for the garrisoning of the Northern forts by small detachments of regular infantry or artillery. Nothing is said about the regiments of the Veteran Reserve Corps, from which it may be inferred that the Lieutenant-General is waiting until it shall be seen what action the forthcoming Congress will take in reference to the retention of that body.
lead_paragraph: The new order for military reduction just issued by the Lieut-General, is of a sweeping character, and quite justifies the opinions of those who had thought that GRANT's designs for a permanent army were of the most moderate character. A short sentence provides for the garrisoning by colored troops of all sea-coast forts south of Fortress Monroe, with two exceptions, and orders the mustering out of all other colored troops as fast as they can be dispensed with. Other sections of the General Order make provision for the garrisoning of the Northern forts by small detachments of regular infantry or artillery. Nothing is said about the regiments of the Veteran Reserve Corps, from which it may be inferred that the Lieutenant-General is waiting until it shall be seen what action the forthcoming Congress will take in reference to the retention of that body.

abstract: Frost's, J. W., Memento of
snippet: Frost's, J. W., Memento of
lead_paragraph: EIGHTH WARD DIVERSIONS. -- Late last evening a drunken dispute occurred between HENRY GERKEN and his mother, ANNA GERKEN, in her disreputable house on the southwest corner of Prince and Mercer streets, and in a scuffle young GERKEN's pistol, which was in his coat pocket, was discharged, and he was wounded in the left leg. Hearing the report, and not knowing whence it came, GERKEN drew his revolver and discharged it thrice at random, wounding his mother and one GEORGE HILLEN, a German, who keeps a grocery in the basement of the building. A bullet entered Mrs. GERKEN's nose, and, glancing off, lodged in her cheek. HILLEN also was wounded in the cheek. Policeman ANDREW P. TUTHILL, having been summoned, arrested the party and took them to the Eighth Precinct Police-station, where, after Dr. FRELIGH had dressed their wounds, GERKEN and HILLEN were committed for the night Capt. MILLS sent Mrs. GERKEN to the New-York Hospital. .In MARY ANN SHAW's brothel, in Greene-street, last evening, a youth who renders the name of HORATIO F. JONES, telegraph operator, quarreled with MARY ANN JOHNSON, one of the feminine boarders, and thrust her through one of the front windows. One of her legs was severely cut by the glass, but she sustained no other injury. Patrolman JOHN CROWN arrested JONES, and took him to the Wooster-street Police-station, and there the female's wound was dressed by Dr. FRELIGH.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. A spirited and excellent performance of "Martha" was enjoyed here last evening by a brilliant and overflowing audience. The cast was all that could be desired for this gay and graceful work. Miss KELLOGG is certainly a charming Martha. She invests the part with much vivacity, and sings the music with perfect facility.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A spirited and excellent performance of "Martha" was enjoyed here last evening by a brilliant and overflowing audience. The cast was all that could be desired for this gay and graceful work. Miss KELLOGG is certainly a charming Martha. She invests the part with much vivacity, and sings the music with perfect facility. Miss ADELAIDE PHILLIPS shares these qualities with her fair associate, and is altogether a better Nancy than we have had for several years. Signor I[???]FRE and Signor ANTONUCCI were both very good as Lionel and Plunkett. The performance indeed was smooth and well balanced in all respects. It gave complete satisfaction to the audience, and could, we think, be repeated to advantage.

abstract: Destitution at the
snippet: Destitution at the
lead_paragraph: A very general impression exists that the destitution of the South has been greatly exaggerated, and that there is much less suffering and want than was at first expected. This is probably partially true. In all those parts of the South which are easily accessible by sea or railroad, and in those through which the army has simply passed, without remaining for any length of time, the condition of affairs is better than had been anticipated; the crops are good, and the prospect is, that with, perhaps, some assistance in the way of clothing, seed and implements, the people will get along. But in the interior of the South, where trade has not yet penetrated, and especially in the track of SHERMAN's army, there are regions where the desolation almost surpasses belief, and where relief must be afforded either by government or by the charities of the North, or thousands must die of hunger and exposure. In an official report of Hon. E. ROOT, agent of the American Union Commission, he declares that on a trip from Chattanooga to Atlanta he did not see as much food growing as would be found on an ordinary Northern farm. And another correspondent from Savannah, writes of naked human beings in adjoining counties, curling down at the roots of their chimney stacks for shelter.
headline: {'main': 'Destitution in the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Destitution in the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Metropolitan Police Commissioners have been diligently employed nearly two months in securing proper polling places, and competent and trustworthy inspectors and canvassers of election. They have made selections for inspectors; but their list of canvassers is yet incomplete. A glance at the list, which the commissioners submit with a card below, will show that not a single poll is to be held in a liquor-store, and that very few dealers in liquors have been selected for election duty -- circumstance that was never before recorded of a New-York election. The following is the commissioners:

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Fire Commissioners, yesterday, the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company was awarded the contract of building ten new steam fire engines, those now in use not being strong enough to stand the wear and tear of the department. Jefferson Engine Company, No. 26, Washington Hook and Ladder, No. 9, and Crystal Hose, No. 35, were relieved from duty, and those members in good standing to be honorably discharged. Two new companies were organized, one to be known as No. 25, to be located in No. 148 East Fifth-street; the other as No. 12, to be placed in the house of Engine Company No. 13, in William-street.

abstract: Spangler's Letter from the Dry Tortugas
snippet: Spangler's Letter from the Dry Tortugas
lead_paragraph: The pathos of Mr. EDMAN SPANGLER's letter from Fort Jefferson, Tortugas Island, is relieved by touches of that humor which always lurks in the expression of deep feeling, and makes the wit's melancholy electric with laughter. This pleasant letter-writer, after giving some unknown friend an affecting sketch of life at the Dry Tortugas, (which is scarcely attractive in its general features,) protests his innocence of complicity with BOOTH in the murder of the President. In his quaint manner, he says: "He asked me to see to his horses, wich I did he said that he would make me a hansom present, wich he did, six years on the Hand of Dry Tortugas." After which follows more protestations of innocence, and a closing prayer for fish-hooks and postage stamps, that a guiltless sufferer may take fish from his prison window, and write letters to "inquiring friends."

abstract: Soldiers; what when let loose
snippet: Soldiers; what when let loose
lead_paragraph: Within the last few months we have seen that take place which Europeans so greatly dreaded in our interest -- the "turning loose" upon the country of seven or eight or nine hundred thousand men accustomed to the use of arms. It had been settled by our foreign friends, that this desperate men were to play havoc as soon as they were let loose. They were to put at their head some great chieftain or other, seize the reins of government, and give the wretched populace a taste of military rule. They were to inaugurate a reign of universal plunder, and establish war as a fixed institution.

abstract: Election; the Prospect of Success
snippet: Election; the Prospect of Success
lead_paragraph: There is every reason to hope and believe that New-Jersey is prepared, at last, to wheel into line and join the ranks of the Union army. Our friends have been making a gallant fight throughout the canvass, and with great confidence in their success. The extent to which the Democratic majority was reduced, in the election last Fall, the return of the soldiers, and the improved tone of public sentiment, led them to believe that a vigorous and steady effort, on the heels of the glorious victory over the rebellion, would place the State on the side of the Administration.

abstract: Abolition of Martial Law in
snippet: Abolition of Martial Law in
lead_paragraph: The President has settled the difficulty about military commanders in Kentucky, which has been the cause of such great uproar for a long time, by abolishing martial law in the State. It now makes but little difference whether Gen. PALMER or any other General is nominally in command; for the innumerable questions arising about slavery and negroes, about contumacious parsons, treasonable language, bilious graybacks, and so forth, will not come under military jurisdiction. Civil law and civil officers will henceforth be dominant, and whether or not they always operate with a prompitude and rigor equal to the military authorities, there is no doubt that they will act more to the public satisfaction, and more favorably to the restoration of of that contented and fraternal feeling which it is now President JOHNSON's great object to foster.

abstract: -- The ancient Grecians were noted for their agility, strength and great powers of endurance. The English women of the present time are celebrated for their robust and healthy appearance, the result, in both instances, of vigorous and healthy exercise. The Americans, unfortunately, have but little taste for this method of retaining their health or building up a broken constitution; hence the great prevalence of weak, sickly and delicate men and women. HOOFLAND's GERMAN BITTERS will in a great measure palliate this want of exercise, by giving great strength to the digestive organs: hence producing a good appetite and a vigorous feeling of body. A moderate degree of exercise, however, used in connection with the Bitters, is much better; the most desperate case of dyspepsia, liver complaint, nervous debility, yielding quickly to their beneficial influence. All druggists have these Bitters for sale. They contain no alcohol. -- Boston Post.

abstract: And his Sympathy with the Union Party
snippet: And his Sympathy with the Union Party
lead_paragraph: The insolence with which the Democratic leaders in this State claim the support of President JOHNSON is simply astounding. We are pretty well hardened to all sorts of misrepresentation at the hands of Democratic partisans, but this caps the climax. Without the slightest warrant in anything he has said or done, they coolly assume, and assure their followers, that President JOHNSON is about to turn his back upon the party which nominated and elected him, whose principles he cordially indorsed, who carried the war against rebellion to a successful close, and upon whom alone he can now depend for support, and take into his exclusive favor the party which has denounced him without measure all through the war, and from whom he has never received a vote or a voice in praise of his character or in support of his policy.
headline: {'main': 'The President and the Union Party', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The President and the Union Party', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A COMPLAINT THAT CANNOT BE SUSTAINED  is that of AUGUSTUS MEYER, of the Hoffman Hotel, at No. 47 Bowery, against CONSTANTINE LAMERGER, alleging that he is confederated with a band of highwaymen. MEYER, who until recently was a sutler ...
lead_paragraph: A COMPLAINT THAT CANNOT BE SUSTAINED is that of AUGUSTUS MEYER, of the Hoffman Hotel, at No. 47 Bowery, against CONSTANTINE LAMERGER, alleging that he is confederated with a band of highwaymen. MEYER, who until recently was a sutler, accompanied LAMERGER abroad, late on the night of the 11th inst., and when they had reached the intersection of Hester and Chrystie streets, a gang of unknown highwaymen sprang upon MEYER, pinioned and gagged him, and robbed him of a wallet containing $1,500. The robbery having been effected, the outlaws and LAMERGER disappeared simultaneously. Subsequently he was apprehended by Policeman P[???]LEY LYONS, and Justice MANSFIELD committed him for examination....On Friday evening the Justice was called upon to act on another

abstract: An accident happened to the day express train going east, between here and Lancaster, this afternoon. Four cars were thrown from the track. Eight persons were killed, and two slightly injured. The only one of the dead recognized up to this time is the wife of J.P. BARR, Esq., of Pittsburgh. The accident was occasioned by a broken rail.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURGH, Penn., Saturday, Oct. 14.

abstract: Fashion in Dress
snippet: Fashion in Dress
lead_paragraph: According to the Bible, the dispensation of the necessity for dross was the first penalty human beings suffered for the crime of disobedience. But, it must be confessed, that is no reason why people should be so foolish as to be continually adding to the evils of the infliction by constantly devising new plans of their own by which to increase and develop the full force of their proper punishment. In order to prove this latter statement, it is only necessary to point to the costumes of the ancients as evidences of the world's degeneration in this matter. It is considered a very bold act in a sculptor to dare to chisel a modern hero or philosopher in the garments now commonly worn; in most cases, the artist prefers to envelop the bust or figure on which he is engaged in the more chaste and easy attire of the ancients. Judgment, therefore, is given against us, we ourselves sitting as the court, and rendering the decisions.

abstract: -- Delicate feeling, we are pleased to learn from Bell's Life in London, is not absent from any rank or calling in England, and is known to the champions of the Prize Ring as well as those who would be prone to deny it to them. The fight for the English Championship, which was lately to have taken place, is now indefinitely deferred, through the illness of Mr. JOSEPH WORMALD, one of the contestants of the belt. Mr. WORMALD, in practicing with the dumb-bells, strained his arm in such a manner as to produce inflammation of the periosteum, and he is therefore unable to take part in the fight. He has called on the editor of Bell's Life to state his inability, and we are assured that:

abstract: Yesterday Manhattan Engine Company, No. 8, composed of eighty numbers, left this city for Philadelphia, in order to participate in the firemen's parade that will take place there to-morrow. They take with them their own engine, which was built at the Novelty Works, and has now been in active service nearly ten years. It is worthy of record that Manhattan Engine Company were the first to use steam fire engines in this city. New-York will also be represented by the following companies: The members of Americus Engine Company, No. 6, with double-deck hand engine; the members of Live Oak Engine Company, No. 44, take with their engine eighty men; the New-York Association of Exempts, with the engine of company No. 22, of Brooklyn; Hose Company No. 30, with a band of music; Nos. 23 and 41, with their apparatus. During their stay in Philadelphia they will be the guests of Hope Hose and Steam Fire Engine Company No. 2, who have invited companies from Pittsburgh, Huntington, Harrisburgh and Lancaster to receive them. On returning to this city on Wednesday a dinner will be given to the returning firemen at the City Assembly Rooms. Boston also participates in the parade, Engine Company No. 4 and the William Penn Company now being en route for the Quaker City.

abstract: RAIN. -- An Autumnal storm worked its way up the Atlantic Coast yesterday, and was in full operation here at midnight. It was greatly needed; there has been no rain of consequence for many weeks: the country, particularly in the Eastern States, has been parched beyond anything known for years; crops, of course, are safe, but pasturage has been burned up, wells are dry, and streams that may ordinarily be depended upon have disappeared. The patter of the big drops, as we write, makes merry music, and we hope the supply will continue until the streams again flow and the pastures once more smile in their rich green verdure.
lead_paragraph: RAIN. -- An Autumnal storm worked its way up the Atlantic Coast yesterday, and was in full operation here at midnight. abstract: We have lately read in a newspaper of the city of the great organ, some praise of the Mayor of a town near Boston, whom we should like to hold up to undying reproach if we could remember his name or the name of his municipal dominion. It is found laudable in this officer that he has instructed his policemen to break up lounging at the street-corners, to order loiterers to move on, and to arrest them in case of refusal. The rigid course to be thus pursued will soon, it is believed, rid the town -- we think it is Chelsea -- of loafers, and will destroy loafing in Chelsea's dismal streets. Everybody there must go to work, or go indoors, and seem to be at work. If the reader should happen to be in Chelsea, and should happen to be yawning in the dullness of his soul at the street-corner, let him be warned that he is indulging in a criminal relaxation. If two of our readers should happen -- which Heaven forbid -- to stop and greet each other on the public way in Chelsea, let them beware of arrest by the most senseless and fit men of the place, acting under the orders of the most preposterous Dogberry ever born.

abstract: Influences of on Reconstrucstruction
snippet: Influences of on Reconstrucstruction
lead_paragraph: Nothing is more certain than that the overwhelming popular majorities given last November for President LINCOLN had an immense influence in hastening the downfall of the rebellion. This exhibition of Northern determination struck discouragement into the rebel heart. The rebel armies showed it in multiplied desertions, and in the loss of all their old fighting temper. The rebel Congress showed it in the new hesitation and bewilderment which entered its councils. The people at large showed it in more bitter complaints of the Richmond rule, and in a more respectful, half-submissive style of speech toward the old government. The suddenness with which the South, after the surrender of LEE, changed from rebellion to loyalty, has excited much surprise, but it was more apparent than real. The change was, for the most part, a gradual one. The five months which elapsed between the reelection of President LINCOLN and the laying down of the rebel arms, was but a period of preparation to the Southern heart for the inevitable event. The necessity of going back to the old allegiance became a familiar Southern thought long before the firing between the armies ceased, and when the peace came it required no mental struggle for the Southern people to adapt themselves to it. The real breaking down of the rebel spirit was accomplished by the great political struggle of the North in November.
headline: {'main': 'The Moral Influence of the Fall Elections upon Reconstruction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Moral Influence of the Fall Elections upon Reconstruction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We begin to have hopes that the WIRZ trial will be ended this year. As we understand the report, the evidence has closed on both sides. There was another struggle, yesterday, between Mr. BAKER, counsel for the prisoner, and the Court, upon technical points merely, and for a time there was a wordy hurricane. The Court finally cooled the counsel down by threatening to eject him from the room. No testimony of importance was put in. The arguments, summing up. &c., are to be in writing. The prosecution is ready to go on in 24 hours, but WIRZ's persistent counsel insisted upon two weeks' time, and the court adjourned until the 26th inst.

abstract: FAIR FOR THE SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS, HOME. The Ladies' Visiting Committee of the Soldiers' Home, in the City of Philadelphia, propose to open a National Fair at the Academy of Music, on the 23d day of October next, for the purpose of raising a building and endowment fund for the institution with which they are connected. The Soldiers' Home has been ...
lead_paragraph: FAIR FOR THE SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' HOME. -- The Ladies' Visiting Committee of the Soldiers' Home, in the City of Philadelphia, propose to open a National Fair at the Academy of Music, on the 23d day of October next, for the purpose of raising a building and endowment fund for the institution with which they are connected. The Soldiers' Home has been incorporated by the State of Pennsylvania, for the relief of soldiers and seamen who have been honorably discharged from, and the children of those who have died in the service of the country. The Cooper-shop Soldiers' Home has been merged in this institution by legislative authority, and is now in successful operation, but as the building now occupied, at the corner of Race and Crown streets, is entirely inadequate to the necessities of the Home, the managers have given their sanction to the proposed fair. Although the Home is located in Philadelphia, its benefactions are not limited by State boundaries. Its doors are freely opened to every deserving soldier and sailor of the republic who seeks admission. The management contemplates an Industrial Department in the institution, in which the inmates who are able to work at their trades may find employment, and thus be relieved from the position of mere dependants on public charity. It contemplates also a department where children of those who have died in the service will be tenderly protected and carefully educated and prepared for suitable vocations. Donations in money for the fair may be sent to WILLIAM STRUTHERS, Treasurer, No. 1,022 Market-street. Donations in goods, provisions, &c., may be sent to the Soldiers' Home, corner of Race and Crown streets, Philadelphia, marked to care of Mrs. D. HADDOCK, Jr., President, or Mrs. J. HORNER, Secretary.

lead_paragraph: A safe of the Erie Railroad Company, in use by one of their paymasters at Port Jervis, was opened on the 11th inst., and $20,000 in currency abstracted therefrom. Over $14,000 of the amount was yesterday morning found buried on premises near by, and such information has been obtained as to justify the hope that the whole will be recovered and the thieves arrested.

abstract: The public are requested to be upon their guard in regard to a swindling operation which now is being extensively practiced. The operation is as follows: a person representing himself as a messenger from the American Telegraph Company will call at the residence of some merchant, lawyer, or other citizen, and ask if he is in, and if the messenger is informed that he is not in or is not at home, the messenger then asks for the lady of the house, and hands her a message purporting to be for her husband. The messenger informing her that there is two, three or four dollars to collect on the message, and as the swindler has the appearance of a regular telegraph messenger, she generally pays him the amount.
lead_paragraph: The public are requested to be upon their guard in regard to a swindling operation which now is being extensively practiced. The operation is as follows: a person representing himself as a messenger from the American Telegraph Company will call at the residence of some merchant, lawyer, or other citizen, and ask if he is in, and if the messenger is informed that he is not in or is not at home, the messenger then asks for the lady of the house, and hands her a message purporting to be for her husband. The messenger informing her that there is two, three or four dollars to collect on the message, and as the swindler has the appearance of a regular telegraph messenger, she generally pays him the amount.
headline: {'main': 'Telegraph Swindlers at Large Look out for Them.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Telegraph Swindlers at Large Look out for Them.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Travelers and Artists in Europe; American Artists in Europe
snippet: Travelers and Artists in Europe; American Artists in Europe
lead_paragraph: According to all reports, the continent of Europe is just now flooded with American tourists. As a general rule, the American visits the continent to get rid of his money; the Englishman, to save it. It is quite certain at least that the former, on his European travels, is recognized by the people as a man who has money to spend; and, firmly convinced of the essential truthfulness of this notion, we propose to draw from our own observation and experience while " abroad," a suggestion to our countrymen in behalf of that noble band of ladies and gentlemen who, under more or less of pecuniary difficulties:, are always to be found engaged in the study and practice of art in the schools and galleries of the Old World.
headline: {'main': 'American Travelers and American Artists in Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'American Travelers and American Artists in Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: CASUALTY ON THE MORRIS AND ESSEX RAILROAD. -- Shortly before 8 o'clock yesterday morning, as a train of cars was crossing the meadows back of Hudson City, a heavily laden wagon, drawn by three horses, was struck at the turnpike crossing. The wagon and contents were scattered in all directions, the driver fatally injured, and two of the horses were instantly killed. The train was stopped, and the injured man, who was in the employ oi Mr. KINGSLAND, paper manufacturer, was taken to OSCAR SANFORD's hotel, where everything possible was done for him, but he survived only a short time. The name of the deceased could not be ascertained.
