abstract: On Friday night a party of Irishmen tarried late over their cups in PETER MATTHEWS' bar-room, at No. 9 James-slip, a place which is familiarly known as Slaughter-house Point, and at about 3 o,clock yesterday morning, the company having drunk themselves into fighting humor, the subject of Fenianism was introduced. The topic was discussed with considerable ...
lead_paragraph: On Friday night a party of Irishmen tarried late over their cups in PETER MATTHEWS' bar-room, at No. 9 James-slip, a place which is familiarly known as Slaughter-house Point, and at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, the company having drunk themselves into fighting humor, the subject of Fenianism was introduced. The topic was discussed with considerable warmth, and at length FLORENCE MCCARTHY, of No. 45 Oak-street, demonstratively said that every Fenian ought to be drowned. Whereupon one DENNIS FOLLY sprang upon MCCARTHY with a knife and stabbed him twice, inflicting a severe gash on his left wrist and ripping open his abdomen. This occurrence somewhat sobered the revelers, and they called in Patrolman FERNES, and he at once took FOLLY to the Oak-street Police-station. MCCARTHY was removed to his abode, and there his wounds were dressed by Dr. CONWAY; but later in the day, there being [???] that the [???] might result fatally, [???] was summoned to take the sufferer's [???], which is as follows: "My name is Florence McCarthy; I am a native of Massachusetts, 29 years of age; at about three o'clock this morning I was at the [???] of [???] and Water-street, in a porter[???] by [???]; with a number of [???] I was [???] a bench; [???], the [???], was standing in front of me; I saw him [???] knife [???] then [???] to get away [???], but [???] could he [???] in the left [???] and on my left wrist; I had neither done nor said anything to [???]perate him, except, when joking about the Fenian Brotherhood, I remarked, in just, that they all ought to be drowned; he then stabbed me." Previous to committing FOLEY to the Tombs, Coroner WILLEY took his statement, as follows: "I dwell at No. [???] Water-street, am a native of Ireland, 38 years of age, and am a laborer; I went into the bar-room with a friend to get a drink, when McCarthy [???] me twice, and to defend myself I cut him."

abstract: Abolitionism, British; Dr. McLeod on
snippet: Abolitionism, British; Dr. McLeod on
lead_paragraph: -- For many years our friends on the other side of the water -- particularly our English friends -- have been painfully exercised about American slavery. They never wearied of drawing the contrast between our sordid attachment to the proscribed institution and the national magnanimity which had "redeemed, regenerated and disenthralled" all British soil by the touch of the "genius of emancipation." When the civil war broke out here, they were as strongly opposed to slavery as we, but then they sympathized with the slaveholders, because the institution was not involved in the contest; or, if it was, the Federal Government would never abolish it; or, if they should, it would be done from very worldly and selfish motives. When, at last, the great work was accomplished, where was the joy, the enthusiasm of English philanthropy, which had never wearied of bragging to the very echo of the liberation of half a million slates in the West Indies, over the unconditional emancipation of four millions of bondmen in the United States? We catch scarcely a lisp of congratulation, aside from the utterances of the enlightened few who have comprehended, from the first, the deep significance of our struggle. The majority silently and sullenly accept the glorious result as men who see in it only the falsification of their own prophecies, and the defeat of their own party.
headline: {'main': 'ENGLISH ABOLITIONISM.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ENGLISH ABOLITIONISM.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In continuation of the attractions at the Fair of the American Institute, the managers introduced last night a novel, unique, and not altogether pleasant feature. The advertisement of men wares is not, we take it, the end and aim of these exhibitions, and yet one finds that a fair and candid criticism of this, that or the other article, is instantly met with the objection that the exhibitor "won't like it." Very He rely he won't; if he wont, that's his misfortune; if he does, that's his good luck. The late war, with all its train of blessings, was not exactly an occurrence to be hankered after, and among the many evils resulting to individuals therefrom, the loss of life or limb is most prominent.

abstract: The success of such a paper as the Nation is one of the most gratifying signs of the times. It has now been before the public fourteen weeks, and in the last number we are assured that no such reception has ever been accorded in this country to any weekly paper, not pictorial, as the Nation has received. We do not believe this is an exaggerated statement. Certainly the paper deserves all the success which it seems to have met. Modeled after the best English weeklies, it maintains the high tone which distinguishes them, and in comprehensiveness of thought, earnestness of purpose and ability of discussion it is in no ways inferior to them. It is an organ of the most advanced thought, and its discussions, as temperate as they are luminous and forcible, are of the utmost value at this particular epoch of our history. We must not omit to speak of the literary department of the paper. The criticisms are characterized by great conscientiousness and rich scholarship. Unlike the criticism which has too long been in vogue in this country, that in which the Nation indulges is just and candid, severe when severity is demanded, and commendatory when commendation is fairly earned. It cannot fail to have an excellent influence on our literature, which has so long needed something of the kind. Altogether the Nation is a paper which we can heartily commend to those who love thoughtful discussions, and which, typographically, is worthy to be placed upon any table. -Albany Express.

abstract: If our Park be fast losing the fullness of those charms of flower and foliage it boasted in the Summer months, it can scarcely be said to look less beautiful in its Autumn drapery. True, we miss the balmy breath of honeysuckle and of heliotrope from rocky slopes and sunlit borders, and the modest fragrance of the violets as we linger in the shady places, but the air is soft and cool, and we revel in the genial breeze, laden but one short month ago with the hot vapors of the South. We miss the rainbow beauty of the Bridge of Flowers, and of the vases on the terrace, but the vines, trailing along the parapets or upon the rocks, are beautiful in decay, seeming to have borrowed for their dying hours the rarest tints of those that have passed away.
lead_paragraph: If our Park be fast losing the fullness of those charms of flower and foliage it boasted in the Summer months, it can scarcely be said to look less beautiful in its Autumn drapery. abstract: Registry of Voters in Person
snippet: Registry of Voters in Person
lead_paragraph: We call the attention of every voter to the absolute necessity of registering his name at the poll where he expects to vote. The law of last Winter makes this imperative. No man can vote on election day whose name has not been registered previously; and this must be done, in every case, by the voter in person. Old registers are of no avail nor can any other person have your name registered. You must attend to it yourself, if you expect to vote. This may seem a stringent law, but it was necessary for the prevention of fraud. To-morrow is the day for registering.

abstract: Protestant Episcopal Convention on national affairs
snippet: Protestant Episcopal Convention on national affairs
lead_paragraph: The warm discussion which took place on Saturday, in the Episcopal Convention, shows how little of the political element, introduced into such a body, it takes to stir up a keen party division. Up to the day named, the proceedings of the convention had been characterized by unusual harmony -unusual for an ecclesiastical assembly. The sectional division of the Church, which dated from the beginning of the civil insurrection, seemed to have been fairly in the way of being healed by mutual forbearance. And this conciliatory temper in the earlier sessions of the convention may have been only temporarily banished by Saturday's discussion. It is, nevertheless, perfectly manifest by the tenor and the result of that discussion, that much more has to be forborne by the members, lay and clerical, of the Episcopal Church, than they had anticipated in restoring a healthy and perfect union between the Northern and Southern branch of the Church. The naming of a day of thanksgiving for the general mercies of Providence might have been supposed to be the question of all others least likely to evoke discordant views. And yet, the simple fact of a Northern member's proposing that the observances of the day should include a common expression of thankfulness on the part of the Church for a restored Union, was regarded as a brand of discord. And a pacific solution of the difficulty was only reached by a majority consenting to lay the resolution aside.

abstract: The matinee on Saturday brought another operatic week to a successful termination. Mr. MARETZEK has now deployed all his artists, with the exception of the new basso, who is yet to be heard. The old operas have been received with remarkable favor, and the new singers, with a single exception, have fully come up to the public expectation. The manager now feels himself at liberty to announce a novelty. On Monday, then, we are to have FRICCI's opera of "Crispino e la Comare," a thoroughly charming and delightful work, which we are sure will please. It was written many years ago, enjoyed a brief success in Italy, slept the sleep of death for a generation, was then resuscitated by the Paris opera, and is at this moment more popular than any other comic opera of the Italian repertoire. Its new career indeed, has been marked by every kind of enthusiasm. Mr. MARETZEK has all the artists needed for the work, and the cast will be quito equal to any it has heretofore enjoyed. To-night at the Academy, VERDI's "La Traviata" will be given with Mme. ZUCCHI, Signor MAZZOLENI, and Signor BELLINI in the principal roles.

abstract: A very large and enthusiastic meeting in behalf of the Union candidate for Governor, was held at the above place on Saturday afternoon. Between 4,000 and 5,000 people were assembled. The speakers for the occasion left New-York on the 1:15 o'clock train, and were met at Englewood by several Union...
lead_paragraph: A very large and enthusiastic meeting in behalf of the Union candidate for Governor, was held at the above place on Saturday afternoon. Between 4,000 and 5,000 people were assembled. The speakers for the occasion left New-York on the 1:15 o'clock train, and were met at Englewood by several Union delegations from the surrounding country, including the Fort Lee and Spring Valley Union Clubs. From the depot the whole party proceeded in a grand procession, composed of a long line of equestrians, carriages, wagons and vehicles of every description, followed by a large number on foot, to a platform capable of accommodating several hundred, which was erected about a quarter of a mile from the depot, in the open fields; here the procession halted, and the speakers, including Gens. KILPATRICK and SMITH, Cols. VAN BUREN and JARDINE, Maj. PANGBORN, A.W. TENNY, Esq., and others, were greeted with vociferous cheers. The meeting was then opened by the nomination of THOS. H. HERRING, Esq., as Chairman, who addressed the audience in a few appropriate remarks, after which the Union Glee Club of this city entertained the audience with one of their favorite airs.

abstract: We see it announced that JOHN VAN BUREN is to speak at the Democratic ratification in this city. Will he not oblige us, if it is not too much trouble, by completing his account of the private conversation which he had with Hon. Mr. DEPEW just before the Syracuse Convention. He told us what Mr. DEPEW said about the election, and Gen. BARLOW and Gov. SEYMOUR. It was very interesting; but the public would be very glad to know also what Mr. VAN BUREN himself said. Will he now indulge us?

abstract: Downing-st., Senior's Coffin Factory--$15,000; Erie R. Clerk, A. A. Jones, Arrested
snippet: Downing-st., Senior's Coffin Factory--$15,000; Erie R. Clerk, A. A. Jones, Arrested
lead_paragraph: COFFIN MANUFACTORY DESTROYED. -- Between 5 and 6 o'clock on Saturday evening, fire was discovered on the second-story of Mr. EDWARD H. SENIOR'S coffin manufactory, at No. 57 Downing-street, and before the bells struck the alarm, the flames had enveloped the entire second story. This delay in calling out the firemen is said to have been occasioned by an alarm just at that time for a fire in Mr. FALKEN METER's looking-glass-frame manufactory, at No. 171 Suffolk-street. The fire had enveloped the coffin manufactory before the firemen had unlimbered their hose and they therefore turned their attention to saving surrounding property. In this they succeeded. Mr. SENIOR's loss is estimated at $15,000. He has $3,300 insurance on stock and $2,000 on the building, in the Greenwich office. No. 59 Dowing-street, owned by Mr. SENIOR, and occupied by Mrs. MARY BARRON, was slightly damaged by fire and water. The building is insured for $2,000 by the Irving Company, and Mrs. BARRON has $4,000 insurance on her furniture, in the Peter Cooper office. Mr. R. SOMERVILLE, of No. 61 Downing-street, sustained trivial loss from damage by water. Mrs. DOUGLAS, Mrs. BRADY, Mr. MCCLOSKEY Mr. McAvoy, and Mr. WOLF, occupants of Nos. 76 and 78 Carmine-street, also lost something from dam age by water and breakage of furniture in moving. The Sixth-avenue cars, which, it appears, have no bridges to cover the firemen's hose on their track, were stopped two hours.

abstract: The usual Saturday night murder was committed at about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, JOHN RAMMING, of No. 372 Hudson-street, keeper of a lagerbier saloon, having been stabbed in the right eye by one AUGUST BUCKLEY. RAMMING lived about half an hour after receiving the wound. BUCKLEY escaped, Officer EDWARD BARBELET, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, arrested MATHIAS CONNELLY, HUGH McNELLIS, ROBERT BROWN and ROBERT ANDERSON, and they...
lead_paragraph: The usual Saturday night murder was committed at about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, JOHN RAMMING, of No. 372 Hudson-street, keeper of a lagerbier saloon, having been stabbed in the right eye by one AUGUST BUCKLEY. RAMMING lived about half an hour after receiving the wound. BUCKLEY escaped, Officer EDWARD BARBELET, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, arrested MATHIAS CONNELLY, HUGH McNELLIS, ROBERT BROWN and ROBERT ANDERSON, and they were committed, by Capt. DICKSON, to the cells in the Greenwich-street Police-station, to await the result of the inquest which Coroner COLLIN is to hold at 2 o'clock this afternoon. BUCKLEY, who has sometimes passed under the name of Hutchings, was until recently a Lieutenant in the Fifteenth New-York Volunteers.

abstract: Rumor has it that another comic paper is to be started in this city, and that on immense capital has been secured to sustain it. Various names have been suggested: "The Cynic," "The Idiot," "Baalam's Ass," and "The Goose," are some of them. Perhaps the christening may be put up for public competition. If so, let the publisher beware of the fate of "Vanity Fair." That title was the result of a $50 premium, and was forced upon the unwilling proprietor by the clique of subterranean literary undertakers whose pens speedily dug the grave of that ambitious funny thing. The poor publisher got not only the name but the whole Admiration Society with it; they settled upon him like musquitoes in Jersey upon a white stranger, and never let up as long as he could bleed for even twenty-five cents per joke. Starting a comic paper is very serious business, and the projectors ought to military among the tombs of "John Donkey," "Yankee Doodle," "Vanity Fair," "Picayune," "Mrs. Grundy," and others of the loved and lost before making their desperate venture.

abstract: -- The most intelligent and thoughtful men of the South are already taking steps to promote immigration into the Southern States. We have already referred to several letters and speeches made upon this subject, and we published in yesterday's TIMES a careful and interesting letter from J.D. DE Bow, Esq., in regard to it. He addresses it to Gov. PERRY, of South Carolina. He reminds him that a lack in the requisite supply of labor has long been regarded in South Carolina as the principal reason of her want of progress in material development, and says it was a conviction of this which led some of her public men to desire, from time to time, the reopening of the slave trade. The same evil is likely now to be much more severely felt, and he advocates a resort to white immigration as the proper means to meet it. He says the abolition of slavery will be accepted as final in South Carolina, and the Legislature will make laws, as rapidly as possible, for the "social, physical and political advancement" of the freedmen. He thinks the experiment of emancipation will work much better than many believe, -still there must be a transition period, during which efforts must be made to increase their supply of labor.
lead_paragraph: -- The most intelligent and thoughtful men of the South are already taking steps to promote immigration into the Southern States. He addresses it to Gov. PERRY, of South Carolina. The same evil is likely now to be much more severely felt, and he advocates a resort to white immigration as the proper means to meet it. He says the abolition of slavery will be accepted as final in South Carolina, and the Legislature will make laws, as rapidly as possible, for the "social, physical and political advancement" of the freedmen. He thinks the experiment of emancipation will work much better than many believe, -still there must be a transition period, during which efforts must be made to increase their supply of labor.

abstract: Coalition--Tammany and the Wood Faction; Reply to Herald and Express on Coalition with Fernando Wood
snippet: Coalition--Tammany and the Wood Faction; Reply to Herald and Express on Coalition with Fernando Wood
lead_paragraph: It begins to be pretty clear that the purpose of the Democrats in their Albany movement was to regain power and office in this State, at whatever cost of principle. The professedly loyal portion of the party very unceremoniously kicked out of the convention everybody who seemed likely to oppose its action. The McKeon delegates went first, and then the Mozarters: and Tammany Hall pointed triumphantly to this achievement as proof that the character of the party had been restored.

abstract: Railroad Law on Licenses of Cars
snippet: Railroad Law on Licenses of Cars
lead_paragraph: Capt. CHARLES N. BRACKETT, of the City Hall Police, having resolved to enforce corporation ordinances so far as lay in his power, has compelled more than four thousand owners and drivers of carts, trucks, express wagons, , to take out the required license within a month past. He recently notified the Presidents of the city railroads that not only must they pay a license fee of fifty dollars annually for every car in use on their respective roads, but that their conductors as well must walk up to the Mayor's office and take out the necessary papers. But certain of the railway Presidents have informed the Captain that they procured the passage of an act, last Winter, exempting them from the require inputs of the corporation ordinance in relation to conductors and drivers, and they triumphantly quoted the act, as follows:

abstract: Our Washington correspondent says: "The last disgraceful scene in the WIRZ trial took place yesterday. Mr. BAKER, the prisoner's counsel, an obsceue pettifogger, who foisted himself into the case for personal notoriety, was all but ejected from the court for his contumacious conduct. It was not until a motion to pitch him out had been made and seconded that he subsided. The evidence was then closed...
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent says: "The last disgraceful scene in the WIRZ trial took place yesterday. Mr. BAKER, the prisoner's counsel, an obsceue pettifogger, who foisted himself into the case for personal notoriety, was all but ejected from the court for his contumacious conduct. It was not until a motion to pitch him out had been made and seconded that he subsided. The evidence was then closed and BAKER demanded two weeks in which to prepare his argument. The Court first offered him ten days, and then twelve, both of which he refused, and the Judge-Advocate was then requested to prepare the argument for both sides, and announced that he would be in readiness to do so on Wednesday next, to which day the court adjourned."

abstract: The Nova Scotian, from Liverpool Oct. 5, arrived off Father Point yesterday, bringing five days' later intelligence. American securities had experienced a slight decline, Five-twenties selling at 69 1/2@70. The publication in American papers of the list of subscribers to the rebel loan produced an immense excitement in England. The London Times emphatically denies that any of its editors held any of that stock, and Mr. GLADSTONE requests that his name be removed from the list, as he had nothing to do with it. Mr. DONALD MCKAY is still endeavoring to demonstrate to the Lords of the Admiralty the utility of American torpedoes as a means of defending harbors.

abstract: Army >amp; Navy Journal, Vol. 2
snippet: Army >amp; Navy Journal, Vol. 2
lead_paragraph: The second volume of this important weekly journal is now ready, and comprises the issues for twelve months, ending with August last, bound in handsome style. The proprietors of the Army and Navy Journal, in commencing the publication of their paper two years ago, sought to supply what hitherto we had been without -- an organ devoted to the military and naval history and organizations of the United States. That they have fully succeeded, the great mass of material in the volume before us amply proves. There will be found in it a full record of the progress of the war during the period covered by the volume, together with all the important official reports, lists of promotions, discussions upon the various appliances and methods of war, editorial comments upon the various naval and military questions of the day, and a great mass of information for the use of professional and non-professional readers. A compact index is a valuable addition to the work. The Journal deserves the confidence and support of all connected with both military and naval branches of the service, and of the public generally, as an able and faithful representative of our nations defenders.

abstract: Charges
snippet: Charges
lead_paragraph: -- Is it not about time that something was done to popularize the telegraph? The prices charged for the use of it are perfectly outrageous. On the continent of Europe one can send a message across the whole breadth of France for a singe franc, (twenty cents,) while the shortest dispatch from Albany to New-York costs fifty cents. There is no excuse for this. It is the most profitable business in the country. All the lines are making enormous dividends, upon a capital three, five and ten times the cost of the lines. There is no reason why the public should pay such outrageous prices for the service. The cost of working a telegraph is very small, compared with a railroad or anything else, yet the charges in proportion are much higher. This matter is beginning to command a good deal of public attention, and will command more unless a remedy be speedily applied.
headline: {'main': 'TELEGRAPH CHARGES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'TELEGRAPH CHARGES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Pennsylvania election returns
snippet: Pennsylvania election returns
lead_paragraph: -- The sudden subsidence of Democratic exultation over the late elections is very easily accounted for. Their principal organ here had prophesied and worked so persistently for disorganization in the Union ranks that the editors really believed in such a state of facts. Anticipating an easy victory in Pennsylvania, the scream of triumph was written, if not in type, on the night of election; but the late telegrams plainly indicated a Union victory, and the exultant "leader" gave way for a paragraph of the most ludicrous muddiness. Next day the result, by Democratic measurement, was "doubtful." Next day came a prolonged whistle of incredulity, and finally the blustering and bragging settled down into the modest admission -- "Of course, we expected the Republicans would carry the State; but how cruelly their majority is cut down." It is just possible that we can stand a good deal of such cutting down. We have a majority considerably exceeding that of last November for President LINCOLN; we have very largely increased our strength in both branches of the Legislature, and we have made absolute gains in strength in 38 out of 42 counties so far officially reported. And this is upon a largely diminished vote, so that the per centage of gain is much greater than the numerical gain. Will the Democratic journals please print the returns side by side with those for 1862 and 1864?
headline: {'main': 'THE PENNSYLVANIA ELECTION RETURNS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE PENNSYLVANIA ELECTION RETURNS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Hamman, H., Murdered at His Bar in Hudson-street
snippet: Hamman, H., Murdered at His Bar in Hudson-street
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night a party of Eighth-warders played and drank until a late hour in REHM & RAMMING's lager-bier saloon, at No. 372 Hudson-street, and at midnight the bar-keeper, HENRY HAMMAN, wishing to close the place, requested them to depart. At this they became boisterous, and swore that they would finish their game if it took until daybreak, threatening violence to the landlord and bar-keeper, meantime, if they attempted any interference. HAMMAN, anticipating trouble, went to the street and notified Policeman EDWARD BARBELET, the officer on that post, that his services might be needed in the saloon and the officer accordingly kept an eye on the place. The game went on until between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning, and then, a dispute having risen between RAMMING and the players, one of the gang sprang upon him while he was drawing beer behind the bar, and before any person could stay the ruffiian's hand he had inflicted four stabs on RAMMING, one of them a deep and mortal wound in the right eye. The fellow immediately fled, and is still at large. He is, however, well known by the police. At the time of the assault. Officer BARBELET was nearly a block distant; but he reached the saloon before the entire party had effected their escape, and having taken four of their number into custody, he sent for a physician. Dr. A.J. CHADSEY, of No. 288 Spring-street, responded to the summons; but when he arrived the wounded man was breathing his last. RAMMING lived about half an hour after the stabbing; but he was unable to articulate. His partner, however, who was in the saloon at the time of the attack, says that the assault was unprovoked, and that one AUGUST BUCKLEY struck the fatal blow with a large pocket knife. Officer BARBELET's four prisoners, whose names are MATTHIAS CONNELLY, HUGH MCNELLIS, ROBERT BROWN and ROBERT ANDERSON, were committed to cells in the Greenwich-street Station-house, and held to await the orders of Coroner COLLIN. The Coroner impanneled a jury yesterday afternoon, but deemed it prudent to postpone the inquest until 2 o'clock this afternoon. A post-mortem investigation was made by Dr. THOMAS ROBINSON, and four wounds were discovered on the right side of the face; the wound in the right eye was ascertained to be three inches in depth, and at the extreme point which the blade touched the Doctor found pieces of bone from the skull. RAMMING dwelt at No. 9 Carmine-street. He was a native of Germany, aged about 40 years.

abstract: McCarthy, F., Stabbed by D Foley in James-ship Bar-room
snippet: McCarthy, F., Stabbed by D Foley in James-ship Bar-room
lead_paragraph: On Friday night a party of Irishmen tarried late over their cups in PETER MATTHEWS' bar-room, at No. 9 James-slip, a place which is familiarly known as Slaughter-house Point, and at about 3 o'clock Saturday morning, the company having drunk themselves into fighting humor, the subject of Fenianism was introduced. The topic was discussed with considerable warmth, and at length FLORENCE MCCARTHY, of No. 45 Oak-street, demonstratively said that every Fenian ought to be drowned. Whereupon one DENNIS FOLEY sprang upon MCCARTHY with a knife and stabbed him twice, inflicting a severe gash on his left wrist and ripping open his abdomen. This occurrence somewhat sobered the revelers, and they called in Patrolman BYRNES, and he at once took FOLEY to the Oak-street Police-station. MCCARTHY was removed to his abode, and there his wounds were dressed by Dr. CONWAY; but later in the day, there being fears that the abdomen stab might result fatally, Coroner WILDEY was summoned to take the sufferer's deposition, which is as follows: "My name is Florence McCarthy; I am a native of Massachusetts, 29 years of age; at about three o'clock this morning I was at the corner of James-slip and Water-street, in a porter-house kept by Peter Matthews; with a number of others I was sitting on a bench; Dennis Foley, the prisoner, was standing in front of me; I saw him opening a knife in his pantaloons pocket; I rose then and tried to get away from him, but before I could he cut me in the left side and on my left wrist; I had neither done nor said anything to exasperate him, except, when joking about the Fenian Brotherhood, I remarked, in jest, that they all ought to be drowned; he then stabbed me." Previous to committing FOLEY to the Tombs, Coroner WILDEY took his statement, as follows: "I dwell at No. 341 Water-street, am a native of Ireland, 38 years of age, and am a laborer; I went into the bar-room with a friend to get a drink, when McCarthy hit me twice, and to defend myself I cut him."

abstract: Speech at Fort Wayne on National Finances
snippet: Speech at Fort Wayne on National Finances
lead_paragraph: The speech of Secretary McCULLOCH to his old neighbors at Fort Wayne will attract the attention due to the important financial position which this gentleman occupies. We believe it will be well received throughout the country. It should give renewed assurance to all conservative and prudent people that the blame will not be with the Administration at Washington if our finances are not gradually but surely consolidated, and the currency improved without panic or expansion in any direction. It is already sufficiently evident that Mr. MCCULLOCH is not a finance minister of extremes either way. The sudden close of the war surrounded his movements through the Spring and Summer with embarrassments and anxieties. The former related not to the ability, but the readiest and least costly means of raising a very large amount of money; the latter to the importance and duty of paying off our vast armies and navies before, or as soon, as they could be reduced to the peace establishment and were disbanded. The appropriations to the united service designed for six months or a year, were suddenly crowded into a few weeks, and six hundred millions of money had to be raised for the new fiscal year before the old year had closed on the 30th June.

abstract: Professions of Friendship for Pres. Johnson; Can Neither be Flattered nor Deceived by Democratic Party
snippet: Professions of Friendship for Pres. Johnson; Can Neither be Flattered nor Deceived by Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: The Democrats in this State profess to be supporters of President JOHNSON and his policy; and they think it very hard that his old friends doubt their sincerity. There is one feature in their canvass which renders it impossible not to doubt it; and that is, their extreme anxiety to drive Union men away from him. If they were really his friends, they would join his old friends, instead of trying to make them his enemies. If they were really desirous that he should be supported, they would act with those who have given him all the support he has received hitherto, instead of insisting that he shall throw them overboard. The man who, in private life, should pretend friendship for another, and begin to show it by alienating every friend he had already, would be set down and kicked out unceremoniously, as a scheming impostor.

abstract: Account of the
snippet: Account of the
lead_paragraph: Mr. YANCEY and Mr. HILL did have a difficulty in the Confederate Senate, not, however, upon the discussion of the Navy Bill, but of the Supreme Court Bill. Mr. YANCEY had spoken; Mr. HILL in reply reviewed Mr. YANCEY's record in a style which was regarded as offensive by Senators. Mr. YANCEY arose, when Mr. HILL had taken his seat, and remarked that as other Senators desired to speak on that question, he would not consume the time of the Senate then, but that at a proper time he would endeavor to do justice both to the Senator from Georgia and to himself. He desired only to say then, that the assertions of the Senator from Georgia, in regard to what he was pleased to term his autobiography, were false, and he knew them to be false when he made them.

abstract: Brace, C. L.; British and American Thinkers
snippet: Brace, C. L.; British and American Thinkers
lead_paragraph: It is perhaps hardly worth while to "rush into print" on so small a matter, but for the sake of those who read without thinking, I submit that your respected correspondent, the "Veteran Observer," has hardly made out his point against me. My proposition, in brief, was that we, in America, were now inferior to England in thinkers on political economy and the science of government, and that since the founders of the republic, we had produced no "master" of either of those branches. Your correspondent argues in reply that we are the greatest country in the world, "teeming in wealth," and have "produced practical results of economy, wealth, growth and power unexampled," and that we have recovered in a marvelous manner from the effects of this war. All this, he reasons, could not have come about without "thinkers;" ergo, we abound in philosophers and political economists.

abstract: A number of drafted men who had run off, but returned since the end of the war, have been tried by a court-martial at Detroit.
lead_paragraph: A number of drafted men who had run off, but returned since the end of the war, have been tried by a court-martial at Detroit. One man, named WILLIAM JONES, was found guilty of "desertion," and sentenced to confinement at hard labor for three months, to be dishonorably discharged, to be forever deprived of citizenship, and the sentence to be published in at least two papers published nearest his home. Sentence approved, and the State Prison a Columbus, Ohio, designated as the place of his confinement. The same penalty was affixed in the case of GEORGE GIDDING, convicted of a like offence.

abstract: Bridge-st., Harrison's Cotton Warehouse
snippet: Bridge-st., Harrison's Cotton Warehouse
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER COTTON WAREHOUSE CONSUMED. -- Near 11 o'clock last night, fire was discovered on the second floor of Messrs. HARRISON & OSBREY's storehouse, at Nos. 3 and 5 Bridge-street, and the alarm was promptly sounded; but before the firemen could get their streams on, the interior of the buildings was a mass of flames. The warehouses were filled, from the ground floor to the fifth story, with cotton on store, and in the cellar there was a large stock of liquors, all of which was consumed. The fire was still burning when the TIMES went to press; but the firemen believed that they could confine the conflagration to the buildings wherein it originated. One of the firm living on Staten Island and the other in west Nineteenth-street, and there being no person on the spot who knew the value of the goods which were on storage, it was impossible to estimate the loss with any degree of accuracy. It must, however, be very heavy -- perhaps nearly a million dollars. The origin of the fire does not appear.

abstract: Pretence of Supporting Pres. Johnson; Nominations by, for President
snippet: Pretence of Supporting Pres. Johnson; Nominations by, for President
lead_paragraph: The people of this State are asked to elect the Democratic ticket, because the Democratic party will support President JOHNSON. They are referred to the resolutions passed at Albany for the proof. That proof will not answer. Even were we to concede that the terms of those resolutions were a definite pledge to sustain the administration of President JOHNSON -- which most certainly they are not -- two essentials would yet be wanting: a moral guaranty that the pledge would be kept by the party in this State, and the power to make the pledge recognized and observed by the party in other States.

abstract: A few influential ladies of this city and vicinity, interested in the very excellent Ursuline Convent at Morrisania, have entered with great zeal into the project of forming a church organization in connection with the convent.
lead_paragraph: A few influential ladies of this city and vicinity, interested in the very excellent Ursuline Convent at Morrisania, have entered with great zeal into the project of forming a church organization in connection with the convent. We learn that there is room for a good church in that vicinity, and that the people thereabouts are greatly pleased with the effort. Last night, in conformity with the announcement made in all the churches on Sunday, a fair was opened at Irving Hall, under the charge and conduct of a committee of ladies, whose savoir faire on such occasions would indicate a long and continuous experience in bazaars, although we believe the majority of them are novices in the business.

abstract: -- The Herald attaches altogether too much importance to JOHN VAN BUREN's nomination of ANDY JOHNSON for President in 1868. He will forget all about it long before that time. Indeed, according to his own showing, Mr. JOHNSON is only his fifth or sixth choice, -- MCCLELLAN, SLOCUM, SHERMAN and sundry others taking rank ahead of him. And even at that he only pledges himself to support Mr. JOHNSON unless the circumstances change, or he does something to forfeit his confidence! There's great virtue in ifs, -- especially in JOHN VAN BUREN's ifs.

abstract: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. The board met yesterday afternoon, but did very little business of general importance.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. -- The board met yesterday afternoon, but did very little business of general importance. A communication was received from Mr. JOHN J. MERRITT, the owner of the building in Furman-street, where, on two occasions, a number of men lost their lives by the falling of the roof, inviting the board to examine the new structure on the same site, which is now ready for roofing. The invitation was accepted. Majority and minority reports on proposals for building South Sixth-street dock were presented, and after some discussion the matter was referred back.

abstract: Wiley vs. Gooch. Arrest and Confiscation
snippet: Wiley vs. Gooch. Arrest and Confiscation
lead_paragraph: Wiley et al. vs. Gooch. -- This was a motion to discharge an order of arrest obtained by the plaintiffs as assignees of the firm of William Lane & Co., against the defendant, as agent of said firm, on the ground of his having acted traitorously while engaged in a fiduciary capacity. It was shown that in the year 1861, the above-named firm, then doing business in this city, employed and sent the defendant as their agent to the State of Texas, to make collections; that while engaged in such business, and in the year 1861, a dissolution of the firm took place, and the plaintiffs, as assignees, notified him to transfer all assets in his hands belonging to the late firm, to one Butler, thereby revoking his authority as agent.

abstract: Mexican Times, new Newspaper
snippet: Mexican Times, new Newspaper
lead_paragraph: We have received several numbers of the Mexican Times, an English newspaper, recently established in the City of Mexico by a rebel refugee. Judging from the specimens before us, we think news must be a scarce article in MAXIMILLIAN's capital. The first number of the Times opens with an article on "Home, Sweet Home," and this is followed by a sketch of Mexico in 1789. The first article of the second number is a critical dissertation on that "tender and chaste song 'Annie Laurie;'" number three opens with Mrs. HEMANS' poem "Bring Flowers;" and also gives us a chapter from Oliver Twist. The most interesting column in the Times is the "Register of the names of emigrants from the United States of America." Among other familiar names in this list we find the following:

abstract: Steamship Lines to Europe, >amp;c., Needed
snippet: Steamship Lines to Europe, >amp;c., Needed
lead_paragraph: It is pleasant to talk of the new ships of the New-York and Hamburg line; of the rapid increase of the international Liverpool line of WILLIAMS GUION; of the great success of the Cunard and of the Inman lines, and of the prosperity of the Bremen and recently-introduced French lines. We say it is pleasant because it is our own American commerce that supports this immense steamship interest, and we owe the proprietors no ill-will for their good luck or enterprise. But it is not creditable to our commerce, and not dignified for our ocean postal service, that the profit is all theirs. Of course, the fact is due in a large measure to the great civil war from which we have recently emerged, but as this cause interferes no longer, we should earnestly strive to divide this most eligible and rapidly-growing interest: a part at least should be Americanized. How, and not when, to do it, is the question.

abstract: St. George vs. Manhattan, at Hoboken
snippet: St. George vs. Manhattan, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: These clubs played their return game at Hoboken yesterday, and it proved to be quite interesting contest, the victory remaining with the St. George second eleven by a score of 107 to 83. Only one innings on each side were played, the game being commenced too late. St. George opened the game, and some excellent batting was shown by TALBOT, RUMSEY, BAILEY and TILT, HAUGHTON carrying his bat out for 8. On the Manhattan side PEERLESS, SEBRING, TYLER and J. TUCKER made the best scores, the latter carrying his bat out. BAILEY's bowling proved very effective, as did that of H. TUCKER and PEERLESS on the other. We give the score below:

abstract: THE OLD BOWERY. Last night, for the first time, we believe, was produced. "The Spirit King," a melodrama of the most startling kind, said to be translated from the German of "Der Alpenkonig."
lead_paragraph: THE OLD BOWERY. -- Last night, for the first time, we believe, was produced. "The Spirit King," a melodrama of the most startling kind, said to be translated from the German of "Der Alpenkonig." The play in itself does not come up to the average, but lt is replete with startling effects, which please, and that is sufficient. The acting was good. Mr. WHALLEY, as the ill-tempered Kappel Koff was excellent, as was Mr. ST. MAUR as the King. In fact it would be hard, with one or two exceptions, to find fault with the acting. The pantomime, "Mother Goose," was put upon the stage in a manner that is most creditable to Mr. FOX as a manager and author. Everything worked well. The Harlequin (Master TIMOTHY) was fair. The Columbine, Pantaloon and Clown were most excellent.

abstract: A trial of some interest to policemen was concluded yesterday in the Marine Court, before Judge HEARNE and a jury. The parties were S.G. ADAMS, a staff officer in the United States Army, plaintiff, and Capt. CAFFRY, of the Fifteenth Precinct, Metropolitan Police, defendant.
lead_paragraph: A trial of some interest to policemen was concluded yesterday in the Marine Court, before Judge HEARNE and a jury. The parties were S.G. ADAMS, a staff officer in the United States Army, plaintiff, and Capt. CAFFRY, of the Fifteenth Precinct, Metropolitan Police, defendant. The plaintiff claimed that Capt. CAFFRY had made an unwarrantable assault upon him on the evening of the 10th of July last, at Wallack's Theatre. The defence was that the police were there stationed to preserve order, and that no more violence was used than was necessary. The jury took the same view, and, after a charge from the Judge, rendered a verdict for the defendant.

abstract: -- The Croton Aqueduct Board have issued a special notice to the public, calling attention to the fact that the long and severe drought has reduced the flow in the Croton River to its lowest stage. The excess of the consumption over the supply is rapidly reducing the reserve in the storage and receiving reservoirs, and should the drought continue a week longer, the supply will be reduced to about two-thirds the quantity now used. Such rains as fell during Saturday and Sunday nights are at once absorbed, and contribute but little in increasing the flow of the Croton River. The commissioners earnestly request the public to economize in the use of water, much of which is now recklessly wasted; otherwise a scarcity will assuredly be felt, resulting in great inconvenience, and to our manufacturers, possibly, incalculable loss.

abstract: -- The Mutual Coal Companies seem to be in a position to sell to consumers at one-third less than the ordinary market rate. This fact demonstrates one of two points: Either the Mutual Companies make an enormous sacrifice to benefit the general public, or the monopolists are charging from thirty to fifty per cent. over legitimate profits. We do not believe that the Mutual Companies sacrifice their own interest for the public benefit. It follows, then, that the monopolists are making very much more than their due share of profits. This sort of thing ought not to last. We know nothing of the merits of particular companies; but there is a difference in their advertised rates, which ought to command the attention of consumers.

abstract: -- We hear that the Tammany people hesitate about indorsing BENJ. WOOD's nomination for the State Senate in the Fourth District. The secessionism was a little too strong. It seemed likely to taint the entire Democratic ticket, and its present flavor can't bear any more of that sort. So our honorable friend is likely to be left hanging by one eyelid. But how about the Mayoralty? That election is a month off: does "distance lend enchantment" to that view?

abstract: Boston is a knowing town. We are sagely apprised therefrom that on the 19th instant there will be an eclipse of the sun "partially visible in Boston." We are sorry for the Athenians; it is quite too bad that an eclipse should be to the only partially visible.
lead_paragraph: Boston is a knowing town. We are sagely apprised therefrom that on the 19th instant there will be an eclipse of the sun "partially visible in Boston." We are sorry for the Athenians; it is quite too bad that an eclipse should be to the only partially visible. Let us hope that when the next solar obscuration happens they may be permitted to see the whole of it. But we may as well put our own people on guard. Be it known, then, that on Thursday next, the 19th inst., there will be an eclipse of the sun, which will be seen as an annular eclipse in certain portions of the Southern and Western States. The eclipse will be visible as a partial one over nearly the whole of the continent of North America, the northern half of South America, and the whole Atlantic Ocean, and in parts of Western Europe and Africa. The central eclipse begins at 9:32 A.M., Washington time, on the Pacific coast, near the mouth of the Columbia River, and the central line, extending across the continent in an east-southeast direction, comes to the Atlantic near Charleston, S.C., and crossing this ocean, terminates in Africa, near the western coast, at 12 h. 53 m., Washington time. This line passes very near to St. Joseph, Mo., Paducah, Ky., Nashville, Tenn., and Charleston, S.C. The annular phase will be visible on either side of this line to a distance of about ninety geographical miles. Besides the cities we have mentioned there are included within these limits Knoxville, Tenn., Huntsville, Ala., Columbia, S.C., Savannah, Ga., and many other less important places. The position of the central line in this eclipse, passing near to so many accessible places, makes it a peculiarly favorable one for the observation of the phenomena attending the annular phases; and expeditions have accordingly been sent to several positions on the line from the National Observatory, and from the offices of the Coast Survey and the Nautical Almanac. In New-York the eclipse will begin at five minutes before 9 o'clock in the morning; the height of obscuration will happen at about 10:30, and the end will be as twelve minutes past noon. At the greatest obscuration about two-thirds (7 3/4 digits) of the sun will be shaded.

abstract: Rebel Loan and the English Subscribers' Denials
snippet: Rebel Loan and the English Subscribers' Denials
lead_paragraph: --The excitement created by the publication of what purported to be a correct list of the principal English subscribers to Confederate stock, now appears to have been in great measure needless. That list included the names of some of the most eminent members of each House of the British Parliament, the leading capitalists and merchants of Great Britain, and the most influential proprietors and editors of the English press. Among the latter figured the manager of the London Times, who was put down as a victim of misplaced confidence to the tune of £10,000. The proprietor of the Morning Post was also enrolled as a fellow-sufferer to a large amount. The notorious Mr. LAIRD, the builder of the Confederate rams and blockade-runners, was likewise given a prominent place on this block list. And last, but greatest, Mr. GLADSTONE, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, was made by sundry journals to bear a part in this notable financial scheme.
headline: {'main': 'THE ENGLISH SUBSCRIBERS TO THE REBEL LOAN.; LOAN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE ENGLISH SUBSCRIBERS TO THE REBEL LOAN.; LOAN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A few days since the Stonington Steamboat Company, the Commercial Steamboat Company, and Neptune Steamship Company, consolidated their capital stock, and appropriated by unanimous vote a sum of money to build two immense steamers to connect at Bristol, R.I., with the railroad. This forms a strong combination, and will give another Boston line via the Sound. As yet we have not heard the dimensions of the vessels, but the Etna Iron Works have taken the contract for the engines, &c. The cylinders for the boats will be the largest in the world, being 110 inches in diameter and 12 feet stroke of piston. Everything in connection with these vessels will be of the most superior order.
lead_paragraph: A few days since the Stonington Steamboat Company, the Commercial Steamboat Company, and Neptune Steamship Company, consolidated their capital stock, and appropriated by unanimous vote a sum of money to build two immense steamers to connect at Bristol, R.I., with the railroad. The cylinders for the boats will be the largest in the world, being 110 inches in diameter and 12 feet stroke of piston. abstract: Prospects
snippet: Prospects
lead_paragraph: Our Democratic brethren do not feel quite so confident as they did at first, of the success of their "little game" at Albany. The signs of the times are less propitious than they supposed to such a flank movement as they attempted. The Union men are not so sound asleep nor so indifferent to political matters as they believed.

abstract: -- The chief Democratic organ in this city was so pressed for room yesterday morning that it could not print the dispatch from Pennsylvania showing the Union majority (on the official returns) to be 25,000. Its "latest advices" were up to Friday night, when, upon a choice selection of counties to suit its purpose, it pronounced that the result was doubtful, and it would require the official count to decide it. Since that the official count has decided it; but our neighbor seems oblivious of the fact.

abstract: U. S. vs. 300 Bales Wool. Undervaluation
snippet: U. S. vs. 300 Bales Wool. Undervaluation
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Three Hundred Bales of Wool. -- This case, which had been set down for this morning, was called at the opening of court. The District Attorney having called his witnesses, found that some were not present. The District Attorney stated to the court that he thought some action should be taken in reference to the attendance of witnesses from the Custom-house; that witnesses were repeatedly subpoenaed from the Custom-house and failed to attend, to the great detriment of business; that the same thing had occurred on Friday last and attachments had been issued, and he now moved that the case stand over till to-morrow and that an attachment issue against the absent witness.

abstract: Greenleaf et al. vs. Mumford, >amp;c.; Mumford Frauds Case
snippet: Greenleaf et al. vs. Mumford, >amp;c.; Mumford Frauds Case
lead_paragraph: Augustus W. Greenleaf et al. vs. Peter R. Mumford, John Oakey, The Nassau National Bank, Albert Speyers, &c. -- The complaint in this action alleges that in August last the plaintiffs were copartners; that on the 12th day of that month they sold and delivered to the defendant Mumford $20,000 in gold, for which they were to be paid on delivery the sum of $28,200 in legal tender and rational currency; that the gold was delivered to Mumford, and that the plaintiffs received in payment therefore, a check dated Aug. 12, on the Mechanics Bank for $28,200, which check was drawn by Mumford and made payable to the plaintiff's order; that the check was presented at the bank on which it was drawn and payment thereof demanded, which was refused; the reason assigned being that there were no funds there to the account of the drawer. The plaintiffs thereupon notified Mumford of the dishonor of his check, and demanded payment of the amount named therein, or in default of that they insisted they should receive the original amount in gold. Mumford, it seems, refused to comply with either demand, and he is now charged with having perpetrated a fraud in the purchase of the gold, when he well knew at the time he gave the check that he had not the funds in the Mechanics' Bank to meet the same. The plaintiffs insist that he did not intend to pay for the gold when he bought it. Afterward Mumford sent to John Oakey a certified check on the Tradesmen's Bank for $53,000, with a request that Oakey would hold the same for his, Mumford's, benefit. Oakey drew out $53,000 from the Tradesmen's Bank, and deposited the same to his own credit in the Nassau National Bank, and then drew his own checks against this sum and for the whole amount thereof. Subsequently he procured these to be certified as good, the money still remaining in the Nassau National Bank and the checks in his own possession.

abstract: FOUND DROWNED UNDER MYSTERIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES. Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a returned soldier, named THOMAS LARKINS, whose body was found floating in the Morris Canal Basin on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: FOUND DROWNED UNDER MYSTERIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES. -- Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a returned soldier, named THOMAS LARKINS, whose body was found floating in the Morris Canal Basin on Sunday morning. It appears that deceased, who was employed in the trunk factory in Morgan-street, left his boardinghouse, No. 41 Montgomery-street, about 11 o'clock on Saturday night, and there is no further trace of him until his body was found floating in the canal basin. There were no marks of violence on the body; and in absence of any information, the jury rendered a verdict of "found drowned."

abstract: The Sunday morning murder at No. 872 Hudson-street, details of which were published in yesterday morning's TIMES, was investigated by Coroner COLLIN, yesterday afternoon, at the Greenwich-street Police-station.
lead_paragraph: The Sunday morning murder at No. 872 Hudson-street, details of which were published in yesterday morning's TIMES, was investigated by Coroner COLLIN, yesterday afternoon, at the Greenwich-street Police-station. Many interested spectators were present during the examination of the witnesses -- the first of whom was FREDERICK REHM, partner of HAMMING, the murdered man. REHM testified that a party of young men, among whom were Robert Anderson, Hugh McNealis, Matthew Conlin, William McGraw, Benjamin Cohen, Thomas Murphy and Gustavus Buckley, played cards until midnight on Saturday, when he (Rehm) took the cards from them, tolling them that it was time to close the house; the players insisted upon another game, but REHM would not countenance it, and went out; but he subsequently returned to the saloon and found the party again engaged in play, RAMMING having given them the cards and joined them in the game: the play went on without dispute until near two o'clock on Sunday morning, when an order was given the barkeeper to fill the glasses, and words passed between the deceased and BUCKLEY, the latter asserting that it was RAMMING's turn to pay for the refreshments: a wordy wrangle ensued, and CONLIN attempted to strike REHM, while BUCKLEY, who appears once to have threatened to chastise RAMMING, made an assault, and on the restoration of order, RAMMING was found to have been mortally wounded. The testimony of BENJAMIN COHEN, of Ninety-second-street, between Third and Fourth avenues, in interesting, and is as follows: I went into the saloon in the early part of the evening to meet a friend, and sat to play a game of whist; being caught by the rain, I remained there in company with Anderson, whom I had met in there; I remained until about one o'clock in the morning, when there was a quarrel between Buckley and the deceased, which ended in a scuffie; the deceased clenched with Buckley, and the latter bit the former; McGraw and myself separated the combatants, and everything was then quieted down; but ten minutes subsequently the deceased, who was standing behind the bar, and Buckley, who was outside, seized glasses, and Anderson said it there's to be any glass throwing I'll get out; I went out then, leaving Buckley standing at the counter having words with Ramming. The remaining testimony corroborates the statements in yesterday morning's TIMES. It may be remarked that the witnesses seemed to be aware of every occurrence from early in the evening to the moment of the the stabbing; but of that act not one of the party knows any thing. The jury rendered a verdict as follows:

abstract: -- Of course MONTGOMERY BLAIR will address the Democratic ratification meeting in favor of the Democratic ticket. His hostility toward Messrs. SEWARD and STANTON, two of the most prominent and influential members of Mr. JOHNSON's Cabinet, insures hostility to his administration. His pretended friendship for the President himself is only designed to cover the blow which he aims at his administration and party. He was the "original Jacobs" of the Albany movement. He ought to take out a patent for it.

abstract: Hard vs. Kelly, Sheriff; Jail Limits case
snippet: Hard vs. Kelly, Sheriff; Jail Limits case
lead_paragraph: Walter S. Hurd vs. John Kelly, Sheriff of the City and County of New-York. -- This interesting case was tried yesterday in the Supreme Court before Mr. Justice SUTHERLAND and a jury. It involves some points of law and some questions of fact, of interest to laymen as well as to lawyers. The facts are, in substance, as follows: In the Summer of 1864, the plaintiff, Hurd, commenced an action in this court against one Wm.A. Crolius to recover the sum of about $400. The summons was for a money demand on contract, but about the time the proceedings were commenced an order of arrest was obtained from Mr. Justice Barnard, for the reason, as alleged in the complaint and the accompanying affidavits, that the defendant Crolius had been guilty of fraud and misrepresentation when he contracted the debt. Crolius was accordingly arrested by the Sheriff of New-York and held to bail. Some time in October, 1864, judgment was obtained in that suit for the full amount claimed, and execution was thereon issued against the defendant's property, which was returned wholly unsatisfied. An execution against the person was then issued. The defendant was arrested, and after some delay furnished bail to the effect that he would not go outside of the City of New-York until the judgment was paid, or until his bonds were legally discharged. In other, and more familiar phrase, he was "put upon the jail limits," which "limits" are the territory known as Manhattan Island. But the plaintiff Hurd was determined to have the amount of his judgment if he could legally obtain it. He had already become satisfied that his debtor was insolvent, and that he had been defrauded by him, as he claimed. Hence he made up his mind to compel the Sheriff to do his duty. By the statute law of this State, if a judgment debtor on the "jail limits" under circumstances like those above described, is caught outside of those "limits,", (except from Saturday night at 12 o'clock to Sunday night at 12 o'clock), and the Sheriff of the county holding the process, can be served with a summons during the time the debtor is so off his "limits," then it is provided that the Sheriff may be held liable in an action at law for the full amount of the judgment upon which execution had been issued. This seems to have been a case in point, and it can readily be seen that five minutes, or even one minute may turn the scale for either plaintiff or defendant.
headline: {'main': '"Jail Limits" What They Are and When a Prisoner May Pass Them Suit Against the Sheriff for an Escape The Jury Render a Verdict Against the Defendant The Value of a Minute.; SUPREME COURT CIRCUIT PART. 3 OCT. 17. abstract: L' Union Nationale professes to have grounds for believing that the Fenians contemplate a raid on Canada. It sets out by quoting a statement to this effect, from the Dublin correspondent of the London Herald, and then goes on in corroboration of this story. "We learn," says L' Union Nationale, "from a good source that our government has been, or is on the point of being, put in possession of certain facts of the highest importance. Our information does not give us the precise facts; but there is not the slightest doubt that the Canadian authorities have been or are on the point of being officially informed by the Cabinet of Washington if it is the intention, more or less resolute, of the Fenians to invade Canada." L'Union Nationale, after disclaiming the idea of becoming an alarmist, proceeds to prescribe how this invasion ought to be met. It is "to demand that England shall break the colonial tie that exposes us to so many dangers, without giving us any influence or any force sufficient to keep those dangers at a distance or to overcome them."

abstract: Palmer, Mr. A. M., the case of
snippet: Palmer, Mr. A. M., the case of
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday morning a correspondence between Mr. A.M. PALMER and Gen. DIX, in regard to the arrest and imprisonment of the former in Fort Lafayette. Gen. DIX states in his letter that Mr. PALMER was released on parole and his sureties discharged because he was satisfied no case could be made out against him, and he adds that, on every principle of justice, he "should be considered as exonerated from all censure." Mr. PALMER has certainly reason to complain that he should have been imprisoned so long, without any examination, or, indeed, the formal presentation of any charges against him. The only consolation of which the case admits is that he was not alone, and that many things were done under the exigencies of the country during the war, which, now that the war is ended, willnot be remembered by the public to the prejudice of those who suffered from them.
headline: {'main': 'THE CASE OF MR. PALMER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CASE OF MR. PALMER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Party and State Rights
snippet: The Party and State Rights
lead_paragraph: The Democratic leaders make a great deal of noise about State rights. They affect to believe that the Republican party means to destroy them, and to convert the government into a consolidated unitary rule. It is an easy string for them to harp upon, for it has been long familiar to them. That wing of their party which made the rebellion, acted in the name of State rights; and the other wing of the party which, under Mr. BUCHANAN prevented any movement against the rebellion, when it might have been easily crushed, did it in the name of State rights. All through the rebellion, every effort of the Copperheads to weaken the government and obstruct the war was made under the same cry of State rights. It is the most natural thing in the world for them to cry it again, when attempting to recover position. They have absolutely nothing else to resort to, carrying the least show of plausibility.
headline: {'main': 'The Democratic Party and State Rights.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Democratic Party and State Rights.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Paris Letter, Oct. 3
snippet: Paris Letter, Oct. 3
lead_paragraph: INCREASED POST-OFFICE ACCOMMODATIONS. Yesterday, the postage-stamp department of the General Post-office was removed to the Nassau-street side of the building, a part of the space on Nassau-street that was formerly used as an entrance to the registered letter department, and a part that was assigned to the ladies department, now comprising the new stamp-office. There will be four windows in all for the distribution of the stamps -- two for the sales in sums less than one dollar, and two for sales of larger sums; and the public will be served with greater rapidity and convenience than hitherto. The crowding, in regard to which so much complaint has been mode, may hereafter be prevented. The sales of stamps in small sums here average about $900 a day; and the sales in large sums, more than $5,000 daily. The whole number of stamps, from the one-cent to the ninety-cent denomination, that were made last year for the government, was 376,000,000.

abstract: Eclipse, The, of Oct. 19
snippet: Eclipse, The, of Oct. 19
lead_paragraph: This morning the sun and moon intend, rain or shine, to go through their semi-occasional performance of an annular eclipse. Those who desire to witness the phenomenon must be on hand with smoked glasses punctually at the hour fixed, and, as a spur to their curiosity, it may be mentioned that this is the first exhibition of the kind since 1854, and that there can on no account be another worth seeing until the year 1869. Writing in New-York, we naturally describe how the eclipse will look from this city, and with a view thereto we inform our readers that the ceremony as seen hereanent begins at 55 minutes past 8 in the morning, at which time the shadow of the moon will begin to obscure the countenance of Old Sol, and will continue to creep over the same until, at about half-past ten, seven and a half "digits" will be obscured. Then the shadow will commence sliding off, and at 12 o'clock all will be clear again, until the next occasion.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The performances here last evening were truly of a gala character. They commenced with singular promptness at 8 o'clock, and terminated toward midnight. During this rather long session there was a concert of nine vocal and instrumental pieces without counting encores and the entire opera of "Lucretia Borgia." It is safe to say that either of these attractions would have filled the house. The combination sufficed to produce a jam.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The performances here last evening were truly of a gala character. They commenced with singular promptness at 8 o'clock, and terminated toward midnight. During this rather long session there was a concert of nine vocal and instrumental pieces -- without counting encores -- and the entire opera of "Lucretia Borgia." It is safe to say that either of these attractions would have filled the house. The combination sufficed to produce a jam.

abstract: McCready, Irene; Power of Sessions to remit back case to Magistrate
snippet: McCready, Irene; Power of Sessions to remit back case to Magistrate
lead_paragraph: The decision in the case of Irene McCready, charged with keeping a disorderly house in East Fourteenth-street, was rendered yesterday morning. The motion of counsel was to remit the papers back to the magistrate for further examination. The motion is denied. The court holds that if the papers were to be sent back to the committing magistrate he might refuse to reopen the case. In that event the bail having been given, and the papers sent back, the bondsman would be relieved from all obligations; and cases might arise in which this power might be used to enable offenders to escape justice. In 1853, a similar application was made in the General Sessions before Recorder Hoffman. Peter Heffernan was arrested on the charge of larceny. The magistrate who committed him and took bail to answer consented to rehear the case. In the meantime, while this motion to remit was pending before the court, the Grand Jury brought in an indictment, and the Recorder denied the motion to remit the papers to the magistrate. He decided then that an indictment will not be quashed on the ground that it was found and presented by the Grand Jury pending an examination of the same charge before a Police Magistrate. The pith of his decision is in the last paragraph:

abstract: Henrietta and Palmer Race
snippet: Henrietta and Palmer Race
lead_paragraph: The second great ocean yacht race of the season, between the yachts Palmer and Henrietta, was decided yesterday afternoon, the latter vessel being declared victorious. The yachts sailed from the buoy off Sandy Hook at 1l:45 on Monday morning, a strong north westerly wind blowing at the time, and the sea being so rough that it was impossible for the guests on the steamtug to board the Palmer. The second great ocean yacht race of the season, between the yachts Palmer and Henrietta, was decided yesterday afternoon, the latter vessel being declared victorious. The yachts sailed from the buoy off Sandy Hook at 11:45 on Monday morning, a strong northwesterly wind blowing at the time, and the sea being so rough that it was impossible for the guests on the steamtug to board the Palmer. This latter vessel was slightly ahead at the start, and kept the lead for some time. Between 2 and 3 o'clock in the afternoon a violent gale carried away the Henrietta's staysail, tearing it to atoms, in spite of which accident the yachts passed the Barnegat Lighthouse at 3:10. At 5:22 the vessels sailed by the Absecom Light, and at 8:28 the same evening the lightship off Cape May was reached, the Henrietta being six minutes ahead of the Palmer. At 8:10 on the ensuing morning the Barnegat Lighthouse was reached, and the Henrietta passed the buoy off Sandy Hook at five minutes past 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, about twenty-one minutes ahead of the competing vessel.

snippet: Election--Loyalty the Real Issue; State Election, Official Count., Paul Dillingham Elected Governor
lead_paragraph: The Democracy are very desirous in this campaign, as they have been heretofore, to keep out of the sight of the people the real question involved, and to go off upon side issues, and matters which will not be affected either way by the result. The real question which is before the people is whether the men who have been at heart against their country during the last four years shall now be suffered to take the control, or whether that control shall be and remain in the hands exclusively of loyal men.

abstract: Streets, Discomforts--Dirt, Travel, >amp;c.
snippet: Streets, Discomforts--Dirt, Travel, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: It has often been noticed by American travelers, on returning to this country, that the "machinery of life" does not work easily. The discomforts of existence for 4 the upper classes are far greater here than in Europe. Whoever would merely, enjoy life without consideration of its work or duty, or of an honorable ambition, should not remain in our cities. Not to mention the endless "Worries" in regard to servants and housekeeping, or the exorbitant expense for any kind of simple and tasteful living, the great and persisting annoyances are the public discomforts. How any rational American can think of comparing New-York, as an agreeable place of residence, with Paris or London, we cannot see. For a place of work, for commerce or manufacture, or useful labor, or for public excitement, there is no city like it. Its unequaled climate nine months of the year, and the cosmopolitan throng of strangers from every quarter of the world, make it certainly the best residence on this side of the water, but the amount of inconveniences to which we are exposed are not to be surpassed in the civilized world. The nuisance of dirt is something beyond endurance. One cannot go off from a centre thoroughfare without wading through all the slops, and filth, and garbage that packed tenement houses can pour forth. The bright sun of New-York only makes the odors and foul gases worse. The air is fetid with stenches.
headline: {'main': 'The Discomforts of New-York and their Remedies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Discomforts of New-York and their Remedies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: CHILD MURDER. -- The body of a male infant was found about midnight, Monday, by Roundsman BRENNAN, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, nailed up in a deal-box, lying on the sidewalk in Taylor-street, near Kent-avenue, E.D. Marks of strangulation were found upon the neck of the infant, and blood oozed from the mouth and nose. The body was sewed up in coarse canvas, and the box which contained it held considerable blood. The umbilical cord had not been tied, and this accounts for the great flow of blood. Dr. JAMES CREAMER held a post-mortem examination at the station-house, yesterday afternoon, and came to the conclusion that the child was born alive, but did not believe the marks on the neck were evidence sufficient of foul play.

abstract: The Registrars appointed under the new law entered upon the discharge of their duties at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and soon found enough to keep them well employed. There appeared to be conflicting views in regard to the interpretation of the law. Some of the Inspectors considered it their duty to take names from the poll-books of preceding elections, while others maintained that they had no right to enter a name upon the list except upon the personal application of a citizen. In some of the districts they had no list of names, but made it as the parties applied, intending to-day to complete the list by entering the names of all whom they are satisfied are voters in the district.
lead_paragraph: The Registrars appointed under the new law entered upon the discharge of their duties at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and soon found enough to keep them well employed. There appeared to be conflicting views in regard to the interpretation of the law. Some of the Inspectors considered it their duty to take names from the poll-books of preceding elections, while others maintained that they had no right to enter a name upon the list except upon the personal application of a citizen. In some of the districts they had no list of names, but made it as the parties applied, intending to-day to complete the list by entering the names of all whom they are satisfied are voters in the district.

abstract: Efforts are being made to have a congress of steam-engine builders, with a view of ascertaining the relative value of new steam-engines. It is proposed to fit up a large room in which the competitors will place their engines. A large tank will be provided which will be filled with air to a given pressure. Each engine will in turn be connected with the tank and the compressed air turned on, and the revolutions of the engine noted. The engine which makes the greatest number will be judged the best.

abstract: Registry Law; Operations of the
snippet: Registry Law; Operations of the
lead_paragraph: It was not a sluggard's task to select from among thousands of willing and other thousands of unwilling electors a thousand citizens who are in every respect fitted to be Inspectors of registry and of Elections. Nor was the position of Commissioner of Metropolitan Police, during the months of August and September -- the period within which the law requires the Commissioners to appoint Inspectors for all of the two hundred and fifty election districts in this city -- an enviable position. On the contrary, to a man who intended to exercise his appointing functions conscientiously and with intelligence, the labor was onerous and irksome to a degree that cannot well be comprehended by any one who has not had the actual duty to perform. The work was completed on Friday last, and on submitting the lists -- the result of more than two months patient and almost unremitting labor by the Police Commissioners, six police clerks, and thirty police captains, President ACTON declared that if money alone were the consideration, he would not again undertake to appoint inspectora and canvassers for an election in New-York for his entire year's salary as Police Commissioner. Yet all this enormous labor bas been inexpensive. The police captains were required to add to their routine duties the task of submitting to the Commissioners the names of trustworthy and esteemed residents of their respective precincts; to the police clerks was assigned the duty of notifying and qualifying such of these citizens as the Commissioners selected, and the Commissioners, while diligently making up the lists, studiously attended to their ordinary duties as heads of the Police Department. Having said which, let us take
