abstract: Apprentices for the Merchant Service
snippet: Apprentices for the Merchant Service
lead_paragraph: The grievance now, as it has been for years, of American shipowners and shipmasters is that we have no apprentice system in our merchant service, and are entirely dependent upon foreign nations for our supply of seamen. In consequence of this serious drawback, we are obliged to select from the best of these seamen the grade of men who now officer our vessels. As a general thing they are persons without education, and ships daily leave this port and other ports of the United States with a class of men, in the majority of instances, as second, third, and fourth officers who are unable to write their own names and are totally ignorant of practical navigation. The only qualifications they possess for their positions are that they are able seamen and can control by physical force the ignorant jack-tars over whom they exercise authority.

abstract: John McNamarra was placed on trial, changed with stealing two tierces of ham from the commission house No. 6 Broadway. The clerk in the employ of the firm was sitting by the window about noon on July 22, when he saw a track come to the basement and the prisoner assist the driver in placing thereon the aforesaid tierces. Knowing that no order had been received for such a shipment, he asked the prisoner by what authority he acted, and was told that a man had sent him with the driver to get the articles. The prisoner then produced a letter purporting to be from a man in Greenwich-street, and read, "By the bearer you will receive the goods; please send me word back." On going with the officer to Greenwich-street no such man as Johnsenn (the person addressed) could be found.

lead_paragraph: A writ of habeas corpus, on the petition of JOHN HIPKINS, Jr., was granted yesterday by Justice INGRAHAM, of the Supreme Court, against Mr. JOHN A. KENNEDY, Superintendent of the Metropolitan Police. The petition alleges that MICHAEL B. CLINE was lately in the custody of a guard in the City of Richmond, Va., for an alleged debt; that he escaped the guard, and came to this city, where he was arrested. He is now held a close prisoner at Police Headquarters, as his friends testify, without any just or legal cause whatever. The writ was made returnable at 10 o'clock this morning, when the case will be fully argued before the court.

abstract: Stron Divorce Case. Postponement Denied
snippet: Stron Divorce Case. Postponement Denied
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Peter R. Strong and Electra M. Potter. -- The motion for a postponement of the trial of this case was heard yesterday morning. The notoriety which the case has already attained drew a large crowd to the room. Mr. Graham opened the argument by saying that he appeared for the District-Attorney, for the purpose of making a motion to postpone the trial. He would say to His Honor, that it was a case in which he considered the public should be represented by some official agent or servant, end for that reason had declined to take the lead in the management of the prosecution. If the peculiar circumstances were such, as in the opinion of Mr. Hall, would make it improper for him to conduct the prosecution, he would suggest that the Attorney-General of the State be called in for that purpose, and he believed that an understanding had been arrived at with that officer that he was to represent the prosecution. He thought that criminal prosecutions Should be conducted by a public officer rather than by private counsel, who probably would not act with the same respect to the rights of the defence as would an official agent of the people. He had positively declined the responsibility of the management of the prosecution, and in doing so he acted in obedience to the dictates of his own conscience, and from the fact that he felt so strongly in reference to the case that he might exhibit an over-zeal which would be detrimental to the prosecution. The motion now was to postpone the trial on account of the situation of a most important witness for the prosecution. The records of the court would show that she was one of the most important witnesses against the defendant Strong, if the testified to the confessions made by him in her presence, which, if believed by the jury, supposing other facts in the case were true, must result in his conviction.

abstract: Loan and English Subscribers' Denials
snippet: Loan and English Subscribers' Denials
lead_paragraph: The European mail, yesterday, brought various denials on the part of gentlemen whose names were appended to the subscription for the Confederate cotton loan. The telegraph had previously intimated the fact of these denials having been made. Mr.BERESFORD HOPE, of the Saturday Review, puts his protest in very explicit terms. He says he never held a farthing of the loan. Mr. LAIRD makes a disclaimer through a Liverpool Tory journal almost as strong. And Mr. GEORGE G. SEYMOUR, whose name appeared in the schedule as a subscriber for $200,000, says he sustained no loss whatever by it. The London Times, of the 5th inst., which contained, as the telegraph announced, a general disavowal of any connection with the concern on the part of its editor, has not been received. And Mr. GLADSTONE's curt disclaimer, also announced by telegraph, does not appear in any of the journals received by yesterday's mail. Thus far, however, considerable discredit has been thrown upon the authenticity of the list; and there is imposed upon those who first authorized its publication the necessity of showing how and whence it originated.

abstract: Dawson vs. American News Company and McFarland Libel; Right of Criticism; Federalist Case
snippet: Dawson vs. American News Company and McFarland Libel; Right of Criticism; Federalist Case
lead_paragraph: Henry B. Dawson vs. The American News Company; and the Same vs. Michael A. McFarland. -- There are two suits; the complaints in each one the same. The cases came up yesterday in the Special Term Supreme Court, before Justice CLERKE, and were tried on a general demurrer to the complaints. The demurrers were to the effect that the complaints do not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. The nature of the alleged libelious matter cannot be understood without giving the substance of the complaints which is as follows: The complaint alleges, first, that plaintiff, Dawson, now is, and was at the time when the cause of action set forth arose, an author by profession, deriving his means of subsistence from his literary labors; and that previously to the time named the plaintiff composed an introduction to, and edited an edition of, a work called the Federalist, which was printed and published together, and is the same hereinafter mentioned. Second, that at various times in 1864, the American News Company, which is incorporated by the laws of the State of New-York, at the City of New-York, maliciously published concerning this plaintiff the following false and defamatory words, contained among other matter in a pamphlet entitled, "Mr. Jay's second letter on Dawson's Introduction to the Federalist," to wit:

lead_paragraph: Yesterday was one of unusual excitement at the fair. Many supposing it to be the last availed themselves of the opportunity to look at the very many articles of interest and of value. The exhibitors were in a frantic state of expectation, and dogged the footsteps of the managers and committeemen, anxious for an inkling of the results of their deliberations. The piano and organ room was crowded by visitors, and about one of the pianos was gathered a motley group of delighted individuals, who listened with pleasure to the vocal gymnastics of a very pretty damsel who had not only a sweet voice but sufficient "countenance" to exhibit it on so public an occasion.

abstract: Registry and Votes; Comparative Tables
snippet: Registry and Votes; Comparative Tables
lead_paragraph: We give below tables showing the number of votes cast in every election district in the city at the last Presidential election, together with the number of electors who were registered on Tuesday and Wednesday as voters entitled to participate in the elections of November and December next. Of the two hundred and fifty Boards of Registry one hundred and eighty-five were required to sit yesterday, and sixty-five ought to have completed their first session on Tuesday evening; but a number of boards, sitting in districts wherein less than four hundred votes were cast at the last general election, held their books open and registered names yesterday despite the law. Among these (if there was no error in making returns last night,) were the Tenth District of the Seventeenth Ward, the Eighth of the Fourteenth Ward, the Eighth of the Sixteenth Ward, the Fourth, Ninth and Twelfth of the Eighteenth Ward, the Sixth and Eighth of the Twenty-first Ward, and the Sixth, Seventh, Twelfth, Thirteenth and Fourteenth of the Twenty-second Ward. Ten Registry Boards that, according to the figures, should have continued in session yesterday did not sit, or were not reported as sitting, at the time when our figures were received. We have no report of yesterday's proceedings in the Eighth District of the Eighth Ward, and the figures in certain other districts may not have reached us accurately; but our tables are believed to be as nearly accurate as it was possible to make them last night, and they give us an aggregate of fifty-two thousand and twenty-four electors whose names were registered on Tuesday and Wednesday:

abstract: The Vice-President of the late Confederate States, accompanied by his brother, Judge LINTON STEPHENS, and Ex-Postmaster-General JOHN H. REAGAN, arrived in this city on Tuesday evening and took apartments at the Astor House. Their arrival, which was soon known, created considerable excitement in the hotel, and throngs of sight-seers crowded around the dining-room in which they were partaking of refreshments. They soon escaped to the privacy of their own apartments, but for hours afterward numbers of persons lingered round the halls and passage ways in the hope of catching a sight of the Ex-Vice-President. Yesterday Mr. STEPHENS and his brother paid a visit to Mayor GUENTHER and Sheriff KELLY. Their arrival soon became known in the City Hall, but they passed quietly through the crowd collected outside the Mayor's Office, and after visiting the Sheriff went up town on private business. They were out most of the day and did not return to the hotel until a late hour. Several prominent Democrats called to see Mr. STEPHENS during the day but were disappointed in finding him absent. Mr. STEPHENS and his brother leave this morning for the South. Mr. REAGAN will probably remain in town a few days longer. Mr. STEPHENS appears to be in his usual health and in excellent spirits, though presenting a peculiarly worn and haggard appearance, with eyes deeply sunk in the sockets and a frame attenuated in the extreme. His brother, the Judge, is a fine-looking man in the prime of lite, with a ruddy complexion and frank, hearty manner. Mr. REAGAN is a tall powerful man, of dark complexion and rather handsome features. All the party appeared to be in good spirits, and talked to those who approached them in an unreserved manner.

abstract: Marriage among the Priesthood
snippet: Marriage among the Priesthood
lead_paragraph: The recent presentation, in the Episcopal Convention at Philadelphia, of a communication appealing to Americans for support of a part of the Italian priesthood in their efforts to assimilate their state to that of the Episcopal clergy, is the first recognition we have seen in this country of a most interesting and important fact in the social and intellectual revolution of new Italy. Most of our readers are no doubt aware of the progress of Protestantism at Naples, Florence, Milan and other points in Italy, under the auspices of the different foreign evangelical societies, and under the cordial protection of the Italian Government; but the gradual approach of a considerable number of the Romish priesthood to Protestant feeling in a very essential particular, is not so well known, we believe.
headline: {'main': 'Marriage Among the Italian Priesthood.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Marriage Among the Italian Priesthood.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Liddle vs. Cory; Patent case
snippet: Liddle vs. Cory; Patent case
lead_paragraph: Robert T. Liddle vs. Uzal Cory et al. -- This was a motion for an attachment for an alleged violation of an injunction. An action was brought to recover damages for an infringement of a patent belonging to the plaintiff for an improvement in air-heating furnaces designated as Liddle's Gas Tight Furnaces. A judgment in favor of the plaintiff was taken in it by agreement, and an injunction was issued forbidding further infringement of the patent.

abstract: A Nashville paper says, regarding the villain CHAMP FERGUSON: "He is entirely reconciled, we are informed, to the terrible fate that awaits him, and maintains the same firmness and composure that has characterized his actions throughout the trial. His only concern is regarding his little family, who are left almost penniless, according to his own statement.
lead_paragraph: A Nashville paper says, regarding the villain CHAMP FERGUSON: "He is entirely reconciled, we are informed, to the terrible fate that awaits him, and maintains the same firmness and composure that has characterized his actions throughout the trial. His only concern is regarding his little family, who are left almost penniless, according to his own statement. The intelligence of his sentence has ere this reached them, and it is expected they will arrive in the city next week, and take their final farewell on this side of the grave of the husband and father for whom they have given up all the comforts of life. Unless it is otherwise ordained, CHAMP FERGUSON will suffer the extreme penalty of the law on the 20th inst. Several efforts have been made to save him from the gallows, but thus far they have failed, and all hope is abandoned."

abstract: Southampton, England, Fatal Case at
snippet: Southampton, England, Fatal Case at
lead_paragraph: The examination into the case of the six alleged Fenians, which was opened at Dublin on the 30th ultimo, was continued on Monday, the 2d, when additional evidence was fully gone into, and the proceedings were brought to a close. Five of the prisoners were committed to take their trial for high treason, while HOPPER was remanded for a week. The prisoners denied that they ever meditated indiscriminate slaughter, as stated by the counsel in his opening address.

abstract: -All anxiety about scarcity of water may be dismissed. Yesterday afternoon "the latter rains" began, and until midnight the storm prevailed with equinoctial fervor. The wind was high, and swept howlingly through the deserted streets. Autumn falls suddenly; two weeks ago the forest verdure wore all the emerald of Summer; now, without time for change of hues, the leaves are beaten down, and the bare arms of the trees project wintry skeletons upon the leaden sky.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second Parepa evening was marred, but not spoilt by the weather. So far as the house was concerned, there was hardly anything to be desired. The seats and boxes were occupied, and a fringe of "standers" filled up the passages. But the particular and vexatious action of the weather was manifested in the case of Mlle. PAREPA, whose cold not being benefited by the humidity of the atmosphere, became unmanageable.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second Parepa evening was marred, but not spoilt by the weather. So far as the house was concerned, there was hardly anything to be desired. The seats and boxes were occupied, and a fringe of "standers" filled up the passages. But the particular and vexatious action of the weather was manifested in the case of Mlle. PAREPA, whose cold not being benefited by the humidity of the atmosphere, became unmanageable. Under these circumstances it became impossible for the lady to sing, and a golden opportunity was presented to Mr. BATEMAN to make a speech to that effect. The disappointment would undoubtedly have been great had not the best favorite of the public, and the most charming and obliging artist in America, Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG, kindly volunteered at the last moment to take the place of the invalid. This civility enabled the concert to proceed without interruption. Miss KELLOGG was in spendid voice, and sung Quila Voce and the Venzano Waltz with faultless precision and the best of effect. We need scarcely add that she was heartily applauded. The other performances were the same as last evening -- Mr. LEVY, the cornet player, achieving a fresh success in the three pieces which he performed.

abstract: Speech at Dem. Ratif. M'g, N. Y.; Speech at Dem. Ratification Meeting, New-York; Speech at Democratic Ratification Meeting, New-York; Democratic Ratification Meeting at Cooper Institute
snippet: Speech at Dem. Ratif. M'g, N. Y.; Speech at Dem. Ratification Meeting, New-York; Speech at Democratic Ratification Meeting, New-York; Democratic Ratification Meeting at Cooper Institute
lead_paragraph: In pursuance of call, the Democracy rallied in fair numbers at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to listen to addressee and ratify the recent State nominations. At 7:30 o'clock, the hour at which the meeting was called, the hall was by no means full, many of the back rows being entirely vacant, On the platform sat Marshal Rynders, Peter Sweeney, Judge Dean, Wm.M. Tweed, Charles G. Cornell, Sheriff Kelly, Gen. Spinola, Elijah F. Purdy, (with whom an inebriated fellow-citizen persisted in shaking hands,) and others equally well known. At 7:45, the house being quite well filled, the audience impatiently clamored for "organization," "music," and "SLOCUM." Neither request was granted for some considerable time.

abstract: London Pall Mall Gazette on Confederate Loan Holders; Seymour, G. E. Denial of Loss by Rebel Loan; London Star on London Times and the Rebel Loan; Hope, A. J. B. Beresford, Denial of Holding Confederate Loan; Laird, John, M. P., Denial of Holding Rebel Loan; London Star, Mr. Gladstone's Connection with the Confederate Loan
snippet: London Pall Mall Gazette on Confederate Loan Holders; Seymour, G. E. Denial of Loss by Rebel Loan; London Star on London Times and the Rebel Loan; Hope, A. J. B. Beresford, Denial of Holding Confederate Loan; Laird, John, M. P., Denial of Holding ...
lead_paragraph: In the list of "English victims to the rebel loan," published by the American papers, one name appears which all Europe will read with amazement. Is it possible that there can be any ground whatever for the allegation that the Right Hon. WILLIAM E. GLADSTONE, Chancellor of the Exchequer, was among the Englishmen who advanced money toward the support of the Confederate rebellion? The first impulse thies, must be to declare such an assertion utterly beyond belief. But that the American papers assert that the list of contributors to the cotton loan, which they publish, is derived from authentic and official sources, the implication of such a name in such a transaction would seem too obviously unjust to warrant a reproduction of the statement. Let us just consider for a moment the full meaning of the charge implied in the assertion that Mr. GLADSTONE is one of those who speculated in the Confederate loan. For the most obvious reasons one is reluctant to admit the idea of an English Finance Minister engaged in any personal dabblings in any foreign loan whatever. But see what was the peculiar nature of the Confederate loan. Let us even put aside for the moment all considerations founded on moral principle, on the odiousness of the slavery system which the Confederate rebellion was undertaken to uphold. Let us look at the question solely as one of hard and dry political expediency and official propriety. The Confederate loan was raised to supply rebels with the means of carrying on a war against a lawful government, that government being one with which we were supposed to have and wish to maintain only friendly relations. Again and again the Queen and her Ministers had formally proclaimed the determination of Great Britain to act toward the belligerents on the principles of the strictest neutrality. Again and again had the government been accused of interpreting this declaration in a manner specially unfriendly to the North; again and again had it repudiated the charge, and admitted the extreme impropriety and even danger that must be involved in any official act which could lend countenances to it. And now we are told that while all this was going on, while every rational and prudent man, even on the Tory side, was urging on the government the immense importance of avoiding even a word which might seem to favor the rebellion -- all this time we are told that the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the foremost member of the Cabinet with the sole exception of the Premier, was lending money to the Southern Confederation in order that it might be enabled to prolong the war against the Government of the United States. * * *

abstract: all about Peat as Fuel
snippet: all about Peat as Fuel
lead_paragraph: As fitted up for human habitation, the American continent was not adapted to nurse a race of "bog-trotters." Its suns are too bright; its winds are too dry, as they come whistling over the Pacific coast range, the Sierra Nevada, the Wahsatch and the Rocky Mountains, to mingle with those from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic. Even after this cominglsng takes place, we are left with clear skies and arid gales for two-thirds of the year, not only causing evaporation to go on rapidly, but decomposing the vegetable matter about as fast as it falls to the earth's surface. Except in a few favored (?) localities nought remains to wash the spots where whole forests shed their annual harvests of leaves, or where they died and were buried. What burning suns and parching winds spared was quickly consumed by the raging fires that swept over those primeval wilds.

abstract: Lawrence, Hon. George V.
snippet: Lawrence, Hon. George V.
lead_paragraph: -The meeting last night at the Cooper Institute was well attended, as Democratic meetings usually are. MONTGOMERY BLAIR was the principal speaker. (We give a synopsis of his remarks.) Gen. SLOCUM was present, and was, of course, (when he became known) hailed with tremendous cheers. JOHN VAN BUREN was also on hand, and many other magnates of the party assisted. Mr. VAN BUREN made a brief speech, and was followed by Hon. S.S. COX, of Ohio. Instead of an original platform they readopted the Albany resolutions. The tone and spirit of the meeting were tame, and in every respect the opposite of the rousers that used to make old Tammany ring with enthusiasm.

abstract: At the second October meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a memorial was read from the Male Principals' Association, infoming the board that the keeping of a record of corporeal punishments would consume time which the principals could more profitably devote to other matters.
lead_paragraph: At the second October meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, a memorial was read from the Male Principals' Association, infoming the board that the keeping of a record of corporeal punishments would consume time which the principals could more profitably devote to other matters. On motion of Commissioner MILLER the communication was tabled instanter. Professor FRANCIS LIEBER's resignation as a Commissioner of Common Schools was received, and the board unanimously thanked the distinguished retiring member for his past services. The clerk of the board was authorized to draw upon the Comptroller for $398,508, that being the residue of the educational appropriation for the year. Commissioner ROOSEVELT offered a resolution of condolence with Commissioner WILSON SMALL in his bereavement.

abstract: As the steamer Queen, from New-York, was being unloaded at Liverpool the dead body of a man was found stowed away among the cargo. The body was naked and the clothes were discovered tied up in a bundle near the body. There was blood about the spot, and the indications were that the body had been placed there with the knowledge of those who stowed the vessel. A verdict of "found dead" was returned.

abstract: The most successful exhibition ever given by the American Institute in this city, closed last night after five weeks of unprecedented popularity and success. Of the fourteen hundred articles on exhibition at the fair, but comparatively few were unworthy of the prominence given them, while very many were of signal interest and conspicuous usefulness to the American people. The fair was gracefully inaugurated...
lead_paragraph: The most successful exhibition ever given by the American Institute in this city, closed last night after five weeks of unprecedented popularity and success. Of the fourteen hundred articles on exhibition at the fair, but comparatively few were unworthy of the prominence given them, while very many were of signal interest and conspicuous usefulness to the American people. The fair was gracefully inaugurated by a gallant son of New-York in a speech singularly free from objectionable features, reviewing the conduct of the war, and paying merited compliments to the eminent men who had brought the war to a happy end thus enabling the American Institute and kindred organizations to resume their interrupted efforts in the advance and encouragement of the arts and sciences. The publicity given by the Press to its opening, made the fair a pecuniary success, by securing to it the eminent patronage of all classes of our citizens as well as hundreds of visitors from Brooklyn and other adjacent cities.

abstract: The eighth annual fair of the above society is now being held at the City Assembly Rooms, on Broadway, and is remarkably well attended by the charitable portion of the community. The object of the society is to provide by this fair a sufficiency of funds to procure food and fuel for deserving poor Roman Catholics during the coming Winter. By appearances, their object will be completely successful. Seven churches are represented at this fair -- St. Patrick's, St. Andrew's, St. Bridget's, St. Gabriel's, St. Peter's, St. Paul's and the Holy Cross. Around the room are a number of tables, tastefully decorated, and covered with articles, both useful and ornamental, that are for sale for the benefit of the institution. The fair saleswomen, who preside over the tables, are Mesdames McNally, Fogarty, Brennan, Brown, Farley, Donahue, Connor, Eagan, Delany and Hamlin, and Misses Wallace, Goggin, Clancy, Snyder and Quinn.

abstract: During the past week a very successful festival has been held at Irving Hall, having for its object the establishment of a church organization in connection with the Ursuline convent at Morrisania. The masculine managers are Messrs. JAMES T. BRADY and Judge HEARN, and the ladies, under whose direct influence the fair is held, are Mesdames LAWRENCE, MOORE and FIGENS, and the Misses WATERS, HENNESSY, KERERNAN and LAMB. St. Francis Xavier's, Holy Mothers' and St. Ann's are the churches represented-The hall is charmingly fitted up, the ladies having almost every conceivable article in the way of knick-knackeries for sale. The most noticeable, however, is a picture of the "Good Shepherd," worked in floss silk by the sisters of the convent. During the whole of next week the fair will remain open.

abstract: Leach vs. Leach; Divorce case
snippet: Leach vs. Leach; Divorce case
lead_paragraph: Leach vs. Leach. -- The plaintiff in this suit is the fortunate, or unfortunate, husband of two wives. One he married in England, about 1850. He lived happily with her several years. Thinking to better his fortunes he left his wife and children in Leeds, England, came on here and labored industriously to save money to bring on his family. News came to him, at length, that his wife and children had died. The intelligence was from such a source, he says, that he could not disbelieve it. He mourned his loss, as all good husbands and fathers do, but he never went over to see whether his wife was really dead. Time passed; he met with another, and as the evidence is, he loved and married her in this city, not long ago. Now, the first wife turns up alive and well. The husband prefers the first love to the second, and comes into court asking that a decree be granted declaring the second marriage null and void. This is the story of the plaintiff. The defendant, the second wife, has a different story to tell, and is disposed to contest the matter to the utmost. The full history of the defence has not transpired, but it is reported that there are some very interesting developments to be made.

abstract: At the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon and evening, the annual festival of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum was held. It was a complete success, the house being crowded from top to bottom long before the commencement of the entertainment. In the afternoon Mr. F.S. CHANFRAU appeared in the comic drama of "Toodles," followed by the San Francisco Minstrels, and concluding with the drama of the "Maid of Croissey." In the evening the comedy of the "Serious Family" and the farce of the "Jealous Philosopher" were given, finishing the performances with the Bryants' Minstrels.

abstract: Fenianism was still an engrossing topic in the Irish provinces. Rumors of suspicious cruisers hovering about the coast were circulated, not only in the south, but in the County Donegal. Precautions were adopted to prevent the clandestine landing of arms or sympathizers, should an attempt be made, which, after recent events, was considered extremely improbable. The strictest surveillance was kept over all American vessels which touch at Queenstown. The luggage of the passengers is carefully searched before they are allowed to land.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the patrons of this ancient game had quite a gala time at the Normal Quoit Grounds, corner of Broadway and Astor-place, the occasion being a benefit for the veteran player and ground-keeper GEORGE DUNNING. There were present some of the most prominent players in the country, including the two champions of the State of New-York and New-Jersey, who played a match of 31 points up, each one taking a partner. Messrs. GIBSON and KELLOGG represented New-York, MCCLAREN and MCGREGOR being the chosen players from New-Jersey. At first the game went in favor of Jersey, their score marking eighteen to seven. New-York now went to work in earnest, and at the approach toward the end the score stood 27 to 24 for New-York. They, however, took courage, and gradually drew up the score by judicious and admirable play, and at length the score marked 29 each. Now came the tug of war, each party being fully up to the mark, and exhibited a nerve and skill rarely witnessed among the athletes of quoiting. New-York took the last two shots, making a full total, and winning the game by two points. Total, 31 to 29. Several other matches were played, in which some of the leading amateurs in the city participated. Without a doubt, the finest pitching ever witnessed in this city was shown. Arising from this, other interesting matches are on the tapis.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the patrons of this ancient game had quite a gala time at the Normal Quoit Grounds, corner of Broadway and Astor-place, the occasion being a benefit for the veteran player and ground-keeper GEORGE DUNNING. There were present some of the most prominent players in the country, including the two champions of the State of New-York and New-Jersey, who played a match of 31 points up, each one taking a partner. Messrs. GIBSON and KELLOGG represented New-York, MCCLAREN and MCGREGOR being the chosen players from New-Jersey. At first the game went in favor of Jersey, their score marking eighteen to seven. New-York now went to work in earnest, and at the approach toward the end the score stood 27 to 24 for New-York. They, however, took courage, and gradually drew up the score by judicious and admirable play, and at length the score marked 29 each. Now came the tug of war, each party being fully up to the mark, and exhibited a nerve and skill rarely witnessed among the athletes of quoiting. New-York took the last two shots, making a full total, and winning the game by two points. Total, 31 to 29. Several other matches were played, in which some of the leading amateurs in the city participated. Without a doubt, the finest pitching ever witnessed in this city was shown. Arising from this, other interesting matches are on the tapis.

abstract: New Professions of--Daily News' Admission on; Daily News' Admissions on the Democratic Party and the President
snippet: New Professions of--Daily News' Admission on; Daily News' Admissions on the Democratic Party and the President
lead_paragraph: The Daily News, whatever else its political sins, is never chargeable with dissimulation. Always through the war it boldly avowed itself for peace, and consistently labored to accomplish it. Unlike many of its Democratic cotemporaries, it did not profess to be for the war, and at the same time oppose all the means for effectually carrying on the war. There was nothing covert or insidious in its hostility, and therein it was free from the worst traits of Copperheadism. Being always straightforward, above-board, out-and-out, it was always a most valuable witness of the real intent of its party. Possessed still of the same qualities, its testimony concerning the present spirit of its party is equally good. Its frankness in the present canvass distinguishes it honorably from most of its Democratic cotemporaries, whose whole study seems to be how to juggle back the confidence of the people by false pretences. The News makes short work of air this make-believe. In an editorial appeal to President JOHNSON to cut clear of his party, it says:

abstract: HOSPITAL. -- The seventh anniversary of the opening of St. Luke's Hospital was celebrated on Wednesday evening, quite a large audience being present. The Superintendent presented his annual report, which set forth the following facts: Patients treated in the hospital during the current year, 817, of whom 459 were males, and 388 females; 548 were dismissed cured or relieved, 114 died, and 155 were still in care of the institution. The expenditures for the twelve months amounted to $40,562 61; the receipts to $41,078 86. An eloquent address was the delivered by Rev. F.D. HUNTINGTON, of Boston, after which the assemblage dispersed.

lead_paragraph: Reference is again made of late to the subject of the sinking fund for the public debt of the United States, contemplated by the act of Feb. 25, 1862. That act pledged the surplus from customs to the purchase, each fiscal year, of one per cent. of the principal of the funded stocks of the. United States, at least, if not one per cent, of the entire public debt, after first providing for the interest of the debt, and the payment of so much of the gold principal as might fall due within each year. We here repeat the figures, (in round thousands,) the results of the three fiscal years' customs since the act of February, 1862, was intended to take effect, to wit, on July 1 of the same year:

abstract: NEW-YORK TIMES, Suppression of the in; Suppression of in France
snippet: NEW-YORK TIMES, Suppression of the in; Suppression of in France
lead_paragraph: Late English papers have contained elaborate accounts of a new torpedo of American invention, said to possess wonderful destructive properties. Several tests of its efficacy have been made, and with such successful results that the discoverer, instead of being blown up by the Admiralty authorities as an impostor, actually succeeded in blowing up a condemned vessel-of war in that very limited period described somewhat vaguely by Mr. Richard Swiveller as something less than no time." The component parts of this destructive agent are not accurately known, but they are supposed to embrace gun-cotton, powder, old secesh speeches, articles from the late Richmond Sentinel, and other equally inflammable materials.

abstract: Peter Johnson, a sort of nondescript, impossible to say whether he was a sailor or 'longshoreman, was charged with stealing the "kit" of a sailor named John Williams. They boarded in the same house and roomed together. In the morning Johnson was missing, and so was the clothing. Complainant and defendant, a few days after, met, and witness identified some of his clothing on the prisoner, and when he asked him where he got the things, he threatened to break his jaw. Officer Frederick Gilbert testified to arresting the prisoner and finding a slung-shot in his possession.

abstract: The additional letters which we publish to-day from the alleged subscribers to the Confederate Cotton Loan in England, confirm the views we ventured to express yesterday as to the character and origin of the list Mr. SAMPSON, the city editor of the London Times, is guileless enough to give us the cue to the whole case, although we happened not to want it. There was a certain allocation of shares in the Cotton Loan made by the Confederate agents. In that distribution the name of the city editor of the Times was included -- but that gentleman declined to be interested. As Mr. SPENCE, the principal outside contributor of the London Times, was one of the chief Confederate agents, we dare say he could tell how the names set down in the first allocation of the stock came to be employed. Meanwhile, Mr. SPENCE has not given this explanation. The list, we have only to repeat, was Confederate in its origin. And the full history of it has yet to be written.

abstract: Theodore Marschall and George Mittaner vs. Frederick Knoll et al. -- An injunction was yesterday granted in the action above entitled, by Justice MONCRIEF, of the Superior Court, restraining the defendants from manufacturing pianos of a certain kind. The defendants are ordered to show cause on the 1st day of November next, at 11 o'clock A.M., why the temporary injunction granted yesterday should not be made perpetual. All the parties to the suit are engaged in the manufacture and sale of pianos, and the natural consequence is that there is considerable interest manifested on the subject. The plaintiffs complain that the defendants have hitherto infringed and are now constantly infringing on their invention as to certain improvements made in the keys, and consequently in the scale of their instruments. The whole matter will be fully investigated before the court on the 1st proximo.

abstract: Institute Fair; Races of Mutilated Men
snippet: Institute Fair; Races of Mutilated Men
lead_paragraph: -- There was an exhibition the other day at the fair of the American Institute, from which a savage might have turned with a shudder, and from which a wild beast (unless he belonged to some show in New-York, and was consequently depraved,) might have shrunk frightened and sickened away. The reporters give us to understand, however, that this exhibition afforded an amusement for people whom eighteen centuries of Christianity, and a cycle of unexampled freedom, with such advantages for the diffusion of humanizing education as the world never knew before, ought to have made the first people of the age in refinement of feeling and enlightenment of intellect. Yet we may all doubt whether all these great means have not failed of their end, when we read how a large crowd, at the American Institute, witnessed with interest and satisfaction, the struggles of certain mutilated men to outwalk and outrun each other on the artificial limbs of rival manufacture, which were to be tested in the graceful sport. In a place which was devoted as a temple to the inventive genius of our people, and in which the triumphs of their unequaled skill were displayed, this degrading spectacle took place. It could serve no purpose of science which could not have been better served in a decenter way, and the manufacturers of cork-legs could have found ample means of determining the comparative merits of their works without outraging -- we were going to say public sentiment, but it appears the public sentiment was not outraged. It seems that the grotesque and ferocious sense of drollery which could alone have prompted such a hideous show as this race of the cripples is the common instinct, and that we relish the scene which it invented for our gratification. The fact is none the less disgraceful, however; disgraceful to the managers of the fair who permitted the exhibition, disgraceful to the unfortunate men who took part in it, disgraceful to the public, which not alone endured it, but enjoyed it.

abstract: The steamship Scotia, from Liverpool on the 7th and Queenstown on the 8th, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings two days' later intelligence. English papers contain additional denials of complicity in the Confederate loan, from gentlemen whose names were recently published as subscribers. The editor of the London Times not only denies the imputation as far as he is concerned, in a leading article in the columns of that journal, but personally writes to the London Star, under his own signature -- "JOHN T. DELANE" -- emphatically denying that he ever held any of the loan. The Times publishes emphatic denials from Lord WHARNCLIFFE, GEO. WARREN PEACOCKE, and EDWARD AKROYD, and as a heading to the letters, prints the term -- "The Lying List." Fenianism was still the engrossing topic in the Irish provinces. Rumors of suspicious cruisers hovering about the coast were freely circulated. Precautions were adopted to prevent the clandestine landing of arms or sympathizers, and the strictest surveillance was kept over all American vessels which touch at Queenstown. A royal commission has been appointed by the Queen to investigate the cattle plague. The Earl of DERBY was rapidly recovering from his recent indisposition. The Bank of England, on Monday, the 2d, advanced its rate of discount from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent., and again on Thursday, the 5th, it was raised, somewhat unexpectedly, to 6 per cent. JOHN P. HALE, United States Minister to Madrid, was received by the Queen of Spain on the 30th ult.

abstract: on Prest, Johnson
snippet: on Prest, Johnson
lead_paragraph: Hon. J.M. LEACH, formerly a member of Congress, declines to become a candidate, because in the first place he cannot take the test oath. He says: "I know President JOHNSON. I heard his great speech against secession and in defence of the Union and constitution, in the Thirty-sixth Congress. He is our friend. He is a wise and able statesman, and is exerting his great influence against fanaticism and factionists wherever found. Gov. HOLDEN has the President's fullest confidence, and has labored faithfully, I think, in the exercise of wisdom and impartiality in the work of restoration and for the best interests of the people of the State. I shall sustain and give my influence to any conservative Union man, that you, the people of the Fifth District, may bring out for Congress."

abstract: The Advance of and Condition of New-York
snippet: The Advance of and Condition of New-York
lead_paragraph: The news by yesterday's European mail shows that we in America, must begin to "set our house in order." The only point of doubt thus far about the present invasion of cholera, with medical men, has been whether it was more than an epidemic of the Mediterranean basin. Till recently, the disease had not left the shores of that sea. In Italy, no inland towns had been attacked, and even cities in the filthiest condition, such as Verona, had altogether escaped the pestilence. France had, indeed, been assailed, but it was on the coast -- at Marseilles. Now, however, we hear of cases in the interior of Italy, and above all, the news reaches us that cholera has broken out in Paris and other parts of interior France. It cannot be long probably before cases are reported in England. Winter is not necessarily a safeguard against it, nor extreme cold. In the great attack of 1830, the pestilence raged all Winter frightfully in St. Petersburgh, and broke out in England first in October, remaining torpid, as it were, till the next Spring, and then raging through the cities of Great Britain. It did not appear here till June. It is not improbable that as the season is so far advanced before it has reached Paris, its ravages may be but slight this Autumn, and next Spring may witness its reappearance in Western Europe. If that shall prove the fact, the pestilence will inevitably cross the ocean, and appear here next Summer. Physicians already notice a certain choleratic aspect to diseases this year -- a peculiarity said often to precede a general attack of Asiatic cholera. If this mysterious agency which produces cholera -- this current or wave of invisible fungi or animalculae or malaria is on its progress around the world, no quarantine or exclusion can shut it out. In the first invasion it broke out in New-York soon after it appeared in Montreal.
headline: {'main': 'The Advance of the Cholera.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Advance of the Cholera.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Willard vs. Raymond, Principal and Agent
snippet: Willard vs. Raymond, Principal and Agent
lead_paragraph: Eleazer Willard et al. vs. John D. Raymond. -- This was an action brought on a draft drawn by the defendant. The defence was that the drawer of the check was merely an agent for a certain voluntary organization known in commercial circles as "Divisions," and that in drawing the draft he acted not for himself but for the association. It transpired on the trial that there a are great number of associations of this nature in this city, the object of which is, to buy goods of all kinds in this market and sell them again to Western merchants. This "Division" is numbered 757, and the evidence showed that there were numbers all the way from one up to this. The court in directing the jury to find a verdict for the full amount of the draft and interest, said that the idea of there being "Divisions" for the purpose, and to the extent shown, was a novel thing in his judicial experience. At most they were but mere voluntary associations; they were not incorporated companies, and they had none of the elements of a co-partnership. He believed in applying the law strictly, and holding every one to his contract. The defendant drew the draft in question without specifying, or in any way indicating that he was acting as an agent. He should be held responsible, and judgment for the full amount claimed is therefore directed.

lead_paragraph: A motion was made, yesterday, in the Supreme Court, at Chambers, before Justice INGRAHAM, in the case of Maguire vs. Cline, for a discharge from an order of arrest, or, in case that could not be granted, to reduce the amount of bail. The action is brought against the defendant to recover an amount of money which the plaintiff alleges he (defendant) has misappropriated as an agent. He was employed by the plaintiff's wife to secure theatrical and operatic players in this and other Eastern cities, and send them on to San Francisco, Cal. For this purpose a large amount of money was placed in his hands, and, it is said, he did not faithfully apply the same. The Judge took the papers and reserved his decision.

abstract: at Jefferson Market Police Court for about $500 worth of goods which Sergt. GARLAND seized yesterday at the abode of Mrs. ELIZABETH BURTES, at No. 161 East Twenty-seventh-street. The goods are in whole pieces, and were evidently stolen from tradesmen's counters. They were found in Mrs. BURTES' trunk, and with the exception of the store marks having been removed they were, when seized, precisely as taken from store. They consist of pieces of silk, cotton cloth, diaper, dress goods, etc. Mrs. BURTES was apprehended, and CATHARINE CAVANAGH, of No. 144 Wooster-street, identified certain articles as her own, and on her affidavit the prisoner was required to find bail.

abstract: The Bank of England on Monday, the 2d, advanced its rate of discount from 4 1/2 to 5 cent., and again on Thursday, the 5th, it was raised, somewhat unexpectedly, to 6 cent. The movement is fully explained by the weekly statement, which shows a decrease in the bullion of £776,982, and of £1,913,955 in the notes unemployed. This absorption brings the reserve to a much lower point than at the corresponding date last year, when the rate of discount was 9 cent., while the amount of bullion is about the same. Money continued in good demand, notwithstanding the advance to 6 cent., and an impression prevailed that a still further advance might soon be resorted to.

abstract: Yesterday a lot of workmen from this city and Bridgeport were sent down to the bridge to build a foot-way for passengers to cross. Mr. CHARLES WATERHOUSE, from this city, went down to oversee the work of pile-driving, and a large force of men were all busily engaged to-day in driving piles for the foot-bridge, which it is expected will be completed some time to-day, so that by Wednesday but little delay to the trains will be caused by the accident. Yesterday the passengers and baggage were transported over the bay by means of farmers' wagons and STUDLEY's express wagons, going a little over two miles to effect a crossing, and causing a delay to the trains from a half an hour to two hours. We understand a temporary bridge will be built for the track, and that it will be ready for use in about ten days, after which a permanent structure will be erected on the old piers. It is estimated that the loss to the company from the accident will not be less than $50,000. The telegraph company sent men down to the bridge yesterday and replaced their wires, several of which were destroyed by the fire, and the line is now in working order. -- New-Haven Journal, Oct. 17.

abstract: According to promise, the eclipse of the sun, which was looked for so anxiously by the scientific world, came off yesterday punctually at the hour and minute named in the programme. The morning was in the highest degree propitious. None of your clear, staring sky made the exhibition common by allowing it to be seen without interruption; but instead, the day broke gloomily, and a heavy curtain of clouds interposed between mundane gazers and the blue ether. The angry showers that had poured over Nature's face all night, had only just ceased, and a sullen frown seemed left. As the Lord of Day rose higher and higher toward the zenith, however, wide rifts began to stretch across cloudland, and gleams of golden sunlight and glimpses of blue gave promise of an occasional look at the spectacle of the day.

abstract: Philadelphia, Meeting, List of Committees; Collection of Revenue Commission on four months' work of
snippet: Philadelphia, Meeting, List of Committees; Collection of Revenue Commission on four months' work of
lead_paragraph: On the 3d of March, 1865, Congress authorized the Secretary of the Treasury to appoint a commission of three persons to inquire and report upon the subject of raising by taxation such revenue as might be necessary in order to supply the wants of the government, having regard to and including the sources from which such revenue should be drawn, and the best and most efficient mode of raising the same, and to report the form of a bill. The commission was also given the power to inquire into the manner and efficiency of the past and present methods of collecting the Internal Revenue, and to take testimony in such manner and under such regulations as should be prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury.

abstract: Speech at Union meeting, N. Y.; Dispatch to Gov. Holden advising Repudiation of N. C. Rebel Debt; Speech at Union Meeting, New-York; Union Mass Meeting at Cooper Institute; Speech at Union Meeting, N. Y.; Speech at Union meeting, N. Y.
snippet: Speech at Union meeting, N. Y.; Dispatch to Gov. Holden advising Repudiation of N. C. Rebel Debt; Speech at Union Meeting, New-York; Union Mass Meeting at Cooper Institute; Speech at Union Meeting, N. Y.; Speech at Union meeting, N. Y.
lead_paragraph: No larger or more enthusiastic audience was ever convened in Cooper Institute than that which thronged its every nook and corner last night, in answer to the call for the ratification of the nominations of the Republican Convention. At 7 o'clock the house was full, at 7 1/2 the sisles and corridors were jammed, at 7 3/4 policemen were stationed at the head of the stairway to prevent further accessions to the multitude below. Cheer after cheer rang lustily through the building as the long line of men eminent in the spheres of commerce, law, war and politics filed from the committee room upon the platform while the familiar countenances of the most popular were greeted with prolonged applause. Among them, we noticed Major-Gen. Kilpatrick, Chancellor Ferris, Gen. Merritt, Peter Cooper, Hon. Daniel S. Dickinson, W.E. Dodge, Hon. Abram Wakeman, E. Delafield, Smith, Horace Greeley, Col. T.B. Van Buren and Charles S. Spencer. Unlike the audience, which, a few nights since, permitted Gen. SLOCUM to come before it unknown, unrecognized and ungreeted, this gathering rose as one man when KILPATRICK entered, and gave him nine as hearty cheers as he or any other man ever yet received. The walls were gaily and appropriately decked with banners and bunting, the pillars were wreathed with the American flag, and even the plaster busts of WASHINGTON, FRANKLIN, JACKSON and LINCOLN adorned their pedestals in improvised coverings of the red, white and blue. An admirable band enlivened the waiting moments prior to and between the speeches, and Anderson's Glee Club made memorable in song an occasion which was aptly illustrated by two hundred and fifty soldiers from the Union depot, who had participated in many hard fought battles on other but not more important fields.

abstract: Hainings vs. Lamar Insurance Company; Construction of Policy
snippet: Hainings vs. Lamar Insurance Company; Construction of Policy
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Hainings et al. vs. The Lamar Fire Insurance Company. -- This was on action brought to recover on a policy of insurance executed by the St. Louis agent of the Lamar Fire Insurance Company, and covering a quantity of hay shipped by the plaintiffs from Leavenworth, Ind., to Memphis, Tenn., in March, 1863. The cargo consisted of some 800 tons, put up in bales, and was on board the steamer Progress, and three barges in tow thereof. While passing down the Mississippi, one of the barges came in collision with the Crescent City, was sunk, and of the 382,950 pounds on board, 237,225 pounds were totally destroyed, being about nine per cent. of the entire quantity shipped. The total value of the barge was $20,000, and the amount of insurance thereon, $10,000, a premium of two and a half per cent. having been paid. A clause in the policy provides that the company would not be liable for losses, general average excepted, not amounting to twenty per cent. of the value of the articles insured. A recovery was claimed on the ground that the loss exceeded twenty per cent. of the lading of the barge sunk. It was argued that where the cargo consisted of anything put up in bales or individual packages, the estimate of the loss should be on the separate cargo of packages, and not on the whole amount shipped.

abstract: We regret to learn that the rice crop of Georgia this year will be almost an entire failure. In the region raising this crop the negroes have been free from compulsion during the whole year, and this failure of the rice crop is the first fruit (or lack of fruit) of the experiment of free labor in Georgia. We are permitted to make the following extract from a business letter from Savannah to a gentleman of this city. The letter is dated Savannah, Sept. 28:

abstract: ARREST BY CAPT. BRACKETT. Capt. BRACKETT, of the City Hall, having previously notified the city railroad companies that they must comply with the requirements of the law, apprehended an unlicensed driver on an Eighth-avenue car, yesterday, and took him to the Mayor's office. Mr. GEORGE LAW, President of the Eighth-avenue Railroad, appeared in the driver's behalf, and contested the right of the police...
lead_paragraph: ARREST BY CAPT. BRACKETT. -- Capt. BRACKETT, of the City Hall, having previously notified the city railroad companies that they must comply with the requirements of the law, apprehended an unlicensed driver on an Eighth-avenue car, yesterday, and took him to the Mayor's office. Mr. GEORGE LAW, President of the Eighth-avenue Railroad, appeared in the driver's behalf, and contested the right of the police to make the arrest. This arrest is to be made a test case, and carried up to the higher courts, and Capt. BRACKETT, under instructions from the Superintendent of Police, is not to interfere with unlicensed drivers until a decision is reached.

abstract: The first general inspection of the Seventh Regiment, New-York State National Guard, which has been held since the recent change in their uniform and equipments, was made yesterday afternoon. This splendid organization turned out fully eight hundred strong. They marched from their armory, over Tompkins Market, at 2 o'clock, and proceeded to Washington Parade Ground, where they were passed in review by a brilliant group of general and staff officers. The new uniform of the regiment is modeled after the French Chasseur pattern, and a great deal of conflicting criticism was evoked among the admirers of the Seventh, many declaring it a great improvement on the old costume, while others regarded it as little short of unbecoming. The ancient swallow-tail coat is substituted by a short tunic, the trowsers are cut full over the hips, and the stiff shako is replaced by a smart and jaunty little kepi. The color is still gray, embroidered for the privates with black and for officers with gold braid. Epaulets are worn on the shoulders and a small projecting feather in front of the cap. It is superfluous to say that the regiment looked magnificently, and went through the few exercises required of them with the most perfect precision and aplomb. As soon as the inspection was over, the regiment returned by way of Broadway and Eighth-street to their armory, amid the applause of promiscuoasly assembled crowds, though people generally failed at first to recognize them, so marked was the change in their appearance from that with which the public is familiar.

abstract: The Ninety-fifth Regiment, Col. S.N. PINCENEY, were inspected on Thursday afternoon, at Washington-square, by Maj. TAYLOR. This is a now organization, having now 700 names on the muster-roll a portion of the Ninety-third Regiment having been consolidated with it. There were present at the inspection 320 men, who looked quite well in their new uniforms and equipments. Inspector-General Brig.-Gen. BATCHELOR, accompanied by several members of his staff, was on the ground, and seemed quite satisfied with the appearance and drill of the regiment.

lead_paragraph: The bark Wm.E. Anderson, Capt. PIERCE, from Mobile, which arrived at this port on Thursday night, brought one passenger and four of the crew of the steamer Atlanta from New-Orleans, which vessel foundered in lat. 36, lon. 72, on the 15th inst. It appears that the vessel sprung a leak during the gale on the 14th; inst., and soon afterward broke up. The five persons saved clung to a portion of the wreck, on which they remained until rescued on the 17th inst. The remainder of the crew, 34 in number, and 17 passengers, are supposed to have been lost, only one boat, containing four persons, having succeeded in leaving the ship. The vessel was quite new, and was valued at $150,000. Her cargo comprised 1,170 bales of cotton, valued at $600,000.

abstract: N. Y.; Dempsey, of #1,000 by highwaymen
snippet: N. Y.; Dempsey, of #1,000 by highwaymen
lead_paragraph: is the charge on which Detective Officer JONH H. McCARTY, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, arrested JOHN HOCTOR and PATRICK HOCTOR, of Manhattanville, laborers. Mr. JOHN DEMPSEY, of Chicago, won tarrving at No. 153 East Twenty-ninth-street, made affidavit, yesterday, that on the night of the 16th inst. he was at HOCTOR's abode, and there exhibited $1,000; that on his departure he was pursued down Tenth-avenue by PATRICK HOCTOR, JOHN HOCTOR and PATRICK HOCTOR, Jr., and when near One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, knocked down and robbed by them; that on the 18th inst he met the elder HOCTOR, and demanded the $1,000, and that HOCTOR gave him $99, saying that sum would take him home to Chicago; upon which Mr. DEMPSEY appealed to Officers MCCARTY and CROWLEY, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, and the accused were arrested as above. They were committed in default of $2,000 bail each....The

abstract: Wills of the following named persons have been admitted to probate during the week ending to-day: George E. Mendum, Esther Reeve, John Selby, James Hampton, George B. De Forest, Patrick Leddy, Caleb C. Crane, Philip Stoppelbien, Mr. Mendum, by his will, bequeathed a quantity of stock of the Continental Insurance Company, and several bounty land warrants, to Neptune Lodge No. 317 of F.A.M. Geo. B. De Forest has left an estate of more than half a million. Each of his children is to have a legacy of $50,000. Mr. Stoppelbien has bequeathed a residuary estate of about $9,000 for the purpose of founding an asylum for friendless orphans and illegitimate children. Mr. Crane has bequeathed to the Home Baptist Missionary Society, $200; to the Foreign Missionary Society, $100.

abstract: denunciations of President Johnson and Union Party
snippet: denunciations of President Johnson and Union Party
lead_paragraph: WEDELL PHILLIPS has opened upon President JOHNSON in the same way as his old philippics against President LINCOLN. The cause of his wrath, this time, is that President JOHNSON does not force negro suffrage upon the South. There is no measure to the tirade which this "sin of omission" evokes from this reveller in contumely. This is morally worth nothing. It is a thing of course. No public man ever did or ever will live in this country that was secure from this man's railing. He is nothing if not censorious. But his objurgations in this particular case have a certain significance from their breadth of sweep. He denounces not only President JOHNSON, but the whole Republican party for supporting him. He declares that "there has not been a single Republican convention that has not indorsed the President;" that "the Republican party has not dared to utter the word suffrage -- has not dared to deny the President's plan." Thereupon he proceeds to annihilate the Republican party. He avers that the party no longer exists -- that there is nothing left of it but "a spectre walking through the country in its shroud." This summary dispatch by the single arm of WENDELL PHILLIPS of a party that has just prostrated again to the dust the Democratic party in Maine, Vermont, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, and Iowa is an exquisite piece of absurdity. Yet the animus with which it is done is worth something as an index of the real relations between this extreme radicalism, and that great party which raised ANDREW JOHNSON to power and constitutes his chief support.

abstract: The Fifth-sixth Regiment New-York Veteran Volunteers, under command of Lieut.-Col. SMITH, arrived in this city yesterday by United States transport Empire City, from Hilton Head. S.C. This Regiment was organized in September, 1861, at Newburgh, Orange County, New-York, by Brigadier-General  then Colonel VAN WYCK.
lead_paragraph: The Fifth-sixth Regiment New-York Veteran Volunteers, under command of Lieut.-Col. SMITH, arrived in this city yesterday by United States transport Empire City, from Hilton Head. S.C. This Regiment was organized in September, 1861, at Newburgh, Orange County, New-York, by Brigadier-General -- then Colonel -- VAN WYCK. He also raised at the same time, two light batteries, afterward known as the Seventh and Eighth New-York Independent Batteries, the Seventh commanded by Capt. REAGAN, the other by Capt. FITCH. Also, two cavalry companies, afterward attached to the First New-York Mounted Rifles. The whole command was known as the Tenth Legion, being raised in the then Tenth Congressional District. Just four years ago they marched down Broadway, 1,500 strong, now about 200 of the original number return.

abstract: The Eighth Regiment, Col. JAS. VARIAN, held their annual drill and review at the arsenal Thursday night, in presence of Inspector-Gen. BATCHELOR, Gen. HALL and other officers. Every part of the drill was executed with proficiency. Present on review, besides Gen. BATCHELOR, were Commissary-Gen. PALMER and wife, Quartermaster-Gen. MERRITT, Maj.-Gen. HALL, and several other officers. At 10 o'clock the exercises were brought to a close. Gen. BATCHELOR was called out and made a speech, which was enthusiastically cheered. Gen. HALL, Col. VARIAN, Gen. PALMER and Gen. MERRITT followed with suitable remarks, which were listened to with satisfaction. The regiment then was dismissed.

abstract: Almira Walker vs. Alonzo P. Spudlong, et al.; motion denied with $10 costs. Wm. Murphy vs. Sarah A. Murphy; motion granted on condition that defendant gives admission as to title of bond, submits to examination on two days' notice, and pays $10 costs of the motion. Thomas G. Walker vs. the President, &c., of the Granite Bank; motion granted in part as stated in opinion. Augustus Seeley vs. Emma L. Wright, et al.; injunction dissolved, as the plaintiff has ample security in the money deposited, but the court has no power to order a lis pendens taken from the files or released, except as provided in section 134, while the action is pending. I concur in the case in the 12th Howard, p. 215. Julia Smyth vs. Joseph Smyth; motion for alimony granted and case referred to referee to inquire and report as to a proper allowance therefor. The motion for injunction is also granted unless defendant, within ten days, files a bond with sureties in penalty of $2,000, to secure to plaintiff any amount she may recover in this action. lead_paragraph: Almira Walker vs. Alonzo P. Spudlong, et al.; motion denied with $10 costs. Wm. Murphy vs. Sarah A. Murphy; motion granted on condition that defendant gives admission as to title of bond, submits to examination on two days' notice, and pays $10 costs of the motion. Thomas G. Walker vs. the President, &c., of the Granite Bank; motion granted in part as stated in opinion. Augustus Seeley vs. Emma L. Wright, et al.; injunction dissolved, as the plaintiff has ample security in the money deposited, but the court has no power to order a lis pendens taken from the files or released, except as provided in section 134, while the action is pending. I concur in the case in the 12th Howard, p. 215. Julia Smyth vs. Joseph Smyth; motion for alimony granted and case referred to referee to inquire and report as to a proper allowance therefor. The motion for injunction is also granted unless defendant, within ten days, files a bond with sureties in penalty of $2,000, to secure to plaintiff any amount she may recover in this action. abstract: FIRE. The stable of ADOLPH ECKSTEIN, in Vanderbilt, near Park-avenue, was dostroyed by fire on Thursday evening. It was occupied by MICHAEL CONNOLLY. The entire loss is about $200, upon which there is no insurance. The flames extended to the paint-shop of WM. H. KINKAID, in the rear, which way damaged to the extent of $200; no insurance. A dwelling house adjoining the stable, owned by JOSEPH KELLY, was somewhat damaged. Loss about $100; insured.

abstract: Nor  ma" was given last night to the usual crowded and fashionable attendance. Mme. LUCCHI was the Norma and Mile. BOSISIO the Adelgisa. The first-named lady was admirable in all the dramatic parts of the opera, and especially grand in the second act. Her voice, however, lacks the steadiness and purity ne-...
lead_paragraph: Norma" was given last night to the usual crowded and fashionable attendance. Mme. LUCCHI was the Norma and Mile. BOSISIO the Adelgisa. The first-named lady was admirable in all the dramatic parts of the opera, and especially grand in the second act. Her voice, however, lacks the steadiness and purity necessary for the grand scena of the first act. Mlle. BOSISIO displayed a slight improvement on her previous efforts, but is yet timid, immature and unsatisfactory. She was heard to best advantage in the duet of the third act. Signor MASSIMILIANI sang excellently as Pollio, and Signor ANTONUCCI was equally good as Proveso.

abstract: An Arkansas Immigrant Aid Society was formed  on the 30th ult. at Little Rock. Hon. ROBERT J.T. WHITE, the Secretary of State, is President. Gov. MURPHY and Judge BARTLETT lead in a list of some ten Vice-Presidents, Adjutant-General BISHOP is the Corresponding and J.P. JONES the Recording Secretary, and the Treasurer is Major BARNES, of Puliski County. Other officers compose a Bureau of Agricultural Lands; a Bureau of Commerce and Manufactures; a Bureau of Mines and Mineral Lands, and a Committee of Ways and Means. The object of the society, as set forth in its constitution, is "the dissemination of information calculated to encourage immigration to the State, both foreign and from other portions of the United States, and to provide ways and means for the actual settlement of all who may determine to make Arkansas their home."

abstract: Shipowners' Memorial to Secretary McCulloch on Payment of Freight
snippet: Shipowners' Memorial to Secretary McCulloch on Payment of Freight
lead_paragraph: The Shipowners' Association of this city recently adopted a memorial to the Secretary of the Treasury, which has been published in our columns. The point of it was to urge the passage of some law, or the issuing of some Treasury regulation, to secure the payment of freight upon goods which are put into government warehouses. Without wholly disagreeing with the memorial as to the point at which it aims, we cannot but see some errors in its statements.

abstract: Rebel Loan and its Repudiates
snippet: Rebel Loan and its Repudiates
lead_paragraph: -- The denials of English gentlemen whose names have been published as subscribing to the rebel loan suggest one or two reflections. During the progress of the war, even from its commencement, the very writers of indignant disclaimers of rebel investments were persistent in their assumption that the Confederates were, as contrasted with the upholders of the Union, eminently distinguished, not more the heroism than for absolute truthfulness. Now, the list which has caused such a fluttering among these advocates and supporters of blockade-running and sundry other developments of the war -- why not say it, of piracy itself, is of Confederate origin, as we are well assured. It turns out that it contained names inserted without authority -- names of men to whom were offered, but who did not accept, allotments therein, and which names were nevertheless evidently used, without contradiction, until they were made public by the rebel authorities to enhance the value of their securities. May we not suggest that the comparative value of the statements of the putters forth of the loan, and the denials of its moral if not pecuniary backers, is fairly a subject of discussion? There was a man who could have written with some pungency upon this subject, but the tongue and pen of THACKERAY are stilled forever.

abstract: Darnley, Capt. C. C., Ed. Little Rock, Ark., Gazette
snippet: Darnley, Capt. C. C., Ed. Little Rock, Ark., Gazette
lead_paragraph: Capt. D.D. BULLOCK last week had about $300,000 worth of government property, consisting partly of army suits and blankets -- new goods -- at the government storehouse in New Haven waiting shipment to New-York. A part of it has been sent. The remainder cannot be shipped just yet owing to the steamboat company having more shipping to do than it can get through -- the misfortune in the New-York road throwing a deal of extra freighting upon the boats of the line. The Captain has about $2,000,000 worth of government property in New-Haven which is to be sold at auction.

abstract: a Paris correspondent of a M[???]lle EDITH P _____, a young lady of good family, but without a fortune, who was, however, an accomplished musician, and who published some years ago several of her compositions, which gained her some celebrity. As she also happened to posses considerable personal attractions, she soon had a swarm of admirers buzzing round her. Unluckily she left in the hands of one of the most ardent amongst them some letters capable of being turned against her. A German, a great amateur of music, now enters upon the scene, falls in love with the lady, and makes her his wife. The baroness, getting a hint of danger likely to arise from the letters before spoken of, endeavors, by hook or by crook, to get them into her hands. "Ce que femme veut, Dieu le veut," says the old French proverb; and so by a series of romantic incidents she succeeds in recovering them all; but instead of making an auto-da-fe at once, as she should have done, of the dangerous missives, she places them in a private drawer in order to re-read once again the follies of her youth. Suddenly the baroness finds, to her horror, that the letters have disappeared -- have been stolen, in fact, from her desk. A month passes, and no clue is found to the thief, till, only a few days ago, a man calling himself a business agent presents himself to the baroness, stating his business to be of the most private nature. He, of course, is the possessor of the letters, having bought them from her ex-fimme-de-chambre, and in true dramatic style he demands an exorbitant sum for their return. If she refuses, they will be made public, and that in such a way as to ruin the reputation of the lady. He is so remarkably rude that the high-spirited woman, losing patience, has him thrust out of the house. This honest man of business, who occupied a respectable position in Paris, upon his return to his office closets himself with another party, to whom, for some reason, he tells the story. A clerk in the outer office, a sort of Dick Swiveller, takes to "airing his eye at the keyhole," and overhears this confidential chat. The result is that he breaks open another desk, and (most chivalrous office clerk) places the letters once more in the hands of the harmless. This time she does the thing she ought to have done before -- she tells her husband frankly what has happened, and hands him the packet, which he tosses behind the fire unopened. Now comes in the Police Correctionelle. The respectable man of business, furious at being robbed of papers intrusted to his keeping, calls in the police, and Mr. Richard Swiveller -- it must be Dick -is locked up. The matter comes before the proper tribunal, investigations are made, and the clerk is released with a compliment. The respectable man of business takes his place on a charge of conspiracy to extort money. The first purloiner of the letters has yet to be discovered.

abstract: The Party Relations of with the President
snippet: The Party Relations of with the President
lead_paragraph: The Democracy complain in a tone of injured innocence because we doubt their sincerity in claiming to be supporters of the President and his policy. We think that there is reason enough for the doubt to be easily found by any one who will take the trouble to go back over the history of even one year, and see how, with one accord, these men who now claim to be the especial and only friends of the President, then found no words strong enough to express their detestation of ANDY JOHNSON. Do they admit that they were wrong then? Or do they charge Mr. JOHNSON with having so changed as to deserve the praise of those who then so hated him? If they can only account for their friendship by thus slandering the object of it, we may well doubt whether such friendship is anything more than a profession for a purpose.

abstract: Johnson, John, Shot by a Detective in Self-Defense
snippet: Johnson, John, Shot by a Detective in Self-Defense
lead_paragraph: Yesterday forenoon Detective Officer EDWARD L. McWILLIAMS, of Jersey City, shot JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-Street, near the intersection of Cortlandt and Washington streets where he was employed as bar-keeper. Officer McWILLIAMS at once surrendered to Policemen an DALLY, and was taken to the Liberty-street. Police-station, and JOHNSON was removed to the New-York Hospital, where he died. It appears that JOHNSON had been known as one of a gang of thieves, and that on Sunday last, being with the gang on the train which bore the New-York Firemen's Association to Philadelphia, he was violently thrust out. Thirsting for revenge, be bade his brethren watch for Officer MCWILLIAMS, and yesterday morning, that officer, having been sent to this city by the chief of the Jersey police, was waylaid by JOHNSON and his brother. The fellows -- who are said to rely upon political influence in the First Ward to shield them from punishment when the evidence is not overwhelmingly against them -- made a hostile demonstration, and JOHN JOHNSON threatened to shoot Officer MCWILLIAMS; but the officer -- obeying the police order requiring a policeman to take care that no ruffian has opportunity to strike or shoot him -- seeing JOHNSON make a movement as if to draw a pistol from his coat pocket, discharged his revolver and sent a bullet into JOHNSON's brain.

abstract: Hudson City, N. J.; Two Watchmen Shot by Burglars
snippet: Hudson City, N. J.; Two Watchmen Shot by Burglars
lead_paragraph: Two MEN SHOT BY BURGLARS. -- Two Private watchmen, named GEORGE C. HAAS and FRANCIS BUCKMASTER, in the employ of GEORGE V. DE MOTT, at Hudson City, were shot about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, by two unknown burglars, who succeeded in making their escape. It appears that while the watchmen were patroling their beat they met two unknown men carrying a bundle at the corner of Cottage-street and Bergen-avenue. They attempted to stop the strangers, when they turned and fired two shots, and then throwing down their bundles ran away. HAAS was wounded in the stomach, and BUCKMASTER was hit in the hip, but neither of them are considered to be dangerously injured. The package was found to be the proceeds of a burglary at the residence of W.H. HORTON, jeweler, residing in South Bergen.
