abstract: returned on Tuesday evening, having caught, in the City of Quebec, a runaway girl, who eloped with a man from her mother in Cincinnati some two months since. The girl was safely returned to her mother by the Captain, who was amply rewarded for his trouble. The Captain informs us that he has traveled over seven thousand miles in pursuit of the fair maid. He said it cost him at least two thousand miles of rail and water travel more then was necessary, owing to the fact that the elopement was prematurely published in the St. Louis papers. The young lady got wind that the Captain was in pursuit while she was in Buffalo, and then commenced a race unparalleled in police annals. The captain chased her all over the New-England States, when he found that the fugitive had taken the Canada route. She was then followed to Boonshire Falls, in Canada West; thence to Toronto, By town, Three Rivers and Montreal. The Captain got off the scent of the fugitives on the Grand River, owing to the fact that they left the main lines of travel and took to a raft, descending the river two hundred and fifty miles. At Montreal, the girl's paramour getting tired out, the latter was left behind, when the girl steamed down to Quebec, where she was caught by her persevering pursuer. The girl -- who, according to the Captain's statement, "is the prettiest ho ever laid eyes on" -- delivered herself up gracefully, and was returned to Cincinnati, to sin no more it is to be hoped. This was her second elopement, she having tried the experiment once before, and was captured at the Planter's House, in this city, in company with a gambler, by the same officer who recaptured her the second time. -- St. Louis Democrat, Sept. 21.

abstract: Yesterday forenoon JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-street, a bar-keeper, was shot at the corner of Cortlandt and Washington streets by EDWARD L. McWILLIAMS, a Detective officer of the Jersey City Police, and almost instantly killed.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday forenoon JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-street, a bar-keeper, was shot at the corner of Cortlandt and Washington streets by EDWARD L. McWILLIAMS, a Detective officer of the Jersey City Police, and almost instantly killed. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest in the case, when it appeared that the deceased and his brother JAMES had for some time past borne ill-will toward Officer MCWILLIAMS, on account of the officer having thrust them off the cars. On meeting him yesterday deceased threatened him, and made a movement as if to draw a revolver, when the officer fired at him, the ball piercing the left temple and killing him almost instantly. The jury rendered a verdict that the shooting was in self-defence.

abstract: In this case, (Cody vs. Kappen,) counsel for the defendant moved to have the papers sent to the General Sessions. The defendant was charged with larceny. Counsel said his client was a gentleman well known in this city, and the defence was of a peculiar nature. They held that the case was a conspiracy; the charge was a wholesale fraud, and defendant was the last man in the world who could be guilty of a crime. It so happened, that complainant, and defendant were rival suitors for the same lady's hand, and this, counsel alleged, was the occasion of the conspiracy.

abstract: Weights and Measures
snippet: Weights and Measures
lead_paragraph: A very singular and learned work has lately been issued in London, on the subject of the largest Egyptian pyramid. It is written by Professor PIAZZI SMITH, Astronomer Royal of Scotland, who asserts, and endeavors to prove in it, that the system of weights and measures used in Great Britain, the United States, and some other countries, and also the recognized divisions of time, together with those of length, &c., emanated directly from the Deity, and are to be found illustrated, in their proper order, in the various dimensions, departments and galleries of that very celebrated and most ancient structure. The volume is full of curious researches and deductions, one of which is noticed. It respects the measure termed a quarter. The Professor declares we have no account of what it is the fourth part. But there he is mistaken, for it is the quarter of the chaldron, which latter, from its unwieldiness, is not often used, but which holds exactly the number of cubic inches (68,880) contained in the sarcophagus enclosed in the pyramid. Without following the learned author through the details by which he strives to establish the soundness of his theories, we are content with believing that the perfection of justice is one of the attributes of God, and with asserting that, with regard to the Israelites, he established such special divisions of weights and measures, and also in one instance appointed the way in which they should be used; honoring the measure for grain by especial notice in the command, "A just Epha shalt thou have."

abstract: Quite a sensation has been created  in mercantile circles by the absconding of the junior member of an extensive firm on South Broadway, consisting of father and son. The son has for his wife a young woman that he had married in a Western city, who has proved to be of the most gay and volatile disposition.
lead_paragraph: -- Quite a sensation has been created in mercantile circles by the absconding of the junior member of an extensive firm on South Broadway, consisting of father and son. The son has for his wife a young woman that he had married in a Western city, who has proved to be of the most gay and volatile disposition. Not long since rumor had it that she had eloped with all accomplished Brazillian, with whom she had been intimate in a boarding-house on State-street; but the reported elopement proved to be untrue, the fact that she had returned home to her Father's house, in consequence of the stories set afloat by the Mesdames G[???]ps relative to said intimacy.

abstract: ties, of whom HORATIO SEYMOUR was one, Hon. LUCIUS ROBINSON used the following language in reference to the national currencys, "I say that the greenback is a lie. The promise upon its face is a lie. The Congress by which its issue was authorized enacted a lie. The bank by which it is sent forth circulates a lie, by doing business upon a false and fraudulent basis. The whole thing tends to bankruptcy and repudiation." The same idea is presented, in a more adroit form, by Mr. ROBINSON's letter of acceptance. The position thus taken is that of the Democratic party. The people will take care that a man who holds such opinions is not retained as the chief financial officer of the State, to give them effect in a constant warfare upon the securities of the government, and, consequently, upon the capital of the country. -- New-Haven Journal.

abstract: Albany Evening Journal on Gov. Seymour and John Van Buren
snippet: Albany Evening Journal on Gov. Seymour and John Van Buren
lead_paragraph: It is well known, that, in consequence of his failure to be made the Democratic nominee for United States Senator on a certain occasion, Prince JOHN VAN BUREN entertains a feeling of the most uncompromising enmity to HORATIO SEYMOUR. This is sometimes expressed in very bitter remarks. A leading gentleman, a friend and adviser of Mr. SEYMOUR, happened to be on a car a little while before the Albany meeting, when JOHN was expounding his views of HORATIO, in terms more emphatic than polite, and overheard his expressions. He at once wrote to Mr. SEYMOUR, telling him the facts, and urging him, in self-respect, and as he valued his reputation, not to appear on the same platform with the Prince. Hence the absence of the Governor. By the way, will not Hon. CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW, Secretary of State, inform us what JOHN VAN BUREN said to him on a certain occasion, concerning HORATIO SEYMOUR and other leaders of the Democratic party? JOHN has repeated a portion of the conversation from the stump, and it thus becomes public property. Faithfully reported, it would make more interesting reading than JOHN's best speech, or a volume of Punch. -- Albany Evening Journal.

abstract: is said that the editors of the French daily papers now accept seriel stories from their contributors on very odd conditions. If the public are pleased with a novel it is to be extended so as to last several months; if it does not make a hit, its plot is to be completed and the climax brought on at a week's notice. One publisher ordered a novelist to finish at once a narrative having fifteen characters. In four days fourteen of them had been killed by a variety of violent deaths; but just then the editor changed his mind, ordered the story continued indefinitely, and the obliging writer at once created a bevy of new characters. In another instance a gentleman who was publishing in daily numbers in La Patri[???] a translation of Mrs. HENRY WOOD's "East Lynne," received summary directions to cut short the novel, and to close the career of Lady Isabel by immediate suicide by Langing.

abstract: Flushing, L. I.; Railroad Company's Safe; $8,000
snippet: Flushing, L. I.; Railroad Company's Safe; $8,000
lead_paragraph: EXTENSIVE BURGLARY AT FLUSHING, L.I. -- A SAFE BLOWN OPEN AND $8,000 STOLEN. -- Some time after 12 o'clock on Friday night, the office of the Flushing Railroad Company was entered by burglars, the safe blown open, and $8,000 abstracted. The entrance to the office was through a second story window, which was reached by climbing a car standing alongside the building. The sale (WILDER's) was drilled, and a heavy charge of powder must have been used, as the door was blown completely off the safe and the windows of the office shattered and thrown into the street. The noise of the explosion must have been great, but the depot stands some distance from any dwelling, and if heard in the village did not attract any one to the place. Of the amount stolen, $2,000 was the private property of the Superintendent of the road, Mr. ROBERT WHITE. About 6 o'clock on Saturday morning, two men got on the down train at West Flushing, who appeared to act strangely, and the conductor, suspecting them of the burglary, had them arrested at Hunter's Point and handed over to the police of the Forty-Seventh Precinct. Sergt. BOCH, who was on duty at the station-house, searched the men thoroughly, but found nothing to warrant any suspicion of their complicity in the burglary. He afterward ascertained that they were employed by his mother in Greenpoint, and were on their way to work when arrested. The sergeant did not, therefore, feel justified in holding the men, both of whom were Germans, and did not understand a word of English.

abstract: News says that a prominent and reliable citizen of Wisconsin was told by Gen. SHERMAN, when on his recent visit to Milwaukee, that Gen. GRANT's real name is Hiram S. GRANT, and not Ulysses S. Grant, as he is usually designated. Gen. SHERMAN stated that the name by which Gen. GRANT goes was acquired by the blunder of the member of Congress who recommended Gen. GRANT for the military academy, when he handed in the name of young GRANT to the Secretary of War. After his appointment to West Point, the embryo Lieutenant-General endeavored to secure a correction of the error, but the officers of the academy declined to do so, for the want of authority, and referred the matter to the War Department, where for some reason it was neglected. The modest sudent of military tactics finally firnked the difficulty by assuming the name which accident and the official record assigned him. His mother, however, never fails to call him " Hiram," and ULYSSES never fails to respond to the call.

abstract: Historical Precedent for
snippet: Historical Precedent for
lead_paragraph: At the close of the Absalomic rebellion, narrated in the second Book of Samuel, we read that a rivalry sprang up between the tribes lately in revolt, and the men of Judah who had mostly stood by King David. The circumstances recorded there are so much like those at present existing between the two great parties at the North, one of which stood by the Administration during the war, and the other arrayed itself against it, that we quote the passage at length: "And all the people of Judah conducted the [victorious!] King, and also half the people of Israel. And, behold, all the men of Israel came and said to the King, 'Why have our brethren, the men of Judah, stolen thee away, and have brought the King and his household, and all David's men with him over Jordan?' And all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, 'Because the King is near of kin to us. Wherefore then be ye angry with us for this matter? Have we eaten at all of the King's cost, or hath he given us any gift? And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and said. "We have ten parts in the King, and ice have also more right in David than ye. Why then did ye despise us that our advice should not be first had in bringing back our King?" The sequel is equally instructive with the narrative alluded to. "A man of Belial," named Sheba, blew a trumpet and said, "Everyman to his tents, O Israel!" Whereupon the ten tribes once more rushed into rebellion, which was only brought to a close by the loss of the leader's head. That organization which assailed the late President as a vulgar buffoon, and the present as a boorish tailor, are to-day as vociferous as the subjugated ten tribes, that they have "more right" in ANDREW JOHNSON than the men who nominated, elected and supported him cordially till the close of the rebellion. Let their impudent claims be only questioned in high places, and we shall soon hear Sheba with his trumpet ordering every man in the opposition to his tent, for that they have no inheritance in this son of Jesse.

abstract: Sewarage of Large Cities
snippet: Sewarage of Large Cities
lead_paragraph: -- The rapid march of the cholera toward the shores of England seems to have quickened in the Londoners a sense of the peculiar dangers to which all large municipalities are subject in times of pestilence. Precautionary suggestions pour into the office of the London Times by the cart-load. Pleasing theories are elaborated in the columns of the newspapers and reviews, concerning the small chance which any inhabitant of the great city will have of escape. One of these suggestions, although upon an unsavory subject, seems to have some truth in if, and at the present time relates to a matter in which the citizens of New-York are interested. The City of London is drained by an extensive system of sewers, some of which have existed for ages, and through these year after year has rolled the accumulated filth of two millions of people. This sluggish current, sometimes stagnant, sometimes beaten back, and rising so as to flow into the streets at any available outlet, is continually giving forth noisome vapors, reeking with deadly poison, the very breath of death, and the life of pestilence and disease. An eminent citizen of London writes to the Times that every water-closet in that city communicates with the sewers directly, and that owing to faulty construction, they offer to these generators of foul and pestilent gases just so many escape-vents. Thus, in his opinion, the great and intricate sewerage of the city, far from doing any good, is a simple and perfect machine for distributing poison in regular doses to the inhabitants of every house. Various suggestions for ventilating the sewers have been brought out by this novel theory of the circulation of unhealthy gases through the dwellings of the Londoners, but we have only referred to the matter for the benefit of the Croton Aqueduct Commissioners, who are about to build a new system of sewers for the City of New-York. It seems to us that provision should be made as much to carry off the poison emitted by the masses of filth which sewers contain, as to carry off the filth itself, and that the drains should have no direct communication with any buildings or with the street, except through ventilators erected for the purpose.

abstract: The anniversary of the Union of the Sunday-schools of the Methodist Episcopal Church of this city will be celebrated to-day. Forty-two schools will be represented, numbering 300 children in each, or 15,000 in all. In the morning sermons will be preached and collections taken up in behalf of the Sunday-school Union in nearly all the Methodist Episcopal places of worship, and at 2:30 P.M. the children will meet in the following churches, where they will be addressed by several distinguished speakers: Forsyth-street Church, Second-street, Allen-street, Rose Hill, Jane-street, Greene-street, Thirtieth-street, Forty-third-street, Lexington-avenue, Yorkville and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street.

abstract: Laura Keene vs. John S. Clark and William Stuart. The action above entitled was brought on again yesterday morning in the Superior Court, Special Term, before Justice MONELL.
lead_paragraph: Laura Keene vs. John S. Clark and William Stuart. -- The action above entitled was brought on again yesterday morning in the Superior Court, Special Term, before Justice MONELL. It will be remembered that about weeks ago, the plaintiff made a motion, upon affidavits, to Justice Moncrief, of the same Court, to have the defendants permanently enjoined from further acting or performing the comic drama, entitled "Our American Cousin," at the Winter Garden Theatre, or elsewhere, on the ground that the manuscript copy thereof was the copy-righted property of the plaintiff, Laura Keene. The court, after a long argument, which was made at that time, denied the motion for an injunction, but without prejudice to the right of the plaintiff to renew the same on additional affidavits.

abstract: On Saturday forenoon JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-street, a bar-keeper, was shot at the corner of Cortlandt and Washington streets by EDWARD L. MCWILLIAMS, a Detective officer of the Jersey City Police, and almost instantly killed. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest in the case, when it appeared that the deceased and his brother JAMES had for some time past borne ill-will toward Officer MCWILLIAMS. The jury rendered a verdict that the shooting was in self-defence.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday forenoon JOHN JOHNSON, of No. 16 Thames-street, a bar-keeper, was shot at the corner of Cortlandt and Washington streets by EDWARD L. The jury rendered a verdict that the shooting was in self-defence.

lead_paragraph: The amusements at the various places of amusement for this evening are as follows: At the Academy of Music, "Il Trovatore;" at Wallack's Theatre the "Double Gallant," (last time;) at the Winter Garden "Our American Cousin;" at Niblo's Garden the RAVELS and Young America in a new programme of pantomimic, &c.; at the Olympic the "Streets of New-York;" at the Broadway Theatre the comic drama of "Sam;" at Barnum's Museum the great equestrian artiste, OCEANA, in the grand spectacular drama of "Mazeppa;" at Dodworth's, Blind TOM, the negro boy pianist; at the old Bowery, "Life for Life," "Raoul" and a farce; at the New Bowery the sensation drama called the "Dead Hand," and "Hunting a Turtle;" at Wood's Minstrels a new local sensation burlesque called the "Manager's Triumph, or the Black-mailer's Defeat; at No. 444 Broadway a new and powerful bill of attractions; at Bryant's "Les Miserables," the "Wearing of the Green," and other irresistable morceau, and at the Academy of Music (beginning at 2 o'clock) the examination of the pupils of the National Conservatory of Music.

abstract: When the Wirz Military Commission reassembled on Saturday, Judge-Advocate CHIPMAN proceeded to read his agruments on charge second, alleging murder in violation of the laws and customs of war, treating the subject under four heads, as follows: First  The various cases of death resulting from mutilation by hounds. Second Those resulting from confinement in the stocks and the chain-gang.
lead_paragraph: When the Wirz Military Commission reassembled on Saturday, Judge-Advocate CHIPMAN proceeded to read his agruments on charge second, alleging murder in violation of the laws and customs of war, treating the subject under four heads, as follows: First -- The various cases of death resulting from mutilation by hounds. Second -- Those resulting from confinement in the stocks and the chain-gang. Third -- The cases of killing of prisoners by the guards, pursuant to the direct order of the accused given at the time. Fourth -- The cases of killing by the prisoner's own hands. He briefly argued the responsibility of the accused, and said that every death was a murder for which he is accountable, he having grossly violated the laws and customs of war. At the close of the Judge-Advocate's argument, the prisoner requested that Dr. BATES might examine his person in the presence of the court, to show that he was physically incapable of committing the sets of murder and the batteries alleged against him. The request was granted. The doors were then closed, and will not be opened to the public again. The court in secret session deliberated on the case submitted, but nothing can be known of the result until it shall be officially promulgated.

abstract: Officer CUMMINGS, of the City Hall force, took into custody, on Saturday evening, JOHN D. SMITH, driver of Bleecker-street Railway car No. 28, for reckless driving. Mr. JOHN BERGEN, of Pearl and Park streets, who attempted to leap from the front platform of the car, and both of whose feet were crushed by the wheels, appeared against SMITH, and he was committed for trial......Mr. DENNIS KANE, of No. 287 Plymouth-street, Brooklyn, having been knocked down and severely injured by a car on the Belt Road, in South-street, caused the arrest, by Policeman CRUMLEY, of the Fourth Ward, of THOMAS W. SMITH, the driver, and the prisoner was committed.

abstract: Advantages of Peace
snippet: Advantages of Peace
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent states that Gen. GRANT has sent to the Secretary of War a communication recommending the mustering out of all Major and Brigadier-Generals of the volunteer service, save those who have been disabled. And in connection with this we may note that the official returns lately published under the authority of the British Government give us an approximate idea of the cost devolving on it, in consequence of the unsettled state of its transatlantic relations during our late civil war. For the transfer of troops to its various possessions in British America, during the years 1862, 1863 and 1864, their maintenance while here, and the necessary expenditure for stores, a sum of eighteen millions of dollars was disbursed. This includes, it is true, more than four millions of dollars paid out of colonial exchequers -- principally or entirely by the Canadian Government; but it would no doubt be within the mark to say that the dubious relations between the two countries, leaving a margin for obligations incurred which have not been published, would amount to an aggregate of twenty millions of dollars.

abstract: Mr. HENRY BISCHOFF, of No. 21 Second-avenue, listened to the syren voice or ANN CALLAHAN, on Saturday night, and between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning he awoke and missed his watch, a fine time-piece that cost him $500. At about the same hour Patrolman SULLIVAN, of the Seventeenth Ward, observing a female in Second-avenue of suspicious appearance, detained her, and while the girl and the officer were conversing BISCHOFF approached and said that he had been robbed, and, gazing with astonishment upon the female, he added, "this is the girl that robbed me." The watch was found in the bosom of the accused, and she was taken to Essex Market and committed for trial.
lead_paragraph: Mr. HENRY BISCHOFF, of No. 21 Second-avenue, listened to the syren voice or ANN CALLAHAN, on Saturday night, and between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning he awoke and missed his watch, a fine time-piece that cost him $500. abstract: On Saturday a female of the town informed Capt. NATHANIEL R. MILLS that EMMA CANN, a child of 13 years, lay in a Broome-strcet brothel suffering from a frightful malady, and that she had been foully treated by her step-father, one JOHN CANN. A visit to the girl satisfied Capt. MILLS of the genuineness of the story as it had reached him, and he sent her, in charge of Officer ROBERTS, to the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning, and after hearing her statement Justice DODGE gave Officer ROBERTS a warrant for the arrest of CANN, who, the police had learned, was dwelling at No. 77 West Twenty-fourth-street. Thither Policemen ROBERTS and SMITH went, yesterday afternoon; but tidings of their mission had reached the house in advance, and the fellow had escaped. Later in the afternoon, however, the officer apprehended him in West Twenty-fifth-street, and on their approach he fired upon Officer SMITH, missing aim. Officer ROBERTS now fired upon CANN, and wounded him in the back of the head, and then CANN fired twice upon himself, lodging bullets behind his right ear. He was taken to the Wooster-street Police-station, and his head was dressed by Police Surgeons FRELIGH and POOLER, and as his wounds were not of serious character he was committed to a cell. Capt. MILLS took the girl to his station-house and held her as a witness. She says that CANN has four wives alive, and that, having tired of living with her mother, he long ago thrust the woman into a Water-street brothel. More than a month ago, CANN forcibly violated the girl, and threatens her life if she lisped the matter, thus terrifying her into silence until recently, when he repeated the outrage and beat her brutally. She then disclosed her wrongs to the female that communicated the facts to Captain MILLS. The girl is quite comely, and intelligent beyond her years. She is to be taken to Jefferson Market to-day, and thence to Bellevue Hospital. CANN kept a house of ill-repute in Broome-street until the police drove him out, and then opened a like place in West Twenty-fourth-street. He is a Nova Scotian, about 30 years of age.

abstract: Cummings, Charles W., of New-York
snippet: Cummings, Charles W., of New-York
lead_paragraph: typographical fraternity, died in Amity-st., last evening. Mr. CUMMINGS enlisted in the Twenty-sixth New-Jersey Volunteers in the Fall in 1862, and served his time faithfully, being complimented by his Colonel for his bravery in the assault on the heights of Fredericksburgh, May 3, 1863, at which time he was desperately wounded. Returning from the war, he arrived in this city on the 13th of July, and was among the most active of the defenders of the newspaper offices during the riots of that period. He was the youngest son of the editor of the Christian Herald and Messenger.

abstract: -- We print this morning the important  address to the people of Texas, by JOHN H. REAGAN, late Confederate Postmaster-General. The telegraph has already announced this document, but gave no indication of its contents. Since its issue Mr. REAGAN has been set free on parole, and is now on the way to Texas, under a promise, as we understand it, of using his utmost influence to reinstate the people in loyalty. Texas gives hopeful prospect of early restoration to full communion with the Union.
lead_paragraph: -- We print this morning the important address to the people of Texas, by JOHN H. REAGAN, late Confederate Postmaster-General. abstract: Policeman VAN CLEEF, of the Eighth Ward, apprehended JAMES B. JORDAN, young Georgian, and against him appeared Mr. ROBERT K. GAD, of No. 20 Varick-steet, and Messrs. LEWIS O. HARRISON and EDWARD W. BURDICK, of No. 107 Wooster-street, and complained that the prisoner, who had been their fellow border, had stolen garments of the value of $300. JORDAN was committed for trial on his own confession.

HARRISON and EDWARD W. BURDICK, of No. 107 Wooster-street, and complained that the prisoner, who had been their fellow border, had stolen garments of the value of $300. JORDAN was committed for trial on his own confession.

abstract: Complaint having been made against WILLIAM W. SMITH's gaming-house, at Nos. 97 and 99 Sixth-avenue, the Superintendent of Police instructed Sergeant MANGIN, of the Ninth Precinct, to break up the place. Accordingly, yesterday afternoon, Sergeant MANGIN and Roundsman NOBLES, with a section of policemen in civilian attire, went to the place, and entering without warning, caught twenty-eight persons in the act of gambling at faro. The gamesters, perceiving that the police were in strong force, quietly resigned themselves to their fate, and were taken to the Charles-street Police-station, where they were incarcerated for the night. In addition to the prisoners taken the police seized a costly gaming-table, dealing-boxes, cards, checks, and other gamesters' implements, all of which are to be turned over to the police property clerk.

abstract: -- An Ohio Democratic paper  demonstrates that in two years the Union party in that State has lost just seventy thousand votes, and it asks where the organization will be two years from this time at that rate. Perhaps the mathematician will answer who demonstrated conclusively that in twenty years, if the rate of speed in traveling increased as it had done for the last twenty years, any one leaving New-York for Boston  would get there just twenty-four hours before he started.
lead_paragraph: -- An Ohio Democratic paper demonstrates that in two years the Union party in that State has lost just seventy thousand votes, and it asks where the organization will be two years from this time at that rate. Perhaps the mathematician will answer who demonstrated conclusively that in twenty years, if the rate of speed in traveling increased as it had done for the last twenty years, any one leaving New-York for Boston would get there just twenty-four hours before he started.

abstract: We do not know that wiser or more fitly spoken words have been uttered, than those addressed to his congregation last evening by Mr. BEECHER -- so far as these bear on the relations of the President to the late insurgent States. The whole case for the President and his plan of reconstruction is stated in a single sentence which cannot be too carefully pondered, not only by party politicians, but by those who have assumed the special care and supervision of the Southern freedmen. Mr. BEECHER says: "The laws and intents of the government and ourselves will prove of no avail if they are hostile and unpleasant to the white people of the South." The President, as Mr. BEECHER sees his position, has just as keen and thorough appreciation of what is due to the newly emancipated race as the most uncompromising Abolitionist at the North -- while he has the additional advantage of a thorough acquaintance with the South and Southern people.

abstract: Morris, Robert H.
snippet: Morris, Robert H.
lead_paragraph: -- The Cincinnati Inquirer contains an appropriate tribute to the memory of ROBERT H. MORRIS, who died in that city, on the 13th inst., aged 39 years. Mr. MORRIS was a native of Otsego County, and a grandson of Gen. JACOB MORRIS. The deceased studied his profession with Gov. SEWARD. He was Gov. FISH's Private Secretary. Subsequently he was connected with the Chicago Journal, and was afterward connected with the revenue service at New-Orleans. Mr. MORRIS was a truly good man, so good that all who knew him well loved him.

abstract: The Party and Pres. Johnson's "Independence"; Independence of, and the Democratic Party
snippet: The Party and Pres. Johnson's "Independence"; Independence of, and the Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: An independent man was defined by CANNING, we believe, to be a man who cannot be depended upon. That seems to be the Democratic notion of President JOHNSON'S independence. Because he forms his own judgments and adopts his own methods, it is imagined that the party which raised him to power cannot rely upon him, and that any day he may rush into the Democratic embrace. It is a most foolish mistake. True independence always proceeds from principle, and no man is more steadfast, and more to be depended upon, than the man of principle. The great Union party which carried through the war desires no better guaranty that President JOHNSON will remain true to its purposes and ends, than that same fidelity to enlightened personal conviction.
headline: {'main': 'President Johnson\'s "Independence" and the Democratic Party.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'President Johnson\'s "Independence" and the Democratic Party.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The obsequies in honor of the late Gen. WEIGHT and wife, lost with the steamer Brother Jonathan, and whose bodies were recovered from the ocean,  were observed at Calvary Church to-day. The military escorted the remains to the steamer for Sacramento, where they will be finally interred. It is believed that the Legislature will appropriate funds for the erection of a suitable monument.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Saturday, Oct. 21.

abstract: Mr. Jacob Patterson, of Monroe, Orange County, N.Y., had been suffering for years from Consomption, with severe putrid infections sore throat, to make use of his own words, a hurried respiration, hot and offensive breath, the skin of a burning and disagreeable heat, without the least moisture; the pulse quick, hard and irregular, averaging from 100 to 140 strokes per minute; the mouth and throat presenting a fiery appearance, the palate and glands painfully swelled; combined with a pain in the chest, the whole countenance presenting a ghastly, cadaverous look; the white part of the eye had a pearly, unnatural appearance, and, strange to say, the eye itself beamed with sparkling animation and lustre; the expectoration was copious and frequent; white, frothy and sometimes tough opaque substance, solid, of a yellow or green color, having a fetid smell when thrown on burning coals. In this infected state be was treated by the most eminent physicians he could find, but the excruciating pain in his side and chest, which became insupportable, so much alarmed his friends, that in this last dismal waste of life, he was taken to the well-known Dr. Von Eisenberg, of our city. At the doctor's office he complained of weakness at the least bodily exertion, and when placed in the examination chair, the breathing was fearful, the pulse was small and quicker than natural; he complained of a tightness, as if a cord were drawn across the chest. The doctor, with his usual care, made an accurate diagnosis of the case, expressed willingness to undertake to treat him, and to attend to him to the best of his ability. The doctor declared himself to be always impressed with a decided belief that our wise and beneficent Creator has placed within the reach of His feeble creature, men, a cure for all diseases; that he has often cored this fatal complaint by assiduous attention and careful judgment. The preliminary arrangements were made, Dr. Von Eisenberg operated on the patient, after which Mr. Patterson declared himself to be very much relieved, since which time the patient has been under the doctor's, care for a few weeks. To the patient's inexpressible delight, as well as to the great satisfaction of his friends, he has entirely recovered, and has just now come to New-York for the purpose of asking the doctor to allow him to resume his usual business. He looks remarkable strong, and his face is filled out and looks stouter than ever it has been; in fact, he says for the last twelve years he never-enjoyed a single night's nest, and now he sleeps as sound as an infant; and, according to his own words, he seems to have an iron digestion. He appears anxious to make known the great benefit he has derived from Doctor Von Eisenberg's skillful and successful treatment to all who suffer from this wasting and fatal complaint, and he Doctor's unremitting attention to his patients.

abstract: -- A little fact came to our  knowledge a day or two since, which shows how history may sometimes be written. A young man of not over steady habits was lately missing from his home for nearly a month. Last week he returned, saying that he had "been South" to get work, but that everybody was murdering Northerners, and he had concluded a retreat advisable. Investigation  developed the fact that his erratic wanderings had been bounded by the confines of the Sixth Ward during the entire period of his "emigration."

abstract: Anniversary Services
snippet: Anniversary Services
lead_paragraph: Of all the many religious bodies in our midst the Sabbath schools connected with the Methodist Episcopal churches present the most enjoyable features. Hearty, whole-souled singing, familiar, interesting addresses are the normal pastimes of each Sundays's session, and the result is that the benches are always well filled and the scholars never forget the lessons learned.

abstract: We learn, by way of Havana, that MAXIMILIAN issued a proclamation on the 2d inst., in which the departuie of JUAREZ from Mexican territory is officially announced. The proclamation also threatens severe measures against parties in arms against the Imperial Government. All who harbor guerrillas, or supply them with money, provisions or information, are to be summarily dealt with. The voyage of MAXIMILIAN to Yucatan, previously announced, will take place during November.

abstract: John M. O'Brien vs. Julia A. Coulter. -- Plaintiff, a lawyer, claims for professional services in procuring a loan upon defendant's separate estate. It appears that he was employed by defendant's husband, and he then procured a broker, who obtained the loan, which was accepted by the wife. Plaintiff made searches, but took no further part in the transaction and never saw the defendant personally about it.

abstract: Home Building Association
snippet: Home Building Association
lead_paragraph: The great want of the working classes of New-York is a home. Rooms in immense caravanseries of tenement-houses, or houses shared with two or three other families, cannot be called homes. An American mechanic would like to have a place which he could call his own, where he would not be subject to the watching or nuisances of neighbors, where his children could grow up in society which he could choose for them, and he could live at his own taste and fancy, dependent on no landlord or agent.

abstract: The deaths in New-York during the past week were 471 -- 109 men. 94 women, 131 boys and 137 girls -- a decrease of 23 from the mortality of the previous week, and an increase of 107 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased, 226 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 79; infantile marasmus, 44; inflammation of the lungs, 34; infantile convulsions, 31; dysentery, 26; typhoid fever, 18; typhus fever, 13; inflammation of the brain, 13; cholera infantum, 13; deaths from external causes, 41 -- among which are reported 11 premature births, 4 deaths from old age, I drowned, and 11 killed by accidents.

abstract: Keene vs. Clarke >amp; Stuart; postponed to Oct. 31
snippet: Keene vs. Clarke >amp; Stuart; postponed to Oct. 31
lead_paragraph: Laura Keene vs. John S. Clarke and William Stuart. -- The argument of this case, which was set down for yesterday morning in the Superior Court, Special Term, before Justice MONCRIEF, was, by the order of the court, on motion of the plaintiff's counsel, postponed until the 31st inst., at 10 A.M. Counsel for the plaintiff said this was the first time the cause had been put off on their behalf, and he only made the motion now because of engagements made by him prior to Saturday last, when the cause was regularly before the court, and adjourned by Justice Monell to Monday. Mr. Edwin James, counsel for the defendants, said that the speedy disposition of the case was of vital importance to his clients; they were ready to proceed with the argument, but would be under the necessity of bowing to such decision as the court should see fit to make of the matter. The court said that under the circumstances it would postpone the further hearing until the 31st inst.

abstract: Diplomatic Correspondence; Russell, Earl, and Mr. Adams on Confederate Cruisers
snippet: Diplomatic Correspondence; Russell, Earl, and Mr. Adams on Confederate Cruisers
lead_paragraph: We have to-day a brief abstract of a correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Lord RusSELL, on the subject of the depredations committed upon our commerce the Shenandoah and other Confederate cruisers. We do not perceive that there is anything either novel or startling in this correspondence. And why it should have been given to the British public, through the Official Gazette, at this particular time, is not at all apparent. In conformity with the general tenor of his instructions, Mr. ADAMS seems to have taken occasion of the appearance of the piratical craft Shenandoah in the Pacific waters in the Spring of the year, to remind Lord RUSSELL that these rebel cruisers were running up an account which his Lordship might find it inconvenient to settle. In the reply of the British Secretary, which he seems to have taken several weeks to frame, there are strong protests of the honor which has characterized all the dealings of the QUEEN's Government, and there is what appears to be a positive and final disclaimer of all responsibility for the aid and shelter given to the rebel cruizers in British ports. Mr. ADAMS, with admirable temper, suggests a friendly reference of the matters in dispute to the arbitration of neutrals. Lord RUSSELL thinks that the QUEEN's Government would be leaving their integrity as neutrals open to question in such a reference.

abstract: -- Michael Wonderly, the drawbridge keeper of Blissville, L.I., who, with his wife were injured on Saturday morning last, by the propeller Thomas Cornell running against the bridge, died on Sunday evening from the effects of his injuries. Coroner Lewis yesterday empanneled a jury and issued his warrant for the arrest of the Captain of the propeller. This proceeding was in consequence of the jury rendering a verdict incriminating him. Mrs. Wonderly is not expected to recover.

abstract: U. S. vs. 300 Bales of Wool. Undervaluation
snippet: U. S. vs. 300 Bales of Wool. Undervaluation
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. 300 bales of Wool, &c. -- The trial of this case was closed by a verdict in favor of the government. The case, as will be recollected, was brought to forfeit the goods for undervaluation. It appeared on the trial that the goods arrived here in April, 1863, on board the brig Veteran, from Matamoras. They were consigned to the firm of M. Echeverria & Co., and by them entered at the Custom-house. The shipper of the goods was Joseph San Roman of Matamoras, and the affidavit taken before the American Consul and attached to the invoice stated that the price in the invoice was the "true cost value" of the goods. The wool was invoiced at six cents a pound. On entering it here, the consignees advanced its price two cents a pound, to bring it up to market value. On appraisal at the Custom-house, the value was fixed at ten cents a pound for a part, and sixteen cents for the rest, in gold. A second appraisement was had, and the appraisement was confirmed. Upon this value the duty was laid. A penalty of 25 per cent. additional duty was also imposed and paid, and then the government seized the goods and brought this suit to forfeit them for an alleged fraudulent undervaluation.

abstract: Industrial Prospect of the
snippet: Industrial Prospect of the
lead_paragraph: The inevitable consequence of the suppression of the rebellion has been a temporary paralysis of industry and enterprise in the South. The war and the blockade, in the first place, caused a diversion of Southern labor from its accustomed channels. When cotton could no longer be exported it ceased to be produced, for the most part; and when grain and other necessaries of life were the only agricultural products which found a market, all attention was given to their cultivation. But even these articles lost their value to the producer when the so-called Confederate Government turned highwayman and robbed the people of the fruits of their toil; and in the general confusion, uncertainty and terror which prevailed at seed-time of the present year, barely enough attention was given to planting to save the people from famine during the ensuing Winter and Spring.
headline: {'main': 'The Industrial Prospects of the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Industrial Prospects of the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Early yesterday morning Patrolman COUGHLIN, of the Eighteenth Ward, found a paper box in East Fourteenth-street, between Avenue B and C, and in compliance with the police rule requiring officers to deliver at their respective station-houses, to be forwarded to the Police Property Clerk, anything that they may find in the streets, he took the box to Sergt. F.J. BANFIELD, the officer in charge of the Twenty-second-street Police-station; but that officer, opening the box and finding therein the body of an infant that been unskilfully haggled by medical students or other persons, sent it to the Bellevue Hospital Dr. THOS. ROBINSON examined the body, and found it completely disjointed, and in his opinion it had been experimented upon by persons who were practising amputation; but he was unable to determine whether the Child had been born alive.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The steam Hibernian, with European advices to the 13th, arrived yesterday off Father Point. The most important news is an abstract of a correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Lord RUSSELL, on the subject of the depredations of the Shenandoah and other rebel cruisers. Mr. ADAMS suggested a reference of the matter in dispute to the arbitration of neutrals. This Lord RUSSELL declined, but proposed to submit the case to a commission. Mr, ADAMS doubted the expediency of such a reference, when the subject was dropped. The English papers regard the correspondence as involving questions of great magnitude, but express the hope that a peaceful conclusion may be Arrived at. There is nothing very startling in the general news from the Continent.

abstract: and the Fenians
snippet: and the Fenians
lead_paragraph: -- Did not the Fenian Congress cheer too early and too lustily the other day, when they hurrahed themselves hoarse over the announced release of Mr. MITCHEL? Instead of thus going into hysterics over such an event, they ought rather to have inquired whether his liberation was not indirectly brought about by agents of the British Government in this country, for the purpose of destroying the Fenian Organization and thwarting all its schemes. JOHN's past history has demonstrated that whatever he touches politically, he kills. If the use of nervous English could make a cause triumphant, he would be the very "broth of a boy" as a leader; but if with this there should be combined a certain amount of judgment, common sense, and the respect, for the rights of others, then, he is the last man living to head a popular movement. The Fenians ought to know that Mr. MITCHEL's touch is fatal, as shown by his career in Dublin, New-York and Richmond.

abstract: SENTENCE OF A PRUSSIAN CRIMINAL. -- AUGUST ADOLPH VOIGHTMANN, the Prussian railroad officer, who came to this city last year, bringing with him a female companion and a considerable amount of money which he had embezzled from the Berlin and Hamburg Railroad Company, and who was sent back to Prussia, has just been tried by the Court of Justice at Berlin. VOIGHTMANN, it will be remembered, went from New-York to Chicago, where he built a house and proposed to establish himself in business; but he was traced by the late Prussian Consul-General, Mr. SCHMIDT, and by Mr. LAPAUGH, the counsel of the Prussian authorities, and after a hearing before a United States Commissioner, the prisoner was surrendered under the Extradition treaty. His punishment is to be eight years' imprisonment at hard labor and a fine of two thousand thalers.

abstract: Fifth Brigade, N.Y.S.M., took place yesterday on the parade ground at East New-York. The infantry proceeded to the place designated in cars of the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, but marched to the city in the evening. The different regiments presented a very fine appearance, the Fourteenth particularly looked quite gay in their Chasseur uniforms, and, as usual, attracted as good deal of attention along the line of march. The regiments comprising the brigade are the Seventieth (cavalry and artillery,) Col. W.J. CROPSEY; Thirteenth Infantry, Col. J.B. WOODWARD; Fourteenth Infantry, Col. E.B. FOWLER; Twenty-eighth Infantry, Col. CASPAR URBAN; the whole under command of Gen. P.S. CROOKE. The brigade presented a handsome appearance on the field, and went through the various manoeuvres in splendid style. With the exception of the Seventieth, all the regiments have been in active service, of which their movements yesterday gave creditable evidence. The infantry regiments averaged about 500 rank and file each, and the cavalry about 200. They returned about 5 o'clock last evening, each regiment being preceded by an excellent band of music.

abstract: The schooner S. Taylor, from Philadelphia, with coal, for Boston, was run down off Cape Cod, on Monday, by an schooner, name unknown, and sunk in ten minutes. The crew were saved. The colliding schooner is supposed to have been sunk also, as the crew were afterwards seen in their boats.

abstract: THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD ACCIDENT. -- The Grand Jury of Queens County was in deliberation two days, and found twelve bills of indictment against various parties. Two indictments were found against R.J. RACE, conductor on the mail train of the Long Island Railroad at the time of the collision near Jamaica, a few weeks since. One indictment was for manslaughter in the fourth degree, and the other was for negligence in causing the death of passengers on the train at the time. He gave bail in the sum of $6,000 to appear when called upon.
lead_paragraph: THE LONG ISLAND RAILROAD ACCIDENT. -- The Grand Jury of Queens County was in deliberation two days, and found twelve bills of indictment against various parties. He gave bail in the sum of $6,000 to appear when called upon.

abstract: Major-Gen. IMBODEN, of Virginia, is now this city to enlist the interest of our capitalists in the National Express Company, which is to be organized in Richmond on Monday next. While this company will have its headquarters at Richmond, it is designed to be, as it name implies, national in its character, and one of its first objects will be to afford occupation to the soldiers of both armies who are out of employment. The capital stock of the company, which is $10,000,000, has nearly all been taken in the South, but $600,000 was allotted to this city, and the books are now open at the office of CHARLES A. MEIGS & SON, No. 50 Exchange-place.

abstract: The fact speaks volumes in favor of the Southern blacks, that notwithstanding the innumerable atrocities perpetrated upon them in bygone years, while in a state of slavery, we have heard of no instances of revenge for past cruelties since they attained their freedom. There is no doubt that they were keenly sensitive of their wrongs, even while in slavery, and no doubt that they have had opportunities, in many cases, during the past year, for terrible retaliation upon owners, overseers, or others who have maltreated them. But they have universally, so far as we know, forgotten or forgiven the past, and have behaved in a really remarkable and praiseworthy manner toward their former masters. Let them be credited with the fact.
lead_paragraph: The fact speaks volumes in favor of the Southern blacks, that notwithstanding the innumerable atrocities perpetrated upon them in bygone years, while in a state of slavery, we have heard of no instances of revenge for past cruelties since they attained their freedom. abstract: on Vice-Pres. Johnson (Ed.); The Party and Pres. Johnson, and World, N. Y.; Quotations from President Johnson
snippet: on Vice-Pres. Johnson (Ed.); The Party and Pres. Johnson, and World, N. Y.; Quotations from President Johnson
lead_paragraph: The World is apt at quotation, and has a remarkably excellent memory when reciting the sayings of others. In commenting upon the late speech of Hon. JOHN VAN BUREN, it took occasion to point out and call attention to some of the more "solid parts of that effusion," which, to use its own language, "had been lost in the blaze of his wit, as the brilliancy of a corruscating flame conceals the solid fuel that feeds it," the point of which, after so much light has been thrown upon it, our readers of course cannot fail to see. The "solid parts referred to in the brilliant passage, are those in which the "Prince" says that a successful reconstruction must cause a remodeling of the Cabinet, and proposes to replace Mr. STANTON by Gov. AIKEN, of South Carolina; and where he also suggests MT. JOHNSON as the nominee of the Democratic party in 1868. Fearful that these bold and patriotic expressions might be lost sight of amid the scintillations of such wondrous wit, the Democratic organ takes occasion not only to call particular attention to them, but to fully indorse all that was contained therein, and proceeds to say that if the Presidential election were to take place this Fall instead of three years hence, there could be no doubt whatever that the Democratic party would nominate President JOHNSON, and would not for a moment entertain a thought of nominating anybody else.
headline: {'main': 'The Democratic Party and President Johnson.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Democratic Party and President Johnson.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: U. S. vs. 11 Cases Photograph Paper. Undervaluation
snippet: U. S. vs. 11 Cases Photograph Paper. Undervaluation
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Eleven Cases of Photographic Paper. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the goods for fraudulent undervaluation. The goods were imported from Berlin in October, 1863, by A. Hurtzell, the claimant in the cause. The invoice presented at the Custom-house on their entry described the goods as waste paper, and stated their price to be 750 Prussian thalers, and attached to it was an affidavit that that was the market value of the goods. On the entry of the goods the claimant made affidavit that that was the actual cost price.

abstract: ELEVENTH WARD DIVERSIONS. Learning last evening that a party of Eleventh Ward "sportsmen" had arranged a hostile encounter of canine animals in the cellar of DONAVAN  YOUNG'S liquor-store, at No. 75 Willett-street, Capt. ULMAN sent Policeman BERRIMAN thither, in civilian attire, with instructions to take a place in the pit as a spectator, and at the proper moment give a section of policemen in attendance a signal.
lead_paragraph: ELEVENTH WARD DIVERSIONS. -- Learning last evening that a party of Eleventh Ward "sportsmen" had arranged a hostile encounter of canine animals in the cellar of DONAVAN YOUNG'S liquor-store, at No. 75 Willett-street, Capt. ULMAN sent Policeman BERRIMAN thither, in civilian attire, with instructions to take a place in the pit as a spectator, and at the proper moment give a section of policemen in attendance a signal. The officer executed his trust discreetly, and when the quadrupeds had fought their first round he signaled his comrades, who entered and made prisoners of the multitude. DONOVAN escaped through a scuttle, but his partner, GEORGE YOUNG, and JOHN RILEY, MICHAEL FAY and PATRICK FITZPATRICK, owners of the dogs, were taken to the Union Market Police-station and locked up for the night The quadrupeds and bipeds were thrust into the same cells, and are to be taken before Justice MANSFIELD this morning. The spectators, of whom there were between twenty and thirty, were suffered to escape. The programme of the evening embraced a rat-fight

abstract: State Legislatures and Slavery Const. Amend.
snippet: State Legislatures and Slavery Const. Amend.
lead_paragraph: We have been looking with some interest for the action of the Legislature of the State of Mississippi upon the question of ratifying the Constitutional Amendment prohibiting slavery. We have had no notice yet of the introduction of the subject to the Legislature. We see no reason to doubt that favorable action will be speedily taken. The State Convention, which preceded the Legislature in its sessions, gave full proof that Mississippi was prepared to acknowledge existing facts -- those relating to slavery as well as to secession; and we have no doubt that the delay of a few weeks on the part of the Legislature in taking action upon the subject referred to, is perfectly justifiable.

abstract: The Custom-house returns for the week ending last evening make the exports of domestic produce and miscellaneous goods, from this port $5,008,602, in currency value, showing a very handsome increase over the preceding week's clearances, which were $3,402,121, as also those of the corresponding week last year, which were confined to $2,728,519, with gold at 217 1/2@218 1/2, as against 145 3/4@146 1/4 yesterday. The clearances of Cotton alone during the past week exceeded three million dollars in currency value.

abstract: Union Mass Meeting at Acad. Mus.; Speech at Brooklyn Union Meeting; Speech at Brooklyn Union Mass Meeting
snippet: Union Mass Meeting at Acad. Mus.; Speech at Brooklyn Union Meeting; Speech at Brooklyn Union Mass Meeting
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of Kings County generally, and of Brooklyn particularly, held a grand and enthusiastic ratification meeting at the Academy of Music, last evening, in the City of Churches. At an early hour the beautiful temple of art was crowded to its utmost capacity, and Manager WIER was compelled to open the private boxes that the swarming multitudes might find standing room. A fine band of music lent its inspiration to the scene, already brilliant beyond ordinary gatherings of the kind, while fair ladies smiled beamingly and encouragingly from the parquet and dress-circle.

snippet: Reply to World's Denial of Comptroller Robinson's Offering Hand; T. W. on World's Denial of Offering Hand
lead_paragraph: Mr. WEED closes a long and ill-natured letter in the TIMES with a point of startling and dramatic interest. He says that he met Comptroller ROBINSON, who actually offered his hand to him. This is a matter of vast importance to the country and to the world at large. It is, therefore, a great pity to spoil the story, but we are authorized and requested by the Comptroller to "deny explicitly that he has ever offered his hand to the 'king of the lobby' since he has witnessed the corrupt and debasing influences of that body upon the legislation of the State."

abstract: Released and Fine Remitted; Barren Island, Williamsburgh, Fish Oil Factory--$10,000; Incendiary
snippet: Released and Fine Remitted; Barren Island, Williamsburgh, Fish Oil Factory--$10,000; Incendiary
lead_paragraph: FIRE ON BARREN ISLAND -- LOSS $10,000. -- About 4 o'clock, on Monday, the large fish-oil factory on Barren Island, belonging to J.W. SMITH, of Hempstead, and WILLIAM CRYSTAL, of New-York, was fired by an incendiary and entirely consumed. The building was put up only a few months ago and furnished with valuable machinery for the extraction of oil from fish known as menhaden or mossbunker. The enterprise was not very successful, and the odor emanating from the factory was very annoying to the residents in the neighborhood. The loss will reach at least $10,000; covered by insurance.

abstract: The Austrian (press) law, says the D bats, appears to admit of very mild gradations in the punishments it applies to press offences. The New Free Press, a journal of Vienna, was accused of having excited the citizens to a disobedience of the laws, in inviting the deputies of the country to concert, as to the consequences of the new policy of the Maylath Belcredi ministry.
lead_paragraph: -- The Austrian (press) law, says the D bats, appears to admit of very mild gradations in the punishments it applies to press offences. The New Free Press, a journal of Vienna, was accused of having excited the citizens to a disobedience of the laws, in inviting the deputies of the country to concert, as to the consequences of the new policy of the Maylath Belcredi ministry. The director was declared guilty but with extenuating circumstances, and instead of being sentenced to perhaps a year's imprisonment he was simply condemned to a week's confinement in his own chamber. That is unquestionably a very paternal punishment, and we congratulate the new ministry on the happy result of the extenuating circumstances of this its first prosecution for an offence of the press.

abstract: The Burden of an Army in
snippet: The Burden of an Army in
lead_paragraph: The great feat which the government has performed of disbanding the army immediately after the termination of hostilities, will save the country from suffering from a state of things similar to that which, unhappily, afflicts the young Italian nation. Since the unification of the country by the action of GARIBALDI and VICTOR EMANUEL, Italy has retained, and it has, doubtless, been necessary for her to retain a gigantic army; and it is this expensive army which has fettered the national progress, repressed the national energies, weighed upon the nation's heart, eaten up its substance, lowered its credit, and which almost crushes the people by the burden of taxation. Its retention is rendered necessary by the fact that Italian unity is yet imperfect, and, in accordance with the doctrine held by Italy in common with other European Powers, that great standing armies are essential to the national existence. Had the Italian Government been able to deal with its army immediately after unification as we have already dealt with ours, Italy might by this day have been freed from the great burdens and evils which now almost crush her to the earth.

abstract: The Democrats having failed on every other tack, are running Gen. SLOCUM as a martyr. Their organs break out daily with pustulous paragraphs, in large capitals duly garnished with exclamation points, expressing the horror of the Democratic mind that so great a hero should be charged with having aided or permitted anything improper in connection with cotton. The dodge will not succeed. The martyrdom is not made out. The General is only one of the bogus saints of the Democratic calendar. But what if these organs could get hold of similar official documents about any of our candidates? What would they think then of martyrdom in such a connection? They would "make Rome howl" with their calumnious clamor.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats having failed on every other tack, are running Gen. SLOCUM as a martyr. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The new opera of "Crispino e la Comare" was produced here last evening with complete success. The artists who took part in the performance were in excellent voice, and everything  except the mise-en-scene was good, The opera has been hastily produced, and very badly put on the stage.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The new opera of "Crispino e la Comare" was produced here last evening with complete success. The artists who took part in the performance were in excellent voice, and everything -- except the mise-en-scene -- was good, The opera has been hastily produced, and very badly put on the stage. It is scarcely possible to speak in terms of proper reprobation of the scenery of this work. It is utterly beneath even momentary notice. The singers, happily, redeemed everything. There were many encores, and we shall take the opportunity of the repetition to-night to form an opinion of the musical merits of the work. It strikes us as very pleasantly in the vein of DONIZETTI, but with a better sweep than we are apt to find in his purely comic works.

abstract: The trial of Dr. CHARLES COBEL was concluded in the Court of Sessions yesterday. The entire day was occupied by counsel in summing up, and in the charge of the court to the jury. Most of the evidence given in this case, relating to the procuration by the defendant of an alleged fatal abortion, has been unfit for publication. At a late hour in the afternoon the jury brought in a verdict of guilty of manslaughter in the fourth degree, and the prisoner was sentenced to the State Prison for two years.

lead_paragraph: In pursuance of the theory conveyed in the old adage that honor should be given to whom honor is due, we are pleased to place on record that to the ingenuity and energy of Col. WILLIAM R. NEVINS is due the fact that from 250 to 3,000 barrels of flour were daily turned into most excellent bread for our soldiers in the field. His patent mechanical bakery was introduced by order of President LINCOLN, and was the direct and indirect means of preserving thousands of lives.

abstract: A Montreal correspondent of Le Canadien imparts the following paragraph: "The children of JEFFERSON DAVIS have been for some time in Canada, as is well Known. The two boys are just now in Chambly, and about to enter Lennoxville College. The young girl, nine years of age, is a pupil at the convent of the Sacred Heart, Sault-au-Recollets.
lead_paragraph: A Montreal correspondent of Le Canadien imparts the following paragraph: "The children of JEFFERSON DAVIS have been for some time in Canada, as is well Known. The two boys are just now in Chambly, and about to enter Lennoxville College. The young girl, nine years of age, is a pupil at the convent of the Sacred Heart, Sault-au-Recollets. Last Sabbath several Southern refugees went to see her. They brought with them the Federal Gen. COCHRANE, whom they introduced to the girl, telling her that he was a friend of the Southern cause, although circumstances constrained him to fight in the ranks of its enemies. The child, looking to the General, answered: "I shall believe that you are one of the friends of our cause when you shall have obtained the release of my father.' The General was deeply moved with this answer, and promised the child to use all his influence on behalf of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS. Gen. COCHRANE, who, I believe, occupies an official position in the United States, visited yesterday the magnificent establishment of the Hotel Dieu. He was so highly pleased with his visit, that he begged leave from the good sisters to present them with a picture for their church, which he is to forward from New-York."

abstract: Moving; Exports
snippet: Moving; Exports
lead_paragraph: An unusually active business in cotton is in progress at this port. Last week's receipts reached 29,115 bales; sales and resales, 19,400 bales. The receipts thus far in the current week average 3,892 bales a day; and the sales and resales, 7,500 bales a day. The exports from the port during the week ending last evening, reached the extraordinary amount of 12,587 bales, including 12,413 bales -- valued at $3,032,022 in currency -- to the single port of Liverpool.

abstract: John Guest vs. John Hear. Plaintiff, on Sunday evening, went into defendant's grocery store, corner of Thirtieth-street and Ninth-avenue, for some beer. Defendant's dog, being then unchained, seized the plaintiff by the leg and bit him quite severely. The dog was shown to be vicious and to have once before bitten a man's arm.
lead_paragraph: John Guest vs. John Hear. -- Plaintiff, on Sunday evening, went into defendant's grocery store, corner of Thirtieth-street and Ninth-avenue, for some beer. Defendant's dog, being then unchained, seized the plaintiff by the leg and bit him quite severely. The dog was shown to be vicious and to have once before bitten a man's arm. Defendant's counsel claimed that plaintiff could not recover, because, 1st, plaintiff was guilty of carelessness and partly contributed to bring the injury on himself; 2d, it was illegal to go into a store to trade thus on Sunday; and, 3d, plaintiff was a trespasser, the store not being then open for business. On this point the proof was very contradictory.

abstract: Announcements of new publications continue to appear, numerous, in proportion to the late quiet among the trade, as far as the production of novelties was concerned for in the supply of the staple articles of commerce the whole year has been most actively and profitably employed by publishers.
lead_paragraph: -- Announcements of new publications continue to appear, numerous, in proportion to the late quiet among the trade, as far as the production of novelties was concerned -- for in the supply of the staple articles of commerce the whole year has been most actively and profitably employed by publishers. Their productions, indeed, up to the present time, have far from kept pace with the demand, and, go where you will, the complaint is universal that it is impossible to get work done; neither printers nor binders will make new engagements until after Christmas, and a large proportion of the promised new books will have to be laid over from sheer inability to manufacture them. Some accidental causes have increased this pressure. Owing to the long-continued drouth in the Eastern States, most of the paper mills in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, from whence come the chief supplies of printing paper, are absolutely at a stand, and are unable to complete their existing contracts. The price of paper has in consequence largely advanced, and there is little appearance at present of anything like a return to moderate terms. A brisk and healthy public demand encourages the exertions of our publishing houses through these drawbacks on their legitimate profits, and enables them to see bright days across the present "sea of troubles."

abstract: The heavy returns from internal revenue continue to pour into the Treasury with remarkable steadiness. It seems that the system works exceedingly well, producing great results, with, upon the whole, a very small amount of damage to any of the national industries or interests. The greater part of the complaints that were made against the measure from special interests before it was finally established as law, and before the effects of its operation were known, have been hushed up. There are still some, but they are very few. We think the coming Congress should do as little tinkering upon the law as possible. Its leading principle and features, we take it, are now permanent, though of course its burdens may be judiciously lightened from time to time. The governmental commission, which is now in session examining this whole subject of taxation, is understood to be, in the main, satisfied with things, or at least with principles, as they now are.

abstract: Bible Union; Sixteenth Anniversary
snippet: Bible Union; Sixteenth Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The American Bible Union held its sixteenth annual meeting yesterday morning, in the Broome-street Baptist Church. A large attendance was present, and the exercises were full of interest. Rev. THOMAS ARMITAGE, D.D., President of the Union, presided. The annual report was read by Rev. CHAS. A. BUCKBEE, Recording Secretary. This report related mainly to efforts made by the American Bible Union in the circulation of the Scriptures in Spain, Italy, China, Siam, India and Africa, and among the freedmen of the South. The new translation of the Scriptures has progressed favorably. The report states that since the last anniversary, the work on the Old Testament has been recommenced by Dr. CONANT. Dr. BLISS is still prosecuting his labors for the Union on the historical books. The coming year, it is hoped, will be distinguished by the publication of a considerable portion of this part of the Bible. It also afforded the agreeable and interesting information that a pulpit and family Testament, in large print, has just been published. It has been a work of great labor, both in preparation and execution. The poetic parts have been printed in poetic form, thus exhibiting the indications of rhythm which appear in the original, and all the quotations from the Old Testament are so presented as to leave no doubt where they commence and where they close. Very many improvements in the translation from the original have also been made, which will be introduced into the plates of the 16mo. This, it is claimed, is the clearest exhibition of the revelation of God in any existing version of the Sacred Scriptures.

abstract: Diplomatic Correspondence; the Same Subject
snippet: Diplomatic Correspondence; the Same Subject
lead_paragraph: We surrender a very large portion of our available space this morning to the correspondence between Earl RUSSELL and Mr. ADAMS concerning the responsibility of Great Britain for losses inflicted upon our commerce by privateers, built, equipped and fitted out in British ports and sailing under the rebel flag. The subject is one which affects, in its discussion and result, the question of war and peace between England and the United States. It is canvassed with great fullness and ability on both sides, -- and the interest and importance of the discussion can, therefore, scarcely be overrated. The letters of Mr. ADAMS are among the ablest and most admirable of the state papers which have illustrated our history.

abstract: -- Senator HENDERSON, of Missouri, in a recent speech, gave the following account of an interview with President JOHNSON: "When recently in Washington, I called on him, and had a full and frank talk with him in reference to all the questions connected with his reconstruction policy. In that connection he stated that, in his view, the States attempting to secede were still in the Union, and had always been. That slavery was practically abolished in those States, and must be entirely so to secure admission of their members into Congress -- that they must adopt the Constitutional Amendment destroying slavery throughout the nation, and provide in their own constitutions that hereafter property shell not exist in man. Taking his stand-point that the States are still in the Union, he does not think that he can consistently interfere with the franchise in those States, or in any other, that is, that he can confer it upon persons not enjoying it, under the respective State constitutions as they existed before the rebellion. But, as an individual, he desires that the negro shall be enfranchised, and would be gratified to see the several conventions extend the franchise to all persons of color who can read the Constitution of the United States in English, and write their names, and also to all persons of color who own real estate valued at not less than $250, and who pay taxes thereon. I have now quoted the precise words of the President, and you will see that, if the Democratic party indorse him, they must indorse negro suffrage, and thus remove the last plank from their platform. I am rejoiced myself to see all parties indorsing the President. I am satisfied he is doing the best he can to restore peace and harmony between the sections. He may commit errors. It would be strange if he did not. Of one thing, I think we may all rest assured, and that is, whenever he finds an error, he will correct it, and correct it on the side of justice and the Union."

abstract: The Fourth Senatorial District Convention (Mozart Hall) met last evening, at No. 48 Monroe-street, pursuant to adjournment, and proceeded to the nomination for candidate to represent the District in the State Senate. On motion, JOHN H. WALSH, of the Fifth Ward, was called to the chair, and EDWARD B. HEATH was appointed Secretary. On motion, Hon. BENJAMIN WOOD was unanimously nominated as the choice of the party for State Senator. A committee was then appointed to wait upon Mr. WOOD and inform him of his nomination. The committee retiring, soon after returned with the successful candidate, who, on making his appearance, was greeted with applause. Mr. WOOD, in a short speech, thanked the convention for the honor conferred upon him, and accepted the nomination. The convention then adjourned.

abstract: The Union League Club, last evening, received with generous hospitalities and cordial welcome, Sir S. MORTON PETO, and his traveling friends, the English railway capitalists. At an early hour the club rooms were crowded with a gathering of our leading citizens, members of the club and otherwise.
lead_paragraph: The Union League Club, last evening, received with generous hospitalities and cordial welcome, Sir S. MORTON PETO, and his traveling friends, the English railway capitalists. At an early hour the club rooms were crowded with a gathering of our leading citizens, members of the club and otherwise. Gens. Hooker, Barlow and Dix, Admiral Farragut, Chief-Justice Chase, H.W. Beecher. Dr. Bellows, Mr. Cooper and many others, were present. Shortly after 9 o'clock the guests of the evening arrived, and were welcomed by Mr. BUTLER, President of the Club. Sir MORTON PETO made a lengthy and important speech in response. He touched upon the many international topics that now attract general attention, and was warm in his sentiments of respect and love for America and her people. Speeches were also made by Mr. EVANS, President of the English Emancipation Society, and Mr. MCHENRY, thanking the club for their reception. Ex-Senator CHASE also made a short and peculiarly national speech. Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER, Rev. H.W. BEECHER and others also made some few remarks. The club and their guests afterwards partook of a sumptuous supper, and so the interesting proceedings came to a close.

abstract: -- On the Sunday after th first battle of Bull Run, in 1861, the American agent of the house in London through which our government transacts its business, called upon the proper Secretary at Washington and requested the government to give security for the amount due his principals on account. The balance was about $40,000. The Secretary informed him that the government would not probably break up before business hours the next day, and he must request him to call again. As a matter of course, these bankers are very anxious still to be retained as agents of our government in London. The Democrats of this State are making a request very similar in its nature, and with just about as much reason. Confidence in the stability of their country has been with both these parties a "plant of very slow growth;" and the confidence of the people in them will be equally tardy in its development.
