lead_paragraph: We find in our London files the following interesting and important correspondence between Earl RUSSELL and Mr. ADAMS concerning the several questions at issue between the Governments of England and the United States. The subjects referred to have been before the public of both countries ever since the rebellion broke out, but they have never hitherto received the full discussion to which they are subjected in this correspondence. Considering the gravity of the topics and the bearing of the discussion upon the prospective relations of the two nations, its importance can scarcely be overstated.

abstract: on our Sick and Wounded Soldiers
snippet: on our Sick and Wounded Soldiers
lead_paragraph: -- In the course of his speech at the opening of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Fair in Philadelphia, on Monday evening, Maj.-Gen. MEADE said: "I am sorry that in the short time which I have had to prepare for this occasion I could not appeal to the records in order that I might give you some idea of the great debt -- of its magnitude in numbers -- our Union has yet to pay. But I was fortunately in position to have recourse to the records of a single army -- the Army of the Potomac -- [great and continued applause] -- which I had the honor for two years to command -- [renewed applause] -- fortunate in being in command of it at the close of the rebellion. [Applause.] I was in a position to take a close glance at them, and I am able to tell you, on examination, that at the close of the war there were reported to the government, as wounded, over one hundred and twenty-five thousand men. Now, of course, large numbers of them were slightly wounded, many of them returned to the ranks, not disabled. But take a very small percentage of all these -- one-fifth of all these numbers -- at least 25,000 have been disabled out of these 125,000. It will be necessary to take care of these in some way or other -- those disabled from wounds received in battle. Now these are the returns from only one army. It is one of the largest of our armies, I know, that the government had during the war, and did some of the hardest of the fighting. [Applause.] But it is not these 25,000 men alone who have to be taken, care of, but the disabled of the whole armies, East and West. When we know them, then only can we realize the whole mass of suffering. And how are we to take care of these poor men? The answer maybe that they may be taken care of some time by the government, national, State or municipal. But the government is slow to move. There is a Legislature or a Congress, and many men take long to act, and the work cannot go on without appropriations by Congress. A few days ago I had to go to Washington. I am a member of an institution whose object it is to establish a national home for soldiers and sailors. A hundred gentlemen are appointed as corporators, and over fifty must be present before anything can be done on this subject. Three times I have been to Washington, but not once were fifty collected, and upon the last meeting, in order to do anything, it was determined to appeal to Congress for special legislation. So it is with the General Government; so it is, in a measure, with the State Governments. But these poor fellows cannot wait, and to your energetic charity they look to-night."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The second performance of "Crispino e la Comare" took place last evening. We may safely say of it that it was throughly enjoyed by an audience that did not display any prepared familiarity with the pet pieces, but picked them out with promiscuous discretion and the most perfect of appreciation.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The second performance of "Crispino e la Comare" took place last evening. We may safely say of it that it was throughly enjoyed by an audience that did not display any prepared familiarity with the pet pieces, but picked them out with promiscuous discretion and the most perfect of appreciation. There are few comic operas that offer so many temptations to the ordinary listener. The music is perfectly fluent and graceful; the melodies are clearly defined and agreeable; the "patter" songs are not too abundant, and the combinations are effective without being over-wrought. There is in the first act an occasional touch of the old school, which comes quaintly and pleasantly, but which never descends to the level of boredom. Otherwise the opera is singularly fresh and vital.

abstract: -- A sensation journal has presented its readers with the luxury of a new epidemic. The Asiatic cholera, it tells them, has broken out in Brooklyn, and it has the coolness to quote the journals, of that City as its authority. The newspapers on the other side of the East River have referred to a medical report on the subject in terms of doubt. In urging sanitary reform in Brooklyn, they have discountenanced all excitement, and have, in fact, rested their pleadings in the case on the ground of a wise foresight. The people of Brooklyn are naturally amazed that their city should have been declared under the scourgings of the cholera.

abstract: The Algonquin and Winooski are still running their engines, and with a fair prospect of continuing the race until the 96-hour test shall be concluded. At 11 A.M., yesterday, our reporter visited the vessels, and found that the Winooski had made, up to that time, 37,611 revolutions, and the Algonquin 38,636 -- making a gain in favor of the latter vessel of 1,025 revolutions. Everything seems to work well on board the racers, and there is no doubt in the minds of the engineers in charge but the trial will be at last concluded.

abstract: the celebrated aurist and oculist, continues to receive patients at his office in Broadway; and, what is more to the purpose, invariably restores to health those who have lost the use of their organs of seeing and hearing. It is not possible to give the number of cures, all but miraculous, which, in the course of a very extended practice, he has been enabled to effect; but if any one is laboring under any disease of the eye, the ear, the head, the nose, the throat or the chest, the invalid will have such proof of the doctor's accomplishments offered him that he will be entirely satisfied he is among the leading physicians and surgeons of the age. He has been for many years in practice in this city, and if testimonials of his great skill were required, they might be obtained from all parts of the country. He has succeeded in the most desperate cases, and when other practitioners have considered them perfectly hopeless. It may be truly said of this gentleman, that "when the ear heard him it blessed him, and when the eye saw him it gave witness unto him;" for thousands are blessing him this day for the restoration of their sight and hearing. -- Sunday Times.

abstract: Christian Commission; Organization, >amp;c.
snippet: Christian Commission; Organization, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: An initial meeting of the new American Christian Commission, designed to succeed and take the place made vacant by the old Commission, which achieved so much good during the war, was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the American and Foreign Missions Society, Bible House. The meeting was largely attended by the Commissioners, who were appointed at the Convention of Evangelical Christians, at Cleveland. Among those present were Bishop Jane, Rev. Dr. Buddington, Rev. Dr. Durbie, Rev. Dr. Weston, Rev. Jas. J. Duryea, Rev. P.H. Fowler, of New-York; Rev. R.J. Parvin, Messrs. J. Cooke and W.E. Boardman, of Pennsylvania; Judge S.P. Chase, Hon. L.N. Olds and Rev. Dr. Nash, of Ohio; Dr. Kirk and J. Story, of Massachusetts; Mr. G.S. Griffith, of Maryland; Rev. A.D. Gillette, District of Columbia; Mr. K.A. Brunell, of Wisconsin; Mr. J.W. McIntyre, of Missouri; Mr. D.W. Ingersoll, of St. Paul, Minn.

abstract: -- About midnight on Tuesday two young bloods, rather exhilarated, in passing down Broadway, near Astor-placd, amused themselves by upsetting an ash-barrel in the street An officer of the Fifteenth Precinct pursued and arrested them both. Taking them back to the spot he required them either to shovel back the ashes into the barrel or go with him to the station-house. "No station-house for us," said the youngsters, and accordingly they set to work, the policeman standing by to witness their labor. One did his work very reluctantly; the other in the best natured manner possible. He politely demanded the officer's number, remarking that possibly some day he might require a recommendation to the street department.

abstract: Constitutional Amendment--a Word to the South
snippet: Constitutional Amendment--a Word to the South
lead_paragraph: We hope there will be neither doubt nor delay, in any Southern State, in the ratification of the Constitutional Amendment by which slavery is to be forever prohibited. This can only be done, in accordance with the resolution of Congress, by the State Legislatures, -- some of which are already in session. Twenty-seven States must ratify the amendment before it can become part of the constitution. Twenty-three have already ratified it, and four more are needed. Until these four shall have given their votes in its favor, the public mind will be uneasy and dissatisfied on this subject and all connected with it. The people demand the adoption of this amendment, as a legitimate and essential result of the war. They know perfectly well that if there had been no slavery, there would have been no rebellion; and in order, therefore, to preclude the possibility of another rebellion growing out of the same cause, they insist that slavery shall henceforth be impossible within the limits or jurisdiction of the United States.

abstract: Missionary Society; 19th Anniversary
snippet: Missionary Society; 19th Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The Christian public will be interested to know that the nineteenth annual meeting of the American Missionary Association is now in session at Mr. BEECHER's church in Brooklyn. Yesterday afternoon a very small audience assembled in the lecture room of the church and shivered in unison while the venerable secretaries and committeemen read severally their reports.

abstract: The Spirit of the
snippet: The Spirit of the
lead_paragraph: -- The Southern people have undergone a number of extraordinary and violent fluctuations of feeling within the last twelvemonth. In October of last year, they were still confident of their success in establishing a government upon which all their hopes were based, and on the success of which the greater part of them had staked their lives. They had met with disasters, but they still had two great and brave armies, and held possession of a vast territory. In the next month of, November, began SHERMAN's march which, in connection with the tremendous pressure they then began to feel from GRANT at Richmond, and the terrible blow they received in the West, affected their spirits greatly and drove them into something like a panic. The continued action of the two former influences depressed their feelings profoundly by the opening of the year. They nerved themselves up, however, till GRANT's ceaseless menaces and blows, and SHERMAN's near approach to their capital, were enough to drive them mad. Then GRANT began to deliver the last tremendous series of assaults; then despair of spirits united with desperation of action, until, with the destruction of LEE; tumbled at once all their Confederate hope. For a season after this they were sombre, and there were signs of pride struggling through their crushed feelings. Time and Summer went on, and the harp sting of defeat began to pass away, and reason began to reassert itself, and calmness began to succeed passion, and the dictates of necessity were felt to be such. Lately they have been in perfect quiet and quiescence, gaining in strength, and contentedly resuming their old position and duties. In a few months more they will be in the enjoyment of perfect sanity. They have lost a fortune, but all the elements of vitality and of other fortunes are still with them.

abstract: The newly formed American Christian Commission, designed to take the place of the United States Christian Commission, and appointed by the convention of Evangelical Christians at Cleveland, in September, held their initial meeting yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the American and Foreign Mission Society, Bible House. Chief-Justice CHASE, Bishop JANES, JAY COOKE, and other distinguished gentlemen were present. They adopted a plan of work, elected GEO. H. STUART, Esq., of Philadelphia, Permanent President, and Judge CHASE and Rev. Drs. KIRK and DURBIE, Vice-Presidents. The localization of the central office will be determined at their meeting this morning, when the Executive Committee will also be appointed.

abstract: In South America matters look very gloomy. Chili is in a sad state of perplexity owing to the pres  ence of the Spanish fleet and the demands of the Spanish Government, which there is every reason to believe will be resisted by force; for an accession to such demands would doubtless lead to a revolution. Business in Valparaiso is very dull, but there is a good demand for shipping.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Tuesday, Oct. 17.

abstract: It is particularly gratifying to perceive that the Union party throughout the State is putting in nomination some of its ablest and best men for the State Legislature. Hon. H.R. SELDEN, formerly Lieutenant-Governor, a man of rare ability and the highest character, has received and accepted the nomination for the Assembly in Rochester. LYMAN TREMAINE, one of the most eloquent and effective speakers in the State, and one of the Democrats who left their party when it ceased to be loyal, and who urged deeds rather than professions, as the test of patriotism. Hon. CLARKE B. COCHRANE, formerly Member of Congress, is also in nomination for the Assembly. Men of this stamp will give dignity and character to the Legislature and will do something, we hope, toward redeeming that body from the reproach into which unworthy members have brought it during the last few years.

abstract: Registry Law. Oath Sufficient in Absence of Naturalization Certificate
snippet: Registry Law. Oath Sufficient in Absence of Naturalization Certificate
lead_paragraph: -- Attorney-General COCHRANE has replied to an inquiry as to the proof which a naturalized citizen must give to satisfy the Board of Registry of his right to vote, in the absence of a certificate of his naturalization. The sum of the opinion is, that "the oath of the party is legally competent to prove his inability to produce the certificate." There is no likelihood of this opinion being called in question. Verbal proof, unimpeached, as the Attorney-General puts it, is legal proof.

abstract: DEATH OF A WOMAN UNDER SUSPICIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES. -- Yesterday forenoon, Coroner BARRETT was notified that a woman named ANNE JOHNSON, 35 years of age, died under suspicious circumstances, about 3 o'clock the same morning, at No. 8 Marshal-street, E.D. The facts thus far developed show that deceased, who is a native of Germany, was the wife of a colored man, whose name she bore. She had been living, for some time previous to her death, in a house of questionable repute in Broadway, kept by a Mrs. JONES. Her husband is absent in the army. Last week Mrs. JONES and deceased quarreled, the former being jealous of an intimacy existing between Mr. JONES and Mrs. JOHNSON. In consequence of this quarrel, deceased left Mrs. JONES' house on Monday last, and took up her residence at the place where she died. On Tuesday she was visited by Mrs. JONES, and a quarrel ensued. On Wednesday she called again, and the quarrel was renewed, but it is stated that they afterward purchased some liquor and drank together. After this Mrs. JOHNSON became very sick, and she sent for some medicine. Some powders were obtained, one of which she took, but she got no relief, and expired after much suffering at 3 A.M. Thursday. Some of the powders were found in her room, one of which was shown a druggist, who stated as his opinion that it consisted of corrosive sublimate. The body became considerably discolored shortly after death. Dr. CREAMER will conduct a post-mortem examination this morning, and an inquest will be held by Coroner BARRETT.

lead_paragraph: The commission held their adjourned meeting yesterday morning, to settle upon the location of the central office and the appointment of an executive committee. Owing to members having to leave by the early trains, the session was very short. It was decided, after considerable debate, to make the location that of New-York, and steps ordered to be taken with that determination.

abstract: Union Course. George Wilkes vs. Com. Vanderbilt, trot for $2,000
snippet: Union Course. George Wilkes vs. Com. Vanderbilt, trot for $2,000
lead_paragraph: The great match stallion trot between those rival stallion champions of the trotting turf George Wilkes, whilom known as Fillingham, and the new aspirant for trotting honors, Commodore Vanderbilt, came off at the Union Course, Long Island, yesterday. The merits of the two contestants have long been patent to the public. The fame of the stallion Wilkes, was an established fact prior to the current trotting year, during which he seemed to have lost his old trotting form, and like Butler and some others of our trotting notables to have gone into equine decadence. A change of trainers and drivers appears however to have exercised a most beneficial effect -- as the result of yesterday's race fully proves.

abstract: Views on Reconstruction; Missouri; Appeal for Right to Vote
snippet: Views on Reconstruction; Missouri; Appeal for Right to Vote
lead_paragraph: The colored people of Missouri, through a State Executive Committee, have issued an address to the people of that State, asking for such laws as will give them the right to vote. They ask it as essential to the security and enjoyment of the rights conferred upon them by emancipation, as true and loyal citizens of the United States, and as men who have defended and maintained the government in the field of battle. They say they do not ask for social equality, for that depends upon higher than human laws. They aver their willingness to submit to any tests and restrictions that are required of whites, but they think that political rights and franchises should no longer depend upon color alone. They propose to organize as a party, and to employ speakers, issue appeals, and in every proper way press their claims upon the people of the State, and they solicit contributions in aid of this object.

abstract: Philadelphia; Mr. Perry's (U. S. Consul to Tunis) room robbed of valuable coins; Embassadors from arrive at Washington
snippet: Philadelphia; Mr. Perry's (U. S. Consul to Tunis) room robbed of valuable coins; Embassadors from arrive at Washington
lead_paragraph: A Washington dispatch to the Philadelphia Ledger says: "The notice issued by the State Department, some time since, calling for the presentation of claims against foreign governments has been quite freely responded to, and Mr. SEWARD will no doubt give these matters his attention soon after his return. This notice was made public before Earl RUSSELL had pointedly refused to entertain Mr. ADAMS' proposition for a settlement, but the latter fact will not, it is believed, deter Mr. SEWARD from making up a complete list of all just claims and presenting His Lordship with the bill in full. In no event, however, is an unpleasant result feared. The fact that the finances abroad were not at all influenced by the publication of the correspondence, shows that Lombard and Thread-needle streets at least, were perfectly calm over the matter, and that all the 'apprehensions' of a break in the friendly relations of the two governments were confined to the editorial sanctums of the London journals. The impression here to-day is that the commission suggested by Earl RUSSELL will be accepted, and that all the questions in dispute arising out of the war, on both sides, will be referred to that body for adjustment.

abstract: Five-twenty Loan, Absorption of the
snippet: Five-twenty Loan, Absorption of the
lead_paragraph: Fifty million dollars of Treasury and compound interest notes, and certificates of indebtedness, have been converted into fivetwenty six per cent, gold-bearing bonds, under the funding proposals of Sept. 29, from the Department at Washington. This fact was announced yesterday, accompanied by an authoritative statement to the effect that no further opportunity to convert legal tender notes into interest-bearing bonds would be available to the public, prior to the meeting of the next Congress. The promptness with which the people exchanged their greenbacks for gold-bonds, under the first funding appeal of the Secretary of the Treasury, clearly demonstrates the undiminished partiality of all classes of capitalists for our national securities.

abstract: DISTRESSING ACCIDENT. Coroner LYNCH held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a daughter of Mr. ALEXANDER MATTHEWS, residing in the Town of New Lots, who came to her death in the following manner: Herself and mother arose about 6 o'clock
lead_paragraph: DISTRESSING ACCIDENT. -- Coroner LYNCH held an inquest yesterday upon the body of a daughter of Mr. ALEXANDER MATTHEWS, residing in the Town of New Lots, who came to her death in the following manner: Herself and mother arose about 6 o'clock A.M., and kindling a fire in the kitchen stove, the little girl, who is about 9 years of age, eat beside it. Having complained of a sore throat her mother handed her a bottle of liniment and directed her to rub it on her neck and breast, which she did. The bottle accidentally upset and some of the fluid falling upon the stove caught fire. The flames communicated to her person, and before aid could be rendered she was burned nearly to death. Her mother had previously gone up stairs to superintend some sewing machines, which were in full operation, and the noise made was so great that the shrieks of the child could not be heard. On returning to the kitchen, the mother found her daughter in the agonies of death. She expired in a short time thereafter.

abstract: -- According to the official figures, the national indebtedness was reduced nearly thirteen million dollars in September, or at the rate of one hundred and fifty-six millions a year. Such an energetic process of liquidation would result in the discharge of all the national pecuniary obligations in about twenty years. Rapidly, however, as the public debt is diminished, the interest charge will, of course, fall off. Economy in this important item must lessen materially the national expenses and accelerate the liquidating process. Hence it may be safely assumed that before the long six per cents (now having sixteen years to run) shall have matured, government will have paid off all other claims upon it, and made adequate provision for the prompt cash redemption of the 1881 bonds, "On presentation by the holders."

abstract: E COMPANY, THIRTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT. A very pleasant company assembled last evening to do justice to a very elegant entertainment tendered to the members of Company E, Thirty-seventh Regiment, National Guard, by its newly elected Captain, ERNEST DES MARETS, and Lieuts. WHELAN and BRUNTON. The occasion was one of unmarried pleasure and enjoyment.
lead_paragraph: E COMPANY, THIRTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT. -- A very pleasant company assembled last evening to do justice to a very elegant entertainment tendered to the members of Company E, Thirty-seventh Regiment, National Guard, by its newly elected Captain, ERNEST DES MARETS, and Lieuts. WHELAN and BRUNTON. The occasion was one of unmarried pleasure and enjoyment. After the fhe cloth was removed short and telling speeches were made by Cols. ASHLEY and CATLIN, (the latter recently elected to fill the vacancy caused by Col. ASHLEY's resignation,) Major FARRAR, Capt. DES MARETS, Mr. A.D. MUNSON and others. Capt. DES MARETS is the youngest Captain in the regiments, and enjoys the satisfaction of commanding one of the finest companies in which three years ago he was a private. He is ably seconded in his labors by Lieuts. WHELAN and BRUNTON, both officers of standing and experience.

abstract: Diplomatic Correspondence; the Same Subject
snippet: Diplomatic Correspondence; the Same Subject
lead_paragraph: The World is undoubtedly quite right in assuming that "our government has no present intention to interrupt amicable relations with England." It has no intention to do so now, nor at any future time, unless the obstinate and arrogant refusal of the British Government either to redress the wrongs we have suffered at her hands, or to submit the questions in dispute to a fair and just arbitration, should leave us no alternative. There is every reason why we should be on friendly terms with Great Britain, and the single consideration of the terrible evils which would follow an interruption of friendly relations between the two countries, is weighty enough to forbid the thought of such an event except in the last resort.

abstract: Ann Foley was tried for stealing $60 from a fireman named William Williams, residing at No. 71 Washington-street. The complainant went to the prisoner's room, having $60 or $70 in his pocket, where he remained four hours; was asleep, and on waking up missed his money; when he asked her where it was she told him to go to sleep again, but he got up and informed the landlord, who then locked the prisoner in the room and sent for an officer. On search being made the money was found in the bed between the mattresses, but the accused denied all knowledge of its position.

abstract: on the South Victorious
snippet: on the South Victorious
lead_paragraph: WENDELL PHILLIPS ON VICTORY. -- The more accomplished of the modern quacks have found it profitable to resort to cabalistic phrases in advertising their wares. Some of them startle the expectant public with the coinage of a word presumably derived from Grecian mythology. Others resort to some mathematical or algebraic expression, and mutilate it into a form suitable to their purpose. And yet another class, of less originality, seize upon current slang, and render it subservient to the embellishment of their scarcely marketable commodities. Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS announced himself as belonging to the latter class, when he drew together a company of listeners at the Cooper Institute on Wednesday evening, by placarding the dead walls of the city with his handbills, in which he declared "the South victorious." The South has been declared victorious, over and over again, by the poor Richmond editors; by the people who manufactured the Chicago platform; by the London Times, its money editor and its Liverpool correspondent, SPENCE; by Sir HENRY DE HOGTOWN and the subscribers to the Southern cotton loan; by LAIRD, the ram-builder; and by JOHN MITCHEL, of the New-York Daily News. And having regard to all these authorities, Mr. W. PHILLIPS comes hither by express from Boston, heralding his approach with the announcement that what these touters of the defunct Confederacy, these ram-builders and cotton speculators had declared a fact, was true. Nothing to this arrant pretender and quack that the cause of loyalty, honor and freedom had triumphed in the death of tens of thousands of the best and bravest men of the nation! He must advertise his wares, and proclaim, in the language of the sworn enemies of the republic, the triumph of treason.

abstract: Patrolman HANFORD CORBY, of the Tenth Ward, was clubbed and severely wounded on Wednesday afternoon, by JULIUS BRECHTMAN, keeper of a liquor-store at No. 22 Columbia-street, and yesterday Coroner GOVER thought proper to take his ante-mortem deposition at the New-York Hospital. CORBY says that he employed his day off duty in visiting with Officer GROSSMAN and others; that in the afternoon he drank a glass of lager-bier in a confectioner's where GROSSMAN had once worked; that he went into BRECHTMAN's to get a glass of water; that he had drank no intoxicating liquor and was not drunk; that he suddenly received a blow on the head, for what he does not know; that he staggered and threw up his hands to save himself; that he had a pistol with which to protect himself, but did not discharge it in the liquor-store; that the three persons whom he encountered cried, "Kill the son of a b_____;" that he [???]ade them not kill him for anything he had done as an Officer, &c. Mrs. BRIDGET BRECHTMAN, wife of the saloon-keeper, testified, substantially, that CORBY entered her husband's place very much under the influence of liquor; that BRECHTMAN would not accommodate him; that the officer thereupon assaulted her husband; that she interfered and CORBY drew a pistol and attempted to shoot her; that HERMAN BOLTE, a tenant of the house, descended from his apartments and aided BRECHTMAN in putting CORBY out, and that in the struggle CORBY was struck on the head with a club. After listening to other testimony the jury found a verdict against BRECHTMAN, and Coroner GOVER required him to find $3,000 bail to await the result. It is not probable that CORBY's wounds will prove mortal.

abstract: Washington, of Harriet Wells; Arrest of Farwell
snippet: Washington, of Harriet Wells; Arrest of Farwell
lead_paragraph: LEVI L. FARWELL, the young Bostonian whom a Washington jury have accused of the murder of his paramour, HARRIET WELLES, was arrested in West Broadway, yesterday afternoon, by Detective Officers ELDER and MCCORD. The murder was committed on Monday morning last, in the victim's brothel, in Thirteen-and-a-half street, Washington. It appears that FARWELL became enamored of the deceased when she dwell in Albany, and that he accompanied her thence to Washington. He appears to have been a rejected suitor for her hand, and is alleged to have said that if she would not marry him she should be no person's bride; and in pursuance of this threat he is said to have administered chloroform while she was asleep, and to have strangled her and thrust her corpse into a closet. The Washington police, immediately after the commission of the deed, communicated by telegraph with the police of the seaboard and other cities, describing FARWELL, and making it known that he probably had the gold watch which had been worn by the murdered woman; and with this information our detective officers undertook to find the fugitive. He was captured while in the act of pawning a lady's watch, which is believed to have belonged to the victim, and this watch, which is in the hands of the police, may be an important link in the chain of evidence against the accused. FARWELL was taken to the Headquarters of the Metropolitan Police, last evening, and there held to await the arrival of officers from Washington -- for whom Inspector LEONARD telegraphed, and one of whom (Detective CLARVOE) was put aboard the night train for this city by Chief-of-Police A.C. RICHARDS, of Washington. The deceased, who was quite respectably connected, had a son at school at New-Brunswick, N.J. The TIMES is requested to say that FARWELL sold to some person in this city, recently, a lady's gold chain, and that the purchaser thereof (who, if he conceals it, may be held as accessory after the fact of the murder) is requested to deliver it to the Superintendent of Metropolitan Police.

abstract: Internal Revenue, Increase of
snippet: Internal Revenue, Increase of
lead_paragraph: The income of the government from internal revenue is again on the increase. Thus far in the current week it has averaged close on to a million a day, or equal to nearly six millions a week. Since the commencement of the current fiscal year, July 1, the National Treasury has received from this prolific source about one hundred and fourteen million dollars, or a weekly average of nearly seven million dollars, equal to an aggregate of over three hundred and sixty millions a year. The revenue which the government is assured of, from direct taxation, in the current fiscal year, will enable it to defray its expenses, reduce its indebtedness, strengthen its credit in the money market, and prepare the way for the prompt restoration of the national finances to a specie basis, in conformity with the mature policy and steady aim of Secretary MCCULLOCH.

abstract: Among the distinguished visitors at Police Trials, before Commissioners ACTON, BERGEN and McMURRAY, on Wednesday, were Major-Gen. JOHN C. ROBINSON, commander of the Northwestern Department of New-York, and Capt. JOHN McMURRAY, Chief of the Commissary Department of Northwestern New-York.
lead_paragraph: Among the distinguished visitors at Police Trials, before Commissioners ACTON, BERGEN and McMURRAY, on Wednesday, were Major-Gen. JOHN C. ROBINSON, commander of the Northwestern Department of New-York, and Capt. JOHN McMURRAY, Chief of the Commissary Department of Northwestern New-York. The calendar was lighter than usual, there having been only seventy-three complaints; and among these not one was from Brooklyn -- a fact from which it is inferred that the recent changes among superior officers and transfers of their subordinates have worked a wholesome reform over the river. Alderman TERNAN was expected to appear against Patrolman JOHN MATTHEWS and JOHN EICHHORN, of the Fiftieth Precinct, he having accused those officers of taking an active part in a Brooklyn primary election while in full police uniform on the afternoon of the 4th inst.; but the Alderman tarried in the City of Churches, and the policemen were not molested. abstract: Peto, Sir M., Speech at Union League Club, N. Y.
snippet: Peto, Sir M., Speech at Union League Club, N. Y.
lead_paragraph: On Wenesday evening, agreeably to previous announcement, the President and members of the Union League Club, of this city, held a special festival in honor of the English Railway Capitalists, who have been traveling through the country the past month. The proceedings were full of interest, from the fact that they drew together nearly all of our leading citizens of the Empire City, besides many who belong to other sections. At an early hour the rooms of the club-house were filled with the members and friends, among whom were conspicuous Gens. Hooker, Dix and Barlow, Admiral Farragut, Chief-Justice Chase, Hon. Robt J. Walker, Peter Cooper, Esq., Rev. Dr. Chapin, Rev. Dr. Bellows, Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, Cyrus W. Field and others, fully as well known. Shortly after 9 o'clock the guests of the evening arrived, and were immediately ushered into the main saloon by the House Committee. The rooms leading into this apartment were speedily filled by the gentlemen present Mr. BUTLER, the President of the Club, welcomed the party of tourists in an appropriate speech, speaking of the interest felt by Americans in the extensive and exhaustive tour just completed by Sir MORTON PETO and his companions. He also spoke of the gratification felt by the club at being able to welcome to their hospitality so many well-known and hearty friends to the cause of the Union.

abstract: The steamer Africa, with dates to the 15th instant, arrived at Halifax yesterday. The steamers Hansa and City of New-York, with dates to the 12th, arrived at this port, the former yesterday forenoon, the latter at an early hour this morning. The Adams-Russell correspondence continued to be the chief topic of discussion in the papers. Lord RUSSELL's course in refusing to submit the question of damages for injuries inflicted on our commerce to arbitration is fully approved and sustained by the English press, though none of the papers appear to adopt an offensive tone toward the United States. The Atlantic Telegraph Company have resolved to increase their capital to two millions sterling. Arrest of Fenians still continue. A dispatch from Rome denies that any movement of the French troops has yet taken place. It is reported that several of the German Governments will soon recognize the Kingdom of Italy. The cholera is diminishing in Madrid.

abstract: The calendar yesterday was not as heavy as usual. Martin Hudson, a hotel thief, was convicted and sent to the Penitentiary for six months.... Michael Rooney, employed in the gas-house in the Sixteenth Ward, stole a pair of boots worth $9, while he had plenty of money in his pooket to pay for them....John Rodgers (colored) ran out of a tailor's store with a coat and was caught. Penitentiary four months....George Mortimer, a respectable looking young man, was convicted of an unnatural offence, committed in the World Building, on a man who gave his age as 17, but who looked nearer 24. He was remanded for sentence....Patrick McCusker entered the liquor-saloon of Edward Kelly, with 13 cents, and asked all hands to drink. Kelly didn't see it. A row ensued, and Cusker hit Kelly; Kelly hit back, and had the best of the personal damage, but the worst of it after they were defeated, as they threw bricks in through his window. Guilty. Fined $25....Wm.E. Allen, well known in sporting circles as Butt Allen, who was convicted at the last session of the court of keeping a disorderly house in Broadway, was sentenced to one month in the penitentiary and fined $50. This sentence of the court has created more excitement in the city among sporting men than any other case that has arisen in years.

A row ensued, and Cusker hit Kelly; Kelly hit back, and had the best of the personal damage, but the worst of it after they were defeated, as they threw bricks in through his window. Guilty. Fined $25....Wm.E. Allen, well known in sporting circles as Butt Allen, who was convicted at the last session of the court of keeping a disorderly house in Broadway, was sentenced to one month in the penitentiary and fined $50. This sentence of the court has created more excitement in the city among sporting men than any other case that has arisen in years.

abstract: Algonquin Dock Race; Note of E. M. Dickerson
snippet: Algonquin Dock Race; Note of E. M. Dickerson
lead_paragraph: At 11 A.M. yesterday our reporter visited the Algonquin and Winooski, and found the engines of each vessel working with their usual ease. The Winooski appeared to be gaining on her rival, while the Algonquin seemed to be getting tired. On examining the logs of both vessels, we found the counter of the Winooski to be 59,328; that of the Algonquin, 60,566 -- making 1,238 revolutions in favor of the latter vessel. It will be remembered that Mr. DICKERSON complained that the Algonquin's position at the dock was unfavorable to her, on account of the action of the tide. The Navy Department ordered the Winooski to take the place occupied by the Algonquin, and the Algonquin to go on the other side. It is believed that at the expiration of the present trial the vessels will change places and start on another 96-hour contest. This will be necessary to obtain a correct average of the working of both vessels.

abstract: The American Bible Union held their second and concluding session yesterday. The principal business transacted was the adoption of committee reports, especially that relating to the issue of the new and revised edition of the New Testament. Sir MORTON PETO visited the meeting and made a short address.
lead_paragraph: The American Bible Union held their second and concluding session yesterday. The principal business transacted was the adoption of committee reports, especially that relating to the issue of the new and revised edition of the New Testament. Sir MORTON PETO visited the meeting and made a short address. Addresses were also made on the condition of the Church by Dr. SMITH, of New-Jersey, and Dr. CALDICOTT, of Canada. The evening was devoted to the delivery of two addresses by Rev. Drs. EATON and HENDERSON in defence of the new edition and the proposed alliance.

abstract: -- Mr. VAN BUREN recently took the liberty of making public part of a private conversation held by him with Mr. DEPEW, Secretary of State. Mr. DEPEW has now taken the liberty of completing the narration. It will be found worth reading. Mr. VAN BUREN's indorsement of Gen. BA[???]LOW, as having made a very "remarkable record for extraordinary personal courage and brilliant achievement," and his denunciations of Gov. SEYMOUR and JOHN B. HASKIN, are particularly emphatic. JOHN must either be more cautious in his walk and conversation, or less ready to report what others say in private intercourse.

abstract: ALLEGED OFFICIAL CORRUPTION -- A HOBOKEN COUNCILMAN EXPELLED FROM THE BOARD. -- A few weeks since, Councilman CHAMBERLAIN, a member of the Hoboken Council Board, preferred charges against Mr. BACKER (Democrat,) a member from the First Ward, for soliciting and receiving bribes in control of his action as a member of the board. It was alleged that in August last Mr. BACKER, in his capacity of Councilman, solicited and received from GEORGE HECKER a bribe of $15 for his vote and influence in procuring the passage of a contract; through the Board of Councilmen in which HECKER was interested; that Councilman BACKER proposed to SEBA M. BOGERT, for certain consideration in money, to vote for and use his influence in procuring the payment by the board ofcertain bonds, in which Mr. BOGERT and others wore interested; that he proposed to PETER MEAN, for the sum of $1,000, to vote for and use his influence in procuring the passage of certain resolutions guaranteeing the issuing of bonds and scrip in which a number of parties were interested. The Board of Councilmen held a meeting on Thursday evening, when the matter was thoroughly investigated. The charge of receiving a bribe of $15, also the second charge, were fully sustained. The third charge fell through for the want of sufficient evidence. At the conclusion of the investigation, the board by a unanimous vote passed a resolution expelling Mr. BACKER.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's popular, and as some think, best, opera of "Ernani," is selected here to-day for the matinee. It will be remembered that when this work was given a fortnight since it created a genuine furore, so admirable was the cast. The same distribution is yet preserved. We notice that Mr. MARETZEK's second subscription opens on Tuesday next, and seats and boxes can now be secured. The great event will be the production of MEYER BEEB's "Africaine."

abstract: Russell, Earl; Dispatch on Emancipation Proclamation in 1863
snippet: Russell, Earl; Dispatch on Emancipation Proclamation in 1863
lead_paragraph: Earl RUSSELL, in the last of his letters to Mr, ADAMS, takes occasion to congratulate him upon the close of the war, and especially upon the abolition of slavery. Upon this last point he says that the British nation have always looked with the deepest abhorrence upon slavery, and that "the efforts by which the United States Government and Congress have shaken it off, have, therefore, the warmest sympathise of the people of these kingdoms."

abstract: Regular Infantry, died of congestion of the brain, on Wednesday, at the New-York Hospital. His company and the officers of his regiment, with a fine band, bore his body from the hospital to Greenwood Cemetery, on Thursday, and there, after the reading of the burial service by the chaplain of his regiment, the Captain was buried under a salute. Capt. MENZIES, who had served seven years in our army, and risen through merit from the ranks, was a native of Yorkshire, England, and had highly respectable relatives there at the time of his death. He was 37 years of age.

abstract: A MYSTERIOUS AFFAIR. -- Officer PHELAN, of the Forty-sixth Precinct, on Thursday afternoon, found Mr. GEORGE SPRAGUE, of No. 30 Ainslie-street, E.D., lying in the vacant lots in Bushwick-avenue, near Remsen-street, E.D., in a state of insensibility, with a cut on his head and blood issuing from his mouth and nose. The officer conveyed Mr. SPRAGUE to his residence, where he still lies in a low state. It is not believed that he has met with any foul play, but he is unable to give any account of the cause of his injuries. It is probable that he fell in a fit and struck his head against a stone. Mr. SPRAGUE had only been absent from home a few hours when found in the condition described.

abstract: The contest between the Algonquin and the Winooski is practically at an end. The Winooski stopped her engines at 4 30 yesterday afternoon, she having run for 96 hours without any stoppage whatever. At the time of stopping, the engines of the Winooski were in as good, if not better, condition than when she began the trial. On the other hand, it is said that the engines of the Algonquin will require several new tubes before she can again resume the contest.

abstract: Gen. THOMAS has telegraphed as follows to Gov. BROWNLOW, under date of Washington, Oct. 15: "The Secretary of War has authorized railroad companies South to give their bonds for the payment of debts due the government for railroad property, the government retaining full title to the property, with the right to take possession of the same at any time deemed necessary until paid for. No road is allowed to purchase more than sufficient for its actual wants."

abstract: -- Mr. MASON, late Minister of the Confederacy in London, has taken the trouble to deny that he over knew anything of the original allocation of the Confederate cotton loan, or that he ever sent information to the Richmond authorities respecting such allocation. Probably this may be true. But Mr. MASON's deputy in Liverpool, Mr. SPENCE, corresponding editor of the London Times, knew something about the matter in question. Why, then, is Mr. SPENCE silent? His report on the so-called fabricated list is eagerly looked for, and will be read with interest.

abstract: LARCENY IN THE U.S. APPRAISER's OFFICE. -- Collector KING having informed Justice DOWLING that he suspected an employe of the Appraiser's office of theft, the Justice deputed Capt. JOURDAN and Sergt. QUINN, of the Sixth Ward, to make an investigation. The result was, that they arrested, yesterday, LEWIS H. VAN SCHAICK, on charge of stealing a piece of dress silk. The charge was preferred by Ex-Police Justice JEREMIAH LOTHROP, and on his affidavit the accused was required to find $1,000 bail to answer a charge of grand larceny.

abstract: Policeman CHARLES C. BUDDINGTON, of the Fifth Precinct, took an unknown young woman from the rear of No. 27 Leonard-street, where she had fallen from the top of a staircase, and she was admitted to the New-York Hospital, suffering from concussion. She died on Thursday morning, and Coroner WILDEY was summoned. To give the police authorities opportunity to learn something of the deceased, the Coroner adjourned the inquest until to-day. The body, which lies at the New-York Hospital House for the Dead, for identification, is that of a blonde of about 20 years.

abstract: Letter of on the Test Oath; Mr. Stuart's letter
snippet: Letter of on the Test Oath; Mr. Stuart's letter
lead_paragraph: We publish, this morning, a letter from Hon. A.H.H. STUART, member of Congress elect from the Charlotteville District, Virginia, in reply to our article counseling the people of Virginia not to elect representatives who could not swear, according to law, that they had never participated in the rebellion. Mr. STUART denies that he ever participated in the rebellion, inasmuch as he "neither sought nor held any public position during the war." Yet he admits that he "gave aid, countenance and even encouragement, in every way I could, to my gallant though misguided countrymen." It seems, then, that he needs to be informed, first, that, by common law, one who aids and encourages the commission of a crime is particeps criminis, which means a participator of the crime; and, secondly, that the Constitution of the United States declares that "adhering to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort," is treason, which makes Hon. A.H.H. STUART, by his own confession, a traitor.

In very few instances have they left their old homes.

abstract: UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S COURT BEFORE COMMISSIONER NEWTON SEIZURE OF ALCOHOL BY THE GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES. Some time since a  libel was filed before Commissioner NEWTON against 800 barrels of alcohol which were on board of a vessel at the foot of South Sixth-street, E.D., and on private  information the commissioner ordered the marshal and deputies to seize the goods, which was subse-...
lead_paragraph: UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER's COURT -- BEFORE COMMISSIONER NEWTON -- SEIZURE OF ALCOHOL BY THE GOVERNMENT AUTHORITIES. -- Some time since a libel was filed before Commissioner NEWTON against 800 barrels of alcohol which were on board of a vessel at the foot of South Sixth-street, E.D., and on private information the commissioner ordered the marshal and deputies to seize the goods, which was subsequently carried into effect. It is alleged that the seizure of this alcohol will bring to light a system of frauds against the government in which certain parties in the New-York Custom-house are implicated. The manner in which they operated appears to be this: They would enter in bond a quantity of goods for exportation, ship them on board outward-bound vessels, and transfer them again to other vessels and lighters, which succeed in evading, or rather are permitted to land the goods, thus defrauding the government out of the whole amount of the duty, which on the article of alcohol is very heavy. It is reported that one Custom-house clerk receives as his share of one transaction $10,000. Commissioner NEWTON and the Assistant District-Attorney are now busily engaged in investigating the case, and as soon as they procure all the facts the names of the parties engaged will be divulged.

abstract: In Western Europe and Preparations Here
snippet: In Western Europe and Preparations Here
lead_paragraph: Cholera has not yet loosened its hold on Western Europe. This mysterious epidemic, after making its presence slightly felt in England, and in a more alarming degree in France and Italy, was at last advices making great havoc in Madrid. In one day, as many as five hundred and forty cases had presented themselves in that city, and of these not less than one hundred and seventy had terminated fatally. It is needless to say that a general panic had seized the citizens, and that the usual pitiable scenes common in times of these visitations were once again enacted.

abstract: Sir MORTON PETO and friends, yesterday, visited the institutions under the charge of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, and were accompanied, by special invitation, by Gen. JOSE ANTONIO PAEZ, Ex-President of Venezuela, and several officers of his staff. The whole of the distinguished party, not numbering over twenty in all, were received by the commissioners at the Bellevue Hospital at about 11 o'clock, and conveyed in a special steamer first to the institutions on Randall's Island, where they were received by the boys of the institution in the usual semi-military manner, with drawn sabres and flying colors. As soon as the party had received their salute an urchin of ten years stepped forward and welcomed England's representatives to the home of New-York foundlings. The little orator said they had heard of the great work in which Sir MORTON PETO and his friends were engaged, investing millions in developing our resources, opening new avenues of trade and binding together in iron bands the different sections of country along our borders. In conclusion the little orator said: "We thank you for this mark of your recollection, and trust the visit of such a distinguished assemblage may prove a powerful incentive to our well-doing, and praying that success may crown your great effort, I again welcome you to Randall's Island."

abstract: We are having a great many inquiries for sewing machines from various parts of the country, and as we cannot conveniently reply to them all by mail, we have thought it proper to state our opinion in regard to them in this public manner. We have used WILSON's patent, manufactured by the Wheeler & Wilson Manufacturing Company, No. 625 Broadway, and we can say in regard to it, that it is without a rival. It is simple, not easily put out of order when in proper hands, and, in point of effectiveness and finish, no other machine stands ahead of it. This famous sewing machine is highly appreciated the world over. We state this much in regard to the excellent machine upon our own responsibility.
lead_paragraph: We are having a great many inquiries for sewing machines from various parts of the country, and as we cannot conveniently reply to them all by mail, we have thought it proper to state our opinion in regard to them in this public manner. We have used WILSON's patent, manufactured by the Wheeler & Wilson Manufacturing Company, No. 625 Broadway, and we can say in regard to it, that it is without a rival. It is simple, not easily put out of order when in proper hands, and, in point of effectiveness and finish, no other machine stands ahead of it. This famous sewing machine is highly appreciated the world over. We state this much in regard to the excellent machine upon our own responsibility.

abstract: Kentucky; Mayor Wingate's, of Lexington, Attempt to Return to former Owners, and Gen. Palmer's Action There-on
snippet: Kentucky; Mayor Wingate's, of Lexington, Attempt to Return to former Owners, and Gen. Palmer's Action There-on
lead_paragraph: The congregation of colored persons in this city, claimed to be slaves by the neighboring farmers and others, has become an evil of such magnitude as to require correction. It is, therefore, hereby notified to such owners and claimants, that unless such colored persons are removed from the city to the homes of their claimants by the 25th day of this month, legal proceedings will be instituted under the State law to compel compliance. The City Marshal and his assistants shall at once make out a roll of the age, sex and claimant of all colored persons going at large in this city, and hand a copy to the City Attorney for proper legal proceedings.

abstract: Fashion Course. Butler and Dexter, wagon race
snippet: Fashion Course. Butler and Dexter, wagon race
lead_paragraph: This match created unusual excitement in the trotting world. The recent fame which Dexter has established for himself, both in public and in private, as the best trotter of his year, has been patent throughout the past Summer and Fall. All trotting men have been previously versed in the knowledge of the merits of the "Contraband" Butler as a trotter under saddle, and especially to wagon, he having, prior to this date, made the best time on record. Hence unusual interest was attached to the meeting of these two champion trotters at the Fashion yesterday. The day, at this late season of the year, was unusually fine, although it threatened rain during the early morning.

abstract: -- A recent supplement of the Calcutta Gazette contains a very interesting report from Mr. ANDERSON, of the damage sustained by the Botanical Gardens during the destructive cyclone of October last. The fury of the storm was greater at the gardens than in the City of Calcutta, since they were nearer the centre of the storm; but it seems to have been principally owing to the "open surface of the river across which the gale at its height blew diagonally, and thus struck the garden with a force unbroken, for the space of a mile, by any obstacle whatever. Few trees fell before 11 o'clock on the 5th of October, and almost none after 4:30 P.M. At 4 o'clock the great specimen of Andansonia digitata, the Baobab tree of Africa, was uprooted, and fall with a crash that caused vibrations in the earth, which were felt at a distance of some hundred yards. Three gigantic specimens of Casuarina equisitifolia, the oldest of the species in the garden, and none of them less than 150 feet in height, fell comparatively early in the storm." It trill take years to repair the damage done to those beautiful gardens, and no description can give an accurate idea of it. "The scene in the garden, the morning after the cyclone, was most dismal," says the Superintendent. "A thousand trees, many of them gigantic specimens and the pride of the garden, were prostrated, besides innumerable shrubs of which no account could be kept. Nothing had been spared, and those trees that had not fallen were more or less stripped of their branches; some recorded as standing were mere bare poles, without a branch. Not a vestige of a leaf, flower or fruit remained in the garden." The destruction among the smaller plants in pots has been of equal extent, but these losses are of secondary importance compared with the destruction of trees, many of them the growth of three-quarters of a century. Several specimens were only in cultivation in the Calcutta garden, "and some of them are known to botanists only by dried specimens and descriptions of those trees now lost.....In the teak avenue, along the road from KYD's monument to the large bridge over the khal, only two mutilated specimens remain. The trees in this avenue were sixty-nine years old. Out of sixty-seven mahogany trees, thirty-one have been blown down. The mahogany grove, consisting of trees forty-five years old, is destroyed." The cycadeae and palms, and the endogenous trees generally, seem to have escaped with comparatively little injury. The report, which extends over ten pages of the size of the London Gazette, concludes with a detailed list of the trees injured. It appears from this that 1,010 specimens have been totally destroyed.

abstract: The Board of Fire Commissioners held their regular meeting yesterday morning, and transacted a great amount of routine business. They organized Metropolitan Hook and Ladder Company No. 11, to be located at No. 518 Fifth-street, and a new engine company, No. 39, for duty, at Manhattanville, on the plan of other suburban organization, (fifty men, with a company fund of $1,000 per annum, in lieu of compensation.) They also established the statue of volunteer firemen in good standing. Hose Companies Nos. 47,59 and 24, and Truck Company No. 13, were relieved from duty, and ordered to be discharged on the 10th of November. After awarding several contracts for alterations and buildings, and approving appointments and transfers, the board took a recess until Monday morning.

abstract: London Herald on Pipes of Peace
snippet: London Herald on Pipes of Peace
lead_paragraph: opinion, which is sage even for that journal, when it says of the Adams-Russell correspondence -- "We had hoped that the whole of this tedious business was done with, and that when Federals and Confederates had agreed to bury the hatchet of war, Lord RUSSELL and Mr. ADAMS might have agreed to smoke the pipe of peace together." To back up this compromise view of matters generally, the Herald says the demands made by Mr. ADAMS are "insulting," and that no English Minister "could listen to them." This is the London Herald's idea of smoking the pipe of peace, and making things comfortable generally.

abstract: The story about a collier having inherited the Drummond estate, near Swansea, and  8,000 a year is denied.
lead_paragraph: The story about a collier having inherited the Drummond estate, near Swansea, and £8,000 a year is denied. Though the collier was a claimant, the heir to the property is Mr. RICHARD BACKHOUSE, of Liverpool, whose solicitors write: "The report has arisen, we believe, from certain proceedings in ejectment which were lately commenced against some of the tenants of the property by this same THOMAS, during which, owing to the tenants failing to enter an appearance or communicate with the receiver appointed by the Court of Chancery, he obtained temporary possession of their dwellings and farms, from which, however, he has not only been ordered by Vice-Chancellor WOOD to withdraw, but was, along with the Sheriff and Under Sheriff of Glanmorganshire, as the officers executing the writ of possession, ordered to pay the costs of their illegal proceedings on pain of attachment. Our client, Mr. RICHARD BACKHOUSE, of Liverpool, is the proved heir-at-law of the former owner of the estates, and we are happy to say that his title is perfectly clear, and depends not upon any such misty pedigree as that rested upon by this would-be fortunate collier or by those who, fostering his hallucination, made him the the hero of a comedy called 'A Reverse of Fortune.' We think it fair to add that, though very considerable, the value of the estates has been much exaggerated."

abstract: that the veteran officers and soldiers of this State will not forget that the Union candidate for Comptroller is that same THOMAS J. HILLHOUSE who so ably filled the office of Adjutant-General to Gov. MORGAN. Remembering the identity of this gentleman, they cannot forget his uniform courtesy to all New-York officers who had business with his office, his unwearying assiduity in attending to the necessities and wants of the State troops, and the promptness with which all recommendations for promotion were acted upon during his term. Many a New-York officer who has attained rank in the service owes his advancement to the discernment of Mr. HILLHOUSE. And need we say more to claim the gratitude of these veterans, than to remind them that Mr. HILL HOUSE was the originator of that noble institution, the Bureau of Military Statistics, designed to perpetuate the memory and record the patriotism and bravery of the New-York Volunteers.

abstract: A year or more ago LEVI L. FARWELL, of Concord, Mass., became enamored of HARRIET WELLES, of Albany, mistress of a brothel. This female dallied With him a while, and once accompanied him to his parents' abode, in Concord, and there passed as his wife; but the dalliance was of short duration. The female recently changed her place of abode to the Second Ward of Washington City, and FARWELL followed her thither and there pressed his suit, but was rejected; and resolved that if the object of his affections would not become his bride she should marry no other man, he went to her bed-chamber and applied chloroform while she slept, on Monday morning last, and having paralyzed her with the other, strangled her and thrust her corpse into a closet. He fled to this city, taking a small gold watch which she had worn. Chief of Police A.C. RICHARDS, of Washington, having secured a description of the fugitive and the watch, telegraphed to the Metropolitan Police, and our detective officers -- ELDER and MCCORD -- putting their peculiar machinery in motion, traced him, after searching three days and nights, to a house in West Broadway, and there captured him on Thursday evening. When taken, FARWELL had his victim's watch on his person, and knowing it to be the only tangible evidence against him, strove to conceal it; but in this attempt he was defeated. Detectives ELDER and MCCORD took their prisoner to Police Headquarters And incarcerated him in Murderer's Cell -- the same wherein BEALE and KENNEDY, and another murderer who committed suicide therein, were held while in custody at Headquarters -- and he was left for the night under care of doorman ROBERT P. BROWN. Inspector LEONARD, meantime, telegraphed to Washington, and Detective JOHN A.W. CLARVOE, of that city, was dispatched to receive the prisoner; but on the officer's arrival here, yesterday morning, FARWELL was found to have committed suicide. It appears that subsequent to his imprisonment at about 10 o'clock on Thursday evening, his food was passed into his cell on a tin plate -- the attendants giving him no knife or fork, lest he should make improper use thereof; and having no sharp instrument, he tore the plate in two, and with its jagged edges opened a vein in his right arm, and, lying over on his prison couch, died of hemorrhage. Murderers' Cell, wherein FARWELL died, is on the ground or basement floor, underneath the Detective's office, and is approached by a staircase from that office or from the apartments of the Broadway Police, on the Mott-street side of the police building; but it is surrounded by solid masonry and seldom visited at night, it being the duty of the night watchmen merely to see that no prisoner escapes. The cell is so situated that the inmate is completely concealed from the watchmen outside, and all that the police can do to prevent their prisoners from committing suicide in this place is to deprive them of weapons. When found, yesterday morning, the body was quite cold, and under the head was a bloodstained note, written in pencil, bequeathing FARWELL's effects to his brother, and saying that he was going to meet "HATTIE." Coroner WILDEY impaneled a jury, and a verdict of "suicide" having been rendered, the body was surrendered Mr. CHARLES H. FARWELL, of Washington, brother of the deceased. FARWELL was 36 years of age. His victim, who was aged about 35 years, was respectably connected, and had a son at school at New-Brunswick, N.J.

Murderers' Cell, wherein FARWELL died, is on the ground or basement floor, underneath the Detective's office, and is approached by a staircase from that office or from the apartments of the Broadway Police, on the Mott-street side of the police building; but it is surrounded by solid masonry and seldom visited at night, it being the duty of the night watchmen merely to see that no prisoner escapes. The cell is so situated that the inmate is completely concealed from the watchmen outside, and all that the police can do to prevent their prisoners from committing suicide in this place is to deprive them of weapons. When found, yesterday morning, the body was quite cold, and under the head was a bloodstained note, written in pencil, bequeathing FARWELL's effects to his brother, and saying that he was going to meet "HATTIE." Coroner WILDEY impaneled a jury, and a verdict of "suicide" having been rendered, the body was surrendered Mr. CHARLES H. FARWELL, of Washington, brother of the deceased. FARWELL was 36 years of age. His victim, who was aged about 35 years, was respectably connected, and had a son at school at New-Brunswick, N.J.

abstract: The case of Major DE VERE, of the British Royal Engineers, who was deliberately shot by JOHN CURRIE, a sapper under his command, was lately commented on in this paper in an article under the heading of "Military Morality."
lead_paragraph: The case of Major DE VERE, of the British Royal Engineers, who was deliberately shot by JOHN CURRIE, a sapper under his command, was lately commented on in this paper in an article under the heading of "Military Morality." In it extracts were given from letters by officers of the corps to which the deceased Major formerly belonged, declaring that their security required that the murderer should be taken from the civil authorities and tried by a court-martial. Though their assertions in this particular have been unheeded, it is decreed that the criminal shall be transferred to the military authorities for punishment. CURRIE is therefore to be executed at Chatham Barracks in presence of the regiment of which he was a member when he committed the crime. It is due to his comrades to state that no collusion on their part is charged or oven suspected. The London Daily News, in a leader upon the subject, laments that the present system of British military punishments, among which it enumerates head-shaving, flogging, &c., does not tend to reform the character of the soldier; at the same time, with singular inconsistency, indorsing the proposition for the execution of the murderer in the compulsory presence of his former comrades, on the ground that, if any one of them be at present at heart a murderer, he will be taught, by such an exhibition, a lesson he will not be likely to forget. Permit us to add, that criminal records abundantly prove that such lessons are not only not forgotten, but in too many instances, imitated and embellished with additional horrors.

abstract: of South Carolina, on the South as it is
snippet: of South Carolina, on the South as it is
lead_paragraph: Hon. KENNETH RAYNER, of North Carolina, has publislied a letter of marked interest on the condition and necessities of the Southern States. He says the people of his section regard JAMES BUCHANAN as more responsible for secession than any other man, and that a strong remonstrance from him at the outset would have arrested the sccession movement so as, at all events, to have given the people time for reflection. His inaction led the South to suppose the government intended to be inactive, and when Mr. LINCOLN came in they regarded the Union as dead. His call for troops, therefore, seemed to them vindictive -- not as the act of a government exerting its rightful power and vindicating its just authority, but as an attempt to punish them for the steps already taken. Under this feeling the North Carolina Convention met and passed the ordinance of secession; and, having passed it, a sentiment of honor impelled them to back it up. On this point Mr. RAYNER says:

abstract: Political Ornithology
snippet: Political Ornithology
lead_paragraph: It is sometimes both amusing and instructive to study the analogies which exist between the different departments of nature; the comparative habits of beasts and birds, for example, and the organic structure and modes of life which are common to the animals and vegetable kingdoms. An interesting study of this sort, in natural history, has recently been furnished us in a new and unexpected quarter. One would hardly look for ornithological analogies in the developments of a political party -- the great unterrified Democratic party, for instance -- unless, indeed, it might be found in the memorable attitude of that famous rhetorical eagle who, standing on the highest peak of the Alleghanies, stretched one wing to the Rocky Mountains and the other to the Atlantic ocean -- and split in a blaze of glory. Nevertheless, the pages of the naturalist do furnish us with a coincidence which, though less imposing, enjoys the advantage of being more definite and comprehensible, than that which is formed in the fierce gray bird, with the bending beak, the fiery eye and the very peculiar shriek.

abstract: -- We learn that a few days since Captain GEORGE MCFADDEN, while on his way from New York to Lubec, fell in, when opposite South Old Long Island, with what is termed a dead calm. The opportunity seeming propitious, the captain and a young man named PETER JOHNSON, determined to enjoy a salt-water bath. Jumping into the water, it was not many minutes when young JOHNSON says he saw something "all white," and in an instant he was carried under the surface to a depth of twenty feet. He now discovered that he was in the jaws of one of those voracious man-eater sharks. Struggling with all his strength, JOHNSON managed to break away and reach the surface again; but the shark was soon after him, and continued to bite him in various parts of the body, when the young man bethought him of the sailor trick of putting his fingers in the shark's eyes, which he did, and to his no small gratification soon saw the frenzied monster fleeing from him. JOHNSON now swim to the vessel, and being taken aboard, was found to have been fearfully torn about the abdomen -- its lower section entirely off -- both thighs and shoulders being terribly lacerated. There being no wind to get anywhere, the crew took him in the yawl and rowed him eight miles to the village of Greenport, where his wounds were sewed up and dressed by Drs. KENDALL, BRYANT and SKINNER, and the young man made as comfortable under the circumstances as possible. JOHNSON was formerly a member of the First Maine Heavy Artillery, and is said to be one of the best swimmers in the State. -- Portland Advertiser, Oct. 23.

abstract: Mr. RUSKIN, in his late volume entitled Sesame and Lilies, declares Englishmen to be "a money-making mob," which is satisfied with "concentrating its soul on pence." This is the perfect echo on English soil of NAPOLEON's famous description of England as "a nation of shopkeepers." It is the reappearance and affirmation by an Englishman of the Emperor's verbal attack on the British character. How just it is we leave Mr. RUSKIN and his countrymen to settle between themselves.

abstract: State Election; Nominations, so far as made
snippet: State Election; Nominations, so far as made
lead_paragraph: Rarely in the history of politics, here and hereabouts, have the opposing parties permitted the day of election to draw so near, the nominations being yet incomplete, the organizations remaining so undefined, the plan of campaign so entirely unrevealed. We are within a few days of the battle of ballots which is to determine the strength and influence of parties, the popularity and worth of candidates, and as yet the party lines are obscure and the candidates are not all made known.

abstract: -- The Temps, of Paris, contains a high eulogium on the Washington Cabinet. On the cessation of the civil war the American Government had 1,000,000 of troops under arms, perfectly disciplined, and proud of their recent triumphs. A single word from the War Office has sufficed to disperse this mass of military. In less than three months every camp has been cleared -- those immense groups of men who, it is said, were lost to the arts of peace, have quietly returned to their homes, and are restored to agriculture, commerce and industry. There have only been retained a sufficient number of men and officers to complete the work of pacification and consolidate order in the South, which is struggling with the difficulties inseparable from a state of transition from slavery to the institutions of a free country. Having disbanded its troops, the American Government not only sells its locomotives, steam-engines, horses and beasts of burden, but its whole war equipments. An advertisement published in Philadelphia states that there will be an auction of cannon, bombs, pistols, swords, powder, shot, &c.; while another announces the public sale of wharf-boats, transports, &c. Other governments leave their cannon and war accoutrements to rust in their arsenals, but the sharper practice of the United States has promptly converted these useless materials into ready money, a system which the Temps strongly recommends to the practical statesmen of Europe, and especially to the apostles of political economy.

abstract: Reports of suspicious doings at the place in the rear of No. 5 Goerck-street having recently been made at the Delancey-street Police-station, Capt. STEERS instructed Special Officer ANDERSON to make an investigation. Obeying orders, Officer ANDERSON "piped" the neighborhood of Grand and Goerck streets and observed that many persons clad as countrymen called at the house and went thence with bundles under their arms, and that other persons, who drove fleet horses, visited the place at early dawn and after nightfall and left huge and mysterious packages. Making cautious inquiry of the persons who dwell nearest No. 5 Goerck-street, Officer ANDERSON ascertained that about two months ago one FRANCISCO BOHAGER, a young Italian, hired two dark and uninviting rooms in a rear dwelling, and that he had studiously kept himself aloof from all other occupants of the house; that no person had learned his business or that he had any business, and that the frequent calling of strangers, either delivering or bearing away packages whose contents were unknown, had excited remark.

abstract: Red Jacket Medal, History of the; Red Jacket and the Six Nations, History of
snippet: Red Jacket Medal, History of the; Red Jacket and the Six Nations, History of
lead_paragraph: There is now on exhibition at the jewelry-store of Messrs. BROWNE SPAULDING, under the Metropolitan Hotel, a curious medal, formerly the property of the famous Indian Chief RED JACKET, and now belonging to one of his descendants, Col. PARKER, of Gen. GRANT'S staff. The history of this relic of revolutionary days is somewhat interesting. After the revolution, the six nations of Indians were left by their allies, the British, to secure a treaty of peace for themselves as best they could with the American Government. In 1784, the first preliminary treaty was made. In 1794, a final and definite treaty of peace was made and concluded. During the pendency of the final negotiations in 1792, a deputation of the six nations of Indians visited Washington, and were presented with several medals of this size. With this deputation was RED JACKET, who was just then coming into notice as an orator, and at that visit made quite an impression upon Gen. WASHINGTON, then President of the United States. RED JACKET was selected as a recipient of one of the medals. A profound veneration and friendship was created in RED JACKET's mind toward Gen. WASHINGTON, which he retained until the day of his death, in 1833. Of the great number of presents received by RED JACKET in his several visits to Washington, this medal was the only relic he retained to the day of his death. His regard for it arose from the fact that it was given in evidence of the good will and friendship of the United States toward the Six Nations. Its brightness was said to be emblematical of the brightness of the peace entered into, and the material, the value of the great friendship which should ever thereafter continue between the United States and the Indians. No tarnish could rest upon its white surface without its being immediately seen, and the parties to the compact, of which it was an emblem, could immediately unite their efforts and remove it. RED JACKET always wore the medal on all great and state occasions, and it was his pride in his speeches to allude to its emblematic character, At his death, in 1833, it was made a sort of heir-loom, and descended to his nephew, JAMES JOHNSON, a protege of his and a Seneca Chief. JOHNSON was apparently an proud of the sacred memento as was his illustrious predecessor. In 1851, however, unknown to the Indians generally, some parties prevailed upon JOHNSON to part with it for a small consideration, to the New-York State Museum at Albany. In its transit it was intercepted by Col. PARKER, then living at Rochester, New-York, who paid the consideration that JOHNSON expected for it. Col. PARKER retained it until 1852, when the principal sachemship of the Senecas and the Six Nations having become vacant by the death of JOHN BLACKSMITH, he was installed into the office and formally invested with the medal as an official badge. Col. PARKER has since retained the medal as an official medal, although it is not probable that it will be continued after his death, as the Indians are gradually abolishing the system of government by chiefs and adopting republican forms of government.

abstract: Owing to the recent rain-sterm, very few  sited the Central Park yesterday, though those who did, found the walke in admirable condition, being firm and pleasant to the feet. The day, during the forenoon and the earlier hours of the afternoon, was charming, there being neither heat nor dust to annoy the visitors, while the modulated warmth of the October sun made it both delightful and agreeable.
lead_paragraph: Owing to the recent rain-sterm, very few sited the Central Park yesterday, though those who did, found the walke in admirable condition, being firm and pleasant to the feet.
