abstract: GIDEON JONES YOUNG, an opium-eater, died at Believue Hospital, and Coroner COLLIN was summoned, yesterday, to hold an inquest.
lead_paragraph: GIDEON JONES YOUNG, an opium-eater, died at Believue Hospital, and Coroner COLLIN was summoned, yesterday, to hold an inquest. It appears that YOUNG, who was 51 years of age, and without family, had recently lounged in the dining-room of the St. Charles Hotel, and became known thereabouts as an opium-eater; and on Tuesday evening last, after having taken a room at the St. Charles, he sent a boy out to get a quantity of opium, twenty grains of which he took that evening. On the following morning, while suffering from delirium, he sent for more opium, but was given other stimulants, and sent to Bellevue Hospital, where he died on Friday. Dr. THOMAS ROBINSON made a post-mortem examination and found that YOUNG had suffered from gangrene of the lungs. Among the deceased's effects the Coroner found the following choice production:

abstract: -- At about 8 o'clock, Mr. T.R. AGNEW's grocery, at No. 260 Greenwich-street, was damaged to the extent of about $10,000 by fire, which was kindled by a lighted match carelessly thrown into a lot of waste paper. The building, which may be repaired for $500, is insured for $10,000 by the Star Company. Mr. AGNEW has insurance on his stock as follows: In the Gebhard office, $10,000; in the Germania, $20,000; in the Relief, $10,000; in the Mechanics' and Traders', $10,000; in the Humboldt, $20,000; in the Hope, $10,000, and in the Jersey City, $10,000....At about 6 o'clock, a bed was burned in Mr. JOHN KELLY's apartments, in the rear of No. 16 Cherry-street, and damage to the amount of about $250 was done to the furniture and building. The latter is insured for $4,000 in the Firemen's office....Between 9 and 10 o'clock, a fire in the show window of the dry goods store at No. 159 First-avenue, was extinguished by Officers LOHR and RODDY, of the Seventeenth Ward, with damage not exceeding $100. Insurance, $3,000, in the North American office.

abstract: -- In the hospital at Nashville, a short time ago, a wounded hero was lying on the amputating table, under the influence of chloroform. They cut off his strong right arm and cast it, all bleeding, upon the pile of human limbs. Then they laid him gently upon his couch. He woke from his stupor and missed his arm. With his left hand he lifted the cloth, and there was nothing but the gory stump. "Where's my arm?" he cried; "get my arm, I want to see it once more -- my strong right arm." They brought it to him. He took hold of the cold, clammy fingers, and looking steadfastly at the poor, dead member, thus addressed it with tearful earnestness: "Good-by, old arm. We have been a long time together. We must part now. Good-by, old arm. You'll never fire another carbine nor swing another sabre for the Government," and the tears rolled down his cheeks. He then said to those standing by: "Understand, I don't regret its loss. It has been torn from my body that not one State should be torn from this glorious Union."
lead_paragraph: -- In the hospital at Nashville, a short time ago, a wounded hero was lying on the amputating table, under the influence of chloroform. They cut off his strong right arm and cast it, all bleeding, upon the pile of human limbs. Then they laid him gently upon his couch. He woke from his stupor and missed his arm. With his left hand he lifted the cloth, and there was nothing but the gory stump. "Where's my arm?" he cried; "get my arm, I want to see it once more -- my strong right arm." They brought it to him. He took hold of the cold, clammy fingers, and looking steadfastly at the poor, dead member, thus addressed it with tearful earnestness: "Good-by, old arm. We have been a long time together. We must part now. Good-by, old arm. You'll never fire another carbine nor swing another sabre for the Government," and the tears rolled down his cheeks. He then said to those standing by: "Understand, I don't regret its loss. It has been torn from my body that not one State should be torn from this glorious Union."

abstract: -- The last will and testament of EDWARD MOTT ROBINSON has been filed in the Probate Court of this city. He bequeths in his daughter, HETTIE H. ROBINSON, $919,000, and the property known as the North Point Dock Warehouse. To HENRY A. BURLING, of New-York, $10,000; to ABNER H. DAVIS, of New-York, $10,000; to WILLIAM E. WATSON, of New-Bedford, Mass., $1,000; the town of South Kingston, R.I., $10,000, to be paid in eighteen months, the interest accruing to be applied to the endowment of an educational institution. The rest of the estate to BURLING, DAVIS and E.P. MANDVELL as trustees and executors in behalf of said HETTIE. If she dies without issue, all but $400,000 goes to such persons as she may by her will devise, and the balance be divided according to law provided she dies intestate, otherwise $100,000 each is bequeathed to WILLIAM A. ROBINSON, of Providence, R.I.; ALBINON ROBINSON, of South Livingston, R.I.; SLYVESTER C. ROBINSON and AMOS A. CHASE, of Salem, Mass., brothers and sister of testator, or to their issue. The will particularly requests that his mercantile obligations growing out of the partnership concern of WILLIAM T. COLEMAN & CO., shall be liquidated. Each executor is to be responsible for his own acts, and not for those of his co-executors. -- San Francisco Bulletin.

lead_paragraph: -- A letter from Wiesbaden, in the Cologne Gazette, gives some curious details relative to the discussion which has just taken place in the Chamber on the subject of the diplomatic representatives of Nassau abroad. It appears that the functions of the Envoy Extraordinary from Nassau to Darmsdat were confined, according to official documents of 1863, to -- 1. The paying a visit to the Minister of Hesse; 2. having an audience with the Grand Duke; and 3, being, present at the marriage of a Princess. For each of these acts the Envoy Extraordinary sent in a note of expenses, the amount of which excited the surprise and hilarity of the chamber. Another diplomatist represents at the Diet of Frankfort both Nassau and Brunswick. In consequence of this he has found himself forced, in 1862, to combat in the name of Nassau actively in the Diet the treaty of commerce with France, and to defend not less warmly the same treaty in the name of Brunswick. In the same way be protested, on behalf of Nassau, against the Prussian dispatch of 20th December, 1861, relative to federal reform, and supported energetically the same dispatch on behalf of Brunswick.

abstract: -- The stories told by some of the Eastern papers, regarding the cave discovered here, surpass all the latter-day sensations. They have increased the number to five caves, with a great lake immediately under the city. We are not told how many small towns are in existence beneath us, but it would appear from foreign accounts that a new country has been discovered. -- Nashville Dispatch, Oct. 24.

abstract: -- Those persons who have occasion to travel by this important line of conveyance, will doubtless be glad to learn that the work of rebuilding Cos Cob Bridge, destroyed by fire on the night of the 14th inst., has been so far completed that trains will probably pass over it some time to-day or to-morrow, and by Monday next all trains will be running again on their usual time. Instead of bulky spans of 120 feet long, as formerly, piles have been driven and trimmed off level with the stone piers, and upon the whole a heavy frame-work of timber is constructed to the level of the road bed. The new bridge is believed to be stronger if possible than the old one. When it is home in mind that every piece of timber for the construction of the bridge, 650 feet long, had to be taken from distant points, it will be conceded that the work has been pushed with commendable alacrity.

abstract: -- In this district Mr. BEACH of Queens County and Mr. GILBERT, of Brooklyn, have been nominated as candidates, to fill the place of Judge BROWN, whose term will expire on the first of January next. Mr. GILBERT, having received a nomination from the members of the Democratic Convention, who withdrew therefrom for very good reasons, has also been indorsed by the Union Convention of the district. This should, and probably will, ensure his election. He is an able lawyer and an upright man, and withal a loyal War Democrat. We trust it is not necessary to ask for Mr. GILBERT the hearty support of the Union men of the district.
lead_paragraph: -- In this district Mr. BEACH of Queens County and Mr. GILBERT, of Brooklyn, have been nominated as candidates, to fill the place of Judge BROWN, whose term will expire on the first of January next. Mr. GILBERT, having received a nomination from the members of the Democratic Convention, who withdrew therefrom for very good reasons, has also been indorsed by the Union Convention of the district. This should, and probably will, ensure his election. He is an able lawyer and an upright man, and withal a loyal War Democrat. We trust it is not necessary to ask for Mr. GILBERT the hearty support of the Union men of the district.

abstract: ern people, yet they might have continued the contest a while longer. But the impression was a general one, that if we were overcome we should be conquered, but not destroyed. I know the fact that those who have been most anxious for peace, those who for the last eighteen months or two years of the war were in favor of taking the best terms the Government and the Northern people would grant us -- "reconstructionists," as they have been termed -- have always relied on the magnanimity of the North in the day of victory. They never would believe -- and they have repelled the charge -- that the North would take pleasure in humiliating the South, and rioting in their cruelty over a bold and manly fee. They believer, the North was sincere in their professions; that their purpose was to preserve the Union; and that when that great purpose was accomplished, they would relent and allow sympathy for suffering, and magnanimity in the hour of triumph to take the place of vengeance and wrath. Sincerely and respectfully your friend,

abstract: In the Circuit Court, Part II., of this city, during the October term, there were three separate panels of jurors summoned, and out of them about one hundred non-attending jurors have been fined by the court $25 each.
lead_paragraph: In the Circuit Court, Part II., of this city, during the October term, there were three separate panels of jurors summoned, and out of them about one hundred non-attending jurors have been fined by the court $25 each. The presiding Judge expressed his opinion to the effect that until the Legislature of the State sees fit to alter the law, it will be impossible to secure the services, as jurors, of the wealthy and business men of the city. They pay the fine prescribed by the statute rather than sit in the jury box two or three weeks every year. He concluded his remarks on this point by expressing the hope that some action would be taken by the next Legislature, in regard to the law of jurors for this city.

abstract: -- The little more than a week that remains before the election, should be given to an active canvass by the Union electors of the Sixth and Seventh Districts, where the candidates for Senators -- ABRAHAM LENT and THOMAS MURPHY -- are worthy of united and zealous efforts. When conventions present such nominees, they confer a favor upon the electors, and if the electors do their duty, the city and all its great and varied interests will be promoted and protected.

abstract: Election Expenses in England
snippet: Election Expenses in England
lead_paragraph: In these days when placards meet the eye at every turn, reminding us that this or that man is the "regular candidate" for some office or other, we have found it interesting to read some statements which we have noticed in the English papers, regarding election expenses, at the late Parliamentary elections. It seems that in England an official account of the expenses incurred by any candidate has to be made out and filed, where it is accessible to all, in the Sheriff's office, if we mistake not. As a matter of course, these accounts get into the newspapers, and we have been at the pains to bring together what we have found.

abstract: Rollins, E. A., Appointed Commissioner, vice Orton, resigned
snippet: Rollins, E. A., Appointed Commissioner, vice Orton, resigned
lead_paragraph: Commissioner ORTON, the accomplished Chief of the Internal Revenue Bureau at Washington, resigned his position last Wednesday to enter upon the discharge of the duties of President of the United States Telegraph Company, to which position he was recently elected. His successor as Commissioner of Internal Revenue, it is now announced, will be Hon. E.A. ROLLINS, the able and indefatigable Assistant Commissioner. Mr. ROLLINS has been connected with the Bureau from its organization early in 1863, first as cashier, and since the election of the former Assistant Commissioner, Hon. E.D. MCPHERSON, to the position of Clerk of the National House of Representatives, as successor of Mr. MCPHERSON. He has most creditably performed all duties assigned to him, through the successive administrations of Commissioners BOUTWELL, LEWIS and ORTON, legitimately earning the promotion to the head of the Bureau, which, it is now understood, is gracefully accorded to him by President JOHNSON on the special recommendation of Secretary MCCULLOCH and the retiring commissioner. He cannot fail to meet the just and reasonable requirements of all interested parties. Commissioner ROLLINS is a New-Hampshire man by birth, a graduate of Dartmouth College and of the celebrated Cambridge Law School. In his State Legislature he represented the district in which he resided through several terms, being twice chosen presiding officer of the Assembly. He is now about thirty-nine years of age. Commissioner ROLLINS, on his return from a short visit to his home in New-Hampshire, will formally assume the position to which he has been chosen, on next Wednesday, Nov. 1, and will be succeeded in the position of Assistant Commissioner by Mr. D.C. WHITMAN, heretofore Chief Clerk of the Bureau, and now promoted.

abstract: -- The Moniteur publishes some statistics of the manufacture of beet-root sugar in France for the season of 1864-5, ending July 31, of the present year. At that date 398 manufactories were in operation, against 366 in July, 1864, and the quantity of sugar produced was upward of 146,000,000 kilos, an increase of 39,000,000 kilos on last year's yield.

abstract: Florida Times established at Jacksonville
snippet: Florida Times established at Jacksonville
lead_paragraph: -- Messrs. REED & HODGSON have commenced the publication at Jacksonville, Florida, of a daily journal called the Florida Times. It is handsomely printed, and ably edited. In short, it does credit to the name it has adopted. Mr. REED who performs editorial labor upon the Florida Times is a veteran in the service, having served an apprenticeship of twenty years upon different journals in the North.

abstract: A catastrophe almost unparalleled for the horrors with which it was attended is reported by the last mail from Calcutta. It was occasioned by the loss of a vessel -- the Eagle Speed -- and yet it can scarcely be designated as a shipwreck, but rather a cold blooded massacre of some hundreds of human beings. Let us briefly refer to the facts. On Sunday, August 19, a cargo of 497 coolies, natives of India, consisting of 305 men, 93 women, 65 children under ten, and 39 infants in arms embarked in the Eagle Speed, Captain BRINSDEN, from Port Canning for Demerara. This practice, carried on to stock the labor market of the West Indies recognized and placed under restrictions to prevent abuses. It will be observe from the classification of the passengers that about two-fifths of the whole would be almost completely helpless in an hour of great danger. The ship seems to have been average vessel. All the usual formalities of inspection were observed except one, that of mustering the crew by the pilot, which it seems was a duty which should by no means have been neglected. Only six men were fit for work. The captain was ailing, and he was anxious to get out to sea, "that there his men might get well after a debauch on land;" the chief officer was off duty, and even the coolie doctor was ill; but the port doctor, Capt. HOSKINS, took his place and accompanied the ship down the estuary. She was towed by the Lady Elgin, a Calcutta steamer, Capt. HEATH, on board of which as a passenger was Capt. W.G. MAITLAND, of the Twenty-ninth Punjabees. At 4 o'clock the next day, during rough weather, the tow-rope broke, and whilst efforts were being made to stretch another the ship drifted on to some sands and sprang a leak. This it is asserted would not have occurred had the ship been an iron one or new. Then with a bad leak and heavy weather, instead of towing the ship back to Halliday Island, the nearest good anchorage, the steamer took her out towards sea, the consequence being that the steamer also broke down at 10 that night, and both had to anchor. During the whole of this time, from 4 o'clock to 10, the coolies were kept at the pumps, and they continued working until 3 the next (Tuesday) morning. The Eagle Speed was then sinking fast, and the steamer was signalled for help. The steamer, however, neither towed the ship with her living freight back to Halliday Island, nor passed lines by which the coolies might have boarded her, nor sent off her own boats to help in transhipping them. The sea was high, but all of the witnesses assert that any one of these plans might have been adopted, and would have saved every soul on board. Instead of this, only three of the ship's boats were lowered. The shrieking coolies clung to the gangways and bulwarks, eager to save themselves, and a few threw themselves into the water on hencoops and were picked up. One boat, manned by the pilot and crew, made one trip and never returned. A second, manned by the second officer and others of the crew, was stove in after the first trip. Capt. HOSKINS made five trips, till sunstroke disabled him. Then the steamer put down one of its three boats, and it was long till the offer of money and shame would induce the now saved ship's crew to man it. They positively refused to save their Captain, who was still on the wreck. At last they made two trips, bringing him and the Coolie doctor and others off. The scene that ensued on the ship is described as something terrible; the interpreter had disappeared; the pilot had not returned; no orders could be given; no person could speak a word of the language of the unfortunate creatures; the Captain left at half-past twelve, and though the ship did not sink for eighteen hours after, the steamer actually put about and returned to Port Canning with only 169 coolies saved; leaving some three hundred human beings, without a word of advice or encouragement, to a fate too horrible almost to be pictured. All Tuesday afternoon and night they watched death slowly approaching them, -- the ship sinking lower and lower, the sullen waves creeping nearer and nearer to them, the breakers washing off the exhausted, and the strong battling with death, and climbing higher and higher on the masts. The dawn of Wednesday brought the unhappy beings no ray of hope, and at 7 o'clock they were swallowed up by the waves which had so long been waiting for their prey. Two steamers came from Calcutta and found three little children clinging to the top of a mast. A few others saved themselves on pieces of the wreck: but no less than 265 of the 497 coolies were lost. To add to the horrors of the tale, if that is possible, several of the poor wretches who escaped a watery grave were devoured by tigers on landing on the mud islets. One left his companion for a moment and returned to see him in a tiger's jaws. In desperation he again committed himself to the mercy of the waves to escape from a like fate. The catastrophe has roused the indignation of the people of Calcutta to the highest pitch. Of course an inquiry has been instituted, and it will be hard indeed if those responsible for the frightful calamity do not receive their just deserts. For the conduct of the crew there is no excuse; it was such as Englishmen are rarely guilty of, and can only be accounted for by the condition in which they sailed. Capt. HOSKINS seems to have done his duty nobly, and he declares that every soul on board might have been saved. The Captain of the steamer excuses himself on the ground that he had only one day's coal on board, but at least he could have lent the assistance of his boats. The pilot is most severely blamed. He knew the language of those whom he had in charge, and yet never returned to the wreck, excusing himself on the ground that the crew would not work, and that his boat was smashed -- there being at the same time other boats which he could have obtained. The correspondent who communicated these facts winds up with an earnest appeal for the abolition of the coolie trade.

abstract: Age of Wealth, the
snippet: Age of Wealth, the
lead_paragraph: The philosopher who shall hereafter describe this age will especially entitle it "the age of wealth." Not only has the great increase in the production of gold raised apparent values the world over, and thus made living seemingly more expensive in all countries, but the vastly augmented productiveness of all labor in the most civilized communities has brought about in the last decade an immense increase of wealth. In Germany and France the building of railroads, the emigration of a surplus population, the removal of mediaeval barriers of trade, and the use of machinery, have caused a stream of riches to pour through their fields and towns. The wages of labor rise, comforts are spread abroad, luxuries are in demand, as was never before known in the experience of those countries. The great middle class are acquiring what was once the possession of the aristocracy, and the laboring class are approaching more the position of the corresponding class in this country. There is no longer anything of that cheap mode of life for cultivated persons in Germany and Switzerland that used to be. Expenses on the Continent are not materially less than here.
headline: {'main': 'The "Age of Wealth."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The "Age of Wealth."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: State Convention; Resolutions Indorsing Pres. Johnson and Gov. Holden; State Convention; Resolution Indorsing Pres. Johnson and Gov. Holden; Various Political, >amp;c., Items from
snippet: State Convention; Resolutions Indorsing Pres. Johnson and Gov. Holden; State Convention; Resolution Indorsing Pres. Johnson and Gov. Holden; Various Political, >amp;c., Items from
lead_paragraph: -- BEDFORD BROWN, formerly a United States Senator, offers himself as a candidate for Congress in the Fifth District of North Carolina. He declares himself honestly anxious to aid in the work of restoration. In his address he says: "During the entire war, I have no doubt, if the freedom of opinion had not been suppressed, that North Carolina was, at all times, in favor of an honorable settlement of the question. Such were my own anxious wishes, as I always regarded a dissolution of the Union as bringing with it military despotism and the abolition of slavery. Those who were in power at Richmond, however, pursued a different course, and the result has been such a sacrifice as no people have suffered. The restoration of the Federal Union gives assurance of peace and civil liberty. Disunion is civil war, anarchy, military despotism and all its attendant evils. The reestablishment of the Federal Union nobly vindicates the principles of republican freedom, and proclaims the great principle so much denied by titled orders -- that man is capable of self-government.

abstract: Mr. Jacob Patterson, of Munroe, Orange County, N. Y., had been suffering for years from Consumption, with a severe putrid infections sore throat, to make use of his own words, a hurried respiration, hot and offensive breath, the skin of burning and disagreeable heat, ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. Jacob Patterson, of Munroe, Orange County, N. Y., had been suffering for years from Consumption, with a severe putrid infections sore throat, to make use of his own words, a hurried respiration, hot and offensive breath, the skin of burning and disagreeable heat, without the least moisture; the pulse quick, hard and irregular, averaging from 100 to 140 strokes per minute; the mouth and throat presenting a fiery appearance, the palate and glands painfully swelled; combined with a pain in the chest, the whole countenance presenting a ghastly, cadaverous look; the white part of the eye had a pearly, unnatural appearance, and, strange to say, the eye itself beamed with sparkling animation and lustre; the expectoration was copious and frequent; white, frothy and sometimes tough opaque substance, solid, of a yellow or green color, having a fetid smell when thrown on burning coals. In this infected state he was treated by the most eminent physicians he could find, but the excruciating pain in his side and chest, which became insupportable, so much alarmed his friends, that in this last dismal waste of life, he was taken to the well-known Dr. Von Eisenberg, of our city. At the doctor's office he complained of weakness at the least bodily exertion, and when placed in the examination chair, the breathing was fearful, the pulse was small and quicker than natural he complained of a tightness, as if a cord were drawn across the chest. The doctor, with his usual care, made an accurate diagnosis of the case, expressed willingness to undertake to treat him, and to attend to him to the best of are ability. The doctor declared himself to be always impressed with a decided belief that our wise and beneficent Creator has placed within the reach of his feeble creature, man, a cure for all diseases; that he has often cured this fatal complaint by assiduous attention and careful judgment. The preliminary arrangements were made; Dr. Von Eisenberg operated on the patient, after which Mr. Patterson declared himself to be very much relieved, since which time the patient has been under the doctor's care for a few weeks. To the patient's inexpressible delight, as well as to the great satisfaction of his friends, he has entirely recovered, and has just now come to New-York for the purpose of asking the doctor to allow him to resume his usual business. He looks remarkably strong, and his face is filled out and looks stouter than over it has been; in fact, he says for the last twelve years he never enjoyed a single night's rest, and now he sleeps as sound as an infant; and, according to his own words, he seems to have an iron digestion. He appears anxious to make known the great benefit he has derived from Doctor Von Eisenberg's skillful and successful treatment to all who suffer from this wasting and fatal complaint, and the Doctor's unremitting attention to his patients.

abstract: The Richmond Bulletin makes this statement regarding the lands of which Gen. WISE was so anxious to recover possession: Gen. TERRY decided that he, as military commandant of the department, could not take the lands of Gen. WISE from the Freedmen's Bureau, which had possession of them as "abandoned lands." The Secretary of War confirmed this decision of Gen. TERRY.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Bulletin makes this statement regarding the lands of which Gen. WISE was so anxious to recover possession: Gen. TERRY decided that he, as military commandant of the department, could not take the lands of Gen. WISE from the Freedmen's Bureau, which had possession of them as "abandoned lands." The Secretary of War confirmed this decision of Gen. TERRY. But neither Gens. MEADE nor GRANT passed upon the application of Gen WISE at all. The application passed through their offices when both were absent, and the Secretary of War did not refer the application to the Secretary of the Treasury, who alone could restore the land from the possession of the Freedmen's Bureau.

abstract: has inaugurated a very laudable business enterprise in connection with the Wheeler & Wilson and Howe sewing machines. He has organized an extensive establishment on Broadway, at the corner of Twenty-second-street. Here he has made arrangements by which he is enabled to let out sewing machines by the month, allowing half and in some instances the whole rent to apply on the final purchase of the machine, which is invariably sold without any advance on the company's prices. To this he also adds every facility for the most thorough instruction in working the machines, with much useful advice and aid in procuring, work. Special attention is paid to the claims of soldiers' widows and daughters, multitudes of whom daily make applications to hire or purchase machines, to be paid for by installments. None such, whose honesty is vouched for, are allowed to go away empty handed. In connection with this branch of the sewing-machine business, Mr. ELLIS has organized a bureau for executing the finest and best family sewing. He has, by generous wages and a deal of painstaking, succeeded in procuring a large staff of intelligent young American ladies, who either perform their work at their own homes, or go into families with or without machines, working by the day or the week, or in the establishment, as may be preferred. The Wheeler & Wilson Machine is the favorite for family sewing, and the Howe Machine, invented and perfected in all its details by Mr. ELIAS HOWE, is especially designed for tailoring and heavier manufacturing work. -- Tribune.

abstract: are rapidly settling all their differences and putting in nomination candidates who will command confidence and support. In the Sixth District they have nominated ABRAHAM LENT, of the Fifteenth Ward. He is a practical, straightforward, upright man, and will make a strong candidate and a useful and reliable Senator. He has been a Councilman for some years, and in that most difficult of all positions he won an enviable reputation by the unsuspected integrity of his political action. In the Seventh District, THOMAS MURPHY, the Union candidate, is one of the most popular and esteemed of its citizens. Success in business has only enlarged the sphere of his generosity, which has always been liberal and prompt. No man has warmer friends or deserves them better. He has two or three opponents, and although the district is strongly Democratic, his chances of success, with proper effort, are good.

abstract: Atalanta Club, New-York, Regatta
snippet: Atalanta Club, New-York, Regatta
lead_paragraph: On Saturday the regular Autumn regatta of the Atalanta Boat Club, the crack rowing club of New-York, came off upon the Hudson River on the usual three-mile course, from a state boat moored off the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, to Day's Point and return. The first race was for single scull 17-feet working boats, for the champion silver belt, a very handsome and costly affair, manufactured by Messrs. TIFFANY & CO. This belt is the property of the club, and is offered for annual competition. The entries for this race were as follows: Meteor, rowed by W.A. KNAPP; David Banks, Jr., rowed by GEO. ROAHR; and the Zephyr, rowed by WM.C. MAINLAND. The start was an excellent one, and for some two or three hundred feet the contestants kept well together; after this the David Banks, Jr., rowed by ROAHR, took the lead, gradually increasing it to the end of the race, coming in an easy winner in 27:40; Zephyr second, in 29:55; Meteor last, in 30:30. The second race was between the married and single members of the club, in four-oared shell-boats. The New-York was rowed by the following married members: Alden S. Swan, stroke; W.C. Mainland, Ransom Parker and George Roahr, bow. The single members manned the Knickerbocker as follows: B. Russell, stroke; W.A. Knapp, John J. Wilson and John H. Lindsey, bow. At the signal they got off evenly, the New-York obtaining a slight advantage by being pulled more steadily than the Knickerbocker. The race was, however, a close one while the boats were in sight; the New-York turned the upper stake-boat first, and came down the homestretch closely pursued by her bachelor rival until she passed the judge's yacht, a winner by one boat's length, in 23:45. The Knickerbocker's time was 28:49. Judges, J. Shurlock and R. Russell, Referee, Charles A. Peverelly.

abstract: dates of any kind, into investing their money in either the Mexican or Fenian bonds, which are announced as soon to be put upon the market. Neither is likely to be worth the paper it is printed on. Even if the Republicans should eventually reestablish themselves in Mexico, they will have no means of redeeming their debt, and it is not likely in any event to be assumed by our own government or any other. The Fenian financial scheme is still more desperate and mischievous, for thousands of impulsive and thoughtless Irish men and women may invest in it money which they have earned by hard labor, and of which they and their families stand in need. There is something very attractive to an Irishman in the prospect of redeeming his native land from oppression, and it is very likely to run away with his judgment and good sense. But the whole Fenian movement is a bubble, if not a swindle. The leaders in it will probably collect a good deal of money from their credulous countrymen, but a very small portion of it will ever find its way across the Atlantic. There is no more chance to-day for a successful revolution in Ireland, than there is in New-York. Irishmen will do a great deal better to use what money they can save, in getting comforts for their families, in educating their children, and in building up their own prosperity, than in giving it to a set of irresponsible adventurers, who will only laugh at their credulity.

The TIMES reporters have collated the facts as far as they can be ascertained in advance of the thorough investigation which Coroner WILDEY intends to make, and we give them below.

abstract: on Saturday afternoon last, a Mrs. HORNE, who keeps a boarding-house in Ash-street, near Union-avenue, Greenpoint, found a young man in her hall way with a black valise in his hand and it coat thrown over his arm. The fellow immediately pulled a roll of bills from his pocket when he saw Mr. HORNE and asked her if she could accommodate him with board, saying he would prefer to pay in advance. He was informed that the house was full, when he politely took his departure. Shortly afterward it was found that the house was robbed of $100 worth of wearing apparell. The thief is about 23 years of age, rather slim, light complexion, and stands about 5 feet 9 inches.

abstract: New-York; Great Seizure at No. 5 Goerck-st.
snippet: New-York; Great Seizure at No. 5 Goerck-st.
lead_paragraph: Reports of suspicious doings at the place in the rear of No. 5 Goerck-street having recently been made at the Delancey-street Police-station, Capt. STEERS instructed Special Officer ANDERSON to make an investigation. Obeying orders, Officer ANDERSON "piped" the neighborhood of Grand and Goerck streets and observed that many persons clad as countrymen called at the house and went thence with bundles under their arms, and that other persons, who drove fleet horses, visited the place at early dawn and after nightfall and left huge and mysterious packages. Making cautious inquiry of the persons who dwell nearest No. 5 Goerck-street, Officer ANDERSON ascertained that about two months ago one FRANCISCO BOHAGER, a young Italian, hired two dark and uninviting rooms in a rear dwelling, and that he had studiously kept himself aloof from all other occupants of the house; that no person had learned his business or that he had any business, and that the frequent calling of strangers, either delivering or bearing away packages whose contents were unknown, had excited remark.

abstract: Greenwich-st., Agnew's Grocery--$10,000
snippet: Greenwich-st., Agnew's Grocery--$10,000
lead_paragraph: FIRES. -- About 8 o'clock, Saturday evening, Mr. T.R. AGNEW'S grocery, at No. 260 Greenwich-street, was damaged to the extent of about $10,000 by fire, which was kindled by a lighted match carelessly thrown into a lot of waste paper. The building, which may be repaired for $500, is insured for $10,000 by the Star Company. Mr. AGNEW has insurance on his stock as follows: In the Gebhard office, $10,000; in the Germania, $20,000; in the Belief, $10,000; in the Mechanics' and Traders', $10,000; in the Humboldt, $20,000; in the Hope, $10,000, and in the Jersey City, $10,000....At about 6 o'clock, a bed was burned in Mr. JOHN KELLY's apartments, in the rear of No. 16 Cherry-street, and damage to the amount of about $250 was done to the furniture and building. The latter is insured for $4,000 in the Firemen's office.... Between 9 and 10 o'clock, a fire in the show window of the dry goods store at No. 159 First-avenue, was extinguished by Officers LOHR and RODDY, of the Seventeenth Ward, with damage not exceeding $100. Insurance, $3,000, in the North American office.

abstract: the new Governor of South Carolina
snippet: the new Governor of South Carolina
lead_paragraph: Carolina, does not encourage confidence in the loyalty and fidelity of that State to the Union. It is natural, undoubtedly, for the people to stand by a man who has stood by them, and HAMPTON's active and effective share in the rebellion has evidently commended him to the confidence and support of the people of his State. But the people of South Carolina can scarcely afford just now to indulge these personal preferences to so great an extent. They are not yet in position to insist upon the unrestricted enjoyment of their political sentiments. They may still believe, as probably most of them do, that they had a right to secede; but they must remember that this right is no longer open to discussion. It has been decided against them in the field of their own selection. They profess to acquiesce in the result, and, on the strength of that acquiescence, they seek restoration to their old status in the Union. They cannot doubt that the strongest disposition exists throughout the country to accept their professions as sincere, and to concede what they demand. But this disposition will not be strengthened by the election to office of the most conspicuous and defiant of the rebel leaders. So far as they are personally concerned, we have faith in their fidelity. They are men of strong convictions, resolute action, and sincere in their declarations. They proved their sincerity in the cause of secession, and we have little doubt that they are just as sincere in conceding its failure, and in pledging themselves now to the cause of the Union and the coun- But they must not expect the government or the people to accept personal assurances of this kind as conclusive, or as a safe basis for action. In the election of WADE HAMPTON, South Carolina has not hastened the time when she will be allowed full control over her local interests and political affairs.

abstract: And the United States; the Monroe Doctrine; their and the Mexican Bonds
snippet: And the United States; the Monroe Doctrine; their and the Mexican Bonds
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON, receiving the Minisister of Brazil a few weeks since, remarked that the desire of the United States is to promote civilization in the New World, improve commerce, and "introduce free and intelligent labor as fast as possible into the virgin fields of the American continent." The London Daily News, of Oct 10, finds in this expression ground for assuming that "whenever the case of Mexico is considered, at Washington, the mere fact that the form of its government is monarchical will not prevent the recognition of the Emperor Maximilian, whenever military successes and the consent of the people enable him to claim acknowledgment." Possibly, in the very guarded and restricted form given to this opinion, it may be true. We do not suppose that our government feels warranted, or called upon, to guarantee to every nation on this continent a republican form of government. It reserves that high pledge for the several States of its own Union. And if the people of Mexico, or of Brazil, or any other country, deliberately choose and maintain a monarchy or an empire, our government would not probably interfere in any way with their choice. Its fundamental principle is respect for the popular will, whatever forms it may assume.

abstract: of Mrs. MARTHA GRINDER, the female poisoner, commenced in Pittsburgh on Monday, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, and has continued during the week. Several days were occupied in impanneling a jury, it being difficult to find persons who had not formed decided opinions on the case. Mrs. GRINDER protests her innocence, and pleaded "not guilty," but the evidence is very strong against her. She appears in excellent spirits and seems quite calm and collected. She was put on trial for a single murder, that of Mrs. MARY C. CARUTHERS, and if found guilty on that case the others will not probably be pressed. The motive for the poisoning, as stated by the prosecuting attorney, was that the deceased (Mrs. CARUTHERS) had been authorized by her father to purchase some property, a fact well known to the defendant, from her intimacy with the family, and it was to secure the money devoted to this purpose that the crime had been committed. The evidence of poisoning seems direct and conclusive, and indicates a deliberate heartlessness that is almost unparalleled.

abstract: In the Circuit Court, Part II., of this city, during the October term, there were three separate panels of jurors summoned, and out of them about one hundred non-attending jurors have been fined by the court $25 each. The presiding Judge expressed his opinion to the effect that until the Legislature of the State sees fit to alter the law, it will be impossible to secure the services, as jurors, of the wealthy and business men of the city. They pay the fine prescribed by the statute rather than sit in the jury box two or three weeks every year. He concluded his remarks on this point by expressing the hope that some action would be taken by the next Legislature, in regard to the law of jurors for this city.

abstract: State Election
snippet: State Election
lead_paragraph: The Union ticket is almost certain to be elected in New-Jersey. A touch of sadness shades the prospect. What shall we do without her as an "awful example" of the effects of long indulgence in bad politics? What will become of our lively jokes about going out of the Union into New-Jersey, -- about the State of Camden and Amboy, and the other little pleasantries which have so long enlivened the dullness of our stump speeches, and stirred the boys into wild "hy, hy's," figuring in newspaper reports as "loud applause," in a parenthesis? Apparently we must reconcile ourselves to this bereavement, as we do to many others. "Jarsey" seems to be coming over. The campaign has been active, determined and effective. The popularity of MARCUS L. WARD, our candidate for Governor, is unbounded and well deserved. The committees have been unwearied and practical in their labors. KILPATRICK has swept through the political battle-field as he used to sweep around and over the rebel cavalry. And LOGAN, of Illinois, comes in to wind up the contest with such heavy blows as he alone can strike. He speaks to-night at Jersey City, and then goes to one or two other places in the State. We hope he will reserve a few days for service in New-York.

abstract: A GENERAL JAIL DELIVERY SEVEN CRIMINALS SENTENCED TO STATE PRISON ESCAPE THROUGH THE ROOF. Seven prisoners, who had been sentenced in the Kings County Court of Sessions on Saturday, and who had been remanded to jail for safe keeping until they could be transferred to Sing Sing, effected their escape some time during Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: A GENERAL JAIL DELIVERY -- SEVEN CRIMINALS SENTENCED TO STATE PRISON ESCAPE THROUGH THE ROOF. -- Seven prisoners, who had been sentenced in the Kings County Court of Sessions on Saturday, and who had been remanded to jail for safe keeping until they could be transferred to Sing Sing, effected their escape some time during Saturday night. The prisoners were confined in two adjoining cells in the upper tier of the male prison, and it seems that an entrance was gained from the outside through the roof. The manner in which the entrance was effected appears to be thus: The outside parties mounted the roof of the dead-house, which adjoins the jail inclosure on the easterly side, and by means of a rope-ladder, which was in some way fastened on the top of the fence, they mounted. The fence is braced against the jail building with heavy wooden beams, over which a person can easily walk, and thus gain the roof of that portion in which the prisoners are confined. A hole was cut in the roof, the deliverers descended, and with skeleton keys soon succeeded in unlocking the; cell doors. The prisoners then escaped through the aperture, and, by means of the beams and rope ladder, crossed over and descended upon the roof of the Dead-house, which is not more than ten feet in height, and jumped off on the Willoughby-street side. As no watchman appears to be employed in the jail, the parties were in no danger of being disturbed. A skeleton key and the rope ladder were discovered about a o'clock yesterday morning, which was the first that was known of the occurrences of the night previous. The names of the prisoners and the terms of the sentences, together with the offences of which they were convicted, are as follows: Edward McNeill, sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment, for attempt to kill; James Harnold, 10 years' imprisonment, for burglary; James Robinson, William Brady and Henry Stevens, 5 years' imprisonment, each, for attempt at burglary; B. Komph, forgery, 5 years' imprisonment; and Thomas O'Keefe, larceny, not sentenced. The latter was to have been used as a witness against other parties. The roof of the jail is constructed of shingles, put on in 1840, and is represented to be in a dilapidated condition.

lead_paragraph: GIDEON JONES YOUNG, an opium-eater, died at Believue Hospital, and Coroner COLLIN was summoned on Saturday to hold an inquest. It appears that YOUNG, who was 51 years of age, and without family, had recently lounged in the dining-room of the St. Charles Hotel, and became known thereabouts as an opium-eater; and on Tuesday evening last, after having taken a room at the St. Charles, he sent a boy out to get a quantity or opium, twenty grains of which he took that evening. On the following morning, while suffering, from delirium, he sent for more opium, but was given other stimulants, and sent to Bellevue Hospital, where he died on Friday. Dr. THOMAS ROBINSON made a post-mortem examination and found that YOUNG had suffered from, gangrene of the lungs. Among the deceased's effects the Coroner found the following choice production:

abstract: Worcester, Dr. Joseph E., Author of Worcester's Dictionary
snippet: Worcester, Dr. Joseph E., Author of Worcester's Dictionary
lead_paragraph: The death of JOSEPH EMERSON WORCESTER, L.L.D., which occurred at Cambridge, Mass., Friday, Oct. 27, was announced in yesterday's TIMES. Dr. WORCESTER was born in Bedford, N.H., Aug. 24, 1784, and removed to Hollis, N.H., in 1794, with has father's family. He was educated at Hollis, Andover and Salisbury Academies, and was graduated at Yale in 1814. While teaching school he published a Geographical Dictionary (1817) and a Gazetteer of the United States in 1818. In 1819 he published Elements of Geography, Ancient and Modern, at Cambridge, Mass., whither he had removed, and the next year, Epitome of Geography. Several works of various value, but in related fields, followed these, and then he commenced with TODD's Johnson, that great lexicographical labor which gave him reputation. This work was published in 1827. The next year he prepared an abridgment of Webster's Dictionary, and in 1830 a Comprehensive Pronouncing and Explanatory Dictionary. He then visited Europe, and spent much time in those philological inquiries which had their fruit in his revised lexicon. A Universal and Critical Dictionary of the English Language was published by him in 1846, which was immediately reprinted in Europe. His Pronouncing, Explanatory and Synonymous Dictionary made its appearance in 1855, and in 1860 his magnum opus, quarto, "A Dictionary of the English Language," was published. He also published a spelling-book, and edited the American Almanac for twelve years from 1831. His doctorate came from Dartmouth and Brown Colleges, and he was a member of various learned societies.

abstract: The accident which happened yesterday to the splendid North River steamer St. John, and by which ten persons lost their lives and seventeen were injured, is one as inexplicable as it is appalling. The boat was considered, like her consort, the Dean Richmond, not only a magnificent specimen of naval architecture, but a vessel every way thoroughly and perfectly appointed, especially in the matter of her machinery.
lead_paragraph: The accident which happened yesterday to the splendid North River steamer St. John, and by which ten persons lost their lives and seventeen were injured, is one as inexplicable as it is appalling. The boat was considered, like her consort, the Dean Richmond, not only a magnificent specimen of naval architecture, but a vessel every way thoroughly and perfectly appointed, especially in the matter of her machinery. The boilers had been but a few months in use, and not only from the price paid for them, which reached the vast sum of $62,000, but from the thorough inspection ordered before their acceptance, it was hardly possible to anticipate anything but the results of the most perfect material and workmanship. Yet it would appear, if our reports are correct, that one of these boilers -- that on the larboard side -- was not only imperfect, but there was in it one whole sheet, several feet in surface, composed of what is technically called sand iron, liable at any moment, since the boiler was made, to give way as it did yesterday, and cause such a catastrophe as we now record.

abstract: The fifty-seventh anniversary of the New-York Bible and Prayer Book Society was held yesterday evening, at Trinity Chapel, in Twenty-sixth-street, near Broadway. This society, as the name indicates, is connected with the Episcopal Church of this State, and is fostered for the extension of the ritual of service of that church.

abstract: seen by a letter from P.S. FORBES, Esq., which we publish in another column, that he refuses to permit the qualities of the Algonquin to be tried any longer at the dock. He says she was not made to "strain hawsers or pull docks," but to go to sea. He is ready at any time to give her such a trial, both for power and economy, in motion at sea. We think the public, and we trust the Navy Department, will see the justice and propriety of this decision.

abstract: A NEW SWINDLING METHOD. About ten days ago a young, gentlemanly-looking man called upon Mr. FATRICK LYNAGH, residing at the corner of F-street and Union-avenue, Greenpoint, and represented that his son was lying dangerously ill at the Marion Hospital, Newark, N.J. Mr. LYNAGH had a son named ...
lead_paragraph: A NEW SWINDLING METHOD. -- About ten days ago a young, gentlemanly-looking man called upon Mr. FATRICK LYNAGH, residing at the corner of F-street and Union-avenue, Greenpoint, and represented that his son was lying dangerously ill at the Marion Hospital, Newark, N.J. Mr. LYNAGH had a son named DAVID in the rebel army, and having four months ago heard that he was a prisoner at Fortress Monroe, he was easily led to believe in the representations of the stranger. He was urgently pressed by the stranger to hire a carriage and leave with him for Newark in the evening, so that they might arrive at the hospital by 10 o'clock at night. Mr. LYNAGH was earnestly urged to take at least $150 with him, as that amount would be required in case of his son's demise, which he was informed would no doubt happen before the place was reached. Mr. LYNAGH being in poor health got his son-in-law, Mr. PATRICK WALKER, and his daughter, to depart on the sad mission, the stranger accompanying them. Mr. WALKER had about $300 with him when he started. On the arrival of the party opposite the Merchants' Hotel, in Cortlandt-street, New-York, the stranger pressed his companions to enter that hotel and partake of some refreshments previous to commencing their carriage ride to Newark. This they acceded to. After this Mr. WALKER's suspicions were aroused by the strange familiarity of his new-made acquaintance, and he concluded not to leave until the morning. This disappointed the stranger considerably, but finding that he could not prevail on Mr. WALKER to hire a carriage and accompany him, he very kindly offered his services to take his valise to Newark. This offer made Mr. WALKER more suspicious still. The stranger finally left empty-handed, and the next morning WALKER and Miss LYNAGH started for Newark in search of their dying relative and the Marion Hospital. But there was no such place to be found, and they returned home with the very natural belief that the villain who misled them wanted to get them on a carriage ride for the purpose of robbery. He gave his name as GEORGE A. ATKINSON, and said he did business at No. 23 Broad-street, Newark. Since the above transaction, Mr. JOHN M. OAKLEY, residing in Dupont-street, between Franklin and Union avenues, Greenpoint, received the following letter, probably from the same young man:

abstract: The steamer North Star put into Norfolk on the 27th, in a sinking condition, in consequence o injuries received in the gale off Hatteras on the night of the 24th. Such was the force of the leak on the morning of the 25th, that the water reached within four inches of the fires, and would have extinguished them but for the superhuman efforts of the troops and passengers on board to prevent it. After throwing much of her cargo overboard, the vessel made one thousand gallons of water a minute. The passengers have published resolutions denouncing the owners of the North Star for sending her to sea in the condition in which they knew her to be in. Her copper was so torn that the passengers say that the ship could not make seven knots an hour. The boiler was was only equal to eighteen pounds of steam. There was an insufficiency of life-boats, and the vessel in every respect was unseaworthy.

abstract: Although the new opera of "Crispino o la Comare" has achieved a very marked and decided success, it will for the present only be repeated once more to-morrow night. It is withdrawn in accordance with Mr. MARETZEK'S well-known and publicly approved policy of giving the greatest amount of variety to his programmes, and also to make room for other revivals and novelties.
lead_paragraph: Although the new opera of "Crispino o la Comare" has achieved a very marked and decided success, it will for the present only be repeated once more to-morrow night. It is withdrawn in accordance with Mr. MARETZEK'S well-known and publicly approved policy of giving the greatest amount of variety to his programmes, and also to make room for other revivals and novelties. A different opera is given every night this week, beginning with "Un Ballo in Maschera" to-night, and ending with a grand matinee on Saturday. Wednesday is set apart for Signor MAZZOLENI's benefit, when "Ione" will be given -- a work in which the gentleman is seen to the greatest possible advantage. On Friday MEYERBEER's opera of "Robert le Diable" is to be revived with a grand distribution. When we add that the rehearsals of "L'Africaine" are progressing satisfactorily it will be seen that Mr. MARETZEK and his company are not precisely what can be called people of leisure.

SMITH, of the Ninth Ward, has at the Charles-street Police-station, for identification, a very valuable gold watch, which he took, yesterday morning, from one CHARLES MVLOY, who had offered to sell it in a lager-bier saloon, at No. 71 Eighth-avenue, for $15. The hook and part of the chain are wanting, and MALOY had no key that fitted the watch; Sergt. SMITH, therefore, in-...
lead_paragraph: THE POLICE COURTS. -- Sergt. S. B. SMITH, of the Ninth Ward, has at the Charles-street Police-station, for identification, a very valuable gold watch, which he took, yesterday morning, from one CHARLES MVLOY, who had offered to Bell it in a lager-bier saloon, at No. 71 Eighth-avenue, for $15. The hook and part of the chain are wanting, and MALOY had no key that fitted the watch: Sergt. SMITH, therefore, inferred that MALOY had stolen it, and took him into custody. The prisoner wan committed for examination by Justice DODGE....ALICE BAKER, of Greene-street, appeared at Jefferson Market yesterday, and made oath that, on the night of the 29th instant, while she was crossing the intersection of Wooster and Grand streets, JOHN MCNAMEE and CHARLES BUCK assaulted and robbed her, taking a gold watch of the value of $30. The accused, who arc youths of nineteen and twenty years respectively, were taken into custody by Officer RICHARD HOLLOWAY, and committed by Justice DODGE....At the Tombs, before Justice DOWLING, one of the St. John's waiters was committed for an alleged robbery at the time of the explosion.

abstract: Our distinguished English visitor, Sir MORTON PETO, last evening reciprocated, and most generously, the courtesies of his New-York friends, (and also his Western friends, as far as they could be assembled in this city,) by a splendid entertainment at Delmonico's, Fourteenth-street. The sumptuous richness and elegance of this banquet, we feel free to say, has never been exceeded in this country. We doubt, indeed, whether so complete, so elaborate, and so delightful a dinner was ever served to a party so large as 250 guests in New-York. Whether this be due to the caterer, Mr. DELMONICO, or to Sir MORTON PETO'J committee of management, it is proper to the appreciation of the occasion that it should be said. The festive board was graced by the presence of a number of ladies -- a fact which added materially to the evening's enjoyment.
lead_paragraph: Our distinguished English visitor, Sir MORTON PETO, last evening reciprocated, and most generously, the courtesies of his New-York friends, (and also his Western friends, as far as they could be assembled in this city,) by a splendid entertainment at Delmonico's, Fourteenth-street. The sumptuous richness and elegance of this banquet, we feel free to say, has never been exceeded in this country. Whether this be due to the caterer, Mr. DELMONICO, or to Sir MORTON PETO'J committee of management, it is proper to the appreciation of the occasion that it should be said. The festive board was graced by the presence of a number of ladies -- a fact which added materially to the evening's enjoyment.

abstract: Her mirror may satisfy a lady that her dress is faultless -- that all that can fascinate the eye is combined in her costume -- but yet she will not consider herself irresistible until she has added the crowning charm to her attractions, by sprinkling Phalon's "Night-Blooming Cereus" on her lace handkerchief. -- Portland Press.

abstract: The deaths in this city last week, according to the City Inspector's return, numbered 448--119 men, 87 women, 123 boys and 119 girls -- a decrease of 23 from last week, and of the same number as compared with the corresponding period of last year. Of the deceased, 204 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 62; mflammation of the lungs, 38; dipthoria, 14; diarrhea, 16; dysentery, 21; infantile convulsions, 35; typhoid fever, 19; infantile marasmus, 38; inflammation of the bowels, 13. Deaths from external causes 29, including 4 burned or scalded, 6 from old age, and 6 premature births. There were 64 deathe in the Institutions, and 38 interments in Potter's Field.

abstract: Yesterday, Capt. WARLOW, of the First Precinct Police, having heard that several of the sailors on board the ship Villafranca, Capt. ANDERSON, now lying off Governor's Island, had been beaten in a shocking manner by some of the officers, sent a possee of police on board the vessel, and there found four of the crew who had evidently been shamefully treated. These men declared, that without any sufficient cause, the first and second mates of the vessel -- WM.

abstract: At a meeting of this committee, held at headquarters, which was very largely attended, resolutions were unanimously adopted, ratifying the nomination of Mr. J. DITTENHOEFER for Justice of Marine Court, and pledging to him the united and enthusiastic support of the Germans of the City of New-York. A committee of one from each ward was appointed to act in conjunction with a Central Committee of seven to make all necessary arrangements and adopt all measures that may tend to insure the election of Mr. DITTENHOEFER.

abstract: A very large and enthusiastic meeting was held last evening at the great warehouse of CAMPBELL & FITZPATRICK, Morgan-street, Jersey City. It being generally understood that Gens. LOGAN, HOOKER and KILPATRICK were to be present and to speak, the hall was crowded long before the hour named for the meeting, the fair sex being liberally represented. In answer to the impatient appeals of the audience for something to listen to, the New-York Glee Club generously administered a melodeous morsel of rebel heroism, known as "Poor Old Jeff."

abstract: The President yesterday received in a formal manner the special Tunisian Ambassador, the introduction having been conducted by Secretary SEWARD. There were present the Secretary and interpreter, the Aid-de-Camp to the Ambassador, Consul PERRY, Mr. Cox, of the State Department, and a number of spectators. The letter of credence from the Bey of Tunis was read by the Ambassador, to which the President responded, expressing his gratification with the visit, his appreciation of the hindness and friendly sentiments enunciated, and saying that every facility would be afforded to make their visit both agreeable and interesting. The portrait of the Bey, which was presented, was not only appreciated on account of the original, but it was beside a wondrous work of art.
lead_paragraph: The President yesterday received in a formal manner the special Tunisian Ambassador, the introduction having been conducted by Secretary SEWARD. abstract: We publish, this morning, from our special correspondent in the Gulf States, an important letter, containing his impressions of the present condition of Southern society in various sections of Alabama. These impressions have at least the value of freshness. If they do not furnish any profound analysis of the social and political changes in progress at the South, they present...
lead_paragraph: We publish, this morning, from our special correspondent in the Gulf States, an important letter, containing his impressions of the present condition of Southern society in various sections of Alabama. These impressions have at least the value of freshness. If they do not furnish any profound analysis of the social and political changes in progress at the South, they present... a carefully-drawn picture of what came under our correspondent's observation. Many readers here may question the correctness of the writer's conclusions as to the degrees of loyalty with which he credits the various classes of citizens in Alabama. But it is at least worthy of particular note that he gives special credit to those who have been openly in arms against the National Government for a frank and candid bearing in their submission, which is not apparent in the less martially-disposed portion of the inhabitants. Our correspondent likewise offers certain statements respecting the freedmen of Alabama, which we commend to careful notice. While it is apparent from all the facts that could be gleaned, that large numbers of the released plantation hands absolutely refuse to work, and many of them take to dishonest ways of living, our correspondent points out the dangers that might arise, from leaving the freedmen without some military protection, whether it is called "a Freedmen's Bureau" or anything else. The great value, however, of the pictures given in our correspondence, lies in the fact of their being free from any bias which might attach, on the one hand, to a sectional prejudice for the white residents of the South, or on the other, to a cheap and easy patronage of the colored race.

abstract: The process of washing and wringing clothes greatly needs the aid of labor-saving machines. The clothes wringer has come into general use, and no one who has seen or used them doubts their utility both as labor savers and clothes savers. But most washing machines have proved failures by bring too hard to operate, or in destroying the clothes by rubbing them between two irregular surfaces. The Doty Clothes Washer, it is claimed, avoids both of these difficulties, being easy to operate, doing the work rapidly and with less injury to the clothes than by the old process of hand-washing. We notice the first premium at the fair of the American Institute, just closed, was awarded to the " Universal Clothes Wringer," and to Doty's Clothes Washer. -- New-York Tribune.

abstract: The naturalization office of the Union Central Committee, No. 6 Centre-street, was closed last Friday as none are allowed to vote who were not naturalized at least ten days previous to the election. The results achieved by the Naturalization Committee are very satisfactory. Six hundred and fourteen persons, members of the great Union party, obtained their certificates of naturalization through the above-named office, while about three hundred citizens were assisted to obtain copies of their naturalization documents which they had lost. About one hundred more persons called at the office, but could not be naturalized, as they had not declared their intention to become citizens. These nearly all then made that declaration, and will be naturalized two years hence. Four hundred and forty-eight of these new citizens, or 73 per cent., had served in the army, and had been honorably discharged. We learn that Tammany Hall has not naturalized more than about one hundred and fifty returned soldiers, which would indicate that threefourths of our returning heroes will prove themselves as loyal and patriotic citizens as they were brave soldiers in the army of freedom.

abstract: Yesterday was a most delightful day for cable ascensions in the war balloon, and many visitors availed themselves of the circumstance. Among the visitors who gained a bird's eye view of New-York were Gen. GEO. B. STONEMAN, the distinguished cavalry officer of the West, and his wife. The General was the first officer who accompanied Prof. LOWE on his army ascensions in 1862, from before Richmond, and the two thus gained the first glimpse of the rebel capital from cloud land.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a most delightful day for cable ascensions in the war balloon, and many visitors availed themselves of the circumstance. Among the visitors who gained a bird's eye view of New-York were Gen. GEO. B. STONEMAN, the distinguished cavalry officer of the West, and his wife. The General was the first officer who accompanied Prof. LOWE on his army ascensions in 1862, from before Richmond, and the two thus gained the first glimpse of the rebel capital from cloud land.

abstract: Gov. SEYMOUR said, in his late Buffalo speech, that "the questions of the past are not the questions of the day." Undoubtedly this is true, Peace questions concern us now as war questions concerned us then. It don't require much wit to discover that. But what of it? Does Gov. SEYMOUR really believe that the people of this State can be turned from their purpose by any such shift as that? Your agent of last year, who was sent packing for shameful abuse of trust, comes back now for new employment on the plea that you are now in a new line of business. "Impudence!" would be your exclamation. Gov. SEYMOUR, of course, don't mean to be impudent, but what does he mean? What has the fact that the business now in hand is not the same it was last year to do with his public character, and that of his party? He and his party were discarded last year for the worst public unfaithfulness ever known to the country. When the confidence of the people is again asked, the thing necessary to be proved is that character is changed. Nothing could be more irrelevant than this talk about the change in the kind of work to be done.
